average The dry cold, without wind, for about 15 days yearly is 30 below zero, with 18 below zero as a winter average. Notwithstanding the great differences, the inhabitants are healthy, sturdy, and energetic. Read "A Year in Manitoba," (Is Chambers, 47 Paternoster Row, EC). The drawbacks—mosquitoes, occasional blizzards of rain or snow, etc.—are no doubt great, and require a stout heart to combat; yet the advantages and hopes of success are much in excess of these obstacles. I particularly enquired at what price good Manitoba wheat could be put on the Liverpool market. Owing to the new railways and route via Prince Arthur's Landing and Lake Superior, it will cost 33s per quarter; in the Old Country, 42s hardly pays. In Ontario, they are largely rearing cattle, sending them over here dead or alive. There are excellent farms selling cheap. Apply, Hon.

18830119: P., is a bright and shining light in the Reform ranks, in which his ability to shift his opinions from year to year in pursuance of the winding courses of his leader has given him an excellent position. Mr. Charlton is a Yankee, whose natural sympathies are with the United States, and who, in obedience to the promptings of those sympathies, would apparently delight in a disruption of the provinces forming the Confederation. That at least is the inference to be drawn from his language at the recent Reform convention, when he described the French-Canadian race as "the hereditary enemies of Ontario," and as "the sworn and mortal foes of Ontario." A year or two ago this same gentleman, having occasion to refer to some French-Canadian, politely described them as "lick-spittles." It is only in the Liberal party that a man of this character would be tolerated, and perhaps, after all, he only speaks in plain language the sentiments of his leaders. The London Money Market Review has been doing its utmost to deter English investors from placing their money in the Canadian Northwest, and in pursuit of this object has opened its columns to all who desire to traduce the land. One of the most wicked of these slanderers has been a Mr. Kennett Ffarrington Bellairs, whose history is thus recounted by the Winnipeg Times: Mr. Bellairs was some time ago one of the leading men in the English colony which settled in Martin County, Southern Minnesota. While there, he wrote letters to the St. Paul Pioneer Press and other newspapers denouncing his native land, which he described as a nation of paupers. He represented himself as a member of the London Stock Exchange. Of course, Mr. Bellairs and the colony came to grief, and "K. I. T.," as he was called by his profane Yankee neighbors, returned to London and the curbstone, breathing vengeance against the American Northwest. He has now turned his attention to the Canadian Northwest. But, as a matter of fact, Mr. Bellairs was never in the Canadian Northwest in his life; and his description of blizzards, of the settlers being compelled to burn hay in ovens, and so forth, is wholly based on his experience in Martin County. Unfortunately, the misrepresentations of an adventurer of this character are too often accepted as gospel by the English public.

18830120: J., January 19. Two girls of the Salvation Army instituted $10,000 damages against the Rev. Charles Pelletreau, Rector of the Episcopal Church. Pelletreau last Sunday severely criticized the tactics of the Army. Lawlessness in the South. Shreveport, January 19. In a desperate encounter between desperadoes and a sheriff's posse in Sabine Pass last night, John Morgan, leader of the desperadoes, and John Furlow of the sheriff's posse, were killed. The Hawaiian treaty. Washington, January 19. The National Board of Trade today passed a resolution favoring the abrogation of the Hawaiian Treaty. The ice harvest strike. Kokomo, January 19. The strike among the icemen on the Hudson has ended; in most cases, the proprietors acceded to the demands of the laborers. A row about Mrs. Landry. St. Louis, January 19. Since Mrs. Langtry and Fred Gebhardt came here, the papers have published many articles about them. On Wednesday, the Globe-Democrat contained a more than usually annoying article. On Wednesday evening, meeting Major Cunningham, reporter for that paper, in the hotel, Gebhardt charged him with being responsible for all the vileness published regarding himself and Mrs. Langtry. Cunningham declined to accept the responsibility, when Gebhardt insulted Cunningham grossly and challenged him to a fist encounter. Cunningham refused to fight with fists but said he would give Gebhardt a chance to fight with gentlemen's weapons. Cunningham was finally led away by his friends. Yesterday, Cunningham sent the dramatic critic of the paper to Gebhardt with a challenge, which was delivered in the presence of Mrs. Langtry. The latter was very much agitated and entreated Gebhardt to ignore the challenge. After a time, Gebhardt consented to do so, and admitted that he had, perhaps, spoken hastily. Cunningham considers Gebhardt's concession insufficient and says he will post him as a coward unless ample apology is made. Friends of both parties are seeking to effect a reconciliation. Another account says the trouble originated in comments on Mrs. Langtry made by parties in the audience and printed in the Globe-Democrat. Heavy Snowfall in the Northwest. St. Paul, January 19. Last night and a portion of today, the hardest snowstorm of the winter has prevailed. Some railroads are blocked, and the trains are snowed in near Morris. Cedar Rapids, Mich., January 19. Trains on the Burlington, Cedar Rapids Northern Railway have been abandoned on account of the snow blockade. The thermometer is 20 below zero. Sioux City, IA, January 19. The blizzard in this section is very severe. All the roads leading here, except the Sioux City and Pacific, are blocked, and not a wheel is turning on the St. Paul. Omaha, Neb., January 19. The storm today was the severest in five winters. The thermometer ranged 21 below. The Reading Salt. Philadelphia, PA, January 19. Alexander McEwen, the English financier, has filed a claim in court for $343,000 against the Reading Railway. He maintains that this amount is due him for originating and carrying out the deferred income bond scheme. Locomotive Explosion. Boston, January 19. The engine of the Providence express on the New York & New England Road exploded at Norfolk tonight. The engineer was badly scalded, the cab was blown to pieces, and the tender damaged. Donation to Harvard. A gift of $250,000 is reported from the citizens of Cambridge to Harvard College for the erection of new dormitories, the rent of which is not to exceed $30 a year. The Tariff Bill. The New York Tribune's Washington dispatch says: Republican representatives strongly favor the dropping of the Tariff Bill, reported by the Ways and Means Committee, should an opportunity offer, and the accepting as a whole of the one prepared by the Tariff Commission. The objections of many representatives to the House bill seem to spring from the despair of ever being able to understand the effects of its provisions. Sports and Pastimes.

18830203: M. Duclos is now out of danger and M. Fallières is recovering. A new planet has been discovered by Rolla, an Austrian astronomer. The Ontario elections will be held on the 27th instant, nomination day being on the 20th. A blizzard is raging in the West, and trains are blockaded on the Union Pacific and branch lines. Workingmen's candidates have been nominated in West Toronto for the coming elections. Heavy gales on the British coast continue. Two wrecks are reported on the Isle of Man, the crews in each case being lost. It is believed the authorities have got a witness who can positively swear to two of the prisoners at Dublin as the men seen driving from the scene of the Phoenix Park murder. The revolution which recently broke out in Ecuador has been almost completely successful, the Government forces having retired to Guayaquil, the last stronghold of the Dictator. Dominion News.

18830206: C., who is now in this city, is greatly interested in the workings of the fire departments of the large cities in the Dominion and the United States. On his way hither, he has stopped at all the cities of importance and investigated the workings of the departments, and will render a report of his observations to the Victoria City Council on his return. At the present time, the Victoria Fire Department is not working satisfactorily, and in view of rapid development in the near future, the question of waterworks is being agitated and will probably be among the improvements in a few years. He will make a thorough inspection of the methods adopted in this city for the suppression of fires, and will then make a trip eastward to Quebec and Montreal for the same purpose. Revenue has confirmed the seizure of a large number of empty petroleum barrels in Kingston and Napanee from which the inspection marks had not been obliterated, in contravention of the law. The barrels will be confiscated. The Minister has also ordered a fine of $1,000 to be imposed in each case where an infraction of the law has been shown. An accident of a rather serious nature occurred this morning at the Canadian Pacific Railway depot. The Aylmer train had just crossed the Chaudière Bridge and was rounding the curve near the depot when a freight train came along, and before anything could be done to avert the disaster, the two trains collided. The engineers and stokers of both locomotives jumped just in time to save their lives and escaped with slight injuries. The concussion created the greatest consternation among the passengers on the Aylmer train and sent them flying in all directions, but they all escaped without serious injury. The locomotive attached to the passenger train is a total wreck; the other is only partially destroyed. The loss will probably reach $15,000. The Typographical Union of this city asked, about a week ago, for an advance of ten percent on their present rate of wages. All the offices except one job office acceded to the request. This morning, however, there was a misunderstanding at the Parliamentary Printing Office, and thirty printers left. A meeting of the Union was held this afternoon, and the difficulties were arranged. The trouble was caused by a question of division of copy among piece and week hands. All the men in the Parliamentary Office have gone to work on week work. Only one office now holds out against the Union. The revenue accrued in 1882, as furnished by the Crown Timber Office at Ottawa, is: Quebec, $457,564.71; Ontario, $270,158.87; Dominion, $114,004.81; total, $841,738.39. On Saturday, Mr. Gisborne, Superintendent of the Signal Telegraph Office, patented his new telegraph wire. He claims that by its use, one thousand words per minute can be transmitted. It will be drawn direct, and he says, will be of greater strength and lighter resistance than any now in use. Mr. MacDonald, Mr. Cape Breton, had an interview with Sir Hector Langevin today with reference to public improvements in his constituency. Dr. Gorrin, Mr., will make some new suggestions during the present session regarding the coast telegraph system, the nature of which he will take an early opportunity of explaining in the House. Dr. Wiggins will issue an almanac in a few days. It will contain the dates of the great storms of 1883. The doctor says there will be a blizzard on Friday next, but it will be nothing to compare with the big blow of the 11th of March. Manning & MacDonald have been notified by the Department that their contract for the Pay Canal improvements is the lowest. They have not yet accepted. Hon. Mr. Harrington, Premier.

18830217: J. Dakin, conductor, and P. Hughes, brakeman, and baggageman, were not seriously injured. A minor law. Little Rock, Ark., February 16. An Act has been passed by the Legislature prohibiting for two years the sale of intoxicants within three miles of any church or schoolhouse, on the petition of the majority of the adult inhabitants, regardless of sex. The Fisheries Clause. Washington, February 16. The House Committee on Foreign Affairs has agreed to report favorably on the joint resolution giving notice of the termination of the Fisheries articles of the Treaty of Washington. It is a copy of the resolution recently reported to the Senate. A blizzard. St. Paul, February 16. A blizzard is prevailing in this region. The thermometer has fallen fifty degrees since morning. Snow is falling with a fierce wind. Some railroads are blocked. Obit. Dungarvan, Iowa, February 16. Ex-Gov. Stephen Hempstead died suddenly today of heart disease.

18830306: MARCH 6. OUR NEW YORK LETTER. What the "World" says: The boom, its rise and real estate; the Keeley Institute; Iron and other things; the New York amphitheater banks; partial commercial business and world affairs; practical science; underground telegraphy.

--- 

Please let me know if you need any further modifications or corrections! Here's the corrected text:

---

**New York, March 2**  
It was amusing to note how the high and dry folks of the old Knickerbocker families, who are such a great ornament to this metropolis, were "consterned" (as the French say) by the marriage of Miss Kernohan to Mr. Tell. Miss Kernohan, who, it appears, is only twenty-five, did not ask her august parents' leave to marry her lover, a mere boy of thirty, and the absurd old gentlemen went and abused the parson who performed the ceremony. Was anything ever more ridiculous? It is a pity if two people whose ages united make 65 years are not old enough to think for themselves and decide what was best for them to do. The "world's" publication, The World, next day had a silly article to the effect that clergymen should not marry people unless satisfied that no impediment exists in the shape of a dissenting parent, and so forth. What bosh! Does The World want French laws here, by which a man under twenty-five dares not marry without the consent of his parents? Or was the writer so "concerned," along with the rest of the fashionables, as to produce an article which sounded very much like as if the author was fuddled when he wrote it? It is worthy of note that the respectable clergyman who married the couple (at a very unfashionable church on the Bowery, by the way) paid no attention whatsoever to the passionate abuse of the old millionaire, but let him pump, pump, till he pumped himself out and away. That is real, practical Christianity for you.

**THE STOCK MARKET AND THE BOMB**  
Though things are undeniably dull in Wall Street, and lots of $30,000 brokers are not making living salaries out of commissions, yet those who can look past a foggy chasm or two see the rosy hue of the coming dawn in the east. The truth question will soon get its quietus, for a time at any rate; the season of blizzards and floods is coming to an end; exports are growing, and indications are that gold will soon be imported. Then prices will begin to rise, and though money may burden, that will not prevent the advance. It always does burden in a boom, as in a buying market people want to borrow money more than when they are selling. There are lots of cheap stocks to be picked up on which large profits will accrue to early purchasers. The Vanderbilt stocks are all low enough for a raise, so is Missouri Pacific, and the Southwesterns, and so is Western Union, which has radically got the telegraph field to itself for years to come. The only trouble which can arise is a railroad war, but there is plenty of business, and railroads don't fight when freights are good, as they are bound to be for months to come. The scarcity of Erie stock excites comment. There are over 800,000 shares yet it is said that a borrowing demand for 30,000 shares could not be filled without difficulty. It is alleged that Mr. Vanderbilt has been picking up lots of Erie, and that next year, when the property is once more controlled by the shareholders, he will be found in possession. By next year three dividends will have been paid on the preferred stock, when under the reorganization agreement the power of the trustees comes to an end. It was one of the pet ideas of old Commodore Vanderbilt to get possession of Erie, but he dropped it like a hot potato when he could get into the concern with Fisk.

**DIRGE DISASTERS**  
The year thus far has been singularly prolific of grotesque and horrible head-lines by sea and land. The slaughter of the 400 passengers on the Cimbria is soon followed by the drowning of seventy miners in a shallow coal mine in Illinois like so many rats. The other day in New York fourteen children were literally crushed to death in a useless panic mainly because their friends and relatives in their anxiety to get their little ones out of a school building presumed to be on fire blocked up fatally the only door of egress. Sunday night at eight o'clock in the village of New Brighton, a woman and her two children perished in the wreckage of a burning house, hardly ten feet above the sidewalk. The firemen did not know that they were in the building till many minutes had elapsed, and it did not seem to occur to the sapient chief to inquire if there were any people in the house. Had he done so, lives would have been saved, as the upstairs was not burned much, and the poor creatures died simply of suffocation.

**18830308: & B Railway Co., Kingston, Ont., March 7**  
The storm today and last night has been very violent. The snow has drifted badly and blocked the railways. No trains today but one on the Hamilton line and no train or mail from Toronto or Hamilton have arrived, but one is expected tonight from Toronto.  
**St. Catharines, March 7**  
A blizzard struck this section last night about 10 o'clock, lasting till tonight at 6 o'clock. The wind blew a gale from the northwest and the thick, fine snow was driven through every crevice and piled up in drifts in favorable places, yards high. Country travel is practically stopped, and railroad traffic is an impossibility. Today no trains, except one due the day before, have arrived here. The Grand Junction morning train put out but three miles east of here became stuck and is there now. It is growing colder now (10 p.m).  
**Toronto, March 7**  
The storm last night was the most severe of the whole winter. Early in the evening the snow began to fall and the wind rose very high from the northwest. All roads and side lines running north and south are completely blockaded. The Midland Railway is blocked from end to end except a few miles at this end. A train left here at midnight for Midland, but at seven o'clock this morning it had only reached Perrytown Station, about eight miles out. Two locomotives were sent to pull it back to Port Hope, and after hard work they reached the train and brought it to this station. Locomotives were then dispatched to clear the track, but by noon had only reached Millbrook, 30 miles north on the main line. Gangs of men are working at all the sections, and it is determined, if the elements will allow, to have communication open tomorrow.  
**Fergus, March 7**  
Trains are all canceled, none having arrived or departed from here during the day, and the only communication we have is by telegraph.  
**St. Johns, Que., March 7**  
A snowstorm set in about 11 yesterday and continued all day and night. The snow being very light, very little delay has been caused to the trains. Very little has fallen today and it is now calm; thermometer 8 above zero. Advices from Eastern Ontario and Upper Ottawa points report a snowfall of from four to eight inches, and cold weather, the roads being much drifted.  
**Newport, March 7**  
A severe storm occurred here yesterday. Wiggins' prediction is creating a good deal of uneasiness, especially among the women and children.  
**The prison labor question**  
**Pittsburgh, March 7**  
The Grand Secretary of the Knights of Labor will shortly issue a circular to the members of the order in New York and Pennsylvania, calling on them to organize in opposition to the convict labor system, and send protests to the legislatures. He says the question will be made a political issue in the next campaign.  
**Albany, N.Y., March 7**  
The Assembly Prisons Commission today heard a long address from John J. Perry, stove manufacturer, in defense of the convict labor system. The Masters, James Connelly, John J. Meddigan, James Lynch and others, representing various trade unions of the State, bitterly denounced the system.  
**Midnight Despatches**  
**PROBABILITIES**  
**Meteorological Office, Toronto, March 8, 1 a.m.**  
The important storm mentioned last night has passed over the Maritime Provinces, and is now apparently situated near Newfoundland. The anti-cyclonic system which lay over the northwest has moved to the Lake region, and comparatively low pressure covers the Northwest Territories and the Gulf of Mexico. The weather has turned decidedly colder in Ontario and Quebec, accompanied during the day by strong winds and gales from the west and north. The gale which prevailed in the Maritime Provinces has subsided, and the weather is now clearing with strong northwest winds.  
**PROBABILITIES**  
**Lakes** - Winds shifting to the southwest and southeast; fair, milder weather.  
**Upper St. Lawrence** - Light to moderate winds; fine weather; rising temperature.  
**Lower St. Lawrence, Quebec and Maritime** - Decreasing northwest to west winds; fine, cold weather.  
**Death of Dr. Green**  
**London, March 7**  

**18830314:**  
**P. Robinson on School Revenue and Expenditure, until tomorrow's issue**  
**The St. Patrick's National County**  
The annual meeting of this Society for the election of officers and other business was to have been held last night, but owing to the absence of the president nothing was done, it being decided to adjourn until tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock.  
**FAREWELL TO WIGGINS**  
Apropos Wiggins, lay him low, lay him low,  
Where Canadian snow-banks grow.  
What to him is flood or blizzard?  
He'll pose no more as weather wizard.  
He missed his true "fit" to come at last,  
Lay him low, lay him low.  
From the Argus, Albany, N.Y.  

**18830508:**  
**UNITED STATES**  
**A drunken father's crime**  
**Boston, May 7**  
John Callahan, of Winchester, went to Woburn on Saturday and bought a gallon of liquor and then went on a spree. He brought a three-year-old child with him and forced him to drink all he could and then threw the liquor in its face. The child went into convulsions and died this morning at a doubtful age.  
**CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio, May 7**  
It is alleged that John Blizzard (colored), who has just died here, was 125 years old.  
**Smallpox in Virginia**  
**Wheeling, W.Va., May 7**  
A smallpox plague is raging in Mecca County. The disease originated two weeks ago from a tramp who was taken sick and who stopped at the house of a farmer named Blankinship. In a day or two Blankinship was taken sick with an eruptive disease. The doctor called in pronounced the malady chicken-pox. The patient died and the funeral was attended by two hundred people. As a consequence, the disease was distributed throughout the county. The physician was taken ill himself, and, after visiting patients several days, called in a brother physician, who for the first time made known the character of the scourge. The disease spread with alarming rapidity. Up to this time, forty cases have occurred and fifteen deaths. The situation is daily becoming worse. The county has been put under strict quarantine by the State Board of Health.  
**The Indian troubles**  
**Fort Apache, Ariz, May 7**  
Twelve hundred San Carlos Indians have left their agencies and are settling in the mountains around this post, and demand grain for seed. The commander has issued six thousand pounds of corn and has asked the Secretary of the Interior for small seed. He fears there will be difficulty in keeping the Indians quiet. The commander here was ordered at the last moment to return to his post from Crooks' expedition, in order to guard against such emergencies.  
**Railway consolidation**  
**Chicago, Ill., May 7**  
It is stated that an agreement has been consummated between the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe, St. Louis & San Francisco, and Atlantic & Pacific Railroads, by which the controlling interest in the St. Louis & San Francisco road is secured to the Atlantic Pacific. This is a practical stoppage of the extension of the St. Louis & San Francisco road and equivalent to merging its franchise in the Atlantic Pacific.  
**Charter forfeited**  
**Harrisburg, May 7**  
The Governor has issued a proclamation declaring forfeited the charters of all corporations which have failed to make a return to the Attorney-General within three years, and have not responded since the issuing of the previous proclamation thirty days ago. Between 650 and 700 charters are declared forfeited. The list is composed largely of defunct concerns.  
**Chief of Police and Boston**  
**Boston, May 7**  
Today Mr. Wade, Chief of the District Police in Pemberton Square...

was shot in the arm and shoulder by Richard Brennan, a crank, recently discharged from a correctional institution, and probably actuated by a desire for revenge. Brennan was arrested. Wade's wounds are not dangerous. 

Mt. Auburn County, Boston, May 7. The Senate has passed a bill for the payment of a dollar-a-ton bounty on beets raised for sugar-making purposes. Railway bill vetoed. Boston, May 7. The Governor sent to the office of the Secretary of State without his signature the bill appropriating $261,000 for double tracking the Hoosac Tunnel line.

18840123: P. Railway open to Lake Superior, and with Port Arthur as the objective point under the low-rate system, we are sure of our emigration fronts, whether they land at Quebec or New York. When I first went over to England, I at once, said Mr. Begg, that unless Canada could bid for emigration to stock, as well as for the St. Lawrence, she would always have great odds against her; and I have never lost sight of this fact. See the large number of powerful steamship lines running to New York from Great Britain and the continent. All these have active agencies everywhere, every one of which was bound under the old order of things to work against Canada. Our own St. Lawrence steamship companies were opposed and hampered by all sides of those agencies. It is important to note that in fighting it, especially as the conditions make Canada at a disadvantage compared to the United States—a situation unequal, with the high rates charged to Canadian emigrants. Under the present order of things, all agencies will see their way to work for Canada. It will be popular, and the St. Lawrence Steamship Lines, having agencies throughout the continent, will participate in the result and will get their full share of the increased traffic. 

On being asked whether the facilities offered via New York would not act against the St. Lawrence ports, Mr. Begg said it would have a contrary effect. In the first place, he said, the representatives of the Canadian lines are about the most active men in the business on the other side. With a united house, that is, all hands working for Canada, consequently bringing increased business, you need not fear but that the Canadian lines will get their fair share of the increase. Instead of having to fight against the antagonism of the New York lines and low rates to points in the United States, they are freed from that antagonism and will benefit accordingly. Then, added Mr. Begg, there is another view: we are not taking emigrants away from the St. Lawrence, but capturing a lot of those going via New York, and, in fact, stimulating extra emigration. 

Then again, the whole success of our manufacturers, tradesmen, mechanics, and farmers depends on a regular influx of population. The whole success of the Dominion depends upon it. Canada cannot afford to shut any avenue for supplying her with emigrants, no matter how they come. What does a rapid peopling of our Northwest mean? It means increased trade for Montreal, Toronto, and other cities; it means increased demand for our manufactures and increased work for our people, and better business for our tradesmen. It means increased trade for our shipping, outward and inwards, increased activity for our seaports. Put the question to our shipowners and see what they will say. Our Canadian steamship owners will tell you that to them the greater the population of Canada, the better will be their prospects now and hereafter. They can well afford to open every avenue for Canadian immigration. 

Being asked what certainty there was of our securing our immigrants passing through New York, even with the low rates, Mr. Begg replied, "Every security." Simply because these rates are only available via Port Arthur as an objective point where the United States have no power to divert the emigrants. When speaking of the difficulties in the way of promoting emigration to Canada, Mr. Begg said they were much more numerous than people imagined. American agents are very active and not slow to take advantage of every weapon they can find. But he said the worst enemies to Canada are Canadians, and the worst difficulties we have to face emanate from Canadian sources. We have to contend against Canadians and others who write or speak against the Northwest simply because they are interested personally or politically in another part of Canada. We find Canadian papers gain some political end by decrying the climate or the resources of the country. There seems to be a morbid desire on the part of some Canadian papers to herald forth in the loudest notes anything disparaging to the country to which they owe allegiance. If a blizzard occurs, it is depicted with great headlines and described with all imaginary horror. When it is 40 below zero, all the world is made acquainted with the fact, but the successive weeks of beautiful weather are unnoticed by them as if they had never been heard of. When an early frost takes place, everybody knows it. Of course, the Canadian public can understand that this is done not from any real intention to injure Canada, but to gain a point against the Government, and if it could be confined to the circle it intended to influence, it would not do much harm. But unfortunately, there is a portion of the British press actuated by motives inimical to Canada and Canadian enterprises, who gladly avail themselves of quoting these disparaging statements and sending them broadcast throughout Great Britain. How can we, agents, resent such statements when we are confronted with the fact that they are the utterances of our own Canadian papers? If these same Canadian papers could understand the damage they are doing to their own patrons, they would perhaps moderate their views, for every blow struck at Canada means a loss, more or less, to every merchant, manufacturer, tradesman, and mechanic in the country. 

"Pretty strong language?" said our representative. "I mean it," said Mr. Begg, "I am a Canadian and speak as a Canadian, and my words in this respect will be borne out by every man working in the interest of Canada abroad. The greatest bugbear flaunted in the faces of Canadian agents is the severity of the climate of Canada, whereas the Canadian climate is one of the healthiest in the world. We are indebted to Mr. Geo.

18840209: NEW BILLS. Mr. Williams introduced a bill to amend the act of incorporation of the Synod of the Diocese of Saskatchewan. Mr. McMaster introduced a bill to incorporate the River St. Clair Tunnel Company; also a bill to consolidate certain railways under the name of the Eastern Railway Company of Canada. Mr. Cameron (Victoria) introduced a bill to amend the act relating to the Manitoba and Northwest Railway Company. Mr. Kilvort introduced a bill respecting the Hamilton and Northwestern Railway Company. Mr. Weisl (Westmoreland) introduced a bill to reduce the capital stock of the Maritime Bank of the Dominion of Canada. Mr. Derglin introduced a bill to amend the charter of the Ontario Pacific Railway Company. Mr. Quinn introduced a bill respecting the Kingston and Pembroke Railway Company. Mr. Rosso introduced a bill to incorporate the Quebec Railway. Mr. Allen introduced a bill to extend the jurisdiction of the maritime court of Buffalo. Mr. Curran introduced a bill to provide for the distribution of assets of insolvent debtors. (A member welcomed him.) 

THE RAILWAY DEBATE. Mr. Lam resumed the debate on the motion of Sir Charles Tupper, "That the house do go into committee of the whole to consider certain proposed resolutions respecting the Canadian Pacific Railway." In his opening remarks, he resumed the history of the enterprise up to the present, dwelling upon its special importance to confederation and the future development of the whole country. He enlarged on the excellence of the alignment and construction thus far and the expedition which the government and company had manifested in their work. He spoke of the immense efforts which the government were making in England and on the continent to direct attention to Canada as a place of settlement, on which account it was only natural to expect that there would be an immense influx of immigrants. He praised the government and the company for what had so far been done in completing the road, opening a highway for settlers on Canadian soil, thus keeping to ourselves the immigrants and trade. They had, on this account, done well in saving six years in the work of completion, more particularly on account of the trade with China and Japan, which would be given and preserved to us. Everyone interested in Canada was bound to rejoice in the rapid completion of the railroad. He thought it a matter of economy to assist the company which had thus ante-dated the contract. Ontario ought not to complain because she would have more speedy relief from the existing monopoly. The company had not only built the road more rapidly but better than their contract stipulated for. The opposition in this house had the effect of depreciating the company's securities and had also injured immigration. They had depreciated the company in a variety of ways and had prevented immigration by preaching about extravagant freight rates, depreciating the Canadian Northwest, and by preaching the beauties of Dakota and the delights of Texas. They said that the railway lands were not of the best, that the road should have gone further north, and in consequence that the lands opened up were inferior. They had declared, in addition, that the acquisition of the Credit Valley and other railways would be an unprofitable investment and had led capitalists to fear that the enterprise would not be a paying one. He ridiculed the construction placed by the leader of the opposition on the interview between Mr. Van Home and a reporter of the Montreal Star, and censured the opposition press for the injury they had done by their sensational reports of blizzards and such like. A number of articles and letters had been written for the sake of being published abroad, whose object was to prevent immigrants coming here. He referred to certain publications in the Globe and advised journalists to take a leaf from the book of the United States and never foul their own nests. Having submitted a number of specimen bricks, he continued that it was certain Parliament would manage its own affairs without calling in the assistance of correspondents in London. The gentlemen to his right were indignant that there should be a monopoly in Manitoba; yet when it was sought to rivet the hand of the Grand Trunk monopoly on Ontario, there was no one to oppose it, nor any sweet singer to compose a ballad. "Ontario! Ontario!" Then there had been, in addition, individual opposition, and more than that, the opposition of nearly all the leading American lines of railroad because they discovered the determination to have a Canadian railway from ocean to ocean. All the opposing influences had been supplemented by the condition of the stock market. At 66, as it was at present, 

18840221: I, yesterday destroyed the post office and custom house, and did other damage to the amount of $250,000. Considerable loss of life and great destruction of property have been caused by a storm which swept over the Southern States on Tuesday night. In the Imperial House of Commons last evening, Mr. O'Connor Power made a violent attack on the Parnell party and their course in relation to Irish affairs. A blizzard has been raging for two days in Dakota, and several lives are thought to have been lost, three or four stages not having been heard of after hunting on their trips. 

TERRIBLE BLIZZARD IN DAKOTA. Fatal colliery explosion. Connellyville, Pa., February 20. An explosion in West Lehigh shaft, near here, today, resulted in a terrible loss of life. Seventy-five men were at work in the mine and out of that number, twenty-nine are known to have been killed. Twelve more were rescued but so injured that they will die. The mine was worked by means of a shaft which reaches the mine a distance of four hundred feet from the surface. This morning, a part of the force that worked all night left the mine and seventy others took their places. Soon after, an explosion occurred 800 feet from the bottom shaft and 1,200 feet from the surface. The report was heard outside for a long distance and caused such a jar that a derrick 100 feet high was knocked off. Dick Halsey alone escaped. He wound his clothes tightly around his face and mouth to keep the foul air from choking him and reached the open air. His escape seemed marvellous. Two hours elapsed before anyone dared face the after-damp to search within the mine. Halsey says the men acted like mice in a burning stable, and were bewildered, and, not knowing which way to go, refused to go in any direction. 

Pennsylvania coal mines. WILKES-BARRE, Pa., February 20. The annual report of the operations of the middle district coal field for 1893 shows the total amount of coal mined to have been 705,000 tons, the number of persons employed 1,7000. Six hundred thousand more tons were mined and three thousand more persons employed than last year. 

A Dakota blizzard. LAMOURE, Dak., February 20. Three...

Out of four stages due here yesterday, none have been heard from. It is believed the drivers and passengers have perished in the blizzard. The Ellendale coach was found halfway between Lamoure and Yankton, turned bottom side up, and the driver was found in a house two miles distant, badly frozen. He had no passengers.

1884-02-22: WRIGHT & CO. Manufacturers of Art & Church FURNITURE, Bank & Office Fittings, WOOD CARPETING AND ALL KINDS OF FACTORY WOODWORK. 11 to 17 Hermine Street, MONTREAL. (Please note: "pmV)nArtM aataiogiM cf Ialal4 Ttam" seems to be garbled and may not have a direct correction without context.)

EPITOME OF LATEST NEWS: General Gordon is to go to Kordofan to interview El Mahdi. A body of rebels advancing upon Suakim has been repulsed. De Lesseps has been elected a member of the French Academy. Severe gales have done considerable damage on the British coasts. Mexico, after May 15th, will increase her customs duties by 10 per cent. The barque Ada Barton, from St. John for Glasgow, has been lost at sea with all hands. Railroad operations in the Northwestern States have been nearly paralyzed by the late blizzard.

1884-02-25: THE LAND REGULATIONS. I asked: "Well, what is the matter?" "Oh, it is the land regulations." "Well, what do you object to in them?" "Oh," they say, "it is the land regulations." Now, as to the land regulations, their advantages were explained so fairly and so fully the other night by the hon. member for Lisgar that it is unnecessary for me to make any long reference to them. But I feel that our land regulations are so liberal, so generous, and so inviting, compared with those prevailing in Dakota, that I cannot refrain from mentioning a few of their features. Hon. gentlemen know that one of the first things that meets a Canadian or any other man who goes to settle in Dakota or Minnesota is the oath of allegiance, especially against Great Britain. (Hear, hear.) Do we impose any such conditions upon anyone who goes to our Northwest? We say: No; you give us your citizenship for three years, and we will give you the land; the American term of residence is five years. They enact continuous residence, with us only six months in each year of the three is required. And with reference to pre-emptions, no settler in Dakota can get a pre-emption until he gets a certificate of his homestead. The result is that he is often obliged to locate his pre-emption 30 or 40 miles away from his homestead. (Cheers.) In our Northwest, the moment a man makes his homestead entry, he can make his pre-emption entry, and he gets the two side by side; and he receives all the advantages that can accrue to him from his entering for that pre-emption by the fact of his occupation of his homestead. It is just as sure to him as his homestead, provided he fulfills the necessary requirements of his homestead. So that there is no comparison between Dakota and our Northwest in that respect. And yet hon. gentlemen get up in this House and state that one of the causes of the exodus, which I could not discover, is the inferiority of our land regulations to those of the United States. 

Now, WITH REGARD TO THE EMIGRANTS, I found a great number of men in Manitoba from Dakota, from Minnesota, and especially from Montana. I met one very intelligent man at Medicine Hat who had been a mixed grazer and farmer in Montana, and he said to me, "As compared with Montana, this is God's country." (Cheers.) That was his expression. Now, I have heard it said that there are large settlements of Canadians in the United States, and hon. gentlemen opposite attribute those settlements to the difference in the land laws of the two countries; I say that is absurd and unfair. I know that there are large settlements of Canadians in the western states, whole districts for miles around; I am speaking more particularly of Michigan and Illinois, in which there are large numbers of people from my own neighborhood. Men whom I have lived with for fifteen years have gone out there. And why did they go? For this simple reason: they were led away by the profuse and attractive advertising not only of the American government, but principally of American railways that had lands for sale. I remember twenty years ago seeing something that I thought should not be tolerated by the Canadian people: the immense placards which were hung up at every prominent point in the country. I remember seeing in the Union station at Toronto, and also at Montreal, immense glass cases, about six feet long, containing specimens of all sorts of grain from Illinois, Minnesota, and other western states. I remember one in particular. In front, there was a prairie scene, with long waving grass, and on one side, a herd of buffalo; immediately in the rear were a number of engineers with their instruments set up, and behind them were men laying a railway track; behind that again were three or four ploughs, a reaping machine, a threshing machine, and other instruments at work, and behind that again were a lot of carts hauling wheat to the railway. Now, what immigrant could resist an advertisement like that? (Hear, hear.) Why, it was a whole lecture in itself. We had no prairie lands to offer at that time, and any young man, or old man either, who was intelligent and vigorous, and was desirous of making a home for himself and his sons at the least expenditure of labor, was not going into the backwoods of Ontario, where he would have to cut down maple trees, and ash trees, and elm trees, to make place for his home. Here was a country completely devoid of all these obstructions, and it attracted a lot of people; hence the settlement of Canadians in the northwestern states. I know many of these old men are strong in their allegiance to British institutions, but they went there for the sake of pecuniarily benefiting themselves and their families, and they lived and died British subjects. I know some who never went to poll a vote; though their sons voted, they did not. (Hear, hear.) What I want to point out is this: that the young people of today are just as strong in their attachment to Canada as those old men to whom I refer; and when we have a country as extensive and as accessible to offer to these people, we will not have many more of these American settlements, provided the gentlemen opposite do not deter people from going in there by their cries about cold, want of feed, bad water, blizzards, and bad land regulations. (Cheers.) 

As regards the weather, the hon. gentleman says the thermometer went down to 40. I remarked that today in my own verandah at Kumptville, it went down to 35, and the strong wind and the damp atmosphere at the time, I am satisfied, registered more on my feelings and those of any man in the country than 40 of the clear atmosphere of the Northwest. I know the frost may have a deterring effect on those who will not thoroughly understand the conditions and the effect it has on that country in an agricultural sense; but it should be remembered that the cold period in the far Northwest is much shorter than it is either in Manitoba or Ontario. Winter comes on in the extreme Northwest about perhaps the middle of November, and men who have lived there ten years say that during all that time there was no season in which they could not sow their grain on the first of March, and the winter is practically gone on the first of February. As to the effects of frost, naturally, it may be difficult to get through the winter until those people have built for themselves comfortable houses and got cheap fuel. But it has this effect upon the country: that every inch of frost that penetrates into the soil during the winter and thaws out in the spring disintegrates the soil elements of the plants which are growing upon it, and adds to the store value of that country as an agricultural region. We know that as you approach the Mississippi from the north, even as far south as southern Dakota, where the frost does not penetrate in such a great depth, from six to eight years is about as long as the average surface of that country would preserve its maximum virgin production, for the simple reason that the frost does not penetrate any further, and as no sub-soiling has been attempted, the roots of the plants do not penetrate into the soil that has not been loosened by the frost. In the lands in that section, which have for years been under cultivation, the falling off from this cause is not compensated by the increase through new territory; but our Northwest will preserve her maximum production of that cultivation four or five years longer, so that even at a much less rapid pace of settlement than our neighbors, her maximum will be continued for a much longer period. (Cheers.)

There is another feature to which I draw attention. Every hon. gentleman who has paid attention to the zone belts of the earth in which food cereals are produced knows that it is in the north temperate zones that nearly all the grains are grown, and the nearer the northern limit of that belt in which grain is matured perfectly, the better is the quality of the grain. What I illustrate by that is this: that we, having today in that Northwest country, a larger area of land fit for agricultural purposes, when we get a fair proportion under cultivation, will produce a larger quantity continuously of a better quality than the American states can ever hope to do, and I state what I know is a matter of fact when I say that wheat near our own boundary in northern Dakota is more valuable than that grown further south. Why is that? Simply because the grain is of a better quality; it is what is technically called of a flinty character, and, when grown, will produce more flour, and is used to mix with the softer grains grown in the southern wheat belt. (Hear, hear.) In the southern belt, the same wheat cannot be grown more than three years successively because it so softens that the germinating properties are lost and half the seeds will not sprout. A large quantity of our wheat, even as early as three years ago, was sent down to that region for seed wheat, as the hon. member for Marquette well knows. The ultimate result of this will be that when that country is fairly under cultivation, when it has a population of five, six, or eight million, its production will be so great that when exported either by the Hudson's Bay route, by the Canadian Pacific Railway, or Port Arthur, I care not how, and landed on the Liverpool markets, those who schedule the breadstuffs and make up their prices for the season will not only ask how much is the production in England, in Russia, or in India or the United States, but the great question will be what will be the export from Canada? (Cheers.) The production of Canada will regulate the prices of the world. This question has been dealt with so long and so variedly and by so many hon. gentlemen in the House, who have many years ago made their maiden speech, that there is very little left for me to say, and I feel that my remarks will have perhaps less interest than they might have had at an earlier date. (Cries of "go on, go on.") But there is one thing, in speaking of the country west in settlement, which I think is very important, and the reason I mention it is that in reading, as I always do, carefully the reports of the geological surveys, I find no mention is made of it, nor is it mentioned by any surveyor or others who have traveled through the country. I think, therefore, that I am perfectly justified in drawing attention to the fact that in the extreme Northwest fuel will be so cheap that the difficulty mentioned by the member for Marquette with reference to building timber will be easily remedied. Now, I quite disagree with him; I am satisfied I know that THE CHEAPEST BUILDING MATERIAL, of the most durable and beautiful quality that exists on this continent, exists in that Northwest Territory. I referred a few minutes ago to the large deposits of almost pure clay. Those beds are the deposits of the disintegration of the hill rocks, long before the country was settled, anyway (laughter), and the lime which the rocks contained has been carried off while held in solution. The clay, almost pure, is deposited, and I refer especially to the coal regions in immense beds over the coal. The only substance that these clay beds contain, aside from the clay, is a silicate sand which is insoluble in water. What drew my attention to this was that I saw at various places on the river banks, natural brick kilns, burnt and almost ready for the market, of acres and acres in extent. It came in this way: The deposits were made over the coal beds by the action of water. In the course of time, ravines have been formed and cut through the coal beds. Eventually, the grass grew over the ravines, and, by some accidents in prairie fires, the coal caught fire, and continued back for acres under the surface, converting the whole superincumbent mass from 150 to 200 feet. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

Feet, into one mass of beautiful brick. Hear, hear! It is the CHARACTER OF THIS BRICK I wish to draw the attention of the house to. It is a brick formed from the clay, entirely devoid of lime, containing a silicate sand. In burning, after mixture, there is no expansion of the particles of lime. The brick is almost perfectly compact. It is a silicate brick. It is a crude glass, impervious to water, and almost indestructible by atmospheric influence. I found blocks in the Saskatchewan and in the Bow River, and north of the Red Deer River, which must have been there, perhaps for a thousand years, where they had fallen, by the action of water and weather, into the water. Taking them up and breaking them with my hatchet, I found they were perfectly dry. Taking up ordinary limestone and smashing it, I could see evidence of the porosity and moisture there, convincing me that that brick was more impervious to water than our blue limestone. I found, where they had drifted down the river for many miles, they were as smooth as any slate I ever saw polished. So much with reference to the building material. There is a scarcity of wood, it is true, and transport will cost something, but in that country you find the clay always overlying the material for converting it into brick; the coal you find it over the whole country; and brick may be made into any form: pillars, corners, mouldings into any shape possible for the construction of beautiful edifices, which in the kiln convert into this indestructible brick. There is a notable feature that, when burnt, they may be polished, because they are so compact, and I saw thousands of evidences of their capability of being polished from the action of the water. That is not all, but these clay beds vary from 25 to 50 feet, which were deposited at several spaces of time, and of different colors, the color having been given, no doubt, by the character of the vegetable at the time the deposit was made, and the color fixed by the silicic acid in this sand, which, I think the hon. the minister of finance, from his knowledge of chemistry, knows is the acid that fixes all vegetable dyes. There you find, in one stratum, a clay which makes a beautiful garnet red brick; in the next, a nice brown; then a beautiful golden yellow; and, at the top, a snow white (Hear, hear!). There is the material and the character and the profuseness of this supply. I am satisfied that when the country comes to be settled, the towns and villages there will be the handsomest, the most durable, and the cheapest that were ever constructed on this continent, and that we will have ornamental buildings of material much more beautiful, because it takes a better polish, as indestructible, and at much less cost to the producer than the ordinary limestone rubble wall of Ottawa. So much as to the building material.

1884-02-27: II Beruathy, who, when hunting, found a cave and evidences of the precious metal. Over $50,000 worth of nuggets are on exhibition in this store. Many strangers are flocking here. Lost in a Dakota blizzard. Valley City, Dak., February 26. The body of Fred Nelson was found five miles from the place whence he started during the blizzard. His two children, who went out with him, have not yet been found. Minneapolis, February 20. The worst blizzard of the season is raging at Crookston and vicinity. Fears are entertained for the safety of passengers who left on the stage for Red Lake Falls. Mardi Gras in New Orleans. New Orleans, February 28. The Mardi Gras procession here today was a long one. It represented King Solomon and twenty tableaux cars illustrated biblical history. The subject of this evening's procession illustrates the history of Ireland for 1,500 years. Measles among the Indians. Albuquerque, N.M.

1884-02-28: K Minister to Russia, is dead. Kelmer, the Norwegian minister of state, has been impeached. The black troops at Kimpkin have been found to be in communication with the rebel camp. A Minnesota blizzard has stopped the running of trains on several roads in that and western states. A London stock broker has been expelled from the exchange for dealing with one of Baring Bros.' clerks. French reports say the situation in Tonquin is excellent, and that the capture of Bacninh will offer no serious difficulty. The British advance on Teb commenced yesterday morning; some anxiety is felt concerning the success of the expedition. Halifax city council has decided to grant the usual number of liquor licenses, and to defend any holder prosecuted under the Dominion Act. The Egyptian garrisons at El Fasher, Darra, Masted, and Koga, in the Soudan, are still holding out, though several others have surrendered. The U.S. Justice, agent of the Dismal Swamp Canal Lottery Company, the jury brought in a verdict of guilty; fixing the defendant's punishment at five minutes in jail, and a fine of $5. The defendant will appeal to the Supreme Court. The Minnesota blizzard is raging. St. Paul, Minn., February 27. The storm along the Minneapolis and St. Louis road developed today into the worst blizzard of the season. The running of freight trains was abandoned, and passenger trains are running on slow time. On the Winona & St. Peter road, all trains have been abandoned until the weather moderates. On the Northern Pacific, it is very cold and stormy. Some trouble is experienced from weakened track from floods on the Yellowstone end. Minneapolis, Minn., February 27. The roads in the State of Dakota are generally blocked. Fatal powder explosion. Omaha, February 27. Four boys, ten to seventeen years old, while hunting south of the city this afternoon, exploded a powder house, containing over six tons of powder. All four were blown to pieces. Snow in Mississippi. Corinth, Miss., February 27. A rain storm this morning turned into snow, and this evening the snow is three inches deep here. A case of miscegenation. Toledo, February 27. The case of Robt. Bailey (colored) on trial for marrying a white girl contrary to the law of 1840, which imposes a fine of $100 and three months' imprisonment for a white person marrying one with negro blood or vice-versa, was tried here today. The defense claimed that the law was unconstitutional under the 14th amendment. The court overruled the defense and Bailey was found guilty and given the full penalty of the law. Only one case under this law has been tried in Cleveland, which was dismissed, the judge holding the law unconstitutional. Notes: It is suspected that some gold is being withdrawn from the New York sub-treasury for special deposit in the banks in case of the continued coinage in silver leading to a premium being placed upon gold. At Boston, a national bird show has opened with 2,000 entries. At Hudson, in, hog cholera is raging and the farmers fear an epidemic. Notices have been posted in nine hat factories at Reading, Pa., employing 800 hands, of a reduction of 15 percent in wages on March 1st. There is great excitement at Eagle, Waukesha County, Wisconsin, over the reported discovery of a rich diamond field. Milwaukee parties have purchased all the land about Eagle at high figures. The Ohio legislature has made provision for bringing the remains of the war correspondent.

The rebels acknowledge having had 1,300 of their men killed in the fighting on Friday and Saturday between Trinkitat and Tokar. The worst blizzard of the season is reported from Dakota on Saturday, when it was impossible to stay on the streets. The railroads are all blocked. About 4 percent of the employees of the Pennsylvania Railroad, after examination, have been found to be defective in vision, hearing, or ability to distinguish colors. An alliance between Germany, Russia, and Austria has been formed, which the German ministerial journals assert is part of a scheme for breaking the maritime power of England. On account of the action of the French government in aiding England to ferret out the dynamite conspirators, the Fenian ring leaders at Paris are preparing to remove to Geneva. A motion to adjourn the House of Commons to discuss the Soudan question, after Mr. Gladstone had refused to answer questions in relation thereto, was defeated by a majority of two in the House of Commons yesterday. Japan, March 3. Recently a young man named Geary shot himself. The authorities of the Catholic Church refused to allow the body to be buried in the church cemetery. The father of the young Geary sought redress in the court and defeated the church authorities. The body of the young man was then interred, and yesterday the elder Geary was excommunicated on the ground that the cemetery was desecrated. Threats have been made to remove the remains by violence. The grave is strongly guarded. Another Dakota case. St. Paul, March 3. Specials from Bismarck, Jamestown, and Fargo, Dak., show that March came in with a blizzard that throws all previous ones this year into insignificance. Heavy snow fell all day on Saturday and yesterday, the wind blowing forty to fifty miles an hour. It was impossible to stay upon the street. Trains were delayed, as all cuts were filled with snow. The thermometer was 20 to 25 below zero. Huron, Dak., March 3. The hardest snowstorm of the winter is raging here. Most of the roads are blockaded again. The thermometer is 17 below zero. A telegraph fight. Philadelphia, March 3. The controversy between the Baltimore & Ohio and Western Union Companies over the possession of an office in 3rd street culminated today in the forcible ejection of the Western Union operator and the throwing out of the office fixtures into the street. For his father's sake. Dover, N.H.

1884-03-12: H. Prentiss in the House of Delegates yesterday. He said he had been deprived of everything but being a Mississippian and that a race newly enfranchised had more privileges than he enjoyed. He had been rebuked for not asking pardon, but pardon came after repentance, and he had never repented. Were the same to be done again, he would do as he had done. Mr. Davis was vigorously applauded. A Minnesota blizzard. Minneapolis, March 11. The most severe blizzard of the season is raging. Travel of all kinds is suspended and people are keeping indoors. The storm is severe everywhere in the state. In the neighborhood of St. Vincent, the snow in places is drifted twenty feet deep. Montflore memorial. Cleveland, Ohio, March 11. The supreme lodge of the Hebrew Order of Kosher Shil Burseel, holding its quinquennial session here today, endowed a home for aged and infirm Israelites, located in this city, in commemoration of the one hundredth birthday of Sir Moses Montefiore and a tribute to his worth. The value of the endowment is $70,000. This is the first memorial founded in honor of the Jewish philanthropist, and was adopted with great enthusiasm.
