Average Manitoba Indian chiefs have been desolating our Northwest, and plundering and pillaging our territories. American papers tell of secret organizations drilling on the prairie beyond the limits of our towns, in the midnight breeze of a Northern blizzard. Whole armies of distracted settlers are described as pouring across the line into Dakota, fleeing from a detestable monopoly and an accursed agricultural duty. A despotic government is represented as imprisoning and persecuting publishers of military proclamations and movers of secessionist resolutions. The impression east, if any credence is placed in these assertions, of Manitoba must be a wonderful one indeed. Certainly, the Northwest is not in want of advertising.

The local home opened last Thursday and adjourned until today. The speech from the throne contained nothing of grave importance. Thousands who attended the opening went away disappointed. The talk upon the streets is considerable, and some stormy scenes in the House are looked for.

1884-04-02: JHE, GAZETTE, MONTREAL, WEDNESDAY, APRIL 2, MONTREAL, WEDNESDAY, APRIL 2

THE PLANTING OF TREES

A new word, forestry, formerly a mere dictionary word, and hazily that even, has come into our common daily speech, and we hear of forestry congresses, schools of forestry, and various applications of it which indicate altogether a change of sentiment on the subject of trees. For centuries the dweller on this continent looked upon the forests that overshadowed so much of its surface as a barrier in the way of his progress which had to be removed. So, with might and main, the pioneers everywhere assailed them, and ruthlessly to right and to left a path was hewn out for advancing civilization. It was long before any practical man discovered that such indiscriminate slaughter of the trees of the forest was a mistake, and those who first uttered words of warning received small attention. Only when the great treeless plains of the west, overswept by icy blizzards, made the newcomers regret the grove shelters of the east, did men begin to realize the blunder of making havoc among those natural protectors. Other regrets followed in time as it was discovered that not only for warding off storms in winter and heat in summer, not only as fuel and building material, but as serving an admirable purpose in connection with climate and temperature and the distribution of rainfall and other features of the wondrous economy of nature, the destruction of the trees in the usual wholesale fashion was a waste of resources of which the consequences could not fail to be widely injurious. During the last few years, this conviction has gradually spread over the whole of North America (not to speak of other countries), and with it has come a desire to repair, as far as possible, the mischief done, as well by putting restrictions on the cutting of timber and taking other measures for its preservation as by giving all possible encouragement to forest renovation and tree-planting where needed. It is not necessary to recount all that has been done in this direction during the last few years. Suffice it to say that both in the United States and our own provinces, governments and people have fully awakened to the advisability of vigilance in preventing further waste and of fruitful effort in reforestation, and what the public now requires to know is exactly what, where, and how to plant so as to effect most good. Anyone who would compile a handy volume or manual on the subject, giving intelligibly and concisely all needful directions on those points would surely, one might think, be performing a task of universally recognized utility. Nor, perhaps, could anyone be found better fitted to undertake it than the zealous and active chief of the forestry division in the Department of Agriculture at Washington.

1884-05-23: H. Kgeleston, of Washington, who said that the value of timber lands was of two kinds: first, a commercial value, which varied with situation and its vicinity to market and the demand for lumber, and secondly, their value with reference to climate, etc., that no money could represent. He deprecated the fact that the government had put the same value on timber lands as they did on the lands swept by blizzards, and took the ground that the government ought to suspend all sales of timber lands until they ascertained what needed to be preserved and what needed to be sold. He recommended the adoption of the system prevailing in Canada of selling the timber only and of making such rules for the cutting of the trees as not to injure the trees which were left, and so as to keep up a perpetual supply, and said that any possible expenditure for the purpose of preserving our woodlands would be abundantly warranted. The forest product of the United States was valued at $700,000,000 a year, and the following statement would show its value in comparison with other products in the year 1880: 

- Forest crop: $700,000,000
- Indian corn: $614,784,000
- Wheat: $474,017,630
- Hay: $371,840,004
- Oats: $160,184,585
- Potatoes: $61,062,814
- Tobacco: $15,414,515
- Barley: $10,000,012
- Rye: $1,181,542
- Buckwheat: $8,844,488
- Cotton: $290,306,142
- Non-precious minerals, such as coal, iron, copper, lead, and zinc ore: $143,504,312
- Gold and silver: $74,490,220

The third paper was by Mr.

1884-07-24: A syndicate is doing grave injury to bona fide settlers in refusing to accept the raising of stock as the equivalent for the cropping of land. Thus far, the raising of grain has been but problematical, while success has attended cattle raising. Surely the ownership of 50 or 60 head of cattle with 160 acres cropped is as genuine proof of bona fide settlement as to have 120 acres cropped with no livestock. To invest in stock means to abridge the ability of the average farmer for extended cultivation, so that the present contract with settlers is a practical prohibition to investing in stock and therefore is unfriendly to the farmer's prosperity. As I understand the matter, for one to be able to retain a syndicate half section, 160 acres must be cropped the fourth year of his contract or else seed much of it down or let what was formerly cropped run to weed. But in the meantime, the poor hard-working settler does not know what meadow will prove hardy enough, and no consideration will be given to any hindrance he may have sustained in using his funds for stock to utilize the pasture and buy when secured. I have seen somewhere in print that the company would make special arrangements with settlers who might wish to unite stock raising with grain growing, but on application to the company, I find they are not favorable to it. A more liberal policy would certainly be in the interest of permanent settlement.

THE INDIAN QUESTION is a difficult and troublesome one, and oft-times comes up there. His well-known revengeful spirit and predatory habits are a source of constant uneasiness to settlers. The opinion is gaining ground that unless the police force is very much increased wherever there is a reserve, actual hostilities are sure to break out on some of the occasions when an ill-equipped and inadequate force is sent to take Indian prisoners. The real spirit of the Indian may be correctly gathered from what took place last winter at the Qu'Appelle Valley. I received the facts from an eyewitness, one of the settlers, who drove the police force from Broadview, a distance of sixteen miles, to the shanty down in the valley, where the stolen flour and bacon were stored and guarded by an armed body of determined Indians. I drove to the place, and from a projecting eminence was regaled with a grand panoramic view of the valley and deep gully through which alone vehicles can gain access to the plain beneath. At that place, the valley is some miles in width and in the long ago had been the bed of a majestic river, which now is dwindled to a mere creek meandering in serpentine course among reeds and brush through the middle of the plain. The banks are high, rocky, and steep, bare and bleak on the north side, but thick-wooded on the southern slopes. They afford almost complete protection from the blizzard that may be devastating everything in the prairie overhead. The gully is about a half mile in length, tortuous, densely wooded on both sides, and the narrow pass along which the police had to enter or escape has deep ruts, huge stones, and stumps of trees, rendering it all but impassable for horse or vehicle. Two miles along the valley is the shanty in which was stored the stolen booty, consisting of flour and bacon, and within were a number of warriors armed with leaded rifles, and without an interpreter. The chief dismounted and approached the door, making his mission known through the interpreter to an Indian decked in feathers and red paint and armed with a club and rifle who guarded the doorway. The chief and the handful of men with him had only revolvers, but he was brave and demanded the restoration of the stolen property and the surrender of the thieves. The warrior, bent on resistance, peremptorily refused, well knowing that the police were entirely at his mercy. Becoming audacious, he approached the chief of police and struck his hatchet into the ground across the approach to the door and challenged him to cross on pain of instant death. The chief hesitated for a time, tried negotiation, which only increased the Indian's contempt, for he took the hatchet and stuck it within a foot of the chief, repeating his challenge. Construing it into mere bravado, the chief advanced, and in an instant door and window bristled with the muzzles of rifles aimed at him. In another moment he would have been a dead man but for the brave and timely intervention of a squaw, Mrs. Papiano. She yelled as only a squaw can, and rushed on the rifles, throwing them upward and preventing any firing. Had one shot been fired at that moment, not a white man would have escaped alive, so furious were the Indians and anxious for the affray. Mrs. Papiano was wise as she was brave. I saw her at the government storehouse. She is a big woman of commanding appearance, and on the occasion of the difficulty in question, she was dressed in black silk. She counseled patience and submission on the part of the Indians and a wise forbearance from the white man. She made a telling speech, and her advice was taken. So sure of trouble and so complete were the arrangements of the Indians that the place was held by a body of riflemen in ambush, to whom intelligence of passing events was conveyed by scouts on horseback, thus calling off the possibility of escape from any of the party. That blood did not flow on that occasion is due entirely to the efforts of Mrs. Papiano. Many interesting incidents which occurred on the frontier could be narrated, but my letter is already long enough. Settlers in the Northwest may have many hardships to encounter, but the country is bound to be thickly peopled, and that with one of the most intelligent and thriving populations on the face of the world.

1884-09-16: I had found two or three discontented, and when I pressed them for the reasons of their discontent, they had told me it was because they had got no ladies in their section of the country, and were, therefore, lonely. I had advised them to go east and see sure that if they were satisfied with their wives, and he was sure that if they did so, they would return to everything. Only a day or so ago, I had a conversation with a very prominent gentleman in the opposition camp, and he told me that the political blizzard had swept over the country, and that at the next election the opposition would be returned to power. It was the first time that I had heard the action of the free electors spoken of as a political blizzard, but if it was so, it was strange that another political blizzard should have swept over the country in 1881! A voice said, "Next time it will be a cyclone!" (Loud cheers.) He believed that the next election would be a cyclone if the last two were blizzards, and that it would lead the Conservative party into power for another five years. (Cheers.) He was sure that the people preferred getting their goods cheaper and manufactured in their own country, and he was sure they would express confidence in a government which put money into their pockets instead of showing them a big deficit. He thanked the company on behalf of himself and Sir John A. Macdonald, and was quite sure that the latter would pay Manitoba a visit when the Canadian Pacific Railway reached Lake Superior, and he hoped he would be able to accompany him. He was sure that when the chieftain did come, he would meet with a reception such as he always met with. Sir Hector resumed his seat amidst enthusiastic cheering.

--- 

Let me know if you need any further adjustments! Lelan was greeted with applause. He made a lengthy and eloquent speech, referring to the progress of the C.

1884-09-18: A BLIZZARD At 11 AM a Here was rls While the snow was falling, a law wind blew and twin! a and hail and the wild wind's wail was edged Swiss in an enfolding blizzard. One was on the prairie, a looming tiara - Jnj (Sued).

1884-12-23: CHAMBER EMIGRANTS TO THE SOUTH. New York Chamber of Commerce posed to the Spanish Treaty. On December 22, natural gas has been playing havoc in different places in western Pennsylvania. Within twenty-four hours, reports of explosions attended with fatal and serious results have been received from Butler and Washington, while in this city, a building occupied as a grocery store was completely demolished last evening. At Washington, Pa., the residence of William Kabe was partly wrecked, and Kabe, his wife, and child were injured badly. All have since died. Mrs. Kabe arose in the night and went into the cellar with a lighted candle when an explosion occurred. The excitement in Washington is intense, as many people have natural gas in their houses. The explosion at Butler occurred yesterday morning and nearly ended in a horrible disaster. The fine brick residence of John Gates was entirely demolished, and the family, consisting of Gates, his wife, and four children, all grown up, were buried in the ruins. The entire family was rescued, all more or less seriously hurt. They retired at 10 o'clock, and two hours later, Winnie, a daughter aged 20, awoke and noticed a tiny blue flame playing on the hearthstone. She put it out; she then called her brother, who, with a light, went to further investigate. He had no sooner opened the door than a terrible explosion followed, and the building was razed from the foundation and came down a mass of ruins. People living a quarter of a mile away felt the shock, and in a short time willing hands were at work trying to save the lives of the six human beings known to be in the building at the time of the explosion. The first taken out was Leonard, aged 28, who was painfully bruised, though he had sustained no internal injuries. John Gates, Jr., was next found, badly burned about the face, neck, and arms. Mr. and Mrs. Gates, who escaped with several bruises, and the daughters were found in the coal vault uninjured. The escape of all from instant death is wonderful. 

CAKRAWMRB. In a collision in Chicago, December 22. The facts regarding an accident on the Baltimore and Ohio railroad near Bremen, Indiana, were made known here tonight. The train was a fast express from Washington City due here this morning. It was running at the rate of 40 miles an hour when it struck a broken rail. The engine and forward part of the train pulled over safely, but the dining car and two sleeping coaches were derailed and overturned. The dining car took fire and burned. The sleeping coaches were saved from destruction. There were sixteen persons in the sleepers, some of them public men. Congressman Shively suffered painful bruises, and all the others are more or less shaken up. The occupants of the dining car suffered severely. Edward McCabe and Jos Pratz, cooks, and Edward Gray and 11 McKaunton, waiters, were fatally lacerated, scalded, and burned. The wounded were brought here this afternoon. 

The Dakota War. Traverse, Dak., December 22. The situation is unchanged since last evening. A blizzard has been blowing. The mercury was 20 degrees below zero at noon. Traverse has scoured the county for arms, and sufficient have been secured. Men from all parts of the county are constantly arriving, and officials now feel relieved. A spy sent out this morning reports the men at Wilmotte are still trying to open the safe, but they have not succeeded. The mob will be kept under arms until the safe is opened and its contents known. If the records are not found, the mob will immediately move upon Traverse. 

The Spanish Treaty. New York, December 22. The Chamber of Commerce today heard the report of the committee to which had been referred the consideration of the Spanish treaty. The committee made three reports. The majority report recommends to the Senate and House of Representatives the prompt ratification of the Spanish treaty and the passage of an enabling act. The minority reports are opposed to the treaty. After discussion, the matter was put to a vote, and the first minority report, declaring "the Spanish-American treaty now before the Senate is hostile to the interests of the people of the United States, and ought not to be confirmed," was adopted by a close vote. 

A desk officer in trouble. Washington, December 22. Sergt. Holtnorth, of the signal service, who was sent by the Secretary of War in search of Howgate, the absconder, has returned and been relieved from duty. It is alleged that Holtnorth obtained the information which induced the Secretary of War to send him as a detective by rifling Lieutenant Greely's private papers. He will be court-martialed. 

The telephone patents. Trenton, N.J., December 22. The United States Telephone Manufacturing Company of New York, and the McDonough Telephone and Telegraph Company of New Jersey, filed a bill in the United States court this morning asking for an injunction against the American Bell Telephone Company of Boston, and the Domestic Telegraph and Telephone Company of Newark, for infringement of patent and for an accounting. 

1884-12-26: TRAIN TALK. "Guess we're going to have a free-in' winter," remarked a passenger from Iowa by way of acquaintance-making with a man from Montana. "Yes, I think we will. But cold weather has no terrors for me no more. I spent one winter up in the mountains that was so awful I've never had the gall to complain of anything since." 

"How was that?" 

"Well, 'twas three years ago. Six of us had a camp on the mountain side, in which we hibernated, as 'twas, all winter long. Nothin' to do but eat and sleep and play cards. The first day of December we started up the poker game, needing selected quartz pebbles for chips, you know. We were all pretty well heeled, having cleaned up good at the end of the season. As there'd been trouble in the camp the previous winter on account of borrowing, we all solemnly agreed that the limit should be $10, except in jackpots, and if a man got busted, nobody was to lend him. The third day we struck a big luck - I went in with two pair and filled, with kings up, and old Robinson started with two queens and got t'other two, and laid me out completely. Took my last cent, froze me out so that I couldn't put up for an ante. The boys wouldn't go back on the rule, and I couldn't borrow a cent. There wasn't no use kickin', so I just turned in to watch them play. Day after day and night after night passed with them mulling the rocks clutter and me sittin' back in the shadows lookin' on. Imagine how happy I was. Every day I got gloomier. I was an outcast, a poor miserable good-for-nothing a-pinin' for a mouthful in sight of plenty. I had just one hope left, and that was one of the others would get fried out, too, and then him and me could play a little side game all by ourselves on tick to be settled in the spring. But nary one of 'em got busted. They'd put up their last dollar many a time, but 'twas just my infernal luck that the short man would win and be able to stay in the game. I talked of committing suicide, or of going off and losing myself in a blizzard, but they wouldn't take no sort of pity on me. The rhyme of the old sailor, what I used to know by heart back in the states, kept running through my mind. Alone, alone, all, all alone, alone on a wide, wide sea. 

"Long in the fore part of February, I got desperate and started off through the snow for Helena. I was half crazy, I was. Hadn't no sort of idea where I was going between the storm and the thing that ran through my brain. I was about gone. The wind seemed to whistle, 'Raise yer, raise yer,' and the big trees seemed to cry out, 'Do yer ten rocks better, pard, ten rocks better.' I wandered around for three days and nights, half frozen and half starved, clean off my base and near done for generally. I reckon I'd died hadn't I come to a camp where a lone miner lived. He took me in, thawed me out, and asked me to play poker with him. Then I began to straighten out, but 'twas a close call, a mighty close call. 

"That, stranger, is the reason why I never complain of cold weather. If I live to be a thousand years old, the coldest winter in all my record will be that one when I got froze out of the game up at Grizzly Bear Gulch." 

"I see in the paper," said an old engineer, "that they have arrested a Nickel-Plate driver over in Indiana for failing to stop his train at a grade crossing in time to prevent an accident. His defense is that the rails were slippery. This reminds me of one of my own experiences, several years ago. I was running a fast express one night. We were three hours behind time, and if there's anything in the world I hate, it's to finish a run behind schedule. These grade crossings of one-horse roads are a nuisance to the trunk line, and we had a habit of failing to stop, merely slacking up for 'em. At this crossing, I had never seen a train at that time of the night, and so I roared the curve out of the car full tilt. I was astonished to see the target set against me, though I had time enough to stop. But it was a downgrade there, and the track was very slippery, and to add to the danger, my air didn't work right. I whistled sharply to clear the target set clear for me, but on looking, I saw that a freight train was standing right over the crossing, evidently intending to put a few cars on our switch. I wish I could tell you what my thoughts were at that moment. I knew the danger and tried to slow my train, but I had seven heavy cars on, and we just slid down that grade despite everything I could do. 

"Now comes the opening part of my story. Quicker than I can tell you, the brakeman on that freight train occupied a car just back of our engine and signaled his engineer to back off, which he did sharply, but just in time to let us through. In fact, the pilot of my engine took the buffer off that rear car. Through that little hole, we slipped, and lives and property were saved. Now that brakeman was only a common railroader, yet he saw that situation at a glance. There wasn't time to run his whole train off the crossing, nor even half of it; barely time to pull up one car-length by prompt, quick work. He kept his wits about him, as I venture to say not one man in a thousand would have done, and saved my reputation, if not my life. He is now a division superintendent on one of the best roads in this country; and may good luck go with him." 

"Home folks don't seem to have any sense about getting off cars," remarked the brakeman. "Every once in a while, some man will jump off and hurt himself when a little common sense would teach him better. Some years ago, I was running on an express on the New York Central. Just as we go into Rochester, we cross Hudson Street. One night as we were running in, at the rate of about eighteen miles an hour, I was standing on the rear platform. A tall, well-dressed man with a shiny plug hat and an elegant valise came out and inquired if that was Hudson Street. I told him it was, and before I knew what he was doing, he jumped. I looked back quick and saw him strike the ground. Then he leaped as if he had been thrown out of a cannon at least twenty feet, turning a half somersault and landing on his head in the mud. Then he rolled over six or eight times. The mud at Hudson Street was about three inches deep, and when this man picked himself up, he was an object. He looked as if he was made of mud. The last glimpse I had of him, he had both hands up trying with all his might to shove his plug hat up off his shoulders. I'd have laughed even if I'd known he was dying, which he wasn't, but I'll bet he gets off at stations now." 

A lawyer from Arizona was returning from the East, where he had been to settle up the affairs of... Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

Some mining company. He was full of indignation at the delays of the law in Eastern courts. "It took me three months," he said, "to get a little formality through that ought to have been settled in twenty-four hours. It worried the life out of me. Now, in Arizona we don't do things that way. Our courts move quick. We haven't so much style or red tape, and believe that when a thing has to be done, the way to get it done is to go right at it and rush it. I remember last spring the Judge came to our place to hold court. There was a jail full of fellows there in for murder and horse-stealing. The Judge was in a hurry and said that docket must be cleared within twenty-four hours. Well, it was. Now, in the world did he do it?" "He didn't do it. That night the boys organized a little committee, took the prisoners out of jail, hung the horse-thief, and told the murderers to get out of the territory. Next morning the judge signed the docket and cost bills and went on his way rejoicing." 

A passenger on a train up in Wisconsin was complaining of hard times. "I don't see nothing but ruin about them," remarked a contented-looking man opposite him. "Well, you're the first man I've seen that wasn't growling," replied the first speaker, "and I should like to know your business. If there is one prosperous man in the country, I want to make his acquaintance. What do you do?" "Oh, I'm working for the railroad company, watching the wood contractor to see that they don't pile in no poor stuff. Got $2 a day." "Two dollars a day! You don't call that prosperous, do you?" "Oh, that ain't all. The contractors pay me $5 a day to spend three-fourths of my time down at a Jackson saloon. Nothing hard about these times that I can see." 

**District of Montreal**

1885-01-03: C, January 2. Paymaster Smyth, who disappeared from Savannah with $5,500 government funds, appeared at the war department today and surrendered himself to the paymaster-general. He turned over $5,150 of money carried off by him and his pay for December, $250, and $100 paid for him by his friends, making the full amount of $5,500. Smythe says he went on a spree on Christmas Day and knew nothing of his actions until he found himself in New York. He then telegraphed to his clerk that he would return immediately. He afterwards, however, concluded to come to Washington and report to the paymaster-general. 

**The Cold and the Cattle** 
St. Paul, January 2. Last night and today have been the coldest of the present winter, and among the coldest on record. The signal office thermometer this morning registered 36 below; others showed 50 below. Reports from other points are as follows: Stillwater, 50 below, the coldest ever known; Lacrosse, 23; Bismarck, 45; Minnedosa, 50; Winnipeg, 55, and a regular blizzard prevailing. A Bozeman, Montana, despatch says: Reports from the stock ranges are most discouraging. Snow is two feet deep on the level, and the cattle are starving. Many fine herds will be annihilated if the cold snap be repeated. 

**Train Robbers in the East** 
Baltimore, January 2. The train which left here over the Baltimore Central railroad for Oxford, Pa, at 5:10 this afternoon was boarded at Rising Sun, Cecil County, by two men who, by threats of violence, compelled the passengers to surrender their money, watches, and other valuables; they then jumped from the train, which was running full speed, and were supposed to be seriously, if not fatally, injured. No particulars could be obtained of the identity of the men, but they are supposed to be residents of the immediate neighborhood and will be captured. 

**A Wife's Despair** 
Macidon, N.

1885-01-23: I came in beneath the wharves and shipping, the fir-clad hills and grainy plains along in the distance making up a panorama, never to be forgotten or surpassed. The grass was alive with long-tails that flew up at every step, exhibiting the dainty colors of their hinder wings; grasshoppers, indescribably lovely swallowtail butterflies, mixed with others of bright yellow and rich red, enlivened the scene and added the welcome charm of life (we had missed so much on the voyage) to the view. 

The drive to Lorette, and the trip in the steamer to Montreal are described. The Windsor receives favorable notice, "the only drawback being the laziness of the white waiters, who proved a sore trial to our English patience." After a description of this city, which is described as "the chief town in Canada," the lecturer referred to the trip from Montreal to Ottawa. "From Montreal we proceeded to Ottawa, the seat of the government, traveling by the Grand Trunk railway, through scenery that struck us as intensely Canadian, wooden houses built with longitudinal planks up to the eaves, the gables being filled in with upright boards and the roof covered with wooden shingles; enclosures small and crops fairly good, though in some places badly weeded; wooden rail fences in all directions made without rails or spikes; all the posts are double, the nails between them being packed on short transverse logs. In some places, wire is used as the old rails wear out or become rotten. To prevent straying, horses, pigs, cattle, and poultry are provided with yokes. 

Near Coteau, the view is particularly agreeable, the St. Lawrence on one hand, studded with islands, and the Ottawa River on the other. This was the scene of the boatman's song, 'Row, brothers, row,' the rapids being close by. From this point, the country became more closely covered with thick woods of firs and undergrowth, the successors of the primeval forest. These are being cleared as fast as possible, the first process being one of fire which destroys the bark for a few feet from the ground and kills the trees so treated; these stems stand up gaunt and grey awaiting the lumberer's axe or heavy gale to bring them to the ground. The leaves of the maple were already assuming the delicious red so characteristic of the Canadian fall, whilst other foliage was a brilliant yellow. 

After visiting the public buildings, we drove to the Chaudière Falls, in the suburbs of Ottawa, and in themselves worth seeing, to inspect the lumber mills for which they supply the power; the huge logs that have floated down the stream are guided by men with boat hooks, end-on to an endless toothed chain, that lifts the log and drags it up an inclined plane to the saw sheds and deposits it on a platform. Here it is rolled onto a carriage that runs it through a set of saws which cut off the slabs or outer pieces and one or two planks on each side, leaving a half-finished baulk in the middle. No sooner is it clear of this first set of saws than it is rolled again onto another carriage close by and turned through more saws that complete the work; the planks are placed on other machinery that draws them through saws set at 13 feet apart, the odd ends falling into choppers on each side and thence are conveyed under the floor to a match factory where they are at once utilized. 

The run to Toronto, the city itself, the trip to Niagara Falls, and its incidents were all described, and then the trip to the Rockies is referred to: "The next day the Rocky Mountain excursion under the auspices of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company started early for Owen Sound. The intervening country was well cultivated, but mixed with large tracts of dead stems and stumps filled in with wild brightly colored red and yellow undergrowth; birds, as usual, were scarce. On arriving at Owen Sound, we at once went on board the Canadian Pacific Railway steamer, Alberta (a most comfortable vessel with luxurious saloon reaching from stem to stem, the state rooms opening into it, the whole ship illuminated by the Edison Electric Light), and leaving the sound entered Georgian Bay, the low shores of which were composed of limestone resting on a bed of gravel. Lake Huron was crossed during the night. 

In the morning, we entered the narrows, known as the River St. Marie that connects with Lake Superior, the banks were clothed with fir, pine, and birch trees, the waters being dotted with settlers' dwellings. The Canadian bank is occupied by the tribe of Ojibbeway Indians, 10,000 in number, who are especially numerous about Garden River. They bury their dead, bound up in birch bark, just below the surface of the ground in an open grave, supplying the corpse with tobacco, and covering all in with a gabled thatch. Several huts were abundant on the banks, huts built of logs dressed only with an axe, the interstices being carefully stopped with grey clay. The course was now intricately marked with stakes between which the Alberta wound her way to the lock at Sault Ste. Marie already described in speaking of the canals. Close by there were the dashing rapids on which Indians are constantly catching whitefish with large hand nets from their skillfully managed birch bark canoes. A magnificent view was had over the water, and a few canoes and gulls were visible in the distance. Shortly after passing the Sault, we stood in view of this inland sea, and all sight of land was speedily lost. This Lake Superior is as large as Ireland. As evening closed upon us, a number of islands, in sight, were about 30 miles away, in full view. The next morning was misty, but revealed the bold and majestic headland known as Thunder Cape, and formed of volcanic rock, which we sailed past in entering Fort Arthur. 

A description of Fort Arthur, which the party availed of for boarding and general gathering, and then proceeded to Winnipeg. 

**WINNIPEG TO THE INTERIOR** 
The description of Winnipeg and the trip westward was given only slightly condensed. The name Winnipeg implies muddy water, and Winnipeg mud is famous in Canada for its tenacity. The depth of it in the main street (a wide span thoroughfare with excellent lumber sidewalks, lofty and well-built, with telephone and telegraph wires innumerable) is simply appalling, with wagons turning about like vessels at sea, the vehicles scarcely clearing the surface, which was broken into irregularities that gave the effect of rough Atlantic waves. Here and there the railways were ploughing it in vain, if possible, into a permanent flat surface; the redeeming feature is a single tram line that runs down the center, and occasional timber crossings that are used as bridges for the passengers. 

An exhibition here of splendid Indian apparel, weapons, and handicraft had been brought together and was displayed by the side of a collection of native work from the Hudson's Bay Company, with which they would not even bear comparison. The fruit and vegetables were excellent, wheat plants with 12 stalks on each, cabbages 10 lbs a piece, and numerous...

This corrected text retains the original meaning while fixing OCR errors. Here's the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

**In the Kindness of the Climate and the Business of the Country**

As the proper journey began, the landscape of the country changed from interminable forest to wide and open treeless prairie. Tons of shucked wheat were seen close by the line. The soil and subsoil were sandy in nature. At a distance, extensive cattle pens implied ample pasturage. This being a typical western city deserves description; wide and straight avenues laid out on a large scale; churches, stores, and hotels, several still in construction, but at long intervals; the tracks sloppy and overgrown with rank weeds and herbage, on either side avenues of young trees planted by the enterprise of the inhabitants who devote one day a year to the task. Telephones and electric light wires overhead indicated a scientific advance on the arrangements of the old country.

At Carberry, we saw our first genuine buckboard or cart of the country, a characteristic conveyance, consisting of a board extending from the axle of the front to that of the hind pair of wheels. On this, the seat fixed over ordinary carriage springs is mounted, and so elastic and easy is this that one can drive with comfort over any irregularity the circle of the wheel can climb. Here a few bluffs or small clusters of undergrowth, principally young birch, relieved the landscape, and at Brandon, a one-year-old city of four or five thousand inhabitants, the land rose into a gentle but considerable eminence. Brilliant red and yellow buttercups, gentian, and wild lobelia attracted both entomologists and botanists, and a large handsomely black-spotted edible frog proved an object of universal interest. A few miles further, the bluffs had again disappeared, and nothing but prairie was visible, not a tree in sight, a sunbleached brownish-yellow waste of coarse short herbage, broken here and there by a patch of ploughed land, turned to secure the government rebate of a dollar and a quarter per acre. Ospreys, herons, martins, and sparrow hawks, grey and black ducks, widgeon and teal in the sloughs, and an occasional bittern in the marshes, with here and there a covey of prairie chickens that flew heavily for a short distance and then scuttled and ran, a train of mounted Indians passing by, another group with their wagons, a couple driving a buckboard drawn by two mustangs, a colt running alongside, all gave a distinctive character to the landscape as our train ran quickly by.

At Broadview, the next halt on our track, we found about a dozen Cree Indians—bucks, squaws, and papooses—the latter bound up like mummies being carried in a shawl on the backs of the squaws and girls, whose heavy yellow and red ochred faces contrasted with the clear brilliance of their dark brown eyes; plenty of cheap native-made ornaments, such as earrings, bead leggings, finger rings, and wire bangles decorated their limbs, and each was wrapped in bright-colored but dirty blankets, behind the folds of which they retired if looked at too curiously. Wild geese, plover, dotterel, a couple of rabbits, and one or two long-furred black and white skunks shuffling clumsily into a small bluff enlivened the next few miles. Indians were fairly numerous, owing to a government reserve being close by, and shortly after we reached the celebrated Bell farm, containing 64,000 acres, 7,000 being under wheat in tracts of from 100 to 3,000 acres each; the harvest is gathered by 27 horse reapers and other machinery in proportion. The average yield here, it being the second year of cultivation, is 11 bushels per acre, but when the sod is rotted, 60 bushels at 74 cents a bushel are expected. The land prepared in the autumn is sown with 15 bushels to the acre the moment the spring thaw gives a few inches of surface. The soil, black and rich with dead vegetable matter, buffalo remains, and prairie fire ashes, is some three feet deep; below this, there is 18 or 20 feet of good clay, producing excellent yellow bricks, and under this again is water. The surface drainage runs into the coulees or hollows, under the shelter of which a certain amount of timber grows. Laborers receive $20 per month and their keep for five summer months; during the winter, they can work in the forest lumbering at $25 to $30 per month, and there is a call and room for 50,000 at the present time.

Since leaving Manitoba, the whole country is remarkably temperate, tea and coffee being the accepted beverages at all meals, tough beefsteak appearing three times a day. At Regina, the future capital of the far west, we visited the barracks of the mounted police by the invitation of their chief, Colonel Irvine. These men are splendidly mounted and equipped, their uniform resembling that of the Grenadiers, but their stirrups are made of wood as being less cold to the feet in winter. In the guardroom, a number of Indian prisoners, mostly undergoing punishment for horse stealing, were confined; these were by far the finest men we had seen, their names suspended by their cage door and were curious, implying Little Fish, Great Rock, Frog's Thigh, and Empty Belly, etc. These barracks are built in a large quadrangle, about a mile distant from the town; the officers told us the life was pleasant enough with the exception of the blizzards or drift storms.

Just beyond here at Moosejaw, we entered the third prairie plateau, the surface of the country becoming slightly undulating, and as we approached Medicine Hat, the train followed the line of a prairie valley, an ancient riverbed bounded on either side at a distance of 400 or 500 yards by a low range of sand hills so closely packed as to present an almost unbroken skyline. The weather was bright and clear, the air pure and bracing; on quitting this, we glided down a steep grade into a modern valley, where a sparkling river was winding backwards and forwards in a flat and strong area, bounded by lofty cliffs. On its banks, poplar trees of considerable height were flourishing, and a couple of teams were dragging heavily-laden ploughs towards the town, which is admirably situated on the river. The river is close here by a handsome iron bridge, upon which swings on a central fulcrum for river traffic; on its banks, extensive sections of Victoria’s rim-head rocks occur, and the remains of dinosaurs have been discovered there. The track from this point misses and crosses the river, a pleasant change from the monotony of the prairie and not far from the "village," where the railway company was boring for water, and at a depth of 100 feet they tapped a vast supply of water, which has been utilized in steam for an engine which now works the pumping-station.

On the date of our visit, September 11th, 1884, no water had been found at the depth of 185 feet. At Calgary, the center of the ranching interest, one hundred and fifty miles south of which our old neighbors, the Darnells, have a considerable establishment, the presence of the Bow River quite changes the aspect of the country; trees were abundant and high banks bounded the valley. Mounted cowboys with their lariats or tether ropes, hung lasso fashion on the pommel peg, were dotted by the trackside, and as the snowy peaks of the yet distant Rocky Mountains topped the horizon, we felt all the pleasure the achievement of a set design yields. It was dark when we reached Canmore, where we snuggled over the roughest of ground to the log hut in which our fifty-cent supper was prepared. On emerging, our train, beautifully lighted, was an imposing sight, and gave the impression that they here boasted some extensive manufacturing.

When we woke next morning, it was to find ourselves at Laggan, two miles beyond Stephen, the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, 5,000 feet above the sea, and consequently on the Bow River valley. The negro attendant assuring us that it is “All lovely, gentlemen, plenty gold and silver.” This is a considerable railway village, composed of hills and tents placarded with huge titles, such as "The most fashionable tailor," "Ting Sing Chinese laundry," or even more humorous "Tea and treacle," "Edibles," "Dollar beans," "Candy," "Bunks," and "Gimlets," whiskey and other things. We were now, by special favor, taken on to Kicking Horse Pass and Lake, the hills and woods being very beautiful on either side. Three miles further, by the side of the winding valley, a belt of white and hard shingle that serves as the great high road is a bustling city, where a canvas tent is labeled "Grand Central Hotel." The view here is perfect, impenetrable forest of fir clothe the sides of the valley for 2,000 feet in dense allure. Above it, in the ravines lie huge accumulations of snow and ice, and yet above these towers the magnificent peaks and aiguilles that render these mountains of British Columbia so imposing and impressive.

This lecture is but one of the many evidences which we have of the increased interest in Canada, and the better knowledge of the country which is certain to result from the visit of the British Association.

**THE LINE NORTH OF LAKE SUPERIOR**

It appears difficult to realize that the line north of Lake Superior will, in the course of two or three months, be open for traffic. For many years past, the wisdom of the construction of this portion of the great transcontinental line has been debated. The country to be traversed has been depicted as of the roughest and most uninviting character, and the expense placed at such an excessive figure that more than once it has been stated that the Syndicate were not likely ever to proceed with the work. Meantime, for much of the year, the freight and passenger business of the Canadian Northwest has passed over American roads by a rather circumlocutory route, and over four or more different railroad systems. Every resident of, and visitor to, the Northwest has become accustomed to the inevitable, and, on the whole, pleasant detours in St. Paul and Chicago, and many connections of a business and social character have thereby been formed. An acquaintance has also been scraped with customs officers which otherwise would not have been of so intimate a character.

The first break in this chain of association occurred when the lake route was opened out, and now almost a revolution is threatened by the opening of the all-Canadian rail route. No doubt the American system will still secure a portion of the business, probably a large share until the Ontario system of railroads has been connected with the Canadian Pacific, but the time is nevertheless close at hand when Fortage, Port Arthur, Callendar, Pembroke, Ottawa, etc., will be more familiar names to the traveler between Eastern Canada and Manitoba than are St. Paul, Chicago, Port Huron, or St. Thomas. The trip from Winnipeg to Montreal will soon be made without change of cars, and the time now occupied in both passenger and freight transportation will be reduced nearly, if not quite, one-half. With reduced time should come a reduction in passenger tariffs and freight rates. The cost of living in...

--- 

This corrected text addresses the OCR errors while maintaining the original meaning and formatting as much as possible. Here is the corrected text:

This country should be "considerably" reduced, and the farmer should in another year get relatively better prices for his grain than at present. Canadian travellers will no longer blush for their country when told that their money is at a discount of from two to eight percent, and burly Manitobans will not receive the imprecations of their fellow passengers if they ask to have the car windows opened when the mercury is hovering about the vicinity of zero. The Toronto and Montreal papers, and all Eastern Canada correspondence, will be at least a day "fresher" than they are at the present time, and in very many ways the long distance from old associations which many now feel will be perceptibly lessened. In summer the route is pretty sure to be a popular one, partly because of the water stretch which it offers to travellers, but in the winter it will be of rather a monotonous character, and it will require all the inducements of quick time and low fares which the Canadian Pacific people can offer to secure the passenger traffic. With most people, however, time and money are powerful persuaders, and when placed in the scale against sightseeing are almost certain to tip the beam. It will be an immense satisfaction, in any event, to get two-thirds of the way to Montreal in the time which is now consumed in accomplishing the equally dreary journey between this city and St. Paul. 

Winnipeg Times - Every woman in the land owes it to herself and her family to take care of her health. When she finds her health failing, and debility and weakness undermine her strength, her surest and best remedy is Kidney-Wort. It builds up the general health, keeps the secretory system in perfect order, regulates the kidneys and bowels, and enables these important organs to perform their natural functions in throwing off the accumulated impurities of the body. 

The Empire Pottery and Brewers' Pottery, at Trenton, N.

1885-01-29: I. O. M., January 28. Sir Charles held a conference today with delegates from the Chamber of Commerce and trade unions upon the subject of wages. Sir Charles said memorials proposing final, but not communistic, change in the laws regulating the relations between capital and labor would be submitted to parliament. He pointed to the great improvement in the working man's condition in Germany by the workmen's insurance bill. Sir Charles strongly reproved a delegate representing the iron founders for making a bitter and indiscriminate attack upon all persons in possession of wealth. 

Fishermen in Nova Scotia, January 28. A terrific blizzard began yesterday on the west coast of Nova Scotia. A large number of fishing crafts were overtaken by the storm. Twenty-three skiffs are missing and many of the survivors are badly frostbitten. One skiff went down in sight with the crew. The crews of the missing vessels aggregate fifty men. There are grave fears that the loss of life will be heavy. 

The Cameroon trouble.

1885-02-16: A Mormon elder now here says the prosecution of the Mormons for unlawful cohabitation under the Edmunds law continues. The Mormons, however, complain bitterly of the partiality displayed by the district attorney in not prosecuting Gentiles for the same offense, although it is notorious that many are guilty. The raid is prostrating business. 

Another K. halite bank failure. Belleville, U., February 15. Considerable excitement prevails over the announcement of the failure of the Exchange Bank. It is reported that the cashier absconded on Friday with $75,000 in deposits. The bank was a private concern managed by David and John Kent and Harrison Alexander, and recently lost heavily by speculating. The sheriff is in possession of their books. 

Feared Chicago, February 15. A driving snowstorm prevailed here today. Another blockade is feared unless the wind abates. There is a fierce blizzard in Iowa. Snow has fallen most of today in Wisconsin, Illinois, and Indiana. Trains are reported laboring heavily or entirely abandoned. 

A founding propeller. Milwaukee, February 14. It is feared the propeller Michigan, which left here a week ago in search of the steamer Oneida, has been lost. She was commanded by Capt. Pruneville and carried twenty men. The vessel is valued at $150,000. 

Minor items. The report that John Kelly is dangerously ill is false. Mrs. Kelly says her husband is feeling splendid. Every saloon keeper at Galesburg, III, and several in the towns adjoining have been indicted for selling liquor to inebriates and minors. 

At White Plains, N.

1885-02-23: LOSSES ON CATTLE RANCHES. The severity of winter and the devastating blizzards have made fearful havoc in the western ranches. From Southwestern Texas to Montana and Dakota, they all alike have suffered, whilst strange to say north of the 49th parallel of latitude, in our own Northwest there has been comparative immunity from any heavy losses by storms, owing no doubt to the protection afforded by the Rocky Mountains and the warm winds which blow over the region. The losses that have occurred on the American side are such as to cripple a great many of their largest stockmen and will have a pronounced effect upon the cattle and sheep interests of the country. Both fat and stock cattle may be expected to be scarce, as it will take a few years of breeding to make up the losses of the season. In relation to this, an American exchange says, "It is a poor time to sell sheep or go out of the business when thousands upon thousands of sheep are being frozen and starved to death in the far west, and when an unusual number are being slaughtered at all leading markets. Farmers may rest assured, that it is low tide in sheep husbandry, and now is the time to take advantage of the rising tide which is sure to follow." The same advice is applicable to our farmers in Ontario, for what affects one country affects the other with regard to the prices of mutton and wool, for our surplus both here and there go to a common market. But without the heavy losses in the west to affect prices, the sheep supply in Ontario is and would be at low ebb, and we want more to meet the demand. There never was a better opening for both good sheep and cattle, both fat and as carrying stock. 

London Free Press: "A new suit faded. Articles of all kinds restored to their original beauty by Lhamond Dyes, perfect and simple, 10c at all druggists. Wells & Richardson Co., Montreal, P.

1885-02-25: T. Lambert, who engaged the Canadian voyageurs, left for Hull this morning to meet them on their return. Capt. Almond is the only officer who returns with them. A stabbing affair took place today between two Italian laborers, one of whom will probably die. Two Toronto whiskey manufacturers, who are operating here, met with severe treatment in a city hotel, being assaulted by five or six men. One of the Torontonians threw a revolver and saved himself and his friend from what turned out to be a very unpleasant experience. 

The report states that all the labor disputes which paralyze business and make life difficult for others and employees persist, says the London Advertiser, the worst, in his zeal, in its things is the very prince of the powers of the air. It is a stormy snow that has already fallen; it is a flood whose billows reach up to the sky; it is a tornado the swath of which is a mile wide, and besides all of these it is a cold which scans out the heart and marrow of man and his olive and bird and beast. In the true blizzard, the sky is clear and only now and then partially obscured by small white clouds, or rather rags of mist which fly off it. The wind comes from none of the quarters in which storms are bred; it blows from the blue western spaces with an edge that cuts like a sword. It is not a steady wind. Now it is almost gentle, were it not for its edge of steel, but every few minutes it rises and roars and sweeps on with howls and shrieks, and every living thing shivers and shrinks from its fierce onslaught and seeks for shelter. And the snow which had fallen a day or two before is at once the plaything and the tremendous weapon of the blizzard. In its play, it catches up handfuls of the fine white crystals here and there and flings them before it and seems to laugh at their splendid gleaming in the sunlight. But in a few moments its nature changes; it suddenly flings up great clouds of snow into the air; the sky and even the sun are hidden; the hollow of the heavens is filled with roaring as the wind drives on the vast white billows, whose spray stings like a whip as it beats against whoever tries to face it. It is such storms that railway men in the Northwest have to face and fight. For the blizzard is the peculiar enemy of the railway. It opposes its swiftness to the speed of the trains, its cold to the heat of locomotive furnaces, its wide sweep to the narrowness of the track. The cost of fighting one of these blizzards is enormous. Every cut on the line is filled to the brim with snow that is often packed like sand. But it does not require a deep cut to enable the blizzard to stop trains. A foot, even six inches, of the packed drift will bring them to a standstill. The snowplow may be forced through by a long line of pulling locomotives, but before the train that follows can get well under way, the snow has sifted in again and progress is impossible. And the blizzard brings accidents and wrecks in great numbers. The flying snow and the clouds of steam make it almost impossible for the engineer to see signals. On each division, a snowplow must be kept at work, and from four to eight locomotives are required to push it. A few days ago it required fourteen engines to get a short train of five cars to the yards in Chicago. 

NOTES: An effort will probably be made at the present session of the North Carolina legislature to secure the adjustment of $16,000,000 bonds, which are repudiated by the state. The bonds were issued in aid of railroads. The railroads of the West are again in first-class condition; after the blizzard, revenues for 1881 were $3,303,000, and the net profit $2,805,000.

THE COST OF THE ROYAL NAVY. London, February 21. The steamship Allegheny, from Ceylon for Guile, has been lost. Her crew, numbering thirty persons, were drowned. 

The Royal visit to Ireland is imminent. February 21. The Freeman's Journal hopes the Prince of Wales, when he visits Ireland, will be received with respect and cordiality. His visit will afford a welcome stimulus to trade. The paper states that it must be clearly dissociated from politics; if the Castle authorities think to make political capital out of the Prince's visit, they will be in much mistake, and it would be better that he should stay at home. The Irish Times is gratified with the proposed visit. It says: "We cannot imagine that anyone should treat the Prince's intention as other than a frank and generous repudiation for past loyal neglect of Ireland." 

It is a reassurance about Afghanistan. London, February 21. A meeting was held last night to discuss British interests in Afghanistan.

Washington, February 24. As a result of the cold weather on Saturday, a large number of persons who participated in the exercises attending the dedication of the Washington monument are laid up with pneumonia and kindred complaints. Three or four deaths have resulted.

In the grain market, there were no new developments, neither was there anything of interest, the general tone being dull and flat, with business limited to supplying the local demand. Along the line, there is some movement, but not of an unusual character. 

On the spot, we quote nominally: Canadian red winter wheat, 66c; white winter, 69c; Canada spring, 67c; peas, 70c-75c; oats, 32c; rye, 38c; barley, 60c-65c; and corn, 61c-63c. The movement of flour is light and restricted, limited to odd lots for the haul trade. There was little business of importations today, and the finding continues weak, values having a tendency to slide through the absence of demand. 

Flour prices range from $4.15 to $4.75, depending on quality, and superior is offered at $5.05, and less would probably be accepted. 

**Flour Prices**  
Superior Flour: $4.15  
Extra Spring: $4.75  
Superfine Canada: $4.00  
Bakers' American: $4.90  

**Hogs**  
The hog market was weak, under heavier receipts, and declined 5-10c. At the close, quotations were $4.25-$4.50 for light grades, $4.50-$4.70 for mixed packing, and $4.70-$5.05 for heavy shipping. The estimated receipts were 29,000, against yesterday's official 27,015 with shipments of 7,714. There were left over from yesterday about 14,000. 

The cattle market was rather dull; receipts 7,500 head. The receipts of hogs for this week, barring "blizzards," are estimated at 120,000 to 130,000. The stock of lard on hand at Chicago is estimated at 97,000 to 98,000 tierces. The movement of provisions during last week included about 60,000 pieces of sides and shoulders to the South.

**Local Provisions**  
There was no change in local provisions, but the feeling was not so steady. A moderate jobbing business was done in pork and lard at about quotations.
