Aid Koiieut moved an adjournment, which resulted in a tie, twelve voting each way. The Mayor gave his casting vote in favor of the motion, and the meeting then adjourned. NO BLIZZARDS IN CANADA, Mattitow's Opinion on the Weather in That Region, Far Preferable to the Northwestern States or in the Northern Territories. 

Montreal, January 4th, 1896. Two men were seated in the public room of one of the Montreal hotels, conversing about the weather. From their appearance and their language, they were evidently from the far West; one of them, by his twang, was apparently from the Northern States and territories, while the other was just as surely a Canadian. "Been living some pretty bad weather lately around St. Paul?" said the Canadian. "Yes," replied his friend, "the toughest weather ever known in that section of the country. Why, sir, the thermometer went down to 57 below zero, and the blizzards were so bad as to tear everything up. I came away as quickly as I could get; I don't want any more of it. I have had enough! But I suppose you have had it worse up North?" "Not at all. We have had no blizzards in Manitoba or the Northwest Territories. We leave that sort of thing to you fellows. They never trouble us. You see, we are north of the line of blizzards, and we are mighty glad we are." "Well, but you must have had it colder than we had." "(Oh no! We have not had it nearly as cold as that. The thermometer seldom goes below 40, and of course with a clear atmosphere we do not feel that. Our trains are delayed but very little with either snow or blizzards. But I see yours south of the line are cooped up constantly." "Well, that is all right enough to talk, but can you prove it?" "Prove it? Of course I can, but there's no need; why, everyone knows that we never have such weather north of the boundary line as you do south. You Americans seem to think and talk as if our country was a second edition of Siberia, only more so, but I can tell you and the records will prove it, that the weather along the line of the Canadian Pacific Railway is never as severe as on the railways in the Northwestern States. Why, only last winter one of the trains on one of your lines was snowed up for two weeks and the passengers were half-starved to death and had to walk along on top of snow twenty-four feet deep, holding themselves up by telegraph wires. We have no such trouble as that, and would not want it. Let me give you a pointer. You are going back to St. Paul? I have been from Winnipeg through that way, and I know what I'm talking about. Now, when you go back, just take the Canadian Pacific Railway from here to Winnipeg, and then go down south from there. I will bet you a dollar even up that you get there quicker and that you have a good time on the road. The Canadian Pacific runs the best sleepers and has the best dining cars on the continent of America, and if you are going from here to St. Paul this week or next during the blizzard season, you take that line and you will never regret it."

18860204: MARINE MISHAPS

LONDON, February 1. Brig Camilla (Br), Sullivan, from St. John's, Nfld, January 8, is stranded at Elgueira. She will probably prove a wreck. Brig Rillteria (Br), Bradley, from St. John, N.B., December 28, for Orau, has arrived at Gibraltar. She lost her main boom and part of her rigging.

ARRIVED, T SINNIR, January 28. Schr Pearl, from St. John's, Nfld. Liverpool, February 1. SS Scotland, from New York.

There is no end to the funny things that are seen and heard by our teachers in our public schools. Once, a teacher observed a huge blot of ink on a boy's copybook. "What is that?" he demanded. "Sure, I think it's a tear, sir." "A tear? How could a tear be black?" "Sure, I think one of the colored boys dropped it, sir." For the comfort of children who know what it is to be "flustered," this is the laughable reply of a very bright and accomplished young lady teacher who was passing a purely formal examination in physiology: "Where is the alimentary canal?" was demanded. "Really," was the pleasant reply, "I forget whether it is in Indianapolis or Illinois." 

San Francisco Argonaut. To save themselves from starvation, an "Uncle Tom's Cabin" company, while caught in a western blizzard, ate their donkeys. It was a step in the right direction. Now, if the bloodhounds had only eaten the company and then if the dogcatchers had only caught the bloodhounds, the work of retribution would have been complete. 

Graphic. A curious club exists in Paris, whose object is to assist intoxicated persons home late at night. If the patient is able to indicate where he lives, he is escorted to his lodgings; if he is too far gone to give the information, he is conveyed to the headquarters of the club and kept until sober.

VOL CURE FOR BLIZZARDS 

"Yes, I am on my way to Washington," replied a man with a buffalo overcoat and a beaver hat who was held up for an interview at one of the hotels the other day. "It is hinted that you have made an important discovery?" "So I have! I am Captain John White, of Montana, the man who first discovered the birthplace of blizzards, and who invented a cure for them." "Tell me about it!" "Well, I have nothing to conceal in the matter. For five winters past I have been in the Far West watching cold waves or blizzards. Nineteen out of every twenty start on a line drawn from Fort Union, in the northern part of Montana, to Fort Laramie, in Southern Wyoming. There are mountains, rivers, valleys, and plains on that line, and these bring about the conditions required for a radical atmospheric change." "Did you ever see a blizzard born?" "A hundred of them." "What is the operation?" "Well, for instance, one day last winter I was in camp on the Powder River, in Wyoming, directly west of the Black Hills. It was a pleasant sunshiny day, and during the forenoon the wind blew smartly from the Hills. Just about noon, while I was preparing my dinner, a puff of wind from the Laramie Mountains, to the south, hit me. On the plains, a mile to the south of me, and just where two valleys brought these two different winds to a focal point, a cloud of snow was lifted high in the air, and the wind began to circle. In ten minutes the cloud began moving toward me, and the mercury soon went down eleven degrees. The cloud bore to the northeast, struck the north fork of the Big Cheyenne River, and followed it east to Fort Sully, spreading its flank as it went. At Sully it ran down the Missouri to the Iowa State line. Here the wave was a hundred miles long. When it got down to Omaha it was 200 miles. It left the river there and went east, and by the time the center reached Des Moines, one wing was at Minneapolis, due north, and the other at Sedalia, due south. From wing to wing was 500 miles. That wave took in Wisconsin, Illinois, and Indiana, and was kept from Michigan by lake influences, and later on all the Atlantic coast, from Maine to Virginia, was overspread by it. That was only one out of the many I have seen born." "Could it have been stopped?" "Certainly! It was no larger than a barrel when it started." "What is your cure for these cold waves?" "Well, I've been experimenting. You must warm the air as the first step. In that case, you kill the germ and the blizzard falls flat. On this line of the birthplace of blizzards, a distance of 50 miles, base-burner coal stoves should be set about six feet apart. Ten thousand stoves might do it, but the Government might as well add 5,000 more and make a sure thing of it. Each stove would burn, say, nine tons of coal during the winter. One man, as I figure it, could attend to five stoves. As all the stoves would be outdoors, only one length of pipe to a stove would be required. I figure on saving 78,000 joints of stove-pipe. This item alone would pay for most of the coal. Every blizzard costs the country 3,000,000. We have an average of ten per season. I figure that I can stop every one for $100,000 each. This saves the country 20,000,000 per season. The Government puts $20,000,000 in its pocket and hands me the other nine." "And you have an idea that your scheme will be adopted?" "Certainly! The only fear I have is that the Government may want to put plain stoves off on me, while I shall stick for the nickel-plated affairs. There's no use in going into this thing with anything cheap. I shall return in about a week, and as I will then know exactly how much I can save on stove-pipe, I hope you come and see me. This afternoon I shall try and figure on using one leg to a stove, thus saving 30,000 stove-legs. This would pay for the coal for 367 stoves. Don't forget to come and see me."

Detroit Free Press.

18860205: NEW YORK IN MISERY

New York, February 4, 1886. The snowstorm which prevailed yesterday continued all night. It is a regular western blizzard, and undoubtedly the worst storm New York has experienced since 1882. The streets are filled with snow and the streetcars are pulled along with great difficulty by double teams. What adds to the difficulties of the situation is the strike upon the Broadway and Seventh Avenue railroads, the Broadway surface railroad, the Sixth Avenue railroad, and the Fourth Avenue railroad. Many business men have been compelled to walk down to their offices. All mails are delayed.

THE WEATHER FOR THIRTY YEARS 

Baltimore, Md., February 4. The snow is seventeen inches deep here, the fall being the heaviest since Washington, February 4. The railroads to the southward have suffered great interruption from the snowstorm. No trains were sent out from Richmond northward yesterday afternoon and last night. 

Lysomir, Va., February 1. Snow falling since Wednesday; is twelve inches deep. All railroad communication is interrupted. Reports from the southwest portion of the state indicate an unparalleled snowstorm, and here the snow is from two to three feet deep.

18860206: FROZEN TO DEATH

Lincoln, Neb., February 5. Advices from Geneva state that the bodies of a man and woman and six children were found frozen stiff on the prairie near Oberlin, Kansas, yesterday. They are supposed to be a man named Lemmen and his family who started in an emigrant wagon for Oberlin just before the recent blizzard and have not been heard from since.

18860208: 

... and there the immigrants will be landed at their destination without the tedious trip from there to Victoria and Seattle, or the equally tedious, and in some respects even more disagreeable trip, overland to Portland, Ore. "Do you think, then, that the road will pay?" "After a thorough examination of the region it traverses, extending my examination from 100 to 300 miles north and south of the main line, I answer, unhesitatingly, that it will. Between Winnipeg and Calgary, a distance of 800 miles, extends an unbroken stretch of magnificent wheat and grazing land, which is being rapidly settled up by the... The hardiest of our home and foreign immigrants, including many Scandinavians. Then the gold quartz discovered in the Big Bend country, about seventy miles north of the line from Farwell, is very encouraging. Very rich placer diggings were discovered late in the summer on Similkameen, in British Columbia, about 300 miles northeast of Victoria, and 100 miles south of the road. From $1,500 to $700 were taken out of two claims before I left, and some 500 men are wintering there. "But will not the rigorous climate be a serious drawback?" "I think not; in fact, I believe the climate to be superior to that of northern Minnesota and Dakota, being less exposed to blizzards. I took very careful notes from the old Catholic priests, who had lived in the country from thirty to forty years, and they confirmed me, without exception, in this opinion. There are 600 square miles of wheat-growing country in the Saskatchewan Valley and the territories of Assiniboine and Alberta, where the frosts are not more severe than in the great grain-growing region of Minnesota and Dakota."

The aggregate stock of grain continues to increase during the week, bus increased 43,000 bushels, chiefly wheat, and peas. Compared with a year ago, the stocks are larger by 337,000 bushels. The market today showed the customary quietness. Wheat was dull and inactive. Peas have not been dealt in here, which makes it difficult to give quotations. Along the line, however, there has been business at 57c. Oats have advanced one cent during the week, with sales at 32c-33c. Canada red winter wheat, 91c-91.5c; white winter, 91c-92c; Canada spring, 91c-91.5c; peas, 68c-71c; oats, 32c-34c; rye, 65c-67c; barley, 50c-54c; corn, 60c. The stock of flour has increased 1,311 barrels during the week on receipts of 6,500, but is still less by 111,000 barrels than a year ago. The market today was quiet, with very little business in progress and that only in small lots. Values were not cited as nominally steady. Patent flour, $4.75; choice superior extra, $4.25; superior extra, $4.00-$4.10; extra super, $3.90-$3.95; fancy, $3.75; spring extra, $3.70-$3.75; superfine, $3.40-$3.60. Manitoba strong bakers', $4.15-$4.30; American strong bakers', $4.00-$5.00; fine, $3.20-$3.25; middling, $3.00-$3.10; pollards, $2.74-$2.80. Ontario bags medium, $1.85-$1.90; spring extra, $1.75-$1.80; superfine, $1.55-$1.60. City bags, delivered, $2.40-$2.45. Oatmeal, barrels, $4.15-$4.30; oatmeal, granulated, barrels, $4.45-$4.50. Receipts of produce posted on 'Change today were: Wheat, bushels; Peas, bushels; Barley, bushels; Flour, barrels; Ashes, lbs; Butter, kegs; Meats, pork, hams, etc., pkgs; Dressed hogs, 2,000 lbs; tobacco, pks; whiskey and wines, casks. Local receipts by rail for the week February 13: Gazette Office, Saturday Evening, European Breadstuff. The British grain markets today were quiet and essentially unchanged, with the exception of corn in Liverpool which was firmer and 1/4d per cental dearer at 4s 2d. Wheat in the same market was very inactive with a poor demand at unchanged prices. Cargoes of wheat and corn in all positions were quiet but steady. Liverpool, February 1J A leading weekly grain circular says: The weather trade has been quiet this week. Values are generally unchanged. Indian wheats on the spot are in less supply, having sold freely. Other descriptions are neglected. Cargoes off coast are steadily held, but the demand is not active; for shipment there is more inquiry. At today’s market there was a poor attendance. A quiet tone prevailed. The business in wheat was limited at the late figures. Flour was slow and unchanged. Peas were steady. Beans were firm and dearer. United States Grain Markets. Wheat in Chicago was dull and featureless again, with light trading and very limited fluctuations, which did not exceed three-eighths of a cent for the whole session. It closed unchanged at 79.5c February, 79c March, 85c May. Corn was firm, closing a trifle better at 57c February, 37c March, 40c May. May oats were stronger and closed 1/4c higher at 32c. Feeder options were unchanged at 29.5c. Today’s inspection was 10 cars winter wheat, 40 spring, 256 corn, 135 oats, 1 rye, and 44 barley. A despatch to Maclver & Barclay says: The estimated receipts for tomorrow at Chicago are: Hogs, 18,000; wheat, 55 cars; corn, 350; oats, 50. Wheat closing quiet and easy, late cables are dull and lower. Pork declined on country realizing. Corn and oats steady. A private Chicago circular, dated Friday afternoon, says: The weather still continues soft all around, with the snow about all gone and frost well out of the ground, but it is said the wheat fields are looking well, and will be all right no doubt until we get a blizzard. Private cables say new crop of Indian wheat is now offering in London at less price than old crop, and looking at market from exporters' basis it certainly looks discouraging enough to holders. If we get a material advance now, it must come from domestic causes. We look upon the weather as the most important factor now in determining values. The trading today was very light, and as usual of purely local character. We must have an increased volume of speculative trade to lift the market out of control of local speculators. The leading operators here are largely short and disposed to fight any advance, and until they change sides can hardly expect a material advance. The New York wheat market was firm, and moved up, closing at 91.5c March, 82c April, 94.5c May, 96c June. Corn was strong and advanced 1/8c, closing at 60.5c March.

The St. Paul carnival cannot by any means be considered a success. Throughout the whole affair there was much that was incongruous. The idea of these sports to the Americans was a new one, but it was almost too much of a novelty. If tobogganing and snowshoeing with them does not suffer the fame of previous years, they will no doubt in time cultivate a liking for them. The carnival has not drawn the large number of people that was expected. Beyond the neighboring towns and cities, there were few visitors to St. Paul. From Canada, about all that attended were those from Winnipeg. The lack of visitors is accounted for by several causes. The project was not commenced soon enough, and consequently not advertised enough. The weather up to within two weeks of the date of the carnival was very mild. So much so, that it was a moot subject whether to abandon the scheme, or to utilize ice cream freezers and refrigerators. Then the blast came sudden and cold; and it was then claimed that the more southern people were afraid to encounter a possible blizzard. The railway fares were not reduced sufficiently enough to attract the large quantities of people, who always take advantage of low rates of passage, to make cheap excursions. Of course, as might be expected, comparisons were continually being made between the carnivals of Montreal and those of St. Paul. One constantly heard it on the street, and read it in the newspapers. The chief merit claimed for the St. Paul affair was the variety of costume. All classes of people formed themselves into toboggan clubs. They cared very little for the sport itself. In fact, they secured, as a rule, no toboggans; but they all purchased uniforms. The average strength of these clubs was about one hundred members; and there were said to be over seventy different clubs, all differently uniformed. Many of them were quaint and picturesque. It might be of interest to describe a few of them, to show to what extent the Americans tried to hit on new effects. One club was arrayed in tight-fitting scarlet, with hoods and black horns. The costume was a facsimile of MEPHISTO's in "FAUST." These were veritably a club of red devils. The "Mikado" craze was not without effect, for one club came out in Japanese costumes, with fans. Their drill included the striking of many quaint attitudes. Probably the most novel effect was the costume of "The Knights of the Grip" Toboggan Club. These were the commercial travelers. They were numerous and their banner proclaimed that twenty-six states were represented. They wore straw hats and long linen dusters. The temperature was low, but they carried palmetto fans and small grip sacks. Everyone has adopted the passing craze of coming out in costume. So common has it suddenly become that there are juvenile clubs, saloon keepers' clubs, clubs from the factories, colleges, mercantile houses, and government offices. The press of St. Paul is very good, very enterprising, and very patriotic. Illustrated journalism is a prominent feature, and the leading papers, the Pioneer Press, the Globe, and the Dispatch have their special artists. The portraiture is bad, but the illustrations of places and events are very good. They are most enthusiastic over the progress of the carnival, and the variations rung on the word success are many and frequent. They consider that the St. Paul carnival eclipses the palmiest days of the Mardi Gras of New Orleans, the Baltimore Orion, the St. Louis festivities; and as for Montreal or St. Petersburg, they are both forever banished to the cold shades of oblivion, so says the American press.

18860219: B, which was the last boat of Brewster, was hauled off this morning by tug and taken to Provincetown, where she will reload and tow to Boston. Vessel in fair condition. Rev. Sam Jones is a man of medium height and slender form, with dark complexion, dark hair, and a heavy moustache, which receives considerable attention from the ends. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

of his fingers when he is not speaking. He is now 38 years old. He began with the law and whiskey, but was converted and left off both and went to preaching. This was about fourteen years ago. He began to acquire local fame about two years ago. Talmage is credited with his discovery. He comes before his audience in a countrified way, swaying on one leg with one hand in his pocket. He has a fairly good voice, is deliberate in his manner, and gives his audience ample time to laugh at his numerous jokes. He has much to say, and in this respect is the opposite of Harrison, who had little to say, but kept up the motions. His style is argumentative and abounds in telling illustrations. He is not restrained by rules of speech, but goes straight to his point either along or across the lines of grammar as best suits his convenience. His drawing power is his wit, and all his printed sermons are full of "laughter." Some patriotic but jocular person at Ipswich, Dakota, has caused to be promulgated, by means of the Associated Press, a statement to the effect that the weather in his blizzard-prone state is warm and sultry, and that the farmers are at work in the fields. The statement requires interpretation. It is warm in Dakota when the thermometer stands at 20 above, and when the mercury falls to zero it is sultry. The farmers then work in the fields, cutting up their fences into firewood to be used during the next blizzard, and digging dead cattle out of the snowbanks to save their hides from the wolves. This explanation makes the Ipswich man's statement intelligible.

Hamilton Spectator, Feb. 25, 1886. Absolutely Pure. This powder never varies. A marvel of purity, strength, and wholesomeness. Made from cream of tartar derived from the grapes. Sold in bulk by dealers in low-grade, short-weight alum or phosphate powders. 

18860225: ANOTHER BLIZZARD COMING. Washington, February 21. The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics estimates that the annual revenue under the Morrison tariff will be $20,170,000. Of the 2,500,000 pounds of sugar imported into the United States during the last fiscal year, 74 percent came from Cuba, Puerto Rico, Brazil, and the British West Indies. These countries, according to the latest advices, impose an export duty on sugar. If such is the fact, it is probable that 80 percent of the sugar imported last year came from countries imposing an export duty thereon. This would change the estimated reduction on sugar from $10,000,000 to $2,000,000, and the aggregate reduction of duty from $14,000,000 to $12,000,000. The import of articles of timber and lumber enumerated in the bill as directed by the proviso as to export duty are imported from Canada, which country, so far as learned, imposes no export duty on the articles specified. Therefore, the proviso has little or no effect. The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, in a letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, explaining his computations, says that the effect which this bill will have upon the volume of imports is a matter of speculation and conjecture, but that the general effect of a reduction in duty is, of course, to increase importation. There are, however, so many elements in the problem that it would be hazardous to venture an opinion on the subject.

A Fight for Her Hand. Sandwich, Mass., February 21. Since last spring, a fair Swedish girl, named Christina, has alternately toyed with the affections of two stalwart farm hands of her own race. Yesterday the two men repaired with a few friends to a secluded spot to fight out the differences with bare fists, the loser agreeing to keep away from the girl. They fought till neither had strength enough to come into the scratch, and the battle was declared a draw, the contestants having to be carried home.

Prisoners Pardoned. Amass, February 24. The Governor signed a bill today providing for the commutation of sentences of convicts for good behavior, which affects nearly five thousand prisoners of the higher grades. The result of the bill is more far-reaching than any measure of its kind which has become law during the past twenty-five years. The act was drawn by Mr. Goodwin Brown, the pardon clerk of the Executive chambers, as a result of thirty years' study and observation by him.

Another Blizzard. St. Paul, February 24. Advices from points northwest of here indicate that a blizzard is sweeping down from beyond the British border headed southeast. At 10 o'clock tonight, the wind was blowing at Haugen'sville, Minn., from thirty-five to forty miles an hour, and it was snowing furiously. The mercury here is descending rapidly under the influence of a cold cutting wind of considerable velocity from the direction of the storm center.

18860303: UNITED STATES DISPATCHES. Fatal Accidents on the Grand Trunk. Portland, March 1. At a Chicago revival meeting, an accident occurred to the Central Vermont train. The train, which left here at 1:30 p.m., was running near Lock's Mills last night with two engines and a snowplow. The plow struck a bank of hard-packed snow and tore up a section of the road, throwing the engines from the track. The first engine went down a six-foot embankment and struck on its side. Engineer Mitchell escaped, but Fireman Martin, in the act of jumping, was struck in the middle of the bank, his hip being dislocated and his abdomen crushed. Mechanic Philbrick, of the second engine, crawled through steam and hot water to the spot where Martin lay under his engine and pulled him out of a position where he might have been horribly injured. Philbrick then fell senseless by Martin's side. The cold was intense. The engines of both went off. The men were removed to Fennant's pond and efforts were made to revive Martin to ease his terrible agony until he died.

A new plow, running ahead of the Montreal express for Island Pond yesterday, struck an obstruction and turned upside down. Eight men were in the plow at the time. Almond Smith, of Island Pond, had an inch bolt driven into his forehead, killing him. Chadwick, of Island Pond, was injured internally and died shortly after. Two or three others were seriously injured, but will recover.

At the First Baptist Church yesterday, Rev. Sam Jones said: "What a privilege it is to pray! Now I want all those who went down on their knees and prayed before they came to this meeting to rise in their seats." About twenty persons arose. The evangelist leaned against the pulpit and seemed to gasp for breath. "You may be scared now," he said. "Why, brethren, you would find more prayerful Christians in Hong Kong, China, than there are in this meeting tonight. If you can't pray, I want you to take your carcasses out of here. I don't want you to come here if you can't pray." An aged man, sitting in one of the front pews, leaped to his feet and in a bittering voice said: "Mr. Jones, I don't think it is necessary for a person to get down on his knees to pray. I consider myself a good Christian and I do not like to hear such talk." "I was about to say the same thing," exclaimed Rev. Mr. Scudder, of Plymouth church. "I prayed while on my way to church. God does not demand that a man shall get down on his knees before his prayers are heard." "Any more exculpatory remarks?" drawled the evangelist. Dr. Scudder: "They are not exculpatory remarks." A man with an ear trumpet, who punctuated his remarks with vigorous pounding on the rostrum, said: "Mr. Jones, I did not have time to get down on my knees to pray for this meeting. I have spent nearly the entire day reading the Bible to a gambler and a drunkard, and I think I am entitled to respect here." Other men and several women began to stand up in various sections of the church, but a few explanatory remarks served to still the tempest, and the revivalist was permitted to finish his sermon without further interruption. In conclusion, he said: "Let us take the lesson in the text to our homes, and get some food out of it."

A Fatal Prohibition Quarrel. Chicago, March 2. A telegram from Milledgeville, Ga., says: The killing of Marshal Haygood by Sam Ennis on Saturday has given a bloody culmination to one of the bitterest contests over prohibition yet conducted in Georgia. Both parties charge the other with inciting to riot and bloodshed. The prohibitionists brought Sam Jones, the evangelist, here. He delivered a speech and preached a sermon. The anti-prohibitionists allege that he advised the prohibitionists to be ready to fight if necessary, to secure the polling of their votes, and recommended that they should go to the polls armed with pistols. The prohibitionists admit that Jones made use of some such expressions, but they insist that he meant that the prohibitionists should stand firm for their rights and nothing more. Immediately after the terrible tragedy, such expressions as these were common: "It was Sam Jones' work" and "How will Sam Jones feel when he hears to what his incendiary utterances have led?" Jones, who is in Chicago, was shown the above dispatch tonight. He said: "I think my name is connected with that affair in order that it might be more sensational. I never made an incendiary speech in my life. In the town of Milledgeville, I said, 'You men who are prohibitionists, be prudent, but stand by your convictions. If these liquor men try to frighten you by cursing or drawing their weapons on you, tell them you have been bullied as long as you intend to be, and if they can die for their infernal traffic, you can die in defense of the helpless women and children of this country, and if they want to run that game of guns and pistols on you, tell them they must strike the first lick, and then you will feed the blizzards with them if you can, but don't you ever strike the first blow.'"

Accident on the Central Vermont. St. Albans, Vt., March 2. A peculiar accident occurred this morning to the first Boston express from Montreal, due here at 10:50. Just as the train reached the crossing, a short distance from the St. Albans depot, it was thrown from the track down into a meadow. The engine kept the track, but the baggage car, Pullman, and an ordinary coach ran off. The baggage car was upset, but the other two kept right up. Nobody was hurt. It is supposed the cause of the accident was spreading of the rails.

Burned to Death. Fulton, Mo., March 2. Neighbors rushing to the burning house, occupied by Mrs. Quisenberry and her two sons, aged seventeen and nineteen, heard low cries of distress and found Mrs. Quisenberry lying in the yard, partly wrapped in a blanket. Her sons were not in sight but were supposed to be inside. Their charred remains were found in the ruins after the fire subsided. 

The Irish Parliamentary Fund. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

New York, March 2 — The last meeting of the Irish Parliamentary Fund committee was held last night. Seventy thousand dollars has been subscribed. Rochester's Mayor Re-elected. Tincnetti, March 2 — The municipal election was held today. Cornelius U. Parsons, nominated by the Union of Labor and elected by a mass meeting of citizens, was re-elected mayor by over 3,000 majority.

Another Congressional Celebration. Washington, March 2 — Senator Gorman introduced a bill today to provide for a joint celebration by the sixteen American republics on the 14th of March, 1894, in honor of the one-hundredth anniversary of the Constitution of the United States. The celebration is to take place in Washington.

Mormon Work in Atlanta. Atlanta, Ga., March 2 — In North Alabama, several Mormon elders have been actively engaged in work for the past six months and have made many converts among the country people. The farmers in Clay County informed them that they must leave, and threaten to use force, but the elders have favored a peaceful approach.

Huston, March 2 — Rev.

Vienna Tract. Vienna, April 10 — Kerr Seriony, a high Hungarian railway official, has been arrested in connection with the death of his daughter Irma. The latter, after a quarrel with her stepmother, took phosphorus. She was locked in a room by her stepmother, who forbade her servants to open the door until the girl's screams had ceased. The unfortunate girl suffered seventy-four hours of torture before death came to her relief. The family moved in the high circle of society and the terrible story has created much excitement.

The French Chambers. Paris, April 10 — In the Chamber of Deputies today, a Radical motion censuring the Government for the arrest of M. Rothschild and Duquesney at D'Amiens, in connection with the riots, was discussed. The debate resulted in a vote of confidence in the Government by 435 to 69. The Senate voted urgency for M. Roserain's bill enlarging the powers of the Executive so as to enable it to deal with strikes. One hundred and fifty-three members voted in the affirmative and one hundred and two in the negative.

The French in Senegal. Paris, April 10 — Advices from Senegal say that a large body of natives attacked Dakar and a sanguinary conflict ensued. The garrison at Dakar made a sortie and drove back the attacking party. For three days there was desperate fighting in the neighboring villages. The insurgents burned a large number of business houses in different localities. Four farmers of the revenue were killed by the natives and many others were wounded. The situation is said to be serious.

A Royal Betrothal. London, April 10 — Princess Clementina, youngest daughter of the King of the Belgians, who bears the title of Princess Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, and who will be fourteen years old on the 30th of July, has been selected as the bride of Prince Albert Victor, the oldest son of the Prince of Wales, now twenty-two years old. In view of the alliance, the Princess is being educated in the Protestant faith and her life and habits of thought will be molded as far as possible on the English basis.

The London Stock Exchange. London, April 11 — Discount was weak at 1% for three months and 1.75% for short. On the stock exchange, during the week, absolute stagnation prevailed, owing to the uncertain political situation. Leading brokers say they are hardly clearing enough to pay their clerks. Prices were steady. American railway securities shared in the inaction. Quotations were maintained until yesterday when there was a lower tendency.

The London Socialists Acquitted. London, April 10 — The trial of Burns, Hyndmann, Champion, and William, the Socialist leaders, was concluded this afternoon. The jury rendered a verdict of not guilty and the defendants were discharged. The jury, however, said that they thought the language used by Champion and Hyndmann at the time of the riot was highly inflammatory and worthy of severe condemnation.

Spring and the Anarchists. London, April 10 — The Government has ordered the residences of all known Anarchists living within the kingdom to be thoroughly searched for the purpose of procuring evidence against them. The authorities have resolved to act with all possible vigor in the work of stamping Socialism out of the country.

A German Poet Dead. Berlin, April 10 — Joseph Victor Von Scheffel, a poet, died today at Karlsruhe of dropsy. He was one of the most illustrious graduates of Heidelberg and was the author of a hymn to be sung at the celebration for the 400th anniversary of the founding of that institution.

Prussia and the Vatican. London, April 10 — Cardinal Jacobini has sent a note to Prince Bismarck saying that the Pope is willing that a notification of religious appointments shall be sent to the Prussian Government on condition that the Ecclesiastical bill be revised now or in the near future.

The Growth of German Trade. Berlin, April 11 — The German River Shipping Association reports that within the last ten years the shipping of goods has doubled on the Rhine, tripled on the Elbe, near Hamburg, and quadrupled on the Oder, near Stettin.

Duties on Petroleum. Vienna, April 11 — The new treaty between Austria and Hungary raises the duty on light American raw petroleum and benzine and other petroleum products and the prohibitive import duty on Russian heavy petroleum.

An Egyptian Scandal. Cairo, April 10 — A committee appointed to inquire into the management of the Egyptian finance ministry has found a public official named Addah guilty of extortion.

MAYMTOH1 MAS MULCTED. Thomas Kidgory experiences a Hyperborean Day in New York. Boston, April 10 — A New York dispatch to the Herald says Thomas Kidgory, an honest grocer of Winnipeg, Man., came here by special blizzard in response to sawdust circles to buy $3,000 in counterfeit Canadian money for $250. He wanted to give it to the poor in Winnipeg. He put up at the Union Square hotel on Wednesday. John Carroll, of No. 126 Spring street, met him, carried him off to a 119 South street, and introduced him to Charles Folsome. Folsome showed him a pile of genuine Canadian money, promised to send $5,000 worth around to Kidgory's hotel, and got the $250 out of him. No money, of course, was sent to the hotel. Kidgory had Carroll arrested, but Folsome cannot be found. To his great surprise, the honest grocer was sent to the house of detention today to ensure his appearance against his honest friend.

cd against him in determining what weight should be given to their testimony. But, in spite of their perjuries, if their testimony had been corroborated by other facts and circumstances, then the jury would be warranted in finding that they had told the truth. Dully, however, should not be allowed to corroborate Kullgruff or Kullg-aff. Dully Koch must be corroborated by testimony outside of the other. The jury had the absolute right to discard the testimony of both. The recorder drew the attention of the jury to the fact that the defendant was not charged with receiving a bribe, but with having made a promise to, or an agreement with someone, that his vote as an alderman of New York should be cast in favor of the charter of the Broadway Surface railroad. The charge on the whole was regarded as favorable to the prisoner, and was objected to on several grounds by the District Attorney. At 9 o'clock the jury went out to deliberate. At 10 o'clock tonight the jury once more entered the court, reported that they were unable to agree, and asked to be discharged, stating that there was no seeming possibility of their coming to a unanimous verdict. Recorder Smythe was unwilling to agree to this request, in view of the importance of the case, and the fact that the prosecution of the rest of the thirteen will probably hang upon the result of this trial, and ordered them back till tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock. A private telegram in this city last evening stated that eight jurymen were in favor of acquitting McQuade and four against.

**Arrested Blizzard Making Things Lively in Northern Dakota and Minnesota**

St. Paul, November 23. The second blizzard of the season reached Dakota early yesterday. The storm is coming from the northeast. Portland reports twelve inches of snow and drifting badly. Jamestown reports passenger trains on time, but freights abandoned. At Grafton at 10 p.m., the thermometer showed 16 above and was falling rapidly. Fargo reports four inches of snow. Aberdeen reports the supply of coal in that region nearly exhausted. The signal officers here say the blizzard was general over Montana, Northern Dakota, and Northern Minnesota. In St. Paul the weather is mild with light snow.

Winnipeg, Man., November 23. A heavy snowstorm, the first of the season, struck Winnipeg yesterday and continued all night. It is related by the gossips that when Mr.

1886-12-01: He was taken to Rockland and beached. The passengers, though somewhat frightened, behaved well. The extent of the damage to the vessel cannot be learned until the water has been pumped out of her.

**Asking for a Divorce**

Chicago, November 30. Society is agitated over a suit for divorce brought against William H. Ferry, a well-known citizen, by his wife, the daughter of John V. Farwell. Mrs. Ferry accuses her husband of an inordinate desire for money and of being exacting and brutal in his nature.

**The President's Message**

Washington, November 30. The president's message again framed the only subject of discussion at the meeting of the cabinet today. All the members were present. It is understood that the message is complete, with the single exception of that portion relating to the naval establishment.

**A Gigantic Defalcation**

Denver, Col., November 30. A report has been received from Fort Collins that F. L. Carter, manager of the Poudre Canal and Land Company, has disappeared; it is supposed he absconded, leaving indebtedness amounting to $306,000, all secured except $75,000.

**The Public Debt**

Washington, November 30. It is estimated at the Treasury department that the public debt statement to be issued tomorrow will show a decrease in the debt for the month of November of a little over a million.

**A Bad Failure**

Cincinnati, November 30. Khinby Dorsey & Co., wholesale dry goods, assigned; many of the assets will pay from 25 to 33 percent of debt. The firm was one of the largest in the city and has been recorded as one of the strongest.

**Another Cloud Man Gone Wrong**

Portland, November 30. Howard Blackstone, discount clerk of the Canal National Bank, has absconded, after embezzling $5,000.

**A Ride in a Blizzard**

Bismarck, Dak., November 30. A report of army officers who have arrived at Fort Yates gives a description of the thrilling ride in the history of the army. They were seventy hours in a blizzard in coming from Fort Lincoln, a distance of sixty miles, or over an hour to a mile. Their vehicle was an ambulance and was drawn by four mules. During Monday night, when the blizzard was at its height, they were compelled to shovel and plunge their way through snow drifts from six to ten feet deep, and the continual use of the whip and goading sticks was necessary to keep the exhausted animals on the walk. The officers state that at the time the blizzard hid the mules from view, and that but for the instinct of the animals, they would have been lost and frozen to death. At one point they passed an Indian camp, but the savages would not give them shelter, as their superstition taught them that this would be fatal to them. They arrived at Fort Lincoln without a covering to their ambulance, this protection having been blown away by the first night's wind, and within thirty minutes from their arrival one of the animals dropped dead. It was a fight for life for seventy-two hours, and they describe the trip as a most horrible experience, compared with which a march against an opposing army would be a pleasant pastime. France and Mexico have concluded a treaty of commerce.

1886-12-16: 

**GOOD BOYS AND THEIR PRINCIPLES**

The Grits have been too good boys. They have, in a very dogged way, stood on principles when they might easily have seen the country did not want principles. The above, from the Witness of last night, is suggestive of the idea that the author was in an ironical humor when he penned it. The goodness of the Grit boys has been of a peculiar kind. Their robe of righteousness has very much resembled the garb of that plausible gentleman known to fame as Mr. Worldly Wiseman. They have interpreted the apostolic injunction to be all things to all men in the wrong sense. Perhaps they got astray by accepting the version of the Scriptures prepared by Mr. Tross instead of adhering to the authorized translation of King James. Anyway, they have become sadly mixed in their striving after righteousness, or what they no doubt thought was just as good a thing, power over the government of the country. Their path has been sadly beset. There have been many stumbling blocks in their way. They have been oftentimes led astray by false prophets. They have sought to "put down bribery and corruption" with "lots of money." Special brands of "raspberry syrup" have been prepared wherewith to lubricate the throat of the unwary voter and through that channel affect his heart in favor of their cause. A light lantern brigade has been organized and has operated on their behalf in constituencies where they were likely to do the most good. A special ballot box was designed in their interest, and managed with efficiency. A gerrymander that out-gerrymandered all other gerrymanders has been framed in Ontario for their special benefit, and the principle declared that six thousand Grit voters were entitled to as great representation in the Legislature as ten thousand Tories. Their "too goodness" has been peculiar, and the Witness must have been mocking them when it spoke of it. So with the principles on which our contemporary says they have stood in a "dogged way." They have indeed stood on an immense lot of principles in their time. It would be hard to get a principle that they have not stood on to their detriment. They stood on the principle that it was wrong to construct the Pacific railway throughout Canadian territory; they stood on the principle that it was wrong to secure to the workingmen of this country the benefit of the markets of this country in opposition to the manufacturers of a foreign state; they stood on the principle that it was wrong to extend the franchise to the young men of the nation, and on the principle that the Canadian Northwest was inferior to the blizzard-swept plains of Dakota and Kansas. Today in Nova Scotia they stand on the principle that the federation should be broken up; in Quebec on the principle that treason and rebellion and murder should not be punished, and that the volunteers who risked and lost their lives to maintain the integrity of the Empire were assassins and pillagers; in Ontario they support this view, and the leader of the government telegraphed his congratulations on the supposed success of a politician who fought an election on the revenge cry and has, as one of his first lieutenants, a man who upholds the principle of driving the British out of the province. In the Northwest four or five years ago their principles were enunciated in a manifesto warning emigrants not to go into the country. The Witness was never nearer the truth in its existence than when it said the country did not want principles of this kind, and until the good boys of the Grit party learn this, appreciate the fact that Canada is a nation, whose people take pride in her prosperity and her progress, and take their stand on some principles that one who calls himself a Canadian can enunciate without hanging his head in shame, they will continue "in a very dogged way" to remain just where they are, and where it is well for the country they should be. The Dublin Express pithily summarizes the situation in Ireland, as regards the rent reduction agitation, when it says either the government of Mr. Dillon must go down. After going the length he did, to stop in his course now would be a confession of weakness on Mr. Dillon's part that would probably result in his losing considerable influence among his followers. His own language does not convey the impression that he intends to desist from the agitation, and we will probably before long hear of his getting into further trouble, as the government, after its recent declarations, will have to keep up the policy it has entered upon, of maintaining, with a strong hand, the administration of the law as it exists today. Alderman Grenier was the subject of a very virulent personal attack in yesterday's Herald. The chairman of the Finance Committee has his faults, like other men, but he has his good qualities as well, and his services to the city have been recognized by all who have watched the administration of its affairs. Such onslaughts as the Herald people have made upon him will have little effect upon the position he holds in the public estimation. He has before incurred the enmity of that journal, and has lived through the storm period without any outward sign of distress. He will, no doubt, be able to bear up equally well against the present cyclone of vituperation. The Herald's enmity these days is a thing less dangerous than its friendship. The state authorities of New Hampshire have been discussing a question that has come up for consideration in some of the Canadian legislatures—the justice of the law that requires the individual states to maintain prisoners convicted of offenses against the federal law. The New Hampshire officials have decided that they will not receive such prisoners in the future, thus bringing the matter to a crisis, in the hope that the central government will build penitentiaries for its own offenders. The case in the United States is different in some respects from that in Canada. There the Federal Government has no prisons whatever, whereas here the Dominion takes charge in the various penitentiaries of those guilty of the graver offenses. The matter is one, however, in which the people are not particularly interested. The cost falls equally upon them, whatever set of officials looks after the lawbreakers. The Canadian Gazette claims Dr. Goldwin Braith as a convert to Imperial Federation on the ground of some remarks that he made at a dinner given by the National Club, Toronto, Lieut.-Col. Denison in the chair. On that occasion, Prof. Smith is reported to have stoutly maintained the cause of a coiled empire. Possibly his mind may have undergone a change in the direction indicated, but, if even the Canadian Omnibus is aware, he was not half as opposed to the federation when it was impracticable. Of late, Dr. Smith's thoughts have run a good deal on the subject of Ireland and Mr. Gladstone's rejection of home rule, and it is not...

--- 

Please review the corrections for accuracy and clarity. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

It is unlikely that when he stoutly maintained the cause of a united empire, it was Italy that occupied his attention. The Canadian journalist, however, interprets his words otherwise and begins to look confidently forward to his becoming an active member of the league at a distant date. "These were wonderful solid wisdom that fell from the lips of Mr. Arthur, head of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, at the late convention of that body: There seems to be a universally prevalent idea that all capitalists are rich, whereas the truth is that no great business enterprise is owned and controlled by one man, but by many, each contributing something towards the mighty whole. I will venture to say that most men of thirty, industrious habits are almost. When we consider that capital is not invested wealth, I maintain there is not one among you, my hearers, who cannot consider himself a capitalist, be you ever so small. The whole world can say hear, hear, to such sentiments, and were they better appreciated by the masses, the disturbing trade of the capitalists would lose its profit, and he would stand a chance of personally appreciating some of the experiences of him whose lot it is to be a working man. 

In reality, it was certainly unfortunate," my learned friend continued, "that in the Lord Mayor's show Canada should have been represented by a model of the unpainted lumber at Montreal. But the fact that so much indignation has been taken of the matter appears to us a subject for congratulation. A few years ago no one would have either known or cared about the appropriateness of any colonial emblem. Now all is changed, and it is just because people are waking up to the grand climate and resources of Canada that they perceive the absurdity of representing her by Arctic symbols. We are convinced that better knowledge of the Empire will lead to keener appreciation of its value; and when the British nation once realizes that the Empire is practically worth preserving, a matter of X s d, if nothing higher, we shall see the movement for Imperial federation advance even more rapidly than at present towards its final consummation." 

It is well at any rate to maintain a hopeful spirit. The advisability of equipping the police force with firearms is a question on both sides of which something may be said. We do not think a good case was made out by the authorities of the force in favor of their recommendation, discussed by the City council on Monday, or that the state of the city calls for such a radical change, which would place in the hands of a body of men, open to considerable improvement in many ways, the power of taking life. But we think there is a point at which criticism of the police should cease. Aid McShane went beyond this in the council meeting, and so did the Herald yesterday, when, in assailing the management and personnel of the force, they encouraged the lawless element which has in the past taken the lives of faithful officers to arm themselves with revolvers with which to resist the police in the discharge of their duties. The roughs of the community do not need encouragement to do this, and they who offer it are enemies to the city.

18870115: 10, C Vt, 8:40 p.m., 2 hours late. South Eastern, due at 8:30 p.m., 2 hours late. No. 4, East, due at 8:12 p.m., cancelled. So far, this winter has been an exceptionally hard one so far as snowstorms are concerned. Yesterday's snowstorm was declared to be the heaviest of the season, and the railway officials fear that traffic will be seriously impeded. At an early hour the storm had not caused much delay to the service, but as the snow fell steadily the whole day and evening, accompanied by a blizzard in the country, there is every likelihood of a block occurring. The number of farmers who arrived in the city yesterday was small, notwithstanding that it was market day. The few who did face the terrific storm complain bitterly of the trouble experienced in reaching the city, owing to the heavy roads and blinding storm, and state that it is the worst they have been subjected to for several years past. The storm evidently prevailed throughout the whole province.

I have habitually prescribed Dr. de Jongh's Oil in cases of Pulmonary Consumption, with very beneficial results, and I can confidently recommend it as the most efficacious kind." 18870119: AN ADMIRER. Montreal, 18th January, 1880. THE HEAVY ROADS, The Work of the Turnpike Trust Company Complained Of. A resident of the Upper Lachine road, who supplies milk in the city, stated to a Gazette reporter yesterday evening that the Lachine roads were very heavy after Monday night's blizzard, and that he wished to complain that the Turnpike Trust makes no extra provision for a heavy storm like the one in question, and that the milkmen especially, who have to come into the city early in the morning, are obliged to make their way as best they can through the heavy drifts. Although some seven or eight inches of snow fell on Monday, up to 8 o'clock that evening no snow plough had gone over the road, and yesterday morning it took him an hour and three-quarters to come to the tollgate (two miles). He claims that instead of the men employed by the Trust commencing at 5 or 6:30 having quietly waited to do a regular day's work, they should get the men out early in the morning, knowing that the milkmen especially have to get to town early and if they are late, more particularly those who supply the hotels, they are certain to lose their customers. The tolls, he considers, are quite heavy enough to have the roads properly looked after. 

A hanging scene was one of the thrilling features of a drama at a theatre in San Antonio, Texas, and a concealed rope placed around the body of the man who acted the part of the victim was to keep the strain off the noose around his neck. The concealed rope failed to connect the other night and the man, after a realistic hanging scene, was cut down for dead, but by hard work was restored to consciousness.

18870208: A BLIZZARD OF SLANDER. In the Lower Province Getting Desperate. BRIGHT CONSERVATIVE PROSPECTS. Effect of Sir Charles Tupper's Return. Late Political News by Telegraph (from our own Correspondent). Halifax, N.S., February 7. The contest in Nova Scotia has assumed some extraordinary features within the past few days. Sir Charles Tupper's arrival has already resulted in straightening out affairs in the Liberal Conservative party, and in thorough organization, the Conservative prospects in Halifax have been vastly improved during the past week, and the speeches of Sir Charles Tupper, Mr. Blair, and Mr. Kenny have had an electrical effect. Mr. Kenny's speech exposing Grit hypocrisy in mixing the miserable cause of Blake with the sacred cause of home rule in Ireland has produced a revolution among Irish Catholics and a mailed reaction in favor of the Liberal-Conservative candidate. Mr. Jones opened his campaign by claiming the election of nineteen Secessionists from Nova Scotia. Since then the Grit cause has become desperate, and the more disheartening it becomes the more abusive and audacious they become. Their campaign has degenerated into A BLIZZARD OF SLANDER AND BLUSTER. 

Ten days ago I announced that Duncan McDonald had been accepted by the Conservatives of Victoria as a compromise Conservative candidate, and that our party, having united, McCurdy, who had been nominated months previously by the Grits, had ignominiously backed out of the fight. The Grit organs immediately claimed McDonald as a Liberal candidate, insisted that it was the Tories who backed down, and have ever since paraded his name in their standing announcement of candidates as a Liberal standard bearer elected by acclamation. Today the announcement is made that, notwithstanding their official statement, their wire-pullers have been working with all their might to induce McCurdy to re-enter the field and face the music, and notwithstanding McCurdy's written pledges to McDonald not to oppose him, he has now entered the field as a secession candidate. Under these circumstances, McDonald announces his willingness to retire and give his enthusiastic support to John A. MacDonald, barrister, as a straight Conservative candidate. In Pictou, the Grits only nominated one candidate for the two seats, and Adam C. Boil, Conservative, the Labor candidate, has retired and accepted the Liberal-Conservative nomination for Guysboro, where Dr. Cudogan is running as a straight Secessionist candidate against Mr. Kirk, Grit. Great interest is manifested as to whether James A. Fraser, THE APOSTLE OF REPEAL, will support the Grit or secession candidate in Yarmouth.

18870212: THE BALL. There was no carnival outdoors yesterday. The weather was unpropitious in the strictest sense of the word. It blew a regular blizzard, as only a Canadian blizzard can blow, but it was carnival ball day, or rather evening. Citizens patiently resigned themselves to keep within doors, and visitors enjoyed the pleasing quietude and comfort of their hotels, all awaiting the ball in the evening, which neither the wind nor the snow could disturb. It was as much as a man's life was worth to venture for a long journey through the streets. So our American cousins thought, and so Canadians, to a large extent, agreed with them, and all remained within doors until the evening. Talk of your public balls and annual festivals in the city. They are grand, it is true. The Caledonians and the Commercial Travellers, and the other societies annually make a display of festivity worthy of the importance of the city, but the Carnival ball last evening excelled all. It was a scene of grandeur and a scene of beauty unexcelled in the history of the city. The Windsor hotel was more beautiful than ever, more beautiful in its floral decorations and beautiful in the usual dignity of its ball room and corridors. Perhaps it was well that the committee did not draw the rigid line of fancy dresses for participants in the ball. There is difficulty about obtaining fancy dresses, especially for visitors, and the pleasing fact that our cousins across the line joined in great numbers in the festivities of the evening may be attributed to the mercantile "evening dress" being the rule. Supper was prepared for 1,200, so Mr. Isaac Ebbits, the steward of the Windsor, said, but the chef must have doubled the supply, because there must at least have been 1,500 present, and they all seemed to have enjoyed the supper, which was not the least important part in the evening's bill of fare of amusement. It was truly a Carnival night. When you see old and dignified men, the gay cavalier, and the handsome lady enjoying the dance together, there must be something unusual in the air. The gay grandsire, skilled in mystic lore, frisked beneath the burden of threescore. So Goldsmith wrote in the "Traveller" about the French peasantry of his day, and the couplet is applicable to many of our ancient city and American friends who joined in the ball last evening. Prominent and respected citizens, engaged in our trade and commerce, mingled in the participation of the fun with the young folks, and Carnival held high revel unmarred by a contrivance. Sufficient to say for the description of the ball, our readers who were not there can imagine its brilliance, and those who were there can blame the reporter for not conveying to the outside world the full measure of enjoyment which they felt. 

Was there a crush? So people will say, and so people will answer that there must have been. Well, there was a crush. There is always a feeling that a joyous ballroom is well filled with friends you know and friends you don't know; but there was not what some society people "call a crush."

1887-02-14: ANOTHER BAD BLIZZARD. Pipestone, Minn., February 12. One of the worst blizzards of the season has been raging here for the last thirty-six hours. All trains on the Burlington road have been abandoned. It is thought there must be considerable suffering in the country. Egg poachers, of three or six rings, price only 35 and 65 cents. They make a fine dish of eggs all even. Potato presses, patent curtain stretchers, price $3.50 and $3 each.

1887-02-15: In helping to entertain some of the Boston Bicycle Club, who were very kind to the Montreal boys when down there, took them to the Park slide during the blizzard Friday. He had J. Paton's big toboggan and got six of a party on to take them down. He did it most efficiently for the hill was in terrible condition and the windup was in a snow bank on the side, out of which the Bostonians climbed completely covered with snow. "Call this fun," said one, "then count me out." They then started to coast down Cote des Neiges and they were again dumped into a bank. They left too soon to find out the real beauties of the sport and have not a very exalted opinion of it now.

A CYCLONE OF FALSEHOOD substituted for the Grit blizzard of slander. CONSERVATIVE VICTORY CERTAIN. Disgraceful Liberal tactics to amuse bare and religious prejudices. (From our own correspondent.) Halifax, N.S., February 18. The National Policy campaign in the Maritime Provinces goes bravely on, and its advocates are marching forward in a solid phalanx to certain victory. The fact that the Grits are not running candidates in five constituencies at all, viz., Pictou, Gloucester, King's, Ken, and Victoria, and that in a sixth their candidate is disqualified by not having resigned his seat in the local Legislature, thus giving the Government a gain of six seats to start with, is a most sickening blow to them. With such a splendid advantage already gained, our Upper province follow-Toryists do not need to be reassured that the party of progress and prosperity will hold their own in the other constituencies which the Grits have mustered up courage enough to contest. The Grits are in their last ditch and in their desperation they have substituted a cyclone of falsehood for their blizzard of slander. Their papers are lined with alarming dispatches from Montreal, Ottawa, and Toronto, giving the most grotesque accounts of how the whole Tory party is going to be annihilated in Ontario and Quebec on Tuesday, from which provinces they claim a forty majority for Blake, while they allege that all the members from Manitoba, Northwest, and British Columbia will support Blake. This is the story they tell in those provinces under the most startling headlines, but only the most gullible believe it as it is but a rehash of their dispatches in 1882 and 1884. These dispatches, however, are not without some humor. For instance, one says that "The Opposition to Alonzo Wright is more serious than many suppose," indicating that they themselves consider the opposition to him a huge joke. The Chronicle today claims Mr. Dupont as pledged to support Blake in one column, and in another denounces him for going back on his pledge and stumping for the Tories in Hochelaga. On the other hand, dispatches of a similarly grotesque character are sent from here to the Upper provinces to enable the organized appetite there to keep up courage. These dispatches conveniently ignore all the facts and make statements and claims as idiotic as they are false. If the Upper province Grits are pinning their faith on the Lower provinces, they will be as wilfully mistaken as they were four and eight years ago respectively. The Grits do not believe in their own claims, and although they say they will elect nineteen, they will not put up money on more than a majority. The Government will hold their own in the Maritime provinces. They may lose one or two seats, such as in Cape Breton, where two Grits are running against five Conservatives, but for every seat they lose, they will capture one from the Grits. Both four and eight years ago they made the most extravagant predictions about the Maritime provinces, declaring they were going to elect two-thirds in Nova Scotia, three-fourths in New Brunswick, and sweep Prince Edward Island. When the votes were counted it was all the other way, and it will be the same next Tuesday. The truth is that the Maritime Grits are in the depths of desperation. The Chronicle and Recorder are making shrieking appeals for repealers to come out and vote or else the great victory of June will be thrown away, and declaring that if they do not get a majority, repeal will be dead. On nomination day at Sydney, Murray, one of the Grit candidates, read what purported to be a telegram from Jones, saying that Blake will not abolish the coal duties if he succeeds in obtaining power. Last night at Waverley, Jones distinctly stated that the abolition of the coal duties was a plank of Blake's platform, and that he (Jones) fully concurred in the wisdom of such a policy. He argued that the coal duty was no good to any person except "a few foreign capitalists," and he reiterated the declaration that he would vote against the coal duty tomorrow as well as the duty on Yankee flour. The Grits are making tremendous but vain efforts to capture the French Acadian vote by stirring up race and religious issues. Catholic missionaries are at work among the French of Westmoreland, where, at Shediac...

**THE CARNIVAL**: More than One Hundred Thousand People Handled. The involved record of the number of passengers who arrived at Bonaventure depot during carnival week will prove of interest to the public generally, and particularly to the people of Montreal, who contributed to the signal success of the event. A period of such variable and severe weather as was experienced in Montreal during that week was never before known. On Tuesday, a sleet and rain storm set in, after which came severe frost. The flanges of the rails were full and solid and the ice required to be picked out inch by inch. During the day on Wednesday and Thursday, finer weather set in. The nights were, however, very stormy with snow. This was followed by a perfect blizzard on Friday, resulting in an entire suspension of traffic. Saturday morning the weather was fairly good, but the station and yard were literally choked with snow and cars embedded therein. Unfortunately, on Saturday evening the weather turned excessively cold, the thermometer falling to 15 below zero. The engine power became almost paralyzed in consequence. Having to contend with all these difficulties, it is to the credit of the Grand Trunk Railway company that with the present facilities at Bonaventure depot they handled 2,306 cars and 105,020 passengers, coming and going, without the slightest injury to life or limb. The record is as follows: Report of passengers arriving at Bonaventure station during Carnival week, with number of passenger cars and the divisions over which they ran.

**1887-02-26**: A dispatch says: The storm which commenced yesterday afternoon caused the most serious blockade of the season throughout northern New Hampshire and Vermont. The temperature suddenly fell below zero and the wind blowing a gale all night completely stopped railroad traffic until this morning. Farmington, Me., February 25. A regular blizzard has prevailed here since yesterday. A snowstorm raged in the forenoon, about six inches falling before night, and a gale followed. Immense drifts block all roads and passenger trains are canceled, something which has not happened before for over twenty years. Reports from the Sandy River and Franklin & Megantic railroads (narrow gauge) state that trains are snowbound on the former road at Phillips and on the latter road at Strong. Travel and business in North Franklin is entirely suspended. Carter's Little Liver Pills must not be confounded with common cathartic or purgative pills as they are entirely unlike them in every respect. One trial will prove their superiority.

**A Legislative Deadlock**: Charleston, W.V., February 25. The Legislative session closed today. The deadlock on the United States senatorship remained unbroken. This leaves the appointment to the Governor, who will most likely appoint a man with free trade ideas. 

**Another Blizzard in the West**: Bismarck, D.T., February 25. A terrible blizzard is blowing in the West. A Northern Pacific eastbound passenger train is snowed in near Sentinel Butte. Hon. Henry L. Cutting, Sr., the New York broker, died suddenly yesterday morning. Four cases of smallpox have been reported since Thursday in Holyoke, Mass. Rev. Jas. Freeman Clarke, the eminent Unitarian divine, of Boston, is seriously ill. The snow blockade on the railways near St. Johnsbury, Vt., is the worst this season. The condition of George Bancroft, the historian, who has been ill of pneumonia, is much improved. Commodore William T. Truxton, United States Navy, retired, died suddenly yesterday afternoon at Norfolk, Va. Gerald Maxwell, the son of Miss M.E. Braddon, the novelist, has recovered from the attack of insanity and will return to England in a few days.

**1887-03-31: A Drive Over the Scene**: "I am afraid I cannot get through here, sir," said the carter to the reporter. There was a huge snowdrift on the Black River road, beyond the Mile End. The snow was piled ten feet high on each side, as the horse struggled through, and the sleigh was tugged along now on one side, then on the other. The wind blew half a gale, driving the pinching snow into the faces of the carter and his passenger. It was a bitter March day, and in its wintry discomfort more like a blizzard day in January. If the poor student were out in such weather, and in such a blizzard, he would have little hope of reaching shelter. On went the sleigh until the imposing and comfortable hotel of Pierre Frigon was reached. Here the missing student was last seen in company with his friends. Should the lost one not be recovered, the hostelry will become famous as the central figure in one of the most extraordinary mysteries which has ever startled society in Montreal.

18870406: SNOW BLOCKADE IN MICHIGAN. Milwaukee, April 5. Despatches from Northern Michigan and Wisconsin report one of the worst blizzards of the season. Snow is a foot deep and Michigan railroads are blockaded. Chief Justice Cameron, of Ontario, and Chief Justice Stuart, of Quebec, Knighted. London, April 5. Chief Justices Cameron, of Ontario, and Stuart, of Quebec, have been made Knights Bachelor. Sir Matthew Crooks Cameron was born in Dundas, in 1823, educated at Upper Canada College and called to the Bar in 1849, and created Queen's Counsel in 1893. He sat for North Ontario in the Canadian Assembly from 1861 to Confederation, and was soon after elected to the Ontario Assembly for Toronto East, a seat which he retained until 1878, when he was raised to the bench. He was a member of the Sandfield Macdonald administration from July, 1867, to December, 1871, holding the office of provincial secretary and commissioner of Crown lands. He led the Opposition in the Ontario Assembly from 1871 to 1875. He is Chief Justice of the Court of Common Pleas. Sir Andrew Stuart is, we believe, the oldest judge on the bench of the Superior Court of this province, and has been Chief Justice since March, 1885. His residence is at Quebec, where he is personally held in high estimation.
