The unfortunate young man missed the road and was lost in the blizzard. ON THE BRANCH. On Saturday afternoon Chief Detective Cullen and Detective Lipton arranged with Mr.

18870518: OCT 07 THE RUNNING. There was a little discussion as to the prospects of foreign competition in the meat trade at a recent meeting of the Cirencester Chamber of Agriculture. The president said that from information furnished him by the secretary, he learned that recent blizzards and snowstorms, and the generally severe weather, had so decimated the herds on American ranches that they would probably be out of the running as regarded store stock for the next two or three years, and therefore there was no immediate danger, but it would recur.

18870704: S informed Toronto, and Toronto kindly wired the Intelligence back to us. The tidings are disheartening, no doubt, but silvered over by the reflection that if these 7,000 had remained they might have proved of that stripe who bow the knee to the idol of discontent. We have a fair supply already of that species of bird that defiles its own nest. Meanwhile, a few authenticated statistics from Mr. S would be in order. For myself, I must believe that gentleman; but all non-grievancers hereabouts pronounce the statement a well, say a fib. Could I trust my own observation as I do Mr. Silcox, I should give it the same name, or a stronger. Desirable settlers are not leaving the country. Some who, in their haste to get rich, got immersed in debt instead, and hopelessly mortgaged through their recklessness, have slipped over the line. Others, finding the atmosphere here too hot for such characters as themselves, have done likewise. Is this a proof of stagnation or decay? Is it a reason for a "change of management?" I see thousands of farmers growing wealthy all around me; indeed all who deserve to prosper are prospering, and I have yet to learn the first instance of one of these solid fellows pulling up stakes for Dakota or any other state. True, though I live in the midst of them, I may not have seen things. They may have gone under cover of the night, calling upon Mr. Silcox at Winnipeg with a fresh budget of woes. True, there is a large Canadian population south of the boundary, but they did not go thither as a rule from the Northwest. They settled there before this country was surveyed or open for settlement, not at all from preference but of necessity. To their credit be it spoken, these earlier settlers upheld their adopted country. Their correspondence with friends and relatives eastward portrayed the land in bright, not dismal colors. In fact, had they done otherwise Jonathan would have very properly kicked them out long ago. And so the number of Canadians multiplied, drawn chiefly from Ontario and other eastern provinces. This clear stream is still flowing, I believe, but not from Manitoba; what little they get from us is muddy. More than this: Not a few of these people are now seeking homesteads in our country. Why? Because of our superior advantages. They know all about us independent of Farmers' Union manifestoes, Winnipeg ebullitions and Silcoxian orations. Living on our borders, they have the means of forming a correct judgment from personal observation and contact with our people, and that judgment is in our favor. The dismal howl of the agitator makes the Dakotan smile, for he knows the facts of our case and his own. He knows that our soil is at least equal to his. He knows that our taxes are very much lighter than his own. He knows that our railroad facilities are far greater than most Dakotans enjoy, and that our freight rates are not higher than he pays. He knows that in this country men do not live in daily terror of their lives from the devouring blizzard and the annihilating cyclone; and his eyes are turning this way. 

With the European populations the case is quite other. No sooner have they read a just account of the country than some damning "resolution," Winnipeg tempest or Silcoxian deliverance meets their eye and spoils all. When its own people paint it black, will strangers and foreigners in distant lands think the country white? They will take it at its own word and give it a wide berth. Capital will do the same. Can the blindness of party or selfishness go further? But Mr. Silcox says this is not the trouble. Hear him: "The whole management of the Northwest country would have to be much altered before that region would prosper." That's it. You see it is not the immigration frighteners or the capital deterers at all, but "bad management," that is, "bad Government," which, being interpreted, means a Conservative Government. Ah! there's the rub. There can be no prosperity here so long as Sir John Macdonald rules yonder. God's noble endowment of this land goes for nothing so long as those Jones sit on the treasury benches. The Hamans still cry, "All this avails me nothing, so long as I see Mordecai, the Jew, sitting at the king's gate." Well, Mordecai has been sitting there some time; let us hope that some of the Hamans may be hanged. Terrible spirit of party, here stalking hand in hand with the besoured spirit of the boom, hast thou come hither also to wither and to waste? Some of us here, however, choose to think that this country has been managed as well as a somewhat unmanageable country could be managed; and treated pretty fairly on the whole. The country has been opened up at vast expense, but not at our expense. The land laws are more favorable to the genuine homesteader than are those of the neighboring states. For so young a country our railway and postal facilities are remarkably good. Very substantial and comprehensive have been the favors showered on us by the central government, and I fail to see where the evil treatment or the bad "management" comes in. True, we have asked some things which we have not yet received; for example, permission to break faith with the syndicate in the name of the Dominion and in the interest of a foreign nation; permission to paralyze an enterprise in which the very life-blood of Canada pulsates, and which has made us what we are: permission to enrich a few Winnipeg traders at the expense of the whole nation; in one word, permission to stab that nation to the heart. This refusal is of course a part of the bad "management." It is ever the way with spoiled children. They can't understand the "governor's" disallowance of powder and shot. Sectional selfishness is at the bottom of our imaginary woes, and radical indeed will be the "change" that will save us from ourselves. It is hard to save a man bent on self-destruction. Of course, I am willing to believe that some change of treatment may be desirable, something to let the wind off the poor old woman's stomach. For real grievances, Ireland stands first; for fancied ones, Manitoba. Anything rather than obscurity. Since the day I first set foot in it, I have heard little but groans. Year in, year out, rolls on the melancholy music. Quite intolerable would it be were it not for the sudden transitions, the striking alternations in the movement; but the undertone of woe ceases never. Favors received may remove the cause; but they cannot stop the wail. Manitoba is like the old woman who found herself very thirsty as she lay tossing one night on her bed in a hotel, next door to a gentleman's bedroom, who couldn't sleep for her unceasing wail, "Ochone, but I am dry!" He arose, gave her a glass of water, and returned to his bed, fancying the trouble at an end. Not to, however, to his dismay he found that the sleep-repelling lamentation went on as vigorously as before, but varied into the retrospective: "Ochone, but I was dry!" Everything from the grasshopper to the syndicate is a source of woe. Winnipeg! in a chronic attitude of unrest and suspicion. This center of sore heads has no faith in anybody. Norquay is a deceiver. Scarth is a traitor. Sir John a tyrant. The syndicate a devouring monster, and each suspects his fellow. The notable thing is the celerity with which some intolerable grievance is dropped, though unredressed, when another looms in sight promising choicer opportunities to the agitator. Who now ever hears of the famous "Bill of Rights?" That cow ran dry. At one time it is canned fruits. At another, agricultural implements. Then the school lands iniquity. Again, the swamp lands enormity. Then a grand rush is made for Hudson's Bay. Lastly, a milted dash down the Red River valley to the haven of the oppressed. Yesterday the cry was "On to Churchill!" Today it is "On to Pembina!" The central authority is set at naught; and open rebellion once more threatened. There is in all this more energy than dignity. I suppose Mr. Silcox would call it the energy of despair; to me it seems like the energy of "A furious maniac slinging flame." The spectacle is as pitiable as it is ridiculous. We are fast becoming a laughing stock to the world. Blow after blow falls on the head of this devoted land, not from without but from within. Compared to our own, the hand of Jack Frost has been light upon us. Our cradle was rocked in rebellion. Hardly had the child left the cradle when the evil spirit of Mammon "boomed" him delirious. Slowly convalescent, the "Farmers' Union" dealt him a terrific thump. Then a second insurrection, fomented by designing men not residing in Old Canada, "plunged him fathom deep in brine; and now a third horror on the horizon, a cloud "like a man's hand," soon, I suppose, to grow "And topple round the dreary West, A looming vision fringed with fire." And all for what? A "monopoly," without which this country would still be inaccessible; echoing the bellow of the buffalo, not the hoot of the agitator: "excessive rates," never yet shown to be excessive. Beyond a certain mark Parliament interferes. It has not interfered. Why? Because, though necessarily high, they are not excessive. Does not everybody know that without the so-called "monopoly clause" no syndicate could have been found; no road built; no Winnipeg created; no theatre erected wherein to strut and pose? As if we only discovered the existence of such a clause after our arrival here! As if we did not know long before how it must tend to pinch us! As if this very pinching had not been very cho... Here is the corrected text:

---

Erfully contracted for by us, to escape the keener life-long pinching that threatened us on the declining or unattainable homesteads of the West. Incredible that honorable men should threaten rebellion unless their rulers deliberately perpetrate a deed of dishonor and downright cruelty that would consign the name of Canada to eternal infamy, not to mention its traitorous unpatriotism. For, what is it these men ask? Simply that the nation turn thief in the first place, reverse its whole policy in the second place, and, in the third, cut the hoop that holds the staves together, that our very life-blood should flow out to our neighbors if only Winnipeg might sip a cup or two extra as it passed. Of course, the Government simply scouts the monstrous idea; ergo, say Silcox and Co, "the whole management must be changed! The misrulers of Canada, who, nevertheless, prefer building her up to benefiting the States, and who think 'a bargain's a bargain's a bargain,' must make way for men who would betray her interests and make 'ducks and drakes' of her obligations." The world is asked to believe that the Canadian Pacific Railway is deliberately crushing the people here, as if the very idiot could not see that not even ourselves have a greater interest in our prosperity than that company. No man or class of men has any such interest in the development of the Northwest. To accuse it of laying crushing burdens on the people, therefore, is simply to charge it with designs on its own life. In other words, that the syndicate consists either of suicidally inclined maniacs or of financial dunderheads. I shall not believe that they wish their own great enterprise to fail, or that the wisdom of Winnipeg would contribute much to its success. Possibly Sir George H. C. might know as much about railroading as do even the firm of Silcox & Co. Our welfare is theirs. This is our guarantee, and it ends the controversy. There is no alternative. You must either believe that the company has the welfare of Manitoba at heart or that it has taken leave of its senses. Mark the significantly tender style in which Mr.

18871031: 0 OVER HEDGES AND DITCHES A Cross Country Record Beaten in a Blizzard. The Montreal McGill Beaten in the final Inter-Provincial Rugby Championship—Gent Beat Hutchins Football in the States. Sporting in General. L. Maltby was referee. "What a day for a cross country race," said someone, as he peered as far ahead as the driving snow would let him, and looked at the expanse of dreary white, with the shadowy outlines of leafless trees appearing through the blizzard. Look at those fellows with no clothes on worth mentioning and legs bare; and then turn up your coat collar, pull up the buffalo robe and enjoy a comfortable shiver while waiting for the start. It would be interesting to know what athletic association, outside Montreal, could turn out sixteen young men in weather like Saturday to travel over hedges and ditches, up hill and down dale, with visions of barbed wire and stone walls, and the weather man doing the best he knew how to make business brisk for the doctors. That's the kind of stuff our athletes are made of, and the weather does not count when there is a trophy waiting at the end of the journey. Not a minute is lost in starting; overcoats are off; a weird sort of aboriginal dance is indulged in to an accompaniment of dental chattering; watches are taken out; "Go!" and they are off. Inside of a hundred yards the pack is in Indian file, Johnson volunteering to show the way, with Moffatt, Ross, Gordon, and Lamb on each other's heels, and the rest following the leaders closely. Then the cut across the field is made. "We'll have to drive pretty hard to catch them at the corner." "Oh, no; the weather is too bad; they can't do it today." Inside 45. "Getting up through Fletcher's field the string had broken in two. Johnson, Moffatt, Lamb, Starke, Barnard, Gordon, and Baillie were the first division and Paton was heading the second part of the pack. Findlay, who was not in the best of trim and only went in to make up a team, had dropped away behind and it was thought he would turn back, but he did not. The Back River course is, perhaps, as good a course as any for those interested enough to follow the race with the aid of a horse or two. There are half a dozen places where a good view can be had from the road. The old heads that know every foot of the road were pretty good guides as to where to stand up in a wagon and take a view. Passing a copse a halt was made; "There's a good opening; we'll stop till they pass." "What are you stopping for? They're away ahead!" and so they were. The first six were hanging on to each other like leeches. "What time they were making! And such a day! They'll beat last Saturday's run if they keep at it." There's a brush; Ross and Johnson are running side by side; Ross is leading; Moffatt is close up; the three leaders are drawing away from the rest of the field; another see-saw; Johnson is showing the way again; Moffatt keeps his distance; it looks as if he were letting the leaders tire themselves see-sawing; but he never lets them get far away. The continual change of places between Johnson and Ross had made the pace a corker. Moffatt is contented with third place so far, and does not care about spurting. The field is gradually being left behind and Lamb makes a great effort to catch up to the company that is leading the way. "Now drive like the wind or we'll miss them at Bougie's corner." The corner is just reached in time. Down the lane they come; Ross is leading; crossing the road there is a brush; a bound over the ditch and Johnson tops the stone wall lift; Ross is not a second behind him; over goes Moffatt; and Lamb appears at the head of the lane. The way the four got over that wall was a sight to see. They looked as fresh as if they had just started, and there was no such thing as being pumped. The rest of the men were invisible, and to be in at the finish a hard drive was necessary for spectators and timekeepers. "Now, catch them coming out of that copse!" They are in just the same order as they were when they got over the wall. Lamb is a little further behind. Johnson is easily distinguishable at a distance by his tuque; Ross is in black and Moffatt wears the club uniform. Ross and Johnson have another little contest to show the way. Moffatt is unshakable; he just stays where he is. "What are they running so fast for now? They'll be pumped out." The outsider did not know the true inwardness of that little burst of speed. Visions of a brindle bulldog give great impetus to a steeple chase, especially when he remembers his nether covering is not extensive. By the way, when a farmer sees a young man cut across the corner of his lot in racing rig, he might know that his chicken coop is not threatened, and when the snow is on the ground there is not much danger of injuring the crops by running over his field. One farmer, with no soul for athletics and a stickler for trespassing regulations, tried the efficacy of a broom handle and then retired hurriedly to the house. This was the time the runner's mind was occupied with bulldog and how fast bulldogs usually travel across country. The canine, however, did not make his appearance and the splendid work of the day is not dimmed by hydrophobic apprehensions, but the visionary canine helped to make the pace just the same. At the last point of vantage on the road the timekeepers named the first four positions correctly. This was where Moffatt began to take a hand in earnest. The pace was a rattling one, and Johnson was making it. Moffatt's spurting; so he was. He's passing Ross; he passed him, but he could go no higher; Johnson had too much speed. It will be a hot finish. Ross is slowly dropping behind. The pace is terrible. At last Peloquin's is reached and just as the timekeepers vault the fence Johnson dashes up. "Make way," say the judges; "Thirty-seven ten," cry the timekeepers. "There goes the record," said one of the judges. "Moffatt, thirty-seven twenty." Two men knock the record endways. Then Ross comes up and vaults the fence without touching. "37.50." "It's a good thing that Toronto team did not come along; we'd have had to send out a search party or they'd have got lost in the snow," was another remark. Every man of the team had some word of encouragement as he reached the goal. There was a sprinting finish between Gordon and Barnard, there being only a second between them, and Weldon and Foster had a pretty close run of it. The following is the order of arrival with the time made and the points, the lowest score to count: 

1. Johnson 37:10 
2. Moffatt 37:20 
3. Ross 37:50 
4. Lamb 38:00 
5. Gordon 38:10 
6. Starke 39:16 
7. Brody 40:16 
8. Baillie 41:16 
9. Fletcher 42:10 

18871129: A MacDonald as a grocery and liquor store. The building and contents are a total loss. The building was insured for $2,000 and the stock for $3,000. The cause of the fire is unknown. Gounod's now morn is dedicated to the memory of Joan of Arc. It was first performed in the Church of St. Eustache, in Paris. Mrs. Weldon was in the church, much to the disgust of the Gounod faction. 

THREE HOURS IN SESSION Another Meeting of the Fishery Negotiators. A MONOPOLY IN DANGER—Another Cut in Eastbound Freight Rates. A Coal Famine Feared in the West. Washington, November 28. The fishery negotiators met at noon today at the Department of State. The English representatives took with them a number of official documents. Among the publications on the subject of the fisheries that have recently come into the possession of the American negotiators is the Canadian book of dispatches, containing correspondence between the Canadian and English Governments, which was to a certain extent unknown to the Department of State, and is expected to prove of value in the pending negotiations. The session lasted until 3 o'clock, when an adjournment was had until Wednesday next. 

The Latest from New York, November 23. There is yet no settlement of the fight between the trunk line pool and the Grand Trunk line over the rates on dressed meats and live stock. Commissioner Kink today announced another reduction in rates to meet the Grand Trunk's last cut. 

Chicago, November 28. The Chicago and Grand Trunk opened the week today with another reduction in the dressed meat rates, bringing them down to 34 cents a hundred pounds from Chicago to Boston and New England points. There is an impression among the majority of railway officials here that the fiercest of the fight is over and that rates will not go much lower. 

A Coal Famine Feared. Chicago, November 28. The announcement comes from Duluth that nearly 1,000,000 tons of coal have been taken there, over 200,000 more than last year, and yet it is already evident that there will be a great shortage in the supply this winter. The first blizzard has come and the towns of western Minnesota and Eastern Dakota are showing signs of great anxiety. At Huron many people are procuring to bring hay burners into requisition. At Adrian there is not a pound of coal for sale and some distress is reported among the poor. 

A Monopoly in Danger. Chicago, November 28. The City Council tonight, by an almost unanimous vote, adopted resolutions requesting the Mayor to write the Attorney-General of the state asking him to file a warrant for the purpose of forfeiting the charter of the Chicago Gas Trust. The forfeiture of the charter of every gas company in the city was also demanded, each of them being now controlled by the trust. 

A Strike Against High Rent. New York, November 28. The telegraph companies occupying quarters on the floor of the Stock Exchange have been paying $2,000 per annum rent. They had a conference with the exchange managers today and notified the latter that unless a reduction of more than 50 percent was made at once, they would remove their wires and instruments on Wednesday next.

Synod of the Lutheran Church (South) today rejected the overtures from the bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America upon the subject of Christian unity. The synod spent most of the day in a heated and tangled debate on the subject.

A Bank in Trouble
New York, November 23 — The Ninth Avenue Bank is under examination by the State bank examiners. Some directors say that depositors will be paid in full, but that the directors and stockholders may have to make up a portion of the capital.

The War on the Bucket Shops
Chicago, November 28 — The grand jury decided to look into the management of the bucket shops tomorrow. The subpoenas for witnesses were issued today. Probably a dozen persons will be indicted.

New York, November 23 — 

1887-12-19: u; THE GAZETTE MONTREAL MONDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1881

CANADA AND HER COUSIN
Study of American Life and American Institutions
ANNEXATION TO BE SHUNNED, Material Prosperity Not the Only Basis of Usual Greatness

Canada Fears the Tyranny of Neither Mob Nor Monarch
Evidences of Decay in the Republic

(Written for the Gazette) The people of Canada are a unit in their readiness for a renewal of reciprocal trade relations with the United States whensoever it may please the latter to evince a similar disposition; not so, however, with regard to commercial union, which, for Canada, would mean commercial vassalage first, then political annexation. I am one of those who deprecate the periodic discussion of "the future of Canada" by Canadians; the very raising of the question implies distrust in that future. Is there not a lack of dignity in these intermittent speculations concerning the success of the Dominion, a thing which it were both more muscular and more patriotic to take for granted? These timorous misgivings tend powerfully to precipitate the very catastrophe they prophetically deplore. I heartily wish the question had never been raised; now that it has been raised once more, in shrieking notes, nothing remains but to grapple with it.

Opinion is divided. The vast majority of Canadians would HOLD CANADA TO HER PRESENT HOLDINGS. Realizing her strong position as a wing of the British Empire, grateful for the maternal care and proud of the old flag, their faces are set against secession; their dream is of a steady march to greatness in monarchical solidity on this otherwise unsteady continent. A small minority have visions of independence, independence in the indefinite future, whilst a fragment of the population either longs for annexation, or, with that fierce opponent of "dismemberment," where Ireland is concerned, Mr. Goldwin Smith, at least regard it as the "ultimate destiny" of Canada. Of course, every annexationist is a hot apostle of "commercial union"; I do not say that every advocate of this is an annexationist (consciously). The Monroe Doctrine has not yet quite faded out of Brother Jonathan's inner consciousness. Deep down in his soul still links the complacent conviction that the wings of the great eagle ought to flap over the entire continent. Bellicose extension of these pinions he no longer contemplates; the idea of forcible absorption has made way for that of natural gravitation. For years his policy has been to let Canada severely alone till her desolate isolation should open her eyes to her true interests, till "ultimate destiny," natural selection-like, should "differentiate" her into his embraces. He was mistaken; she still kept sidling off. He cut off reciprocity; the shock would bring her to her senses. Her response is confederation, national policy, Canadian Pacific Railway. Was the fishery aggression (connived in the interest of the same idea)? No matter. These annexationist blunders in self-reliance have been a grand thing for our country, even though they have cast back her "ultimate destiny," making it more sickeningly ultimate than ever it was before. Canada has always shown a neighborly spirit towards the republic, though asserting her rights when assailed with firmness, calmness, and dignity. Perhaps she has evinced too eager a solicitude for more intimate trade relations with her nearest neighbor. Farther than this she cannot go. The latest, the master snare laid for her, is commercial union. "In vain is the net set in the sight of any bird."

The next general election will give this project a great no. Such is my firm belief. And yet the insane idea seems to be spreading somewhat. It has bewitched the man of one standpoint, whose eye is so dazzled with the temple that his ear hears not the moans of the victim on the altar. The American orator has flashed its fascination in our eyes. A few prominent Canadians are amongst its apostles; and a section of the press contends strenuously for the cause. And what does it all mean? It means that five million people shall put themselves in the power of sixty million! It means national humiliation, the admission of failure in the midst of success, a detestable sycophancy, the posture of the mendicant! It means that Ottawa shall take her orders from Washington, and send the shells hiding through London! That a foreign power shall dictate to England's daughter how she shall behave towards her own mother! It means democracy with its evils, from Florida to the Pole, the burial of our highest hopes in the tomb of Monarchy on this continent! And all for what? For a few very problematical intertrade advantages! Is this not madness? The native-born Canadian without a country; what he once fondly called his country, in the dust, betrayed, conquered! How many will vote for this? Again, THE AGITATION IS CAUSELESS. Canada is prosperous. It is an unpatriotic movement, giving the country away in more senses than one. It is an unfortunate occurrence when the Dominion has just gathered herself together and girded her loins for high endeavor. Such is the moment chosen to turn her eyes elsewhere; to seduce her from her noble purpose of self-development; to persuade her she is ill, and should call in Dr. Jonathan; to invite her to surrender much of what she holds most dear for the doubtful advantage of an alliance with a neighbor, whose would be the gain and the glory, hers the disappointment and the shame. And for even this she is expected to stand as a suppliant at the door of the White House! The Republic affects a sublime indifference. She has grand things to give us, but we must receive them hat in hand. But suppose our material interests will be promoted by commercial union or annexation (which I deny), does it follow that such union is desirable? It has been said that "real prosperity is the coveted destiny of a nation." True; but what constitutes "real" prosperity? If this is to be measured by material standards alone, who can deny it to the Republic? Her march to material greatness has been marvelous, much swifter than it would have been under monarchical rule. So far, so good. But here two questions arise which must admit of an affirmative answer, or this material prosperity falls far short of "real prosperity," and shrivels to insignificance: (1) Will it endure? (2) Is it sufficient while it lasts? Only one of the factors of "real prosperity," though important, it is not the chief. Of far profounder significance are those of A MORAL AND POLITICAL COMPLEXION, on the soundness of which depends the permanence of material grandeur itself. Rome was once the synonym for this species of greatness: wealth, luxury, expansion, intellectual vigor, empire; she fell, for her heart was corrupt. The story of all defunct empires is told in a phrase: material greatness, undermined by moral rottenness; civilization of the intellect without civilization of the heart. On this mine sits the Republic. One of her own writers pictures her as "the most corrupt, and, perhaps, the least cultured of the civilized nations." Terrible indictment of democratic tendencies! For this nation is still a child in years. She is not an upgrowth from the deeper depths of humanity as most other nations have been, rising on stepping stones of their dead selves to higher things. She did not, as did her mother, merge by a slow evolution from barbarism to civilization. No! She started in intelligence and integrity on a level with the highest. If fallen from this high estate, what has caused the decline? No barbarous vandal has swooped on her to fling back her civilization. The germs of moral decay are in her constitution. Already is her beauty marred with furrows deep and ineffaceable. A few years ago another American wrote a book entitled "Are we a Nation of Rascals?" in view of the wholesale State repudiations. More than a dozen States had got rid of their debt, to the tune of hundreds of millions, by simply declining to pay! Nor has there been the faintest indication of any national indignation or sense of shame at the nefarious procedure! Is this a symptom of vigorous moral health? Or does it tell of deep-seated disease? Does Canada aspire to be a sharer in this infamy? Of course, all honorable Americans—and they are counted by millions—deplore the existence of facts such as these; but they are powerless to prevent their recurrence. This is the terrible consideration. Herein lies the darkest count against a pure democracy: it smothers its best children. The higher and nobler the class of citizen, the weaker its voice in the affairs of the nation. In the roar of the mob every finer voice is drowned. Is it not notorious that in most of the cities civic robbery is expected as the regulation thing; and endured as inevitable with all the muteness of despair? Does a system of government which both tolerates and engenders such a state of things hold a long lease of life? Manhood suffrage is a sufficient guarantee for the longevity of the evil; but who gives security for that of the nation? Plainly, I have little faith in the final success of this republican experiment; it is beset with perils.

THE AGENCIES OF DECAY ARE AT WORK already. This form of government is favorable to a very flexible expansion and swift development; the oak of permanent empire is of slow growth. A dominant idea in the world today is expressed in the phrase "triumphant democracy." That America has finally and favorably solved and settled the problem of republicanism is taken for granted, and the hallucination has rolled like a tide over the nations, shaking every throne. Most powerfully has it aided that social and political unrest in Europe which threatens extinction to the very name of monarchy. Yet it is merely a chronological mistake. One century of national existence, though attended with the greatest material prosperity, is too short a test. In my opinion, the Republic is only just entering on the gravest portion of its trial. Let us indicate some of its perils. Money is worshipped. In a commonwealth that bestows no titles as a recognition of literary, professional, military, or other merit, what avenue to distinction is left save the accumulation of wealth? The late Dr. Draper, himself an American, treating of the decline and fall of the Roman Empire, significantly remarks that when wealth comes to be the only mark of social distinction, national collapse is not far to seek. The cant of the day sneers at titles; yet the ambition thus crowned may be noble and elevating; the scramble for sufficient money to constitute distinction must be debasing or worse. The demon of greed is abroad, blasting all he touches and making the fevered life scarce worth living. If the "love of money be the root of all evil," its giant adoration as a good must leave small room for good. Manhood suffrage is fulfilling its mission in controlling and corrupting everything; paralyzing law, fattening the demagogue, and stifling the best citizenship. Lynch law, known only in the States, still flourishes, proclaiming its verdict on the efficiency of the courts. How comes it to pass that Judge Lynch cannot breathe the air of Canada, even in her wild western regions? Then, in the Western states and territories, if a man steals a horse, he is sure of lynching; if he shoots down a man, little is thought about it! Probably Mormonism might still flourish in its abominations, unchecked and unchided, had it not threatened to control, over a vast region, the sacred ballot box. Yes, this precious toy, the center and symbol of all human interest, is never out of sight. Year in, year out, the great electoral cauldron boils away; quadrennially boiling over, with its unpleasant fumes. The very air is heavy with politics. To see the names of "candidates" growing in the leaves of the forest would scarce surprise one. There are two things in this Republic: a wild race for money and a blizzard of politics that never blows quite over. What a wretched ideal of the purpose of life!

ANOTHER CHRONIC FEATURE OF SOCIETY is the insubordination of youth, the feebleness of parental authority. Nor does the prevalent ante-natal infanticide tend to establish the nation. Nor the widespread infidelity. Nor the general admiration for "smart." Here is the corrected text:

Villainy, villainy! What is it that draws thither, as to a congenial rendezvous, the outcasts of the nation? The thinness of the line between liberty and license attracts most of these. Convicted of fiendish crimes, they may be led to the scaffold; but it is with a hesitating step and a trembling hand, two to one of the population deprecating their righteous punishment. Are these symptoms of health? No! The Republic is sick. The Negro question is not settled. Emancipation did but open it. Between black and white "there is a deep gulf fixed," and it can never be bridged. In the poor negro's case, education is the avenue to pain. Increase of intelligence means, in his case, higher pretensions and the bitterer disappointment; socially ostracized, even religion hesitates to recognize him as a man! Is there no germ of national peril in this dehumanization of nine million people? Is there no tempest gathering in the black South? The counts in this indictment are dark and damaging. But suppose I let all the preceding go for nothing; two charges remain which, of themselves alone, furnish a CONCLUSIVE ARGUMENT AGAINST ANNEXATION, and therefore against commercial union. The first is the fearful state of the laws relating to marriage and divorce. Remember, we are criticizing a Christian nation, not a district of savagedom. The founder of Christianity allowed but one justification of divorce, all who break this rule being simply adulterers. In the States, any trifling cause is sufficient. Hence, the country abounds in "ladies" of many husbands, and men of many wives. In Chicago alone, the number of applications for divorce each year is about 6,000, most of them successful. Marriage, divested of all its sacredness and solemnity, degraded to the level of a mere civil contract, and "solemnized" by the village blacksmith; marriage, divorced from religion, nods its fitting denouement in the divorce of the married. This disgraceful trifling with marriage is highly immoral and unwise. Marriage makes the family; that is, the foundation stone of the State. If the pillar on which society rests is unsound, some...

Bobcaygeon Independent. A near-sighted man who lives not far from Kingston had never worn or looked through a pair of glasses until a short time ago. One day a peddler called, and among other things, he offered eyeglasses for sale. He persuaded the man to "try on" a pair. After the farmer had adjusted the glasses, he looked at objects in the room with astonishment. Finally, his eyes rested upon his wife. He took a long look at her and then exclaimed: "Jane, Jane, I never would have married you if I had known you were so homely!" Kingston Freeman. CLOUDY WITH SNOW followed by decidedly colder weather. Toronto, Ont., December 21, 1 a.m. A depression, which is now over the Lake district and has moved quickly northeastward from the southwestern States, is causing light snow in Ontario and strong winds in Quebec and the Maritime provinces. The pressure is increasing with fair colder weather. It continues fine and very cold with extremely high pressure in the northwest. The first genuine blizzard of the season has been raging in Dakota all day. A storm of snow as fine as sand, driven by a fierce wind, and accompanied by very low temperatures prevails at Assiniboine, the thermometer indicating 28 below at 5 o'clock this evening. Wichita, Ky., December 20. A blizzard is prevailing and is general over the west. It is thought it has caught the country without an adequate supply of coal. Great suffering and distress are feared. 

18871231: COMMERCIAL UNION. Senator Macdonald's Speech Before the Merchants' Association. Canada Will Not Discriminate Against Great Britain. Objections to the Project. The following is a report of Hon. Senator Macdonald's speech at the Boston banquet: Mr. President and Gentlemen of the Merchants' Association, allow me to say that I esteem it no small honor to be present at this banquet, to exchange with you friendly greetings and to express by the living voice those sentiments of amity and goodwill of which the flags of both nations, wherever they are seen, are the symbols. (Applause.) I am not here, Mr. President, to combat anything that I may have heard with which I do not agree. I am here to give expression to my own sentiments. I am not here as the representative of anybody or any set of men. And I sincerely trust that I shall not give utterance to a single sentiment which I shall not have the satisfaction of knowing is endorsed by the assembly. In the first place, then, I hold it to be the duty of both nations to adopt and to encourage and to perpetuate the largest possible measure of goodwill and reciprocity compatible with existing rights and with national obligations. Now, it may be asked, what do I mean by existing rights? I am not going to talk about free trade. I am not going to talk about a revenue tariff. I have my own opinion upon these subjects, but I am not going to obtrude them here. But upon the question of protection, I may say this: That it is not right to sweep away suddenly by legislative enactment industries that have been fostered and called into life by legislative action. (Great applause.) I may venture further to say, and I am sure I shall not hurt anybody's feelings, because it does not interfere with the matter of protection itself, that overprotecting industries is never a blessing. I am not going to talk about the fisheries. I have an interest in them and you have an interest in them, but they more immediately belong to the Maritime provinces than to us in the West, and it would be unmanly in me, unpatriotic in me, to want to make a bargain for ourselves by making the fisheries in the Maritime provinces an offset. But I am going to say this: whatever the worth of the fisheries may be, though their waters may teem with wealth that is illimitable, the fishes have to be caught and they have to be sold before they yield a profit, and they have to find a profitable market, and the larger the market and the more abundant the market, the better for the fishermen. (Applause.) I take it for granted that the gentlemen appointed to deal with this matter are worthy of confidence. They will doubtless consider precedents. They will doubtless take up the act. I will simply say this: I would refer them to one precedent. There is a book in which everything noble and lofty and heroic and unselfish is to be found. That book contains everything to guide the individual, the family, and the state. I can give them a parallel case, perhaps the closest parallel that can be found in the whole range of history. It is the story of an old man and his nephew. By the very force of circumstances, their herdsmen had begun to rub uncomfortably against one another. There arose a big strife. How was it cured? It was cured by the unselfish and noble conduct of the old man, who said: "Let there be no strife between me and thee, and between my herdsmen and thy herdsmen, for we be brethren." I should change the figure a little and personify the nations. In that case, it was a question of boundaries, and in this case, it is a question of the three-mile limit. And I would say: "Let there be no strife between thee and me and between my fishermen and thy fishermen, for we are brethren." (Great applause.) I have spoken to you in regard to national obligations. Perhaps you will ask me what I mean by national obligations. I understand, for example, that commercial union means discrimination against Great Britain. In my former remarks, I said, "the widest possible measure of unrestricted reciprocity compatible with existing interests and national obligations." What do I mean by national obligations? I will tell you. I stood today in one of the noblest buildings that is in the possession of any nation. I stood today in Memorial Hall; and from the walls, I saw looking down upon me the handsome faces of young men who gave their lives for their country. I went into the hall, and I saw that the building was erected in memory of the brave young men who fell to perpetuate liberty. That is what I understand to be national obligation, from your standpoint; and when all the records of the corporations that have come into existence, and all their wealth shall have perished, the history of these heroic men will remain and will be handed down to your children as a heritage of which your children will be proud. You ask me what do I mean by national obligation to Canada? Why, I simply mean this: That while there is a desire for the largest measure of reciprocity with you, I tell you that no system that points to discrimination against Great Britain will ever succeed. You cannot expect, when you do all that you have done for union, that there is no union sentiment with us. You cannot expect that you will do everything to serve the best interests of your nation and that we will not guard against anything that would let in the wedge ever so slightly that might ultimately lead to a separation from the mother country. Let me tell you that the Board of Trade in Toronto occupies the very same position that you occupy here. Let me tell you what their position is upon this great question as expressed in a series of resolutions adopted by them: "We disapprove of any proposal to discriminate against Great Britain, whose protection we enjoy and under whose fostering care we have grown to the enviable position that we now occupy among the people of the world."

INTERNATIONAL COMPETITION. The Disaster that Would Attend a Policy of Non-intercourse (St. Paul Pioneer Press). The Kansas City Times dealt quite as sharply as did the Pioneer Press with the plea of Mr. Joseph Nimmo, Jr., for protection to American railroads at the expense of the American shipper. The criticisms that have been made upon the argument of the question in these columns ignore, precisely as Mr. Nimmo does, the fundamental fact that the interests of the shippers of this country are superior to the interests of the transcontinental roads. It is, of course, apparent that the competition of the Canadian Pacific is one hard to meet, because of the heavy money subsidies made to that road by the Dominion Government. But there are some other facts that appear to be forgotten. What are the circumstances on this side? The first transcontinental roads in this country were subsidized as heavily by guarantees of the people of the United States. If they had taken that assistance honestly, if they had run their roads for the benefit of the public, if they had applied their profits to the extinguishment of obligations, if no dollar of earnings had been misapplied or privately appropriated, those early roads would be in a position today to laugh at the efforts of the Canadian Pacific, or any other line, to compete with them. What was their first competitor? The Northern Pacific, a road which did not receive a dollar of public money directly, but was aided only by a liberal land grant. It might have been argued quite as reasonably that the Northern Pacific could not compete for trade with the Union and Central Pacific, and that shippers should be prohibited from sending their freight over the latter line until the roads had gotten upon their legs. The fact shows that the Northern Pacific was abundantly able to take care of itself. Looking a little farther, we discover another line, built from St. Paul to Helena, and thus coming into the field for a share of the business. It has been built wholly by private capital, without either money subsidy or public land grant. Yet we hear nothing of a proposal to Congress to pass a law prohibiting the St. Paul, Minneapolis & Manitoba from carrying through freights to Helena, except at such rates as the Northern Pacific may prescribe, nor any desire on the part of either competitor for anything but a fair race for business. As to the shipper, we need not ask him what he would think of any regulation or device that prevented him from getting the benefit of the lowest rates afforded by competition. As we have already seen, the transcontinental roads have already reached an agreement, including the Canadian Pacific, which not only enables them to maintain rates, but to buy off the Pacific Mail for an immense monthly subsidy. And they are fully protected against the effects of Canadian cut rates by the ruling of the interstate commission, permitting them, in such case, to charge higher rates for the short haul than for the long. They are getting along all right. It is the "forgotten man," the shipper of freight, who gets out of the situation what benefit there is in it. It is he who would suffer by a policy of non-intercourse that would include not only...

--- 

Please let me know if you need further assistance! Here is the corrected text:

---

be Canadian transcontinental line, but the roads which help to make low rates between Northwestern lake points and the ports of the Atlantic seaboard, and the lines over which the people of the Northwest have just established, by immense expenditure and notable enterprise, an independent line to the East by way of Sault Ste. Marie. The advocates of protection to railroads at the cost of the public are likely to run into a healthy Northwestern blizzard.

18880113: IOASA VT DAY With Decided Mixture of Weather Promised It Toronto, Ont., January 13, 1888, 1 a.m. Since last night the high pressure has moved eastward to the Lower St. Lawrence valley and the New England states, and the storm which was over the Northwest territories has moved toward the Lake region. The weather has continued fair and cold in eastern Canada, while in Ontario the temperature has been rising with strong easterly winds. A northwesterly blizzard has prevailed throughout our Northwest territories. Upper St. Lawrence: Strong winds and gales from southeast and southwest; milder cloudy weather with snow, turning to sleet or rain, followed this evening or tonight by west to northwest winds and decidedly colder weather. A TERRIBLE BLIZZARD Osakis, Wis., January 12. A blizzard set in about 3 o'clock this afternoon and threatens to seriously interfere with the railroads. At Muscatine, IA, the worst blizzard of the season is raging, and at Sioux City, IA, the same report is made. No trains are arriving at or leaving the latter place. St. Paul, Minn., January 12. The worst snow and wind storm of the season prevailed in the Northwest today. Railroad travel is badly crippled. At Huron, Dak., the wind is blowing fifty miles an hour. The air is so full of snow that one is unable to see fifty feet at any time. Some unthinking teachers dismissed young school children, some of whom have to go four or five blocks across the open land. Five or six children got lost. Whistles are blowing, bells are ringing, and people turned out and took long ropes and walked fifteen or twenty abreast back and forth over the ground. They have just found two; the other not yet having been discovered. The mercury is 4 below zero, and has fallen 28 degrees since 10 o'clock. In St. Paul, the parade and other ceremonies attending the laying of the cornerstone of the third Ice Palace were postponed to Saturday. Winnipeg, January 12. This has been the stormiest day of the season, a terrible blizzard raging, and railway travel is greatly impeded. 

Impecunious man: "I wish you would be so kind as to lend me $5. I'll pay you back in a few days." Candid friend: "If you had asked me for the loan in a candid and straightforward manner, I would have lent you the money, but asking me in the way you did causes me to distrust you." "I don't understand you." "You asked me to be so kind as to lend you $5." "Yes." "If you had been candid, you would have said to me: 'Be so stupid, be so ignominious an ass, such a hopeless idiot, as to lend me $5,' and you ought to have got it." 

The Lieutenant-Governor's Speech: The Harrison Government Not Attacked in the House, But Receives a Bad Blow by Bye-Election. Winnipeg, January 12. There was a more than usually large crowd at the opening of the legislature today, notwithstanding that a severe blizzard was raging. Lieutenant-Governor Aikens read the following speech from the throne: "I have much pleasure in meeting you at the opening of the second session of the sixth Legislature of the province of Manitoba. I have to congratulate you on the abundant harvest of the past season, which has far exceeded the expectations of the agriculturists of the province. Returns so far made to the Department of Agriculture show that the total yield of wheat alone throughout the Province will exceed 12,000,000 bushels of excellent quality, besides large returns of other cereals. This result must prove very beneficial to all classes in the community and is a cause of gratitude to the Giver of all good, for so many blessings bestowed on the labors of the husbandman. During the past year, vigorous efforts have been made to bring to the notice of the agricultural classes of the eastern provinces and the older markets, the various advantages Manitoba offers to industrious tillers of the soil, and it is pleasing to know that the result has been to induce large numbers to look in this direction for future homes."
