Hogs: The demand for hogs was quiet and the market was steady, business being of a small jobbing character. We quote $7.50 a $7.75 per 100 lbs.

Ashes: There was no change in ashes, the market being quiet and steady. We quote first pots $4.25 a $4.30, pearls $7.30, and second do $3.00 per 100 lbs.

Eggs: The egg market opened strong under a good demand, and in the forenoon mostly all the offerings were taken at an advance of 1¢ at 18¢ cash. Later in the day, supply became very light, and buyers could not fill their wants, and the market ruled much stronger and active with some sales at 20¢, but later in the afternoon the receipts were larger and the market eased off, closing sales being made at 18¢ a 20¢ per dozen.

In another column, we reprint an article from the Toronto Canadian Grocer, together with extracts from the Toronto Empire on the same subject.

Butter: There was nothing of interest in the butter market, business being quiet and confined to local wants at unchanged prices. The New York Commercial Bulletin says: The delayed stock of butter began to come in rapidly early in the week, and though demand was considerably interfered with by the blockades of snow in the streets, making trucking so difficult, still most of the local trade had run down very close, and the outlet was about enough to take the increased supply promptly and freely sustain the higher prices established last week. As the snow disappeared, the demand increased, and an active call came from out-of-town points, mostly for under grades, from 25¢ down, which relieved the market of most of the accumulations of both fresh and held stock. For a day or two past, the movement in fine grades has been moderate, and with the bulk of current supply being of such quality, there has been a little surplus, and the tone is weaker on grades from 27¢ to 28¢ up to 32¢. In fact, the latter has become extreme for Elgin and Pennsylvania, and 30¢ for other Western, but anything from 26¢ to 29¢ down is in light supply and held firmly and with confidence. State dairy new tubs ruled firm at 30¢ early in the week, but that is extreme at the close, though good quality sells readily. In the Western packings, all grades have been in moderate supply, good demand, and firm.

Creamery Townships: Morrisburg 19, Brockville 17, Western 17.

Cheese: Cheese continued quiet but firm, with the market unchanged. Cable 50s50s. The New York Commercial Bulletin of today's date says: "Cheese does not appear to have suffered any damage from the blizzard, but on the contrary, since the enforced rest of last week, the market has steadily gained both in the volume of trade and strength of values. Indeed, there is a positive recovery in price, established through actual sales, and the gain seems to be very well supported thus far, though a noticeable tendency to assume a mildly excited and buoyant position in some quarters is rather overdrawing matters and calculated to mislead. The business transacted has been of a very general character, commencing down among the Pennsylvania skims and running up through the State whole and part skims, and then into full cream stocks, with a great many of the latter costing from 10¼ to 11½¢ taken by exporters, who have also ventured to a moderate extent among the fancies, for which they made further bids. A great deal of the fancy stock, however, has simply changed hands between dealers, with one or two lots supposed to have been absorbed as a protective measure until the new owners' tone became convinced that quotations should be marked up to conform to what they ask. The regular spring game has in fact set in, and variable ideas of value even on specific grades may be expected until cheese has all sold out. The actual distribution on home account has been growing, but the principal feature of encouragement was the increased amounts handled by exporters. There does not appear to have been anything new to start up trade except a run of orders of larger volume than usual, though some dealers have been approached with more or less frequency, suggesting the propriety of consigning parcels of colored stock, but few, if any, consented. White cheese is in very small compass, and if the current belief that two or three shippers are anxious to get some of it holds, the chances are in favor of pretty high rates. At the close, the general feeling appears quite firm and cheerful, with holders in better humor than for some time past. Advices at hand indicate that nearly all factories in Western New York and many in the central section of the State have commenced work. The exports now indicated are 11,000 boxes, of which 4,500 are through "c c."

Finest September and October 10¢ & 11½¢. Fine 10¢ & 10½¢. Finest August 10¼¢. Fine 10¢. Medium 8¢.

THE EASTERN MARKET

1888-03-29: JESS There was a good demand for eggs, and the market was active, with a good business doing. The offerings were fair and prices were steady at 20¢ a 21¢ per dozen.

Butter: There has been no change in the character of the butter market, which has remained quiet, with trade limited to local wants. Finest table goods have a fair sale, but low grades are easy. 

Creamery Townships: Morrisburg 19, Brockville 17, Western 17.

Cheese: Cheese has a quiet but firm tone, and practically speaking, the whole interest of trade is centered on the other side, there being little stock left for sale here. The New York Commercial Bulletin says: "Fancy white in particular shows up stiff on value, aided by a fractional advance in the cable quotation and an apparent desire on the part of most holders to reserve their supplies for domestic use. Advices at hand by mail indicate an awakening of interest among some of the out-of-town customers, as a result of the recent advance; and this, it is hoped, will lead to a better trade at no distant date."

The Dairy Markets: The cheese market did not experience any bad results from the recent blizzard. On the contrary, the enforced quiet seemed to give a swing to the trade both in volume and prices. The amounts handled by exporters increased considerably, and the chances appear to be in favor of a good advance in prices. Nearly all of the factories in western New York commenced work last week, and many of those in the central section. One New York house took 2,500 boxes last week, an approximating amount including 1,700 boxes of colored, and a third is credited with 1,500 boxes. As all these buyers are large jobbers and not given to investing unless they have good assurance that trade will warrant it, the market looks very favorable on all accounts. The higher prices established in butter were freely sustained last week. The firmer grades are not in good demand, however, as stock from 25¢ to 26¢, which sells very readily. Thirty-two cents has become extreme for Elgin. New dairy tubs were firm at 30¢ at the beginning of the week, but at the close the price was extreme. The following is the usual table of cheese quotations: 

Receipts: Exp 11,510 March 27, March 20, March 23, 1880 13,024 1887 11,1888 11,970. Price, 12¢. 

Cable 50s (3s, 50s col, 50s wh). March 27, 1880, March 20, 1887, March 25, 1888. 

Cheese is again a subject of interest here, as it is in all cheese sections. Factory men and cheese buyers are discussing the probabilities of the opening of the market, which will soon occur here. It is the general opinion that prices will not start as high as they did last year. For the corresponding day last year, one small lot of cheese was delivered here, but no price was fixed upon it. On April 4, the Hasenelver factory sold a lot of 30 boxes of full cream cheese at 13¢. Some believe that prices this year will start at least 2¢ lower for the same grade of goods. Probably three-fourths of the factories are now in operation, and nearly all are receiving milk once a day. By the first of April, all will be in operation. We learn of resales of the late fall cheese here during the past week, by dealers, of about 450 boxes, at 11½¢ a 12¢.

Utica Herald

1888-03-31: N.Y., March 30. The Marietta Final Home of this city summarizes its crop reports from all sections of the country as follows: Winter wheat is in the most backward condition of any spring in the past five years. During February and March, this belt has had ample surface rains, but very general lack of sunshine. March has been a general disappointment to farmers, and practically no farm work has been done. In Dakota, there will be less spring wheat sown than usual, although in northern Dakota, the ground is in fair condition. Minnesota has had severe blizzards, and with the most favorable weather, spring seeding will be very late. The trying March weather has also lightened the prospects of the anticipated large average of oats. Last year, the bulk of the crop was seeded at this date, while this year nothing has been done. Further backward weather will tend to greatly cut the crop of oats short. In California, seeding is practically over, and conditions are generally good. Texas has had abundant rains, and promises the finest crop of winter wheat in her history. In Tennessee and Kentucky, the promising crop has been seriously injured by the Minnesota blizzard. The same is true, only more so, in the wheat centers of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois. Michigan has been more protected by snow, and in Kansas, the prospect is good. Crops are suffering only from lack of reserves of moisture. Missouri promises a fair average crop. Canada has been well protected, and her present condition is all that could be desired.

1888-04-02: LIT I US. We’ll Need Them In Summer. Let us gather up the blizzards as they howl around our door; let us pack away the snow drifts that now dot the landscape o'er. Fill this bottle full of the zero that now cuts us like a knife, for we'll need it all next summer when it's ninety in the shade.

Barber (to customer): Do you want a bottle of my Paradise Hair Elixir? 
Customer: No, I see you've got a parrot in the window; can it talk? 
Barber (proudly): Oh, yes, sir; I wouldn't take big money for that bird. (To parrot) Polly, brace up and say something. 
Polly (bracing up with some dignity): Shoot the Elixir!

New York Sun. 

Police Judge: Young man, you are charged with vagrancy. 
Defendant: Yes, and it's an outrage! I'm merely out of employment, after having worked on some of the best papers in the country. 
Judge: Oh, you're a newspaper man, eh? 
Defendant: No, sir, I'm a journalist.

A Final Opinion: 
Old Man (to daughter): Clara, I discovered Nero Mug dead in the yard this morning. 
Daughter: I am very sorry, papa, but I cannot help it. You know very well that young Mr. Harvard was coming to see me last night, and you should have tied the dog out of his way.

The Punch

Policeman: "I arrested him on suspicion, yer honor. He's a newspaper reporter, and displayed a $5 bill on Monday morning." 

The Rotary

The rotary snow plough, which was recently placed on the Huntingdon and Dakota road, is now clearing the line. It was started out at five o'clock yesterday morning with a crew under the charge of Zach Cowles, superintendent of rotary power of the Milwaukee system. The company is so well pleased with the rotary plough that each division of the road will be provided with one next winter. This one, which was the eleventh and last one made last summer, cost the Milwaukee company $15,000, and it is calculated that it has already paid for itself by the work done in half a dozen or so trips over the division. The plough reached Bird Island at one o'clock yesterday afternoon. There was no interruption to the splendid time made to that point. The drifts were not quite so heavy as had been expected. At very many places between Glencoe and Bird Island the drifts were five and six feet high, and several hundred feet long, but these did not tax the capacity of the wheel. The snow was light, however. The rotary is quite a stupendous affair, weighing fifty-three tons, with two gauges of water in the boilers. The boilers are made to stand 175 pounds of steam. The front wheel is nine feet in diameter and cuts an opening of thirteen feet. The snow is thrown from 25 to 100 feet. 

St. Paul Pioneer Press

The Five Hundred

Young Ah Cum led us first to the temple of Five Hundred Genii, and followed by some sixty ragged and dirty boys, who seemed to have sprung out of the paving stones at the gateway, we went through a stone-paved court and into the lofty chamber of the temple. The Five Hundred were all there, sitting in a gilded row around the wall and on long cross pieces extending into the middle space. At one end of the room was a railed altar space with a gilded image of the Emperor Kien Lung in a gilded shrine, with candles, paper flowers, and smouldering incense sticks set before him. A horrible priest, with hard round eyes rolling from side to side craftily, like a beast of prey, an unpleasant smile that disclosed a double row of ferocious-looking white teeth, and a stealthy, cat-like tread, with pauses in it like something crouching for a spring, presided over the altar. There was the same creepy feeling and fascination in watching him as in watching snakes in a museum. One drew back when the priest came near, and if he had touched one of us, we were all agreed that we would have to shriek, except one brave tourist, who threatened to break his umbrella in self-defense first. Our guide was exact and conscientious, and he insisted upon marching us around the temple until we had faced every one of the Five Hundred, many of whom had whiskers and hair of bright Prussian blue. One wears a black sailor hat and passes as the image of Marco Polo, but without the least authority, scholars say. This temple is the place of worship of the Flowery Forest Monastery, but the forest was not visible, and the one cut-like, tigerish, snaky-eyed priest was the only one of the brotherhood visible.

St. Louis Globe-Democrat 

How to Gain Flesh and Strength

Use after each meal Scott's Emulsion; it is as palatable as milk. Delicate people improve rapidly upon its use. For consumption, throat affections, and bronchitis, it is unequaled. Dr. Thomas Prim, Ala., says: "I used Scott's Emulsion on a child eight months old; he gained four pounds in a month." Put up in 50c and $1 size. 

Gen. John C. Fremont once gave some good advice as to the course to be pursued by a candidate for public office. This was to "shut his mouth and throw away his pen." 

Toronto, April 2, 1 a.m. 

Since Saturday night an area of depression has moved from the southwest States to the southern part of the Lake region, causing in Western Canada easterly winds and cool threatening weather. In the Maritime provinces, the weather has been fine and pleasant; in the Northwest, it continues cold, and in Manitoba, there has been a heavy fall of snow. 

St. Lawrence, Piper and Lower Strong: east to north winds; cloudy and cool with light snow. 

MONTREAL'S RECORD 

Observations taken at McGill College Observatory 

March 31 

Wind, p.m. 3:00 
Weather: Clear 

1888-04-04: 

D. Fauquier, who had been admitted to Holy Orders in 1840 by Bishop Strachan, held for twenty-eight years the incumbency of West Zorra. Bishop Fauquier was consecrated on the 28th of October, 1873, and labored earnestly and successfully until his death in December, 1881. That event, which came upon his clergy and people with startling suddenness, left the scattered missions of the vast diocese without a head. The interval between the loss of the deeply regretted Dr. Fauquier and the acceptance of the charge by Bishop Sullivan was a time of suspense and trial. The Rev. Mr. Wilson did all that experience and zeal could prompt to make up for the deficiency, but even he was beginning to despair when Dr. Sullivan undertook the task of continuing Dr. Fauquier's work. He entered on his labors in 1882, and what progress has been made since then, those who have read his printed reports or who have heard accounts of that great mission field from his own lips have not to be informed. But it is impossible for missions, any more than any other enterprise, to succeed without money, and the lack of pecuniary support has been all along the main drawback to the progress of Algoma. We have the Bishop's own testimony to the liberality of the church people of the diocese. They are not, as a rule, wealthy, but they contribute as much as their circumstances permit them to do. 

It is the other dioceses, the well-to-do dioceses that... I have failed to do their duty. So firmly convinced is Dr. Sullivan of their laxness that he does not hesitate to charge them with lack of interest in missions, as compared with the members of other churches. It is for them to consider whether they have left themselves open to such a charge or have really done all in their power. In the latter case, no more can be expected of them, and the missionary diocese of Algoma must be pronounced a failure. Need we say that such a result of fifteen years' struggle would not be to the credit of the Church of England in Canada? We have again and again pointed out the connection between missions and colonization, and how much the success of the latter depends upon the generous support of the former. The Anglican Church of the ecclesiastical province of Canada is bound by solemn engagement to act fairly by Bishop Sullivan and his diocese. It is to be hoped, then, for many reasons, that His Lordship's appeal will not have been made in vain.

A very serious crisis has been averted in the United States by the action of the railroad operatives yesterday in resolving to forego their intention of striking on all railroads handling cars or freight from the Burlington & Quincy line. Though it looks much like a backdown on the part of the men, and no doubt required a good deal of moral courage, the course they have adopted is the best, especially for the laboring classes, whose loss from the disorganization of the business of the country from even a week's continuance of such a struggle as was spoken of would have been of such overwhelming extent as to a hundred times over offset the gain of the locked-out men on the Burlington road, even if success had rewarded their sacrifices. The lessons of recent great strikes are evidently having their effect.

The Winnipeggers must have something to agitate about. The Hudson River Valley matter is hardly settled before there begin to appear signs that the next thing there will be a newspaper blizzard over the Hudson's Bay railroad, coupled with all sorts of demands upon the governments, federal and provincial. The history of that road is the evidence of Winnipeg's instability of purpose. About two years ago there was a craze on for a short northern route to Europe. The contract was given out—there is always a contract in view when Winnipeg is excited—and within a couple of months some forty miles of roadbed were constructed parallel, most of it, to an existing line. And there it was left, and yet remains, never having been operated. The coming agitation will perhaps see trains started on it, and then will come a switch off to some other excitement.

There is every probability that Russian intrigue is at its most active stage just now in Romania, and that the ministerial crisis, resulting in Mr. M. Cristian's resignation, within three weeks after the formation of his cabinet and within a few days after a strong vote of confidence, was due to that influence. The treaty of alliance concluded with Austria is a rebuff which the Czar is not likely to endure with patience. The enmity of Romania would be a serious obstacle to Russian success in case of war. In 1877, but for the assistance of the little Roumanian army, the Russian invaders would have been virtually destroyed by the forces of the Sultan. The alliance of King Charles is, therefore, of grave moment to the Czar, in case of war, which is, as the Bulgarian question now stands, unhappily only too possible. For this reason, Muscovite agents will naturally halt at no measure that may defeat the anti-Russian party in the Romanian kingdom, and that they are busily at work at the present moment is almost certain.

Our Newfoundland correspondent's letter today discusses the prospect of the confederation proposal in the island colony. The condition of the people is depleted, their feeling towards the sea described, and the forces working for and against it detailed. It is quite evident there will be a powerful opposition to Confederation, even if the terms are made much more advantageous than the interests of the Dominion can warrant. The mercantile railway would fight anything that was likely to affect their control of the island's markets, are arrayed against it and will exert a great force in the contest at the polls that will decide the matter. They have also the assistance of a number of public men, some of them members of the government. In favor of the scheme are men foremost on both sides of politics—the fact that the country under present conditions is not prospering, and the desire to get rid of the French shore difficulty, which Canada should insist on being settled before assuming responsibility for the government of the colony. The struggle will evidently be a hard one, though our correspondent thinks it will end in the defeat of the antis.

Although for obvious reasons, several of the European governments thought it their duty to decline an invitation, the acceptance of which might be construed into an unqualified approval of the French Revolution, it is not for that reason to be concluded that the nations of Europe will refrain from participation in the exhibition. In Great Britain, it appears that preparations are being steadily pushed on by leading manufacturing and mercantile firms for due representation at Paris next year. The Times some time ago pointed out that the refusal of the government to take action furnished all the more reason for a display of zeal and energy on the part of private persons. A meeting was held at the Mansion House about a fortnight since, with the object of effecting such organization as may be necessary to secure a creditable illustration of England's industrial skill and progress. It would be very do, the Times urges, for Birmingham, Sheffield, Manchester, Leeds, and the other manufacturing towns of England to make no figure on an occasion when Lyons, Liege, Rouen, and other industrial centers of the continent will be showing to advantage. Belgium is also making similar preparations to be fully represented.

There having been a report that certain foreign nationals had settled in Cork and had been persecuted by some of the artisans of that city, the mayor of Cork, Mr. John O'Brien, has written to the Times to contradict the statement. He acknowledges that, at a time when work is scarce and many are suffering from want, the feeling prevails that it is hard for workingmen to have, as they think, the bread taken out of their mouths by the immigration of a number of refugees. But he denies, in strong terms, that the Jews in question were molested in Cork. Dissatisfaction prevailed at the attempt to introduce convict labor, but the foreigners who had headed that movement were not of the Jewish faith. The wanderers who had been driven to the shores of Ireland by ill treatment in their native country had the sympathy of the Irish people, so many of whom know what it was to suffer hardship and to be strangers in a strange land. Mr. O'Brien thought, however, that it would have been more judicious if the influential leaders of the Jewish community in London, the most powerful body for its numbers in the world, had diverted their coreligionists from trying their fortunes in a country like Ireland which had difficulty enough to maintain its own population.

The Rutherford people who have adopted resolutions against the formation of the territories into provinces are unquestionably in the right, though we believe there is no present intention of taking such a step. Our system of ministries responsible to the legislature is much too cumbersome and costly in its operation for such small populations as it would be applied to in the Northwest for years to come. The less complicated and costly the government machinery provided, the better. Representative institutions as we have them in Canada are ill-suited for small populations. They give a fictitious importance to the position of those who administer the government, and create an unhealthy competition for place that leads to such agitations as that conducted by the Farmers' Union in Manitoba a few years ago and later by the Hudson's Bay and Red River railroad contract seekers. They create a semblance of political party division when no ground for them exists in anything pertaining to the country and so cause a waste of public energy that might be better employed. This has been the experience in the past, and to avoid it in the future it might be a wise course to definitely fix the number of inhabitants a territory should possess before it was raised to the rank of a province, and the number should not be a small one either. Such a course might prevent much future misunderstanding.

M. Corriely has prophesied peril to France through the vote that the Republic has marked out for General Boulanger. He reminds his readers that he raised his voice against that demagogue of the charioteers two years ago, when Republicans were applauding him. He warned them that they had entered on the path of danger but they would not listen. He told them that Boulanger was a general of the circus, a warrior of the streets, a soldier of the mob, and that he would one day cause them trouble. But they laughed in his face. They gave Boulanger carte blanche to defy all authority and discipline, to set duty at naught as an obsolete tradition, and he did so and became the idol of the multitude. Now they have harshly rebuked him and the insurrectionists cry out "treason!" In vain the Opportunists retort that Logerot did right in putting down a soldier in command who had taught and practiced insubordination. "We are on the side of the national defense, and Boulanger is its champion," says one faction. "We are the advocates of military discipline," says the other faction, "and Boulanger was ruining it." But it is for that only reason that he is the darling of the mob, and M. Corriely, little as he likes or respects him, is forced to believe that Boulanger's future is assured. He is the necessary product of a system which introduced politics into the army. Ten years ago the army was an army of soldiers who knew how to obey, of officers who knew how both to obey and to command. An outcry was raised by the populace because it was not Republican enough, and an induced legislature yielded to the outcry. The discipline was contemned, and now those who continued it are asking for sympathy from the people in their onslaught against the man who did their bidding. But it is too late! That man has got to be the bridge of them.

18880406: G. Kust, of Putney, on Thames or Tyne, for £100 a side. Of all the English prophets, Pegasus, of the News of the World, alone gave Veracity to win the Lincolnshire handicap. Oliver Wendell Holmes once made famous the great jockey and rider Build Doble by referring to him as the man with the cold-in-the-head nickname. Sporting Life calls the Brooklyns the "bridegroom team." That name will stick to it all season. Terry, Silch, Caruthers, and Smith were all recently married. The Harvard faculty has absolutely refused to consider any petition from graduates in regard to allowing the Harvard University nine to play against professionals. The New York Mail and Express says: "Oarsmen in this city are willing to bet dollars to cents that Hill Hill will defeat Peter Kemp for the championship on May 15." The Hamilton management are soliciting the business people, who announce the results of games upon bulletin boards, to withhold the same hereafter until the games terminate. The family troubles of Al Latham, the Brown's third baseman, have again come to the surface. This time he charges Mrs. La Garvin, his divorced wife, with stealing his diamond pin. It is announced that as soon as the weather shall be sufficiently settled, Mr. Haggins will send from his ranch in California about 100 head of thoroughbred horses to New York to be sold at auction. Of the sixteen living trotting stallions with records of 2:10 or better, four are now located near Lexington, KY: Jeroma Turner, 2:10; Bonnie McGregor, 2:10; Robert McGregor, 2:17; and Duquesne, 2:17. We are informed that the eldest son of the late... Here is the corrected text:

---

Hon. George Brown, who is attending Cambridge University, was a member of the rowing crew which defeated Oxford. The Canadian did it! The New York Athletic Club thinks it has made a big step in securing William Farmer and Charles H. Sherrill, the two Yale champions, as members. The club will be represented by them in all the games this season. "Just why some clubs are making such efforts to get left-handed pitchers puzzles me," said Captain Hanlon. "For my part, I would sooner have a good right-hand man, as he will outlast the other every time." So confident are many of the league pitchers that this is going to be the pitchers' year and that there will be little batting done, that some of them are making wagers that few batsmen will reach 100 at the end of the season. Some of the members of the Hamilton Bicycle Club, accompanied by members of the Cricket Association, visited the cricket grounds on Saturday and had a surveyor go over the proposed asphalt track. It is almost certain now that the track will be built at a cost of about $1,000. Hamilton. The "Spider" looks like a millionaire coal mine owner with a fondness for horses and sports in general. Last night he wore his "new sporty-looking" shirt with red, white, and blue stripes, a fur-trimmed overcoat (which is so popular in the height of the blizzards), striped, skin-tight trousers, and a pair of patent shoes. 

A Forktown admirer of Mickey Jones, Hamilton's left-handed twirler, says: "Begorra, ye can talk about yer Johnny Wards and yer Mike Kellys, and all them other big 'uns, but that boy Mickey Jones is a daisy and no mistake. He can run around that square more times, throw more balls, and put out more men than any one of them. Mark that!" 

Mail: George A. Leitner, of last year's Indianapolis club, graduated as an M.D. last week. He was second in a class of 144 from Bellevue Hospital. The same week he was a successful applicant for the position of assistant physician at St. Francis Hospital, New York City. Leitner has received some fine offers to pitch this season, but this appointment prevents him from playing ball.

18880407: II. Small, Ottawa, was read. It dealt with the various theories accounting for this phenomenon, leaning to that which supposes it due to meteoric matter in the space between the sun and the earth's orbit. President Smith communicated two papers. One, written in answer to an inquiry put by a member at a former meeting, briefly explained "The Cause of Blizzards in the American Northwest," and showed why the Canadian territories were usually exempt from their disastrous fury. The second paper dealt at length with "Chaldean Astronomy and its Connection with Modern Symbolism," and illustrated the origin of many popular superstitions and customs connected with the existing calendar, besides explaining the probable origin of the symbols now used in astronomy.

Yesterday the contracts for the various works were let, the successful firms being: Masonry, including stonework, brickwork, and plastering, Peter I. Yull; woodwork, Simpson & Peel; ironwork, H...

18880409: "A MIDNIGHT RUN" Serious Fire in Rev. Smythe's Residence This Morning. An alarm was sounded at 12:30 this morning from box 50, corner of Fulford and Coursol streets, for a fire which broke out in the residence of Rev. Dr. Smythe, 387 St. Antoine street, caused by a lamp having exploded in the study, where that gentleman was reading at the time. Reels from 6, 10, and 12 were quickly upon the spot, and after an hour's dexterous work the fire was extinguished, but not before damage was done to the extent of about $1,000, it is estimated. All the furniture in the study, together with a large collection of books in the library, besides some valuable sermons, were destroyed. Dr. Smythe had his hands and head burnt. Seven covers were used by the Salvage Corps in saving the remainder of the furniture, which was insured, but it is not yet known if the house was also insured. 

A THESPIAN QUEEN GONE: Miss Lilian Olcott Dies Suddenly in a New York Hotel. New York, April 8. Lilian Olcott, the well-known actress, died at the Westminster Hotel at 10 o'clock this morning, of inflammation of the bowels. She engaged a room at the hotel about two weeks ago, and on Wednesday last called in a physician, to whom she said that she was suffering from a cold contracted during the blizzard. On Thursday she was feeling better, but yesterday her illness took an unfavorable turn and she sank rapidly. Her maid was her only companion at the hotel, and she asked the physician not to announce her illness to her parents lest it might worry them. Miss Olcott's father, Dr. Olcott, of Brooklyn, was promptly notified of his daughter's death, and with his wife came to the hotel. The body was removed to Dr. Olcott's residence in Brooklyn.

18880410: L. Weston shows two small pictures: "Evening Montreal Harbor" (137), both of them delicately executed and little gems in their way. They are both well worth inspection and much more than a passing glance. "A Blizzard" (107) by Miss Lida H. Lumb is a representation of the blinding snows beating about a country residence. It is realistically done. "A Study of Lilacs" (127) by Miss Zuleika M. Lambe is an ambitious coloring and it is successful. The leaves are very cleverly drawn and the colors artistically contrasted. It is creditable.

18880412: W. Horn, Newport, are registered at the Balmoral. Miscellaneous Items: Robinson Brown says that you owe him $15. Duniley (indignantly): "I do not owe Brown a cent! I did owe him $15, but the debt became outlawed last week. Any man who will lie like he does ought not to be trusted." 

A Rockland man who owned a cow made a bargain with a butcher to kill and sell it on commission. It so happened that the first offer the butcher received for the meat was from the owner of the cow, who did not recognize the carcass. Three-quarters of the meat was sold to him for five cents a pound, and he afterward sold it again at a small profit. The next day he bought the remaining quarter, beating the accommodating butcher down on his price, and sold that quarter for a small profit. When he settled with the butcher for his own cow, he was indignant that the meat man sold it so cheap and was dumbfounded when he heard that he himself was the purchaser. Rockland (Me.) Courier-Gazette. A gentleman was in town last week whose wits stood him in good stead during the blizzard. He was snow-bound at Osontn, N...

18880414: COMMUNICATIONS: LEGISLATION AND RAILWAY BRAKES. To the Editor of the Gazette: On the subject of protection to railway employees and the second reading of the bill at Ottawa, Mr. Shanly suggests that the Westinghouse brake should be adopted in all freight and passenger cars in Canada. Where is our National Policy and its benefit to patentees and manufacturers when we are asked to give a monopoly to a foreign company for an article which can be had here of a superior description and much more effective in its action? I do not depreciate the value of the Westinghouse brake in its own place, but I smile at its action when the thermometer is down among the thirties in a drifting blizzard or snowstorm. At less than a fifth of the cost of the Westinghouse, a train can be fitted with a much more simple and effective automatic brake, the work of our own country, and already patented here and in the States. Among its many superior qualities are: No steam, no rubber couplings; brakes can be applied from any part of the train or by the engineer; it is not affected by the weather, or liable to get out of order; stops a train in its own length; if a coupling pin breaks, the train is immediately stopped by the automatic working of the brake; does not skin the wheels, etc. These are but a few of its many advantages and improvements, and if the railway companies grant the necessary cars, the test can be made at once.

18880418: A VICTIM OF THE BLIZZARD. Emperor Frederick in Much the Same Condition, Great Improvement Perceptible. New York, April 17. Roscoe Conkling is dying, probably will be dead before this is read. Several times today did the report of the end come, but each time only to be contradicted. The turn for the worse began at 12:30 p.m. when he developed edema of the lungs, that is the settling of the blood in the base of the lungs. At 5:20 p.m., Dr. Anderson said Mr. Conkling was fast passing away and did not think he would survive the night. Mrs. Conkling and Mrs. Oakman are with him. At 6:00 p.m., Dr. Barker issued his official bulletin: "Mr. Conkling is failing fast. His lungs are fast filling up with blood, owing to the failure of the heart which has resulted from the gradual wasting away of his vital powers." Dr. Barker would not say definitely how long Mr. Conkling can live, but he says he cannot possibly survive the night. Dr. Fordyce Barker seemed quite overcome as he stood on the steps of Mr. Conkling's house this afternoon and told the reporters of the impending dissolution of his patient. The sad news spread rapidly in the Hoffman House and was telegraphed rapidly by wire to a sorrowing country. There was a hush in the corridors of the hotel nearby and a pervading oppressive quiet and solemnity, and all voices were subdued. The friends who came to make a last call went away with sorrowful faces. 

A victim of THE BLIZZARD. The doctors have based their hopes exclusively on the patient's splendid physique. Putting this magnificent physique to a severe test during the blizzard of March 12 is said to be the very cause of Mr. Conkling's illness. Mr. Conkling delighted in telling the story of his struggle through the snow on that evening when he walked from his office to his home. For two weeks afterwards he continued to work, and at last, on March 30, had to succumb. On April 3rd he called in Dr. Agnew, and on the 4th, Dr. Sands, after consultation, determined on performing one of the most delicate operations known to surgical science. Physical diagnosis proved that a pus sac lay inside the skull back of the ear. In the operation, the rather awkward trephine was dispensed with in order to give vent to the pus, which, doubtless, bore on the brain. Dr. Sands made a lateral incision in the scalp, and then, with a sharp chisel placed on the exposed mastoid bone, with one sharp stroke of a mallet, the chisel was sent right through the bone. Pus freely flowed and the fever was reduced. Temporary relief followed. All the afternoon the sick statesman lay motionless in his bed. He occasionally moved his arms which were under the bed covering. He lay on his right side in order that the wound on the left side of his head might not get irritated. This cut, it will be understood, is the one Dr. Sands made when he operated in his endeavor to save the ex-Senator's life. Dr. Barker called at 10:05 o'clock and remained until 11 o'clock. He said that Mr. Conkling was failing rapidly. His extremities were becoming cold, his legs were quite cold nearly all the way up. He was pulseless. His respiration was very quick. He did not think Mr. Conkling could live much longer. In fact, he did not think he would live for two hours. He was suffering from a general failure of the nervous system. At 11:30 p.m., Dr. Barker said of Senator Conkling: "No pulse, limbs cold, respiration slight, unconscious, will die in three hours." At 2 a.m., a similar report came from the sick room.

18880426: SOCIETY TALK IN GOTHAM Some New Effects in Ladies' Dresses and Headgear Clear Impressions of a Recent Dramatic Success at the Lyceum New York, April 25 My last letter reached you just as we were suffering from our ever-to-be-remembered blizzard, a storm which made this great New York in very truth a beleaguered city. Streets were blockaded, supplies cut off, men separated from their families, telegraph and railroad communication denied us, and life disrupted, and all by the beautiful snow. No wonder a French paper had a notice saying "a fearful epidemic was raging in America called the blizzards, and many people were dying of it." We know not how many impaired their health in trying to battle with that storm, but we do know that one of America's best-known statesmen has succumbed and on Saturday was buried. I remember seeing Roscoe Conkling on one occasion and thinking what an indomitable expression he had; it was that fearlessness in his nature which made him think he was safe in defying the elements. The grand old Kaiser is gone, the blizzard too, and Roscoe Conkling, to be followed too soon by the death of the patient, gentle, and wise Emperor Frederick. How filled the last two weeks have been with startling events! Spring weather alone seems tardy in approaching and makes one lose sight of the beauties in Kingsley's remarkable "Ode to the Northeast Wind." Easter calls for spring attire, and usually brings fitting weather with well-fitting costumes. Elegant tailor-made suits are in season for spring when it is not winter, and though the sun shines warmly, the wind is wintry. I was looking out of a window on Broadway, on Saturday last, when there suddenly came up a fierce snowstorm, lasting only a few moments, but long enough to see an amusing destruction and flight of much spring finery. In a moment, cabs, streetcars, and shops were taken advantage of. The day was too cold and bright to expect rain, and few were provided with umbrellas. The new dress goods are lovely this season, and checks and plaids are seen in great variety and of every texture, and are to be had in costumes, but the more elegant ones are made of the new fine Henrietta cloths combined with moire, broadcloth, or silk of the same color, many with a scarf drapery crossing the front and looped low down on one side, knotted and brought up again, the waist and back drapery being polonaise and braided, but of a contrasting color. Changeable silks with pinked flounces, and many of them (the flounces) are seen in imported dresses; these silks are in startling combinations, orange and blue, green and yellow, etc. They are a revival of the old-fashioned silks. Why they should have been called that I cannot imagine, unless it be that if one got shot, one's colors would be sure to get mixed. There are some daring uses being made of pink broadcloth. Whether these dresses will see daylight in the street has yet to be proved. I saw an odd wrap or street dress for a girl of 12 or 13 of mahogany brown and braided with hempen rope, common clothes line size. By the way, rope has many uses now-a-days not thought of a decade ago, and plays an important part in house decoration, is raveled into fringe, ties back curtains and makes very handsome picture and screen frames if tacked upon a common board frame and painted with gold paint, after first sizing with glue; in fact, any furniture can be ornamented with rope and painted over. Another way to do picture frames, and one I thought of myself, is to stretch a piece of coarse flowered net or embroidered muslin over a plain wooden frame, fasten into each corner a china doll, cupid or angel, or bird if you like, and color the same as the rope ones. Bonnets are presenting an improved back view, and like the new houses are front all around. In holding the new bonnets in the hand one can almost believe they could be worn either way. Bows of ribbon are placed upon the crown standing up as they did in the front a month ago, and on the top of the bonnet rests a cluster of flowers, or feathers, or lace with pretty ornaments. Hats are of every shape and material, the straws being finer than last season. One I noticed was of pink lace, having a bunch of roses so arranged as to appear standing in a bowl with a climbing rose stem going under the rim and bordering the face. Some sunshades are elaborately trimmed with feathers; in fact, I have seen some completely covered. I noticed a pretty tea gown of India silk, white ground with apple blossoms and leaves, gathered at the neck, then from just below the armholes to below the waist, the skirt falling full all around, the front filled in with fan-shaped flowers of soft Mechlin lace, with many ribbon bows of apple, pink, and green; the sleeves were gathered at the armhole and below the elbow, and finished with a frill of lace and bows. Braiding is very popular, mixed with tinsel, and often vests, cuffs, and collars of white broadcloth are covered with this handsome braiding. If the weather permitted, one might imagine summer was here from the abundance of fruit, fresh vegetables, and flowers to be seen. Purple lilacs abound and are sold in great bunches for 20 cents. For some time, spiritualism has been much talked about, and at present, the Marsh-Diss Debar case is much discussed, as one of the most extraordinary incidents of infatuation or hallucination, to give it a mild term, ever known. Mr. Marsh, a man advanced in years, a lawyer, educated and intelligent, believed implicitly in the woman who duped him, robbed him of property, reputation, and reason—a woman whose counsel have declared they can no longer defend her, so disgusted are they with her course, and it is said there are very grave charges of another kind to be brought against her, and she may wear a necklace more elastic than the diamonds she offers her counsel to get her out of this trouble. I know a case myself in New York of a maiden lady of the certain age of fifty or more, who was rich, luxury-loving, bright, and intelligent, until she became imbued with spiritualistic ideas, when a swindling man of spiritualistic calling gained such power over her that he robbed her of all her worldly goods, deprived her of the necessaries of life, and so dimmed her reason that she was willing to render up her life, too, if called upon. Monopolies are legislated against, and outrages of every character publicly exposed. May spiritualists get their deserts and their charlatanism be openly condemned and merited punishment follow. The ever-popular Lyceum still holds crowded houses spellbound with its splendid society play, "The Wife." I cannot tell when I have enjoyed a play more or seen such uniformly good acting by a whole company. The mounting of the play is rich and attractive, the house is unique, the dressing superb, and the acting all that can be desired. In this drama more than any other I can think of, the eloquence of silence is truly experienced. I have not space to more fully describe the ultimate thule of the Lyceum and "The Wife." I only ask you to see for yourself this delightful play, which illustrates many phases in life, and shows the nobility of soul possessed by true men, all that is sordid, cruel, and unscrupulous in the untrained man, and that Cupid can make a brave soldier tremble when the cry of battle and the roar of cannon would be unheeded.

18880517: P, and the most recent English and American authorities, such an affidavit was inadmissible, and no appeal has been taken from the judgment granting this motion. It is scarcely necessary to notice a lengthy affidavit made by George Wallace, agent of appellants, setting forth the Riel rebellion and the newspaper war connected therewith, with the view of showing that French Canadians in general, and the French-speaking portion of this jury in particular, must be biased against the appellant's newspaper. As His Honor Mr. Justice Johnson remarks, the jury were unanimous in declaring that the respondent had suffered a wrong, and that the appellants had failed completely to make out their plea of justification. The only difference of opinion was as to the amount of damages, and on this question, the jury were nine to three. Consequently, three at least of the English-speaking jurors were of the opinion that the sum actually awarded was the proper amount, and they cannot be supposed to have been influenced by the alleged prejudice of Frenchmen against the appellants. Again, we are not told at how much the three dissenting jurors were prepared to assess the respondent's damages; they may have been in favor of awarding $5,000 or $7,000 or $8,000 instead of $10,000, and without such data, it is impossible to compare their ideas with those of the nine jurors who agreed on the latter sum. But at all events, any weight that could be attached to such vague and insufficient suspicions would at once disappear if in fact the amount of the verdict rendered be really not excessive. The review of verdicts given in cases analogous to the present one which the learned Chief Justice of the Court of Review has made in his opinion can have no doubt that in view of the standing of the respondent and of the wanton malice of the attack made on him, the verdict is anything but excessive, but on the contrary follows the amounts which have frequently been awarded by English juries and which the courts have refused over and over again to set aside. When we reflect that the respondent, who has been a member of Parliament, a Minister of the Crown, and a leader of the bar, is assailed eight years after he has retired from the political arena, when he is quietly pursuing the avocations of his profession, and is charged with having invented and boasted of an infamous electoral fraud for which four persons were convicted in a criminal trial, and which the appellants themselves characterize as the grossest and most villainous outrage ever perpetrated on the electors of Canada—that, not satisfied with defaming the respondent in their newspaper, the appellants add insult to injury, and tell him in their written and spoken pleadings that he has no reputation to lose; that he succeeded in attaining to a "bad eminence" by dishonesty and fraud, and that while holding his high office he rendered himself utterly incompetent for the discharge of his duties by drunkenness and dissipated habits—that they charge him with having in vain solicited a judgeship, which was refused him on account of his turpitude—that after having written and said such things and many more, the appellants go to trial and fail to prove one jot of their foul aspersions—we may be surprised that the verdict was not twice as severe as it is. MANITOBA LANDS, A Policy for the Settlement of Vacant Lands Near Winnipeg Inducements Offered Moderate Prices Asked The Prospects of Immigration. Ex-Aid Archibald McNee, of Winnipeg, was in the city yesterday, having just returned from a tour through western Ontario. To a representative of the Gazette, he said: "I have been promoting the scheme of the colonization committee which was appointed by the City Council and Board of Trade of Winnipeg for the settlement of the vacant lands within a radius of twenty miles of that city. I think the scheme is proving successful, letters lately received from Winnipeg stating that already some fifty families have settled on the land. These vacant lands consist largely of the lands granted to the Manitoba half-breeds at the time the province was taken over by the Dominion. They were given the privilege of selecting their lands in the vicinity of their parishes, and the result was that they were largely located in the vicinity of Winnipeg, as of course the parishes were surrounding that city. These lands have largely got into the hands of speculators, who obtained them at a very nominal figure from the half-breeds after they came into their possession, and those speculators held these lands at high figures, the result being that people who came into the province to settle, hearing what prices were wanted for them, gave them the go-by. Then, of course, the boom came along, and matters were made somewhat worse. That excitement was fanned into existence by a lot of speculators from the east, who hearing of the increase in the value of lands rushed up there from the older provinces with the expectation that they were going to get rich suddenly and take a lot of money out of the province, and the consequence was that a still higher figure was put upon the lands there. Many of the people, however, who owned these lands mortgaged...

--- 

Please let me know if you need further assistance! Here is the corrected text:

them to loan companies in order to raise money for further speculations, and the consequence has been that they have got largely out of the hands of speculators and into the hands of private individuals, loan companies, banks, etc. I may say that the question of settling these vacant lands has engaged the attention of the City Council and the Board of Trade for several years, it being felt that it was a great drawback not only to the city and its trade, but to the province as well, because the first glimpse which the stranger got of the public lands of the Northwest was these uncultivated lands and the effect was tiny—but beneficial. "Can these lands be procured at a reasonable price?" "Yes. The owners of these lands were told that if their prices and terms were reasonable, an effort would be made to direct settlement to them. The result was that the owners have discovered that the high prices which had formerly been put on these lands had frightened settlers away and they were really losing the opportunity of selling them. The committee, therefore, procured from these settlers prices and terms which seemed to be most reasonable in view of the many advantages that would accrue to settlers from their vicinity to Winnipeg. The prices range from THREE TO TEN DOLLARS AN ACRE. The low-priced land is mostly low, wet land, but capable of drainage, and the higher-priced land is in the immediate vicinity of the city, and higher and drier, with wood conveniences. The resident population of the city, as ascertained by the assessors last month, is 23,000, besides a floating population of 3,000, making a total population of 26,000. Our school system is said to be as good as is to be found in any city in Canada and a great deal better than in most places; at any rate, that is the opinion of educationalists who have visited the schools from the older provinces. We have twelve common schools, and while only two teachers were employed when I first went there in 1874, there are now over fifty teachers. The city is now expending $100,000 annually on public schools. In addition, we have four denominational colleges: the Presbyterian, Anglican, Roman Catholic, and Methodist, the latter being only recently organized. We are the centre of education, legislation, and law for the Northwest, and under these circumstances offer many advantages to settlers. Farmers can sell everything they raise, from a load of hay to a carrot, for cash. And then we have also nine railways centering in Winnipeg and the Hudson Bay railway will be running to Lake Manitoba this spring. It must not be forgotten either that farmers can get from three to ten cents per bushel more for their wheat at Winnipeg than at points further west, the difference per acre almost enabling the farmer to pay for his land the first year. The land in the vicinity of the valley of the Red River and the Assiniboine is also stronger in character and will bear more cropping than the lighter lands towards the west. It must also be remembered that in the Northwest we are free from the blizzards and cyclones that cause such destruction in Dakota and the Northwestern states, while the soil is equally as good as that across the lines. We have had a very large influx of a superior class of settlers this year. "What accommodation have you for new settlers arriving in the country?" "We have provided an immigrant shed convenient to the station in charge of a man which can be had free by those who wish to remain over in Winnipeg to examine these lands, and we have also a mail to meet immigrants at the station and afford them every information. I may also say that we are very sanguine that the Province will make steady progress, now that the disallowance question has been settled, the crop of last year having been the means of enabling farmers to pay off their indebtedness for implements and stock. Messrs. Wastie and McMillan are now in the Province of Ontario, having been sent down by the Manitoba Government to represent the Province in matters of immigration. Three little boys in a downriver town attend the same school. They are but four years old and are in the same class. The other day they were called out by the teacher and asked to spell a certain word. They all stood up, and one of the little fellows looked at the teacher and said: "Now, Mr., if you ain't in a terrible fix, ain't you?" 

LORD LANSDOWNE'S SPEECH

The Folly of the Imperial Council

Farewell Words (By our own reporters)

Ottawa, May 10. The following is the continuation of Lord Lansdowne's speech at the farewell banquet last evening. After pointing out the difficulty of assimilating the various tariffs of the different portions of the Empire, he continued: "But there is worse to come. You have got the whole of the British colonies into line. Are you sure they will stay there? We all know there is no such thing as finality in these fiscal arrangements. Circumstances alter. New discoveries are made. Now that communications and connections arise, your Imperial tariff will stand in need of revision and adjustment to circumstances as they alter from time to time. We must have an Imperial council, which might in itself be no doubt a very admirable thing. When I look around these tables, I feel inclined to submit a list of Canadian representatives which would take away Lord Rosebery's breath and stagger Lord Dunraven. But of this, I am convinced, that the public sentiment of the Canadian people would not permit such an assembly to tamper with what would be regarded here as the domestic business of the Canadian Parliament. It would be almost possible to draw in our imagination a humorous picture of THE RETURN OF THE CANADIAN DELEGATES to their own country after the adjournment of the Imperial council. They might find themselves in the painful position of having to report that the duties on some articles in which you were largely interested here, some carefully reared offspring of the Canadian tariff, had been removed or reduced, and they would add that they deplore the decision greatly themselves, but that there had been some "log rolling" at Westminster and that they had been outvoted, perhaps because the South African and Australian delegates were anxious that ostrich feathers or opossum skins should be admitted duty-free in a foreign country. I suspect that before long they would wish themselves safely back in their own Legislature again." (Laughter and applause)

THANKS AND REGRETS

I cannot end these observations without expressing my gratitude, not only for your friendly references to the past, but also for the interest with which you have spoken of our future prospects. I rejoice to feel, not only that you do not look upon our departure with indifference, but also that we shall carry with us your good wishes in the new career which is about to open for us in another part of the Empire. I feel that I stand in great need of your support in the face of the heavy load of responsibility which will shortly be resting upon my shoulders. The post which I am called upon to fill is certainly one of which the responsibilities are heavy, whether we look to the historical interest of the nations which it has been inhabited or whether we consider the vast problems which present themselves to those who are today engaged in securing the safety of the Indian empire, in maintaining peace and order within it, as in taking the necessary precautions to guard the people committed to their charge from the inroads of pestilence and famine, or whether again we look forward to those other problems which as time goes on and as education leavens and fertilizes these great masses of human beings and leads them to regard with increasing intelligence and an increasing desire to take part in the public affairs of their own country. Of this no doubt can arise that no more splendid or interesting field exists for those whose ambition it is to serve their country and the Empire of the Queen." (Great applause) 

And now, Mr. Mayor, it remains for me to thank you once more for your kindness to us and for all the kindness which we have received at the hands of your citizens. We shall leave you, but nothing can rob us of the memories and associations which have grown up since we have lived amongst you—memories and associations which we shall preserve amongst the most treasured reminiscences of our lives. (Loud applause) How many and how pleasant will be the Canadian visions which, in years to come, will float across the field of our imagination when we are far from hence—visions of the Canadian spring and of wood and field bursting, as they are bursting now, into leaf and flower; visions of summer and of delightful rambles among your mountains and rivers; visions of autumn and of hillsides clothed in hues which no eastern splendor could surpass; visions of winter with its clear skies, its exhilarating sports outdoors, and within the bright fire of lathroom logs, with our children and friends gathered around us. (Applause) Visions of all these and many more will come back to us as we roam unconsciously through the past. But, sir, above all and through all there will stand out clearly, as it were, in the foreground of the picture, the recollection of the people with whom during these years we have lived in the happiest and most unconstrained relations, a people kindly, hospitable, and generous to a fault. (Applause) And of no part of the Dominion shall we carry away pleasanter or more affectionate recollections than of this city, the city which has been our home, and around which there have grown up all those tender and touching associations which belong to the word. We did not know how deeply our roots had struck here until the time came when it was necessary to tear them up. (Great applause)

A FUNNY CONFESSION

Mr. Mayor, I will close what I have to say with a confession. I spent three-quarters of an hour last night in endeavoring to compose a peroration for this speech, but I could not hit upon anything quite to my liking. I have often noticed that a speaker will make you a speech transparent in its sincerity and devoid of affectation until he arrives at his concluding passage. I became convinced that tonight anything of a conventional character would jar with my own feelings to such an extent that I consigned my peroration to the fireplace where it ended, as most perorations do, in smoke. (Laughter and applause) Under these distressing circumstances, I am going to ask your permission to read to you as a peroration one or two sentences from a document recently discovered at Government House in an apartment which, I understand, will shortly be occupied by Lord Mauley. It is evidently a fragment or a series of fragments of a diary, and you may be able to aid me with a conjecture as to its authorship. The first entry is dated towards the close of 1883. It runs as follows: "In for five years of expatriation. Almost wish I had stuck to North Wiltshire. Must make the best of it." (Laughter) The next entry is in 1884: "We are making the best of it, and find it very far from unpleasant. Fancy the five years will pass quickly." Then comes another in the following year: "Time passing very quickly and pleasantly. I take back what I wrote about expatriation." After this comes the following in 1886: "Time positively flying. We are beginning to feel quite at home here. Not quite sure that we shall not have to make it six years instead of five." Then, sir, there comes in 1888 an entry occasioned evidently by some event which exercised a very great effect on the mind of the writer: "These Canadians are splendid fellows and have stood by us nobly. We have quite made up our minds to make it six years." (Great applause) Last of all comes an entry written in rather shaky character and runs thus: "Why could not he remain where he was? It goes to our heart to leave this country and kind-hearted people. I trust they will remember us. We shall not forget them while we live." And, Mr. Mayor, take my word for it, we shall not forget them. (Tremendous cheers) 

When His Excellency resumed his seat, he received another ovation lasting for a considerable time.

18880811: A WALL STREET BOOK Henry Clews Reviews his Experiences at the Money Centres Mention of "The Street—Nineteenth Century" and its business Commodore Vanderbilt, Daniel Drew, Jay Gould and Others. Seldom does a good actor make a successful dramatist. There never yet was an example of a brilliant soldier making an able historian of his own achievements. By parity of reasoning, it will not be surprising that in "Twenty-eight Years in Wall Street" Mr. Henry Clews, the banker, has made a rambling, dull, turgid book out of a theme with which he is as thoroughly familiar as any living American. It is now thirty years since Henry Clews found his way to Wall Street. It was on the heels of the financial panic of 1857 that he made his advent in the street, but Mr. Clews does not tell us how he came to go there or what he did after he went there. He does not say, however, that the panic of 1857 was called the "Western blizzard." Was it? The mention of the crash that preceded Mr. Clews' debut in the street recalls to his reflective mind the operators and methods of thirty years ago. The old-fashioned business men who did business in Wall Street at that time seem to have inspired the enterprising operator with a sort of contemptuous respect. Although Jacob Little made and lost nine fortunes in his day and Anthony Morse, "the lightning calculator," conjured up a million with assets as unsubstantial as those of Ferdinand Ward and saw it disappear with a magic that would startle Keene himself, these old-timers, the "antique element," as Mr. Clews calls them, knew nothing of the blessings of "corners" and "blind pools" and kept on "choking off salutary enterprise" by doing business in a legitimate way. And yet it seems to be the old fellows after all that make money in Wall Street. Few persons gain sufficient experience, Mr. Clews informs us, to command success until they have one foot in the grave, but when that happy time comes these "old veterans of the street" are seen "hobbling down on their canes to their brokers' offices" in times of panic to secure a big "rake in." According to Mr. Clews' account of them, they are a cross between Dives and the devil, but all the same, Mr. Henry Clews is terribly shocked at that "clerical obliquity of judgment" that has led the Rev.

18880831: THE PARADISE OF WOMEN An English Writer Says that Canada Is the Place. According to Miss Jessie Saxby, Canada is the paradise of women. There are too many women in England; too many men, too, but not enough in quantity nor good enough in quality, for the women. It is the west of Canada, naturally, that is the paradise truly required. In Quebec and Montreal, wages do not seem exorbitantly high. That rare article, a trained cook, only gets some £250 a year in Quebec and Montreal. In the wilder and more liberal west, a good cook may get about £1,000 a year, not at all too much if she is really a good cook, but more than she obtains in England. Moreover, the heavy work is done, and very properly, by men. Men scrub the floors and are hewers of wood and carriers of water, and churn, and milk the cows. Servants in the west of Canada become members of the family in farmhouses as in old England. Best of all, a woman in the west can choose her mate from "Britons of larger body and larger hearts than those at home." Home-dwelling Britons, at least in large towns, are notoriously degenerated and shambling creatures. Pity being akin to love and nobody else coming forward, a woman puts up with the existing race, but she will find in Canada affectionate sons of Anak. They are all most anxious to get married, whereas the Briton of this country rather inclines to defer the crisis in his existence, after which the road (according to America's adopted moralist) lies dusty and long and straight to the grave. The "Titans of the West" have no such hesitation and forebodings. England is advised to lend "the roses of her rosebud girls to soften and sweeten life in the wild West." It is not so much educated girls that are wanted, not our pale, etiolated, anemic girls, but our rosebuds, best quality, education being rather a drawback than otherwise. The pale prodigies of Girton and Lilly Margaret's (if they are pale) would not suit the Titans of the West, and perhaps each would consider herself mated with a clown. That is just possible. There must be some drawback to the most glorious lot in life. We (Saturday Review) would not for a moment discourage the transplantation of hardy rosebud girls, but they must remember that the climate of the wild west has the wild blizzard among its fauna, that the cold, though healthy, is extreme; that they will have to rough it a good deal if they go in an emigrant vessel, and that in the Paradise of Women they will find hard work as well as good food and Titanic husbands who, we trust, do not, like the elder Titans, devour their children. People who encourage female emigration to Canada deserve all praise, but they should beware of painting the prospects of the rosebuds too roseate. Disappointment is certain to come of that, even in a country where "there seems about one woman to every fifty men." In the original paradise, there was only one woman to one man, and philosophers have held that she was one too many. On the other hand, the Canadian proportions are exaggerated in the opposite direction. Each woman must be a queen till she is married to a Titan, but after that her estate will be a good deal more homely and less regal. The condition of affairs appears likely to encourage flirtation rather than marriage. At the very best, a wise virgin will be in no hurry to make up her mind, and this may just possibly lead to difficulties among the Titans. London Globe. 

The Printers' Plea: The remaining races on the programme of the English printers' picnic which was held a fortnight ago will be run at St. Helen's Island tomorrow afternoon at half-past two o'clock.

18880926: A Byrne and Arthur Wallack was produced for the first time at the Royalty Theatre, Glasgow, on Monday week, and has scored a distinct success. Both press and public support it warmly. The flowers that actresses like are as varied as the people themselves. Some of these favorites of the footlights delight in wearing or carrying bouquets made up of the most rare and costly blooms, while others affect the simple blossoms of the country. The actress is a good angel of the florist, for, whether the blizzard blows or the snow flies, she must have her bouquet. Mrs. Langtry, through her love for that flower, is known the world over as "The Lily." Mrs. Potter loves the red rose. Miss Pauline Hall has a penchant for the great ox-eyed daisy. Miss Marie Junsen prefers the pansy. Fanny Davenport loves the lily, the lotus, and the rose. Rose Coghlan in summer wears great bunches of goldenrod, plucked from the hedges about her farm at Yonkers, and in winter she wears La France and big Jack roses. The orchid is Mme. Modjeska's delight, although she wears the more readily obtainable roses. Maud Harrison loves flowers of all varieties. 

Ex A New Kind of Protectionist (From La Minerve): Because the workingmen's candidate refused to enroll himself in Mr. Laurier's free trade battalion, the Liberals have raised a fictitious opposition to him. They have set up against him not another workingman, for workingmen are not free traders, but a young politician without experience in public affairs, whose only title to the confidence of the electors is that he is Mr. Laurier's candidate. They have laid it down as a principle that, in order to have the support of the Liberal party in Montreal, the candidate must declare himself a free trader like Mr. Laurier and Sir R. Cartwright, and undertake, with these two Utopian theorists, to combat the government which has given the country the boon of the National Policy and rescued the working people from the misery under which they groaned under the reign of Messrs. Mackenzie, Cartwright, and Laurier. By such a course, they insult the workingmen, who are about all Protectionists and understand their own interests, and the latter are bound by respect for themselves to vote en masse against the candidate of a policy that is anti-national and annexationist. The young Liberal candidate, who is nothing more than a puppet in the hands of the Rouge leaders, knows only one sort of protection, that which procures places and sinecures. He has sought positions under all governments, Conservative and Liberal. He obtained a situation at Ottawa under the Conservatives, but he brought on his dismissal by grossly insulting the men whose favors he had solicited. He then sought and obtained another position from the Quebec Government, and it is on that he now depends for a livelihood. But that kind of protection cannot be extended to everybody. In order effectively to protect the masses, the working class especially, governments must adopt a certain policy. Now Mr. Poirier, who has hitherto confined his views on protection to what concerned simply himself, comes before the electors as the opponent of protection for the many. He wants it for himself and his friends, but he would refuse it to the people, to the workingmen. He knows very well that the electors will not send him to Ottawa to combat the National Protective policy in the ranks of Mr. Laurier; but his masters will recompense him by increasing the protection that he enjoys from the Liberal Quebec Government whose official he is. He is, in fine, only the creature, the instrument of Mr. Mercier and Mr. Laurier who consulted his own interests alone in imposing him on so important a constituency as Montreal East. 

CHOLERA BELTS! Highly recommended by the Medical Faculty. A complete assortment of sizes to select from, at R.

18881031: R; he was a law unto himself, nay, more, he was above the law. The last session of the Dominion Parliament was, accordingly, allowed to pass without any attempt on the part of the provincial Government to secure such legislation as would enable them to effect these crossings, and, without which, they knew they would be powerless to move except by violating the law. The responsibility, therefore, for the existing situation rests upon our own Government, and especially upon Mr. Martin as the Attorney-General, who is the law officer of the Crown in Manitoba. The defeat of the Manitoba lawbreakers ought to be a lesson to them. It may serve to teach Mr. Martin that even so high and mighty a personage as he esteems himself is amenable to the law, and that he cannot be allowed to outrage it and provoke riot and bloodshed in order to turn public attention from this worse than blundering bargain he has made with the Northern Pacific officials, a bargain the people of Manitoba will have good cause to rue before many months have elapsed. 

A THREAT REVIVED: The story that President Cleveland intends to proclaim the Retaliation act of March, 1887, in the hope of bettering his chances of re-election is revived. It is not an improbable rumor, now that Lord Sackville's blunder has embittered Democratic feeling against Great Britain, frightened the President's friends with the fear that he may thereby lose a large Irish-American vote, and rendered necessary in their opinion some strong and tangible evidence of Mr. Cleveland's hostility to all things British. If he proclaims the act now on the Statute book in its full force and entirety, the result will be absolute non-intercourse of trade between Canada and the United States, and for the serious loss and confusion to the commerce of both countries that would follow such an act of folly, he can throw some responsibility on the Republican party, which was mainly instrumental in securing the passage of the measure. It is not a little disquieting to think that the friendly and commercial relations of Canada and the United States can be suddenly snapped to win a sectional vote in a political contest, that the maintenance of the cordial intercourse between our neighbors and ourselves may hang upon the whims of the demagogic leaders of the Irish-American element. Mr. Cleveland has within a couple of days held close intercourse with men who profess to control this vote, and if he has heeded their counsel, we must prepare for even so stupendous a blunder as the proclamation of the non-intercourse act. Such a course might profit the Democrat and re-elect Mr. Cleveland, but a man of sensitive honor, of broad and courageous statesmanship, would rather suffer defeat a hundred times than purchase it at the price of embittered international relations and commercial hostility to a friendly and innocent neighbor.
