If you have any further requests or need additional corrections, feel free to ask! Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

In consenting to advise a citizen of the country to which he was accredited as an ambassador as to how his franchise was to be exercised in deciding a domestic issue, the exigencies of the presidential election have precipitated Mr. Cleveland's action and compelled him, to face his chances with the anti-British voters, to take a step that for harshness has few precedents in diplomatic usage. It would have been better that Lord Sackville had voluntarily resigned the moment he saw the evil his blunder was likely to cause one of the parties in the political struggle now on the eve of decision. It would have been better even if Lord Salisbury had recalled at once a minister whose usefulness had ceased. As it is, Lord Sackville will depart under a sense of personal humiliation that has been made more intense by the unrestrained criticism to which he has been subjected by the press of Great Britain and the United States. This is a new experience for a British ambassador that will not likely have to be repeated. Lord Sackville will find no imitators in such free letter-writing, and henceforth diplomats in the United States will be even more than usually careful in their correspondence, knowing that when it serves a political party purpose, neither the obligations that rest upon the claimant to the title of gentleman nor the sacredness of private letters will avail to preserve their confidence from the public eye, nor their persons from the attacks of warring demagogues. "What went ye out into the wilderness to see?" would be an appropriate text for the Winnipeg divines to hold forth upon about this time. After weathering the Quebec provincialist gale and the Manitoba provincialist blizzard, the Dominion constitution seems to be just as good as new. Lord Sackville holds that the point west to which it is advisable for a diplomatic young man to go lies considerably on this side of the latitude of California. There is only one thing to be said for the correspondent who betrayed Lord Sackville's confidence; he has so much respect for his name that he will not reveal his identity. When Judas felt much as he must feel, he went and hanged himself. There are a number of old men yet alive who sat around the Council board when the basis of the federal constitution was laid; and how they must chuckle as they see Messrs. Mercier and Martin rubbing their bruised shins after foolish attempts to kick a hole in the solid foundations. Quebec's Mr. Mercier was not just handsome when he gathered himself up after his mill with the federal constitution, but he looked like an Adonis compared with Manitoba's Mr. Martin, as he wipes the dirt of the Northern Pacific roadbed out of his wounds, and looks around to see who the people are laughing at. The meeting to promote the formation of a citizens' league called for this afternoon should be well attended. The work it is intended to co-operate in is of the highest importance to the welfare of the city. Its necessity has been long admitted by all sections of the people. Legislation to advance it can only be secured by strong protestations coming from a strong organization. All who have studied the matter see this, and all who desire a remedy should join in the movement to secure it. The Toronto Young Men's Liberal Club is to include among its objects the promotion of a sentiment of Canadian nationality and the study of the resources of Canada and its people. As they progress in their task, they will come to have a somewhat small idea of some of the old men Liberals whom they have been following in the past. Lord Sackville may feel rather small today, but he would hardly shake hands with Mr. Blaine and the other Republican statesmen who have taken advantage of the betrayal of his confidence to advance their political interests at the expense of their feelings as honorable men. The shame of the matter does not rest alone on a British pair of shoulders. What the Witness calls the "fangs" of the Canadian Pacific Railway are soon to be inserted in the trade of Windsor. To bring this end about, the mayor and council of the Essex town have been exerting themselves at a lively rate and have promised the road substantial advantages. All of which goes to show that there are a great variety of opinions in this world of ours. Mr. Goldwin Smith, if the statement he correctly attributed to him is wrong, is saying that the proper title of the British Minister at Washington is Lord De La Warr. Mortimer, first Baron Sackville, was the son of the fifth Earl De La Warr and the younger brother of the present Earl. His next brother, Lionel Sackville-West, was, under a special remainder, constituted heir presumptive to the barony on its creation in 1876. Lord De La Warr's heir is his son, Lionel Charles Crantield, Viscount Cantelupe. As he also has a brother, there are really three lives, if not more, between Lord Sackville and the Earldom of De La Warr. The City Council has appointed Mr. Benoit, of St. Henri, to the chiefship of the Fire Brigade. Judged by the standard of experience in the duties required of him and acquaintance with the city, Mr. Dockinghain was best qualified for the position, and his selection for promotion would have given greatest satisfaction to the citizens most largely interested in the property that is at risk. The majority of the aldermen in their wisdom, however, have thought differently. Mr. Benoit, to a large extent, has his reputation to make. Justice to him, as well as regard for the welfare of the city, requires that he shall be given fair play by the citizens and that support from the council which alone enables a civic servant to efficiently discharge the functions of his office.

1888-11-08: T. Wesley Mills, in the chair. A student of human medicine of the second year related an instance of apparent heredity of a mental trait. A mare and seven of her colts, though not broken by the same person, showed the peculiarity of stopping with extreme suddenness at the word "whoa." A member of the society had known in Ireland a stallion that always, when going through a stable doorway, etc., made a sudden rush, lowering his head at the same time. This behavior was also evinced by his offspring to the fourth generation. It seemed to have originated from this stallion having been struck when passing out on one occasion, he then having hurt himself against the side of the passage. Another member stated that he had owned a horse perfectly gentle with ladies and when driven by a man that was intoxicated, even stopping if the sleigh was overturned and looking around, but comparatively unmanageable when driven by men if sober. Such an animal must be credited with much intelligence. The president pointed to the sense of humor of horses and their tantalizing behavior at times, as when in a pasture field. One member had known of a large horse that would allow the owner's wife to feed him, but not himself. He, on one occasion as an experiment, put on one of his wife's dresses, but the horse detected the imposture and behaved as usual. Gun-shyness in dogs was discussed. It was found that the same principle was illustrated in horses. One of the members had worked a horse that was greatly terrified by the sound of the whistle of locomotives, and on one occasion he had been held while the whistle was blowing and after a violent trembling had fallen dead. Reference was made to the conduct of the collie dog of an absent member. When the latter was packing his trunk, he could not be induced to leave the spot and contrary to his usual custom had insisted upon following him everywhere through the house. He had seen the same trunk packed for his master once before and moped during his entire absence. His human-like behavior could only be explained on the same principles as apply to our own minds. It seemed but right to take such a dog on the journey and this was done. The president said the realization of the fact that something very grave was to happen could scarcely have been shown more fully by a human being than in the case of a dog of unusual intelligence. He once had occasion to send off by express, when placed on the box that was used to transport him, it was very painful to witness the evidence of his deep emotion. A member from the West instanced the case of a collie that after the death of the herder had safely driven into the corral the 7,000 sheep that composed the herd. This same dog during a blizzard had remained out all night looking after the strayed animals. Another member related how a gentleman living at Point St. Charles, seeing a rat in a bad plight, had given the creature milk and continued to do so as it appeared day after day in his yard. It became tame like a kitten and played around among his children, but never entered his kitchen. It was expressed that a small portion of the press of the city saw fit to publish occasionally a series of narratives of animals, especially of encounters between them and men, which to say the least were very highly colored and not calculated to advance the cause of comparative psychology or truth in any form. 

A Fatal Suicide from Unrequited Love. A sad case of suicide occurred yesterday morning. A young girl named Marie Louise Higgins, aged 10 years, was left an orphan at the age of six years. Mr. Duguay, who resides at No. 679 Mignonne street, having no children of his own, adopted her. She grew up into a prepossessing young lady and fell in love with a young clerk, who, however, did not return her affections. She threw out all her endeavors to get his love, but to no avail. Seeing that she could not gain his love, she resolved to die. Yesterday she went to a chemist's shop and procured a quantity of rat poison. She then returned home and, going to bed, swallowed the stuff. The family were alarmed by her shrieks, which were caused by the agony occasioned by the arsenic in the rat poison. Medical attendance was at once sent for, but she died in a short time. The Coroner held an inquest at 1 o'clock in the afternoon, when a verdict of "Suicide while in a state of mental despondency from unrequited love" was returned.

Address to Mrs. Margaret E. Parker. Yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Margaret E. Parker, the founder of the British Woman's Temperance Association, addressed a crowded meeting yesterday afternoon at the Evangelistic Hall. Miss Dougall introduced Mrs. Parker, telling of her connection with the World's Woman's Christian Temperance Union, of which Mrs. Lucas, the sister of John Bright, was the first president, succeeded by Miss Wilhud, who is at present in office. Mrs. Parker is one of the organizers for the World's Woman's Christian Temperance Union and hopes to visit the Sandwich Islands on this errand before returning to Great Britain. She is now on her way to California by the Canadian Pacific with a party of 32 British temperance women for whom she can secure very desirable situations. She told of the effect which the story of the Woman's Crusade in Ohio 15 years ago had in Britain and especially of the enthusiasm of the women of Dundee in the temperance cause. She spoke of the college house movement and many questions were asked by the ladies concerning the best methods. It was easy to get people to take shares, as there was an average return of 10 percent upon the money invested. Often a lady of means would purchase a public house and fit it up for a coffee house, generally giving the manager a pecuniary interest in the business. The Montreal ladies took much interest in helping to fill the lunch baskets of the party, and a collection of $13.50 was taken up for the World's Woman's Christian Temperance Union.

A woman, charged before the Recorder in the afternoon, requested to be committed to jail for six months. She said she had been on a spree and wanted the time to sober up. His Honor granted her request and added a $10 fine or three months more.

**iik, Dak, November 17** A case of leprosy exists at Harrold, Hughes County. The subject is the child of Mrs. Bausuni, who was a missionary in China when the child was born. The afflicted family is allowed no communication with their neighbors. 

**Yellow Fever in New York**  
**New York, November 17** Flora Schmidt, the young woman who was taken to Bellevue Hospital last night with symptoms of yellow fever, died this morning. 

**A Heartbreaking Discovery**  
**Birmingham, Ala, November 17** Jacob Wells, a farmer living in Fayette County, has discovered, after four years of happy wedded life, that his wife is his half-sister. 

**Minor Items**  
Rear Admiral Baldwin died in New York on Saturday afternoon. The New York World says that Congressman Perry Belmont has been appointed United States Minister to Spain. A special from Muscogee, Indiana Territory, reports the amicable adjustment of the difficulties between Governor Guy of the Chickasaw Nation and the Byrd faction. Frank E. Pooley, who sued the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railway Company for damages in a collision on the day of the big blizzard, March 12th last, was yesterday awarded $6,000 damages. The heavy Chicago wholesale clothing firm of Lindatier BrJ & Co. filed confessions of judgment on Friday, aggregating $181,052. The firm is one of the largest firms of wholesale clothiers in the country. 

**THE FIRES BULLETIN**  
**Many Disastrous Conflagrations in Various Parts of the World**  
**Thessalon, Ont, November 17** The saw mill, stove heading, shingle and lathe factory, owned by W. H. Thompson and operated by Thompson, Tessant & Co., was totally destroyed by fire last night. By strenuous efforts, aided by a heavy snowstorm, the large stock of heading, lumber, etc., was saved. Loss about $5,000, insured for $1,000. 

In the Gore District, Mutual London, November 17, Brokerton's cotton mill at Preston has been burned. Loss $40,000. 

**Charleston, S.C., November 17** The British vessel Sundiiham, loading with cotton for Reval, took fire in the forward hold today. Seventeen hundred bales of cotton were destroyed. 

**Little Rock, Ark, November 18** A fire this morning destroyed five business houses on Main Street. Loss on stock, $50,000; on buildings, $12,000. 

**An Indian Murderer Sentenced to Death**  
**Immigration in October**  
(From our own correspondent)  
**Ottawa, November 18** Judge Priest has made a report to the Department of Justice of the trial at Ucluelet, B.C., of an Indian named Isennoquor for the murder in July last of an Indian boy named Moiso. Isennoquor was found guilty and sentenced to be hanged on the twelfth of December. Senators Sanford and Turner were here yesterday and obtained from His Excellency the Governor-General a promise to open the Hamilton Art exhibition. Immigration returns for the month of October show an increase over the same month last year of 3,180 in the total number of arrivals and of 3,043 in the number of settlers in the Dominion. The total number of arrivals since the first of January has been 186,807, of whom 78,212 settled in Canada, being an increase of 10,511 over the same period last year. West Lynne appears for the first time in the report, there being 246 entries at that point, all of whom settled in Canada. These are presumably either Canadians returning from the United States disappointed or American settlers blown by the blizzards of Dakota to the more congenial climate of the Canadian Northwest. Cunningham Stewart, comptroller of postal finances, is ill with typhoid fever. Dr. Ralph Bell, of the Geological Survey staff, who has been engaged all summer making a geological examination of the unknown regions between the mouth of the Mississagi River, the northeast coast of Lake Huron and the Montreal River, a tributary of the Ottawa River, has returned home and will make an exhaustive report to the Government. 

**ANOTHER BRIDGE ACCIDENT**  
**Cornwall Canal, for a Day or Two**  
**Cornwall, Ont, November 18** Another accident has occurred in the Cornwall Canal. About five o'clock yesterday afternoon while the barge Cleveland was entering Gillie's lock, the lock gates gave way, causing a stoppage of navigation. A force of men was put to work immediately to repair the damage and will be kept at it until it is completed. The gates will probably be repaired by noon tomorrow, when navigation will again be resumed. The last of the boats that had been delayed at the head of the canal before repairs on the break were completed had only just passed through when the accident happened. Another lot of delayed vessels is now gathering at the head and foot of the canal. They will all get through by tomorrow night.

**18881130: B** Thomas will also be disposed of under the hammer. No football eleven has scored against Yale this season, and this clean score is the first on record for the Blues. In the last seven years, the only game lost was to Princeton, 6 to 3, when Lamar made his wonderful run at the very close of the game. Yale scored 2,838 points in 57 games played in this period, against 147. The closest score against Yale in one year was 14 in 1884. This year, Yale scored 308 points to 0. During the mini blizzard of Sunday afternoon, a remarkable game of football was played at Fordham between teams representing St. John's College and the American Athletic Club of New York. The game was played in about a foot of snow, and to see the teams line up after each scrimmage, all covered with snow, was a picturesque if not very cheering spectacle. In the first half, neither side scored, and it was not until five minutes before the end of the second half that the winning touchdown was secured by St. John's, but no goal was kicked.

**18881217: 1L** M Johnson says Fred Davis, the runner, can go around the bases in 12 4-5 seconds, which is better than most players can do on a straightaway race for that distance. During the recent annual meeting of the Western Baseball Association, it came out that the several clubs lost in the aggregate $6,000 last season instead of $14,000 as heretofore published. An exchange asks: "What is the matter with the Bostons for next season?" Nothing at present, my boy. The flies hibernate during the winter months, and the odor that arises from a sugar-cured team is not perceptible when the blizzards blow and the thermometers are wearing overcoats. Wait until the torrid days of July and then ask that question. Mr. Frank Heroic, of Pittsburgh, Pa., proposes to institute a novelty in the shape of six days racing on the ice, at the Exposition Park, in that city, between Christmas and New Year's. The grandstand will be fitted up and warmed so it will be perfectly comfortable, and three or four races, for trotters and pacers, with liberal purses, will be given each day.

**18881219: IUNV** Albany, N.Y., December 18 The storm which ended in this city today was equivalent to two feet of snow. It rained steadily yesterday and last night, and after midnight snowed for several hours. The Hudson has risen rapidly and is overflowing the piers and wharves of the city. A rise of over seven feet since last night was noted at noon today. The storm locally had many of the characteristics of last March's blizzard. The lowest barometer ever recorded by the Signal Officer here was noted today at 29.08. The river is still rising through the southerly winds, but a warming thermometer will probably check the flood.

**TORONTO IS GOOD IN MILD**  
**Toronto, December 18** Toronto has got her winter at last. The mild weather which has prevailed up to the present has kept business at a low ebb, and the city has presented none of the bustle generally seen before the holidays.

**Epps Cocoa**  
By a thorough knowledge of the natural laws which govern the operation of digestion and nutrition, and by a careful application of the fine properties of well-selected cocoa, Mr. Epps has provided our breakfast tables with a delicately flavored beverage which may save us many heavy doctors' bills. It is by the judicious use of such articles of diet that a constitution may be gradually built up until strong enough to resist every tendency to disease. Hundreds of subtle maladies are flitting around us ready to attack wherever there is a weak point. We may escape many a fatal shaft by keeping ourselves well fortified with pure blood and a properly nourished frame.

**18881228: DAKOTA'S GREAT BLIZZARD**  
**Incidents Told by a Government School Teacher**  
(Atlantic Monthly)  
As the time for blizzards comes round again, I propose to invite the club to meet at our camp in Rosebud Agency, Southern Dakota. To prepare the minds of the members, let me recall our experience of last January. We knew before we got out of bed, in this little government schoolhouse, that the most awful storm we had ever witnessed was imminent. The sky was inky. In a few minutes, the storm began, and in half an hour from this time it was at its height. Lilia ventured a few yards out of the front door at its beginning and was near not getting back. The wind struck her with such violence as to bring her head down to a level with her knees and take away her breath. She said she was "near falling on her face, and she knew that if she fell she would not get up again." She got to the house, bent at the angle into which the wind had forced her. The storm raged, without one moment's abatement or lull, during the whole day and far into the night, when we fell asleep. At first, the little frame building creaked and shivered like a ship at sea, and we wondered how anything constructed by the hand of man could stand against that wind. After the first half hour, it was impossible...

--- 

This corrected text addresses the OCR errors while maintaining the original meaning and formatting as closely as possible. Here is the corrected text:

It was impossible to distinguish the sound of groaning timbers, for the cars were filled with the rush of the elements. It was like the roar and surging of a mighty ocean. Being in the house, we could see out a few yards on one side—the side from which the storm did not come. On the other three sides, the snow beat and came in (though the house is close and tight), and went halfway across the schoolroom. It hung in a beautiful fringe, several inches long, from the drying room, stretched across the room, and festooned the maps on the walls, and finally blocked up the windows till they were as impenetrable as snowbanks. It was a comfort for us to believe, as we then did, that this greatest of all the blizzards had set in as early in other camps as in ours, and that no human being was exposed to its fury. No sun had risen over our heads on that day, and we had rung no school bell; we could not know that bells were ringing from many a prairie schoolhouse, and that the fair promise of the day was luring men, women, and children to their doom. 

On the afternoon preceding this destructive day, no snow fell, but the force of the wind was so great that it lifted up from the boundless prairie the accumulated drifts of weeks and carried them along in great waves, so that the whole earth seemed in motion and rising heavenward. The outline of these vast billows and the intervening troughs, as seen against the horizon, was the most impressive sight that had ever met our eyes. On the morning of the 13th, the mercury registered 25 degrees below zero, and the wind was blowing cruelly. The drifts between us and the village were so deep that we thought it unsafe to ring for the children. But they came over the half mile, through drifts waist-deep to large children, and the two faithful policemen, Stiff Arm and Cut Boot, came to see how we had got through the blizzard. 

The schoolroom was not to be thought of on that bitter day, and we brought the children and the policemen into our bedroom to thaw out. We ran the mercury up to 110 degrees within two feet of the stove; at a distance of eight feet, it was ninety-five degrees lower. Not one of the children uttered a sound of complaint, but the big tears rolled silently down the swollen cheeks of one of the little girls when the genial warmth of the room began to make her comfortable. Our fifteen-mile-off neighbor, the young teacher at the next camp, stepped in one evening to ask if we could give him a bed for the night. He had been trying all day to get to his camp and had consumed four hours in traveling one mile and a half. His plucky little Indian pony dragged the wagon through the heavy drifts by main force, the wheels not turning and the horse waddling where he could not walk. The faithful creature was quite exhausted. A sheet of ice enclosed his nose, and an icicle more than a foot long hung from it. This gentle animal, during the blizzard of the 12th, not only broke his halter but pawed down a thick stable door with hinges a foot long. His master went out into the storm to see how he was faring. He spent two hours looking for him, though he was only a few yards from him. When found, he was a mass of ice, his eyes nearly closed by it and a giant icicle hanging from his nose. Mr. Warner's own eyelashes froze every time he winked, and he had to hold his hand to his face and send the hot breath up to them before he could open them again. We hear this is common enough in Dakota, but we didn’t stay out long enough to wink. 

Winnipeg; News Notes. Winnipeg, December 27—It is understood the Northern Pacific Manitoba Railway, despite the recent decision of the Supreme Court, will press for a Dominion charter at the forthcoming session of the Commons. Shadilen's outfit has arrived from Montreal and is already engaged in freighting merchandise goods. The Board of Trade has petitioned the Postmaster-General to extend the mail service on the Glenboro branch of the Canadian Pacific Railway. It is believed the Northern Pacific will erect a large first-class hotel in Winnipeg, as announced some time ago. Treasurer Jones is expected to return to Winnipeg shortly. A clerk named H. I. Ton was a very creditable one, and showed the lodge to be in a very nourishing condition, both financially and in regard to membership.

PREDICTING THE WEATHER. V. by the Meteorological Office. Sometimes full reports are a blizzard. John P. Fluley, of the U.S. Signal Corps, in a paper in Harper's Weekly, says: "In making weather predictions, the officers have great difficulties to overcome, owing to the limited number of signal stations, the sharp gradients of temperature, and the great variety of local peculiarities that must be kept in mind. There is a constant demand for completeness when, owing to the nature of the phenomena, it is impossible to draw a line and predict rain on one side of it and none on the other. The exact extent of a downpour in case the probabilities indicate light rain cannot be measured in advance closely, especially near the Atlantic coast or the Great Lakes, because the coldness and moisture of great bodies of water increase the rainfall. In fact, the correctness of predictions for the Atlantic coast would be improved by the presence of signal light-ships in the Atlantic Ocean. This has been thought of by the Signal Service officers, and the scheme was definitely proposed on three occasions. It was abandoned, owing to the great expense and the difficulties in anchoring and construction. But aside from this lack of observing stations, the difficulties of prediction in the known regions of the central West are very great. Storm centers, as indicated on the tri-daily charts, may move with more than double the speed calculated, or they may remain at rest, or unexpectedly vanish. "Local rain" means rain at half the stations in a district, and when none results in many miles of territory, people think the prediction has failed, yet it may be found verified when the charts are examined. In autumn or winter, the prediction of local rain may mean heavy or continuous storm. For this reason, the word "local" is often omitted in winter. It is the custom of the officer in charge to predict rain as far as possible, that the people may take umbrellas unnecessarily rather than be wet through. The officer usually predicts for forty different districts, for which temperature, weather, and wind must be determined. Each decision must be made in sixty seconds, which requires great quickness and accuracy. It is the most difficult and responsible work required of any government officer. An error in temperature prediction at critical times in the autumn may freeze up the river traffic, causing boats to be detained in midstream, resulting in great damage. A mistake in a cyclone prediction might cause great loss of life and property among the shipping along the coast or on the lakes. The summer predictions are most difficult because the barometric centers lack intensity or are undecided. Decided storm movements have a regularity that can be foreseen better in regions where most of the great storm centers originate, along the northern ranges of the Rocky Mountains. It is far from easy to estimate the special direction of the eastward movement of storms, but as they leave the Mississippi Valley, they become more calculable. They advance toward regions of great moisture, and the knowledge of these regions is an important element of the predictions. The principal use of the weather prediction is to establish averages that shall progressively leave narrower margins of uncertainty. From a local situation, they must often seem to fail; yet it is always best to heed the morning predictions because nearly seventy percent of them will be found correct from the point of view of personal experience, and aside from the verifications by agencies in the Signal Service charts. The skill of officers varies with their natural ability and the extent of their meteorological education. One of the serious defects of the science is the comparatively low pay of officers who undertake so serious a responsibility. Resignations or other changes at times make it necessary to put men in charge who lack the many years of practice and the thorough training necessary for so difficult a task. It is well to remember that failures to forecast the weather are exceptional, and that the average result is unquestionably valuable. 

New York's Great Blizzard. In the United States and part of Canada, the situation of a great storm, like the New York blizzard of March 11th and 12th, is promptly reported by telegraph three times daily. The rate of progress made by the storm and the velocity of the wind are then known almost hourly, and their probable course foreseen to an average extent of about 68 percent correctness for thirty-two hours in advance. The storm track of the great New York blizzard was traced from the very slight atmospheric disturbance at San Francisco to the hurricane of cold air and snow that swept down upon New York City and Long Island. The path of the blizzard and its growing severity were at once drawn upon the Signal Service tri-daily weather maps until it came within three or four hundred miles of New York City, when the fury of the storm became so great that telegraphic communication was very largely interrupted, only here and there a report coming in. There was no combination of reports from adjacent stations whereby the exact movement of the storm center could be then known. Its path and severity through New York and the New England states could not be plotted on the Signal Service map on the morning of the 15th. But the missing data have been gradually filled in to an extent that reveals the remarkable nature of this storm, which in the peculiarity of its track as well as in the velocity of its wind force is unequaled since the establishment of the Signal Service as a regular organization in 1870. In the weather map of March 12th, the storm began to manifest its first indications of power in Southern Colorado on the 11th, where it split into two storm centers of five or six hundred miles in diameter, one center moving southward, along the Gulf, and up the Atlantic coast to New York, the other moving northeast, over the Great Lakes, and on to the same destination. The two storms seem to have been kept apart by the Appalachian ranges of mountains for at least the distance from northern Georgia to northern Pennsylvania. Both steadily increased in severity as they approached their point of reunion at New York City. The southerly storm that came up the Atlantic coast was the more severe, as evinced by the destruction to vessels in the Chesapeake Bay and the Delaware River. On the morning of March 10th, indications of tremendous storm energy were apparent, extending from Arkansas to northern Wisconsin and Michigan. Warm and cold bodies of air were distilled, with marked contrasts of temperature, over narrow areas of regions running north and south for 2,000 miles or more. A venerable sergeant of the Signal Service, a veteran of the Civil War, once pointed to a weather map and said to the writer: "If it were not midwinter, I would say that tornadoes would result from that map"; and great loss of life on the lakes took place from the severe winter storm that the old sergeant had foreseen. The warm air ought to remain south and the cold air north, and whenever the map denotes that this normal distribution is nearly reversed, there is sure to be a combat during the restoration of the equilibrium. The Dakota blizzard of January 12th and 19th was very severe, but its field of operations was much lessened by its... Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed while preserving the original meaning and formatting:

---

Truck forming a short sharp curve through the Northwest, almost doubling back upon itself, as will be seen on the map. The wind blew at a rate of from thirty to sixty miles an hour, and at some points there was a fall of 18 inches in temperature in twenty-four hours. With a temperature of from 40 to 30 below zero and a furious wind blowing, it is not surprising that the loss of life was great. Not even signals accustomed to an arctic temperature could endure it. The number of lives lost was greater than in previous storms owing to the increased number of travelers, and because the blizzard came on in the morning about 10, when people were away from home. Mild weather for two or three days had thrown them off their guard. The Signal Service cannot warn the people of Dakota in these emergencies because there are no chains of stations in that bleak region north of the Canada line, from which a cold wave or a blizzard can descend upon the people with dangerous rapidity. The blinding snow, even by daylight, is equivalent to absolute darkness. Adequate meteorological stations north of the Canada line might result in saving many lives, owing to timely warnings by telegraph; otherwise life in Dakota in midwinter must continue to be extremely hazardous.

SUNDAY SERVICES

Notices Regarding Divine Worship in our Churches Tomorrow, January 6, at 3 p.m. Rev. 

1889-01-19: A.V. Wiman, of this city, and Mr. Erastus Wiman on the subject of the designs of the latter upon the commercial and political integrity of the Dominion. From the day he started the agitation of the trade relations between Canada and the United States, Mr. Wiman has been playing a double game. To Canadians, he has professed the utmost solicitude for the material prosperity and national welfare, and has given as the motive of his active propagation of the commercial union project a desire to extend the trade and develop the resources of the Dominion without impairing her legislative independence. His eulogies of the soil, climate, resources, and capabilities of our country have been glowing to the length of gush, and ostensibly no truer or more disinterested friend of the Canadian people than Mr. Wiman lived. But for his audiences in the United States, he had another object. Commercial union he first freely preached to them, not as a scheme to benefit Canadians, but as a certain and sure means of giving American manufacturers control of the markets of Canada. He praised and extolled the vast latent wealth of the Dominion, indeed, but the means were designed to excite the cupidity of the Americans. Annexation has been the goal of Mr. Wiman's efforts from the beginning of his work. He is shrewd enough to understand that anything savoring of annexation will be summarily rejected by the people of this country, and he has carefully endeavored to disguise his motive with honeyed phrases and professions of American loyalty; but the double game has been so transparent and so difficult to play for any length of time that Mr. Wiman appears at last to have thrown off the mask. How any sane man could ever have regarded the commercial union movement as other than an annexation plot passes understanding. The very essential part of the whole scheme is the surrender by Canada of control of the tariff, and assuming the attitude of a pensioner on the bounty of Washington; and only a fool or a knave can think of maintaining such a position with the maintenance of the political integrity of the Dominion. Mr. Wiman in openly propounding annexation has put himself in line with Senators Sherman and Blair, with Lutterworth and Blaine, with the American politicians to whom he has been wont to point as prepared to extend to Canada his scheme of commercial union. Annexation is understandable; it is the honest avowal of the purpose and intent of the new trade policy our Liberal friends have espoused, but it is not a destiny which Canadians are prepared to accept. 

As supplementing the views of Mr. Wiman published yesterday in our Toronto correspondence, we give the following report of this gentleman's latest public appearance: 

New York, January 10. Mr. Erastus Wiman was before the members and friends of the Lincoln Club, Brooklyn, last night, and told them the reasons why the United States should include Canada. He talked for two hours on his pet scheme, but did it so entertainingly that nobody grew tired. In introducing Mr. Wiman, President William Herri said it was evident that Mr. Wiman was very much in earnest in support of the annexation of Canada to the United States, for he had offered, at his own expense, to take the Canadian Parliament through the United States that they might see its greatness and be impressed by it to favor union. In his address, Mr. Wiman made some comparisons which somewhat surprised his audience. In giving them an idea of Hudson Bay, he told them to think of a bay which began at New York and ended at Chicago. The canal at Sault Ste. Marie, he said, did more business last year than did the Suez Canal. It seemed by his glowing description that the only hope for the future greatness of the United States was its annexation to Canada. He said the potatoes of Canada were much larger than those of the United States, that Canada had more sun than the rest of North America, and that it was free from any chance of drought by natural provision. The wheat of Canada more than equaled the cotton of the South, and its iron was better than that of any other country, and this country wouldn't have to send to Spain for iron if the Canadian mines were properly developed. After praising the natural greatness of Canada as an inducement for annexation, Mr. Wiman spoke of the political reasons. Silence is golden, especially Mr. Francis Langelier's Montreal's ice palace has suffered badly from the warm weather; but preparations for the great carnival still go on. Montreal is not St. Paul. The Opposition cause does not seem to be so strong as its talk in Manitoba. The party has no straight nominee in the November bye-election. As a direct advocate of annexation, Mr. Wiman occupies no new position. It is years since he publicly regretted that the Declaration of Independence stopped short at line 45. Liberal journals are busy advising their friends to look after the revision of the voters' lists. Conservatives had better keep an eye on the mortuary records and see that no townships have double voting powers conferred upon them. The Herald formally announces that Hon. Henry Barnes will shortly occupy the seat and draw the salary of Speaker of the Legislative Council. Would it not have been kinder to have waited a little? It was only on Tuesday the vote was given. Old Boreas has taken a wild revenge on the boisterous Dakotans. The mail accounts of their fan and linen duster picnics are not done coming east when the mercury has gone down to 42 below zero on the inhabitants of the blizzard afflicted state. Mr. Murder's bill to increase the chances of escape for the political corruptionist becomes quite a mild little thing beside the provision for wholesale corruption that his lieutenant, Piletier, thinks the law should contain. The revenue police report that one-fourth of the licensed hotels and restaurants they have inspected fail to meet the requirements of the law. This should afford an opportunity for reducing the excessive number. There can be no vested right in an illegally maintained business. The German Emperor's idea of discharging all the French cooks of the palace just because they are French is about on a level with that of the statesmen of the Kansas Legislature who proposed to change the titles of the chancellor and regents of the state university just because they happen to be similar to those borne by men in like positions in England. Neither French cookery nor English scholarship is likely to suffer from the execution of those designs of little men in high places. In reply to "The Last Word" of the Quebec Chronicle, Mr. J. Israel Tarte says over his own signature in L'Événement, "Do you have finished, while I am only beginning? My evidence in court was, in your opinion, incomplete. If I should speak of the masqueraders that practice political assassination in the dark, who with money get compromising personages out of the way, and close the mouths of dangerous witnesses by means that I know of!" At this point, Mr. Tarte leaves the public to make its own interpretation of these dark hints. Even Liberals must now admit the usefulness of the veto power when it is exercised in circumstances like those of the District Magistrates' Act. The new bill is so framed as to avoid some mistakes of its predecessor. It does not undertake, for instance, to abolish the Montreal Circuit Court, nor does it attempt to rob the Superior Court judges of any portion of their jurisdiction. The last act was clearly ultra vires by the terms of section 96 of the British North America Act, which gives to the Governor-General the power of nominating judges of the Superior, District, and County Courts in every province. The new bill has been more carefully framed. Yesterday, Talleyrand joined Mississippi, L'Assomption, and Barrie, the Quebec counties that have declared for unrestricted reciprocity since that policy became an issue in the country, and Prince Edward, Kent, and Halton in Ontario, so that the strengthening of this policy is such as to cause alarm on the Treasury benches. The policy may cause alarm on the Treasury benches, if the occupants thereof forget that "since that policy became an issue in the country," those have declared against it. East Huron and South Victoria, Restigouche and Digby, South Renfrew and Charlotte, Colchester and Cumberland, Haliburton, Victoria, and K...

1889-01-22: D. BAR & CO., 738 Craig Street, Montreal: It has been triumphantly proved that the Sprague system of electric railways can be successfully operated in all conditions of weather, and this last straw, which a few railroad men are making as an excuse for not giving patrons better transportation at an admitted less cost than by horse or mule power, is gone. Through the courtesy of our agents in Chicago, we take pleasure in sending you a copy of some telegrams and letters received by them from Davenport, and items from the Davenport papers. 

Telegram: Davenport, Iowa, January 10, 1889. Sprague Electric Railway & Motor Co., Chicago, Ill: "Two inches to one foot of snow on the track. Regular blizzard. Could not have been worse. Electric road a signal success. Cars running uninterruptedly. President Allen, of this road, and the president of another Iowa railroad, are here and are greatly pleased with the result. All the citizens and railway men are enthusiastic over the success of the road." 

JOHN HOWARD, Supt., Davenport Central Railway Co. 

ELECTRICITY ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. 

Davenport Tribune, Jan 10, 1889 (Morning paper): "Where are the croakers now? Yesterday morning when the rain ceased, the street and hills became coated with ice, then it was doubtful to many if the cars would be able to ascend the Brady Street hill, but they did not remain long in doubt, for the electric cars went up and down the hill at their usual speed. When the first car started over the line, an interesting pyrotechnic display appeared on the trolley wire: the passage of the current melting the ice and emitting a bluish flame. As we are likely to have a snowstorm this evening or tomorrow, our citizens will get an opportunity of judging how it operated in deep snow." 

Extract from Davenport Democrat Gazette, January 10, 1889 (Evening paper): "Snow has fallen on an average by daylight 8 to 10 inches, it was heavy and damp. The wind drifted it considerably. Long before daylight, street railroad men were at work with their snow plows. It was hard work."

---

Too beginnings of the wind, while the air was full of falling snow. It packed hard on the rails. When time for business came, the electric car had the advantage over the horse car, for when the former started they moved with almost their usual speed. Steel brushes landing from the platforms of the electric cars cleared the rails of the snow left by the ploughs and scrapers.

(Copy of a Letter) Davenport Central Railway Company, Davenport, January 6, 1880

Sprague Electric Railway & Motor Company, Chicago, IL

GENTLEMEN, We have had as bad a snowstorm as far as street railroading is concerned, as is usually encountered in this section of the country, which you know is subject to very heavy snow and ice storms. Our cars made the usual time, while the horse cars ran slowly on their lines on a practically level road, and could not attain any speed over a walk all day. We naturally felt jubilant over our grand success. The president of a prominent Iowa street railway line was here today inspecting the system. He declared that it was not possible to do with horses what we did with electricity today. As we telegraphed you, our citizens are so jubilant over the grand success. The wind was very strong and blew the snow back on the tracks almost as fast as it was cleaned off. The only difference that we could notice in the propulsion of the cars was that, at our power plant, it took 50 percent more all day long to propel the cars. We would not have minded it had it taken 100 percent increase; we were so pleased at being able to satisfy ourselves and the public even in a blizzard. When any railroad men are in doubt when you assert to them, as you did to us, that you can operate better in a snow or sleet storm than cars propelled by horses, refer them to us, and we will only be too pleased to verify your assertions.

Yours truly, Davenport Central Railway Company, W. ALLEN, President

It should be noted in this connection that the Davenport Central Railway Company has a grade of 74 to 1 per cent, a long upon their line.

V. W. TAYLOR, General Agent

Address all communications to Messrs.

---

Cars running uninterruptedly. President Allen, of this road, and the president of another Iowa railroad are here and are greatly pleased with the result. All the citizens and railway men are enthusiastic over the success of the road." 

JOHN HOWARD, Supt., Davenport Central Railway Co.

Davenport Tribune, Jan 9, 1880 (Morning paper): "Where are the croakers now? Yesterday morning when the rain ceased, the street and rails became coated with ice. Then it was doubtful to many if the cars would be able to ascend the Brady Street hill, but they did not remain long in doubt, for the electric cars went up and down the hill at their usual speed. When the first car started over the line, an interesting pyrotechnic display appeared on the trolley wire; the passage of the current melting the ice and emitting a bluish flame. As we are likely to have a snowstorm this evening or tomorrow, our citizens will get an opportunity of judging how it operated in deep snow."

Extract from Davenport Democratic Gazette, January 6, 1880 (Evening paper): "Snow has fallen on an average by daylight 8 to 10 inches. It was heavy and damp. The wind drifted it considerably. Long before daylight, street railroad men were at work with their snow ploughs. It was hard work too, because of the wind, while the air was full of falling snow. It packed hard on the rails. When time for business came, the electric cars had the advantage over the horse cars, for when the former started they moved with almost their usual speed. Steel brushes hanging from the platforms of the electric cars cleared the rails of the snow left by the ploughs and scrapers."

(Copy of a Letter) DAVENPORT CENTRAL RAILWAY COMPANY, Davenport, January 6, 1880

Sprague Electric Railway & Motor Company, Chicago, IL: GENTLEMEN, We have had as bad a snowstorm as far as street railroading is concerned, as is usually encountered in this section of the country, which you know is subject to very heavy snow and ice storms. Our cars made the usual time, while the horse cars ran slowly on their lines on a practically level road, and could not attain any speed over a walk all day. We naturally felt jubilant over our grand success. The president of a prominent Iowa street railway line was here today inspecting the system. He declared that it was not possible to do with horses what we did with electricity today. As we telegraphed you, our citizens are jubilant over the grand success. The wind was very strong and blew the snow back on the tracks almost as fast as it was cleaned off. The only difference that we could notice in the propulsion of the cars was that, at our power plant, it took 50 percent more all day long to propel the cars. We would not have minded it had it taken 100 percent increase; we were so pleased at being able to satisfy ourselves and the public even in a blizzard. When any railroad men are in doubt when you assert to them, as you did to us, that you can operate better in a snow or sleet storm than cars propelled by horses, refer them to us, and we will only be too pleased to verify your assertions.

Yours truly, Davenport Central Railway Co., W. ALLEN, President

18890204: THE WEATHER PROPOSITIONS Carnival! 1880 will bring all predecessors' troop of visitors in the city. The week's panorama (Written for the Montreal Gazette) When Dickens wrote Italian scenes and pictured Rome in hues of light, an all-mill grandeur intervenes 'Twixt squalid art and glory. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

**The Coliseum's mighty strength,  
Its stately, lordly dome,  
Arise in contrast, till at length  
I see all monumental Rome.  
He leaves the ruins to decay,  
The Forum's pillars tall a while,  
The relics by the Appian Way,  
The Pantheon's antiquated pile;  
All disappear, the scene is new.  
King Carnival in costume strides,  
And on that wizard page we view  
How masquerade in splendor glides.  
Along the Corso sweeps the mass  
Of jubilant revelers, even there  
Across the yellow Tiber pass  
A peddler's flash and noise and glare.  
Along the bridge of St. Angelo,  
And the Palatine they rise,  
In the Piazza Popolo,  
Where modern palaces surprise.  
Rome masks and dominoes and din,  
Ariadne carriages, four abreast,  
Sweet flowers without, bon-bon within,  
And steeds in endless garlands dressed.  
And noise from hundred instruments,  
Amidst clatter, shouts, and wildest glee,  
Fantastic females, goblin gents,  
And hideous monsters, all we see.  
The sun on broad Campagna sets,  
Ten thousand rockets hiss in air,  
A fiery column here besets  
A palace built of prisms there.  
The pyrotechnic scene unrolled  
Beyond Arabian visions bright,  
When Lent's great bell is slowly tolled,  
And all the splendors fade in night.  
Not so our own Canadian scene!  
No sweet Italian zephyrs bland;  
A shroud of white on fields of green,  
The Ice-King reigns o'er all the land.  
But blue and deep Canadian sky,  
And crystal splendors 'round us glow!  
The Forest-god, in accents high,  
Proclaims the Carnival of Snow!  
One hundred feet of carved ice,  
The stately tower and walls appear,  
With motto, flags, and quaint device,  
The wintry palace columns rear.  
Its lordly roof, the stalactites,  
Pure icicles, like prisms seem;  
And from below the stalagmites,  
In bright electric glories gleam.  
Behold that frosty palace now,  
In floods of light of rainbow hue;  
With joy in the masked skate show,  
And, dancing, glide in grand review.  
Then music in voluptuous swell  
Gives life to every changing scene;  
The throb of timbrel, sound of bell,  
And roars of laughter intervene.  
Then clad in deerskin moccasins,  
With blanket coats and tuques of blue,  
On snowshoe tramps, loggans they go,  
The kids their divers sports pursue;  
Around the mountain, Indian file,  
Or down the inclined plane they glide;  
Mid frost or snow, and ice, they smile  
In Winter's northern blizzard pride.  
The curlers to the rink repair,  
With brooms and stones to push their game;  
Kite lanterns brightly flare,  
Without, the streets are all a-tame.  
Talk not of Carnivals in Rome,  
Or in that mellow Southern clime;  
Give us our Carnival at home,  
Our glorious air, our winter time!  
And thousands flock that dream to see;  
Kaleidoscopic splendors crowd  
Upon the senses gloriously;  
And mirth is rich and rare and loud.  
The Roman Carnival ascends,  
Like rocket, in a flash of light,  
Then midst confusion, soon descends,  
And fades in penitential night.  
And like its icy palace, ours  
Is brilliant for a glowing space;  
Then warmer suns and April showers  
All relics of its pride efface.  

Joseph K. Fohax  
House of Commons, Ottawa,  
2nd February, 1889  

**Everything in Readiness**  
The city hotels were all astir on Saturday afternoon and evening and yesterday, testifying to the large number of strangers that had come to the city for the Carnival which opens today. Among the visitors are many old-time Montrealers who have been away from the city for years, and they one and all express wonderment at the improvement of the city. Today trains will pour in hundreds at the three depots, and the hotels will fill up to their utmost limits. The arrangements made for the great influx of visitors are very complete, and will doubtless prove highly satisfactory in the prevention of anything like confusion or disappointment. Both the railway companies have made special arrangements for the regulation of public sleighs during the week.  

**L. White, abandoned off Delaware Bay, March 13, during the great "blizzard."**  
All her crew were rescued, and the vessel, with masts and portions of her sails standing and ensign set, with union down, drifted off to the southeast before the northwest gale. Upon reaching the Gulf Stream she turned away to the eastward and commenced her long cruise toward Europe, directly in the track of the thousands of vessels engaged in transatlantic commerce, and now, after an interval of ten months and ten days, she has completed her voyage and lies stranded on the coast of Lewis Island, one of the Hebrides. In her cruise of ten months and ten days she traversed a distance of more than five thousand miles, was reported forty-five times, and how many more times vessels passed dangerously near her at night and in thick weather cannot even be estimated. The cruise of this derelict, as indicated by the very complete records in the Hydrographic office, is by far the most interesting on record. A California clergyman recently threw books and chairs from the pulpit among the congregation. He woke everybody up except one deacon who was superintendent of a boiler factory.

**Enjoying the Day at the Rinks**  
The continuation of Tuesday's storm, which developed from an ordinary snowstorm into an infant blizzard early yesterday morning, again did another good turn for the rinks. All day yesterday the different rinks were filled with the sounds of the scurrying of many feet, and it was not until the attack on the palace began that they were three more silent. At the Victoria matters were exceedingly lively. A good band, a good sheet of ice, and crowds of merry skaters created the amusement of the day for the Carnival visitors, a large number of whom were present. One gentleman, hailing from New York, who had previously passed some rather severe criticisms on the appearance of Montreal's fair sex, after making the circuit of the rink twice, remarked to his friend that he "would have to reiterate what he had said regarding the appearance of the young ladies of Montreal, as he had never seen so many pretty girls under one roof before," and glancing down the rink at two little girls who were waltzing to the popular air the band was then playing, he added, "Yes, and they can skate, too!" Some of the waltzing performed yesterday afternoon drew forth exclamations of surprise from the many Americans present. Among the visitors during the afternoon were His Excellency the Governor-General, Lady Stanley and the different members of His Excellency's party, and that of General Sir John Ross, who all partook of 5 o'clock tea in the directors' room. Mr. Louis Rubenstein, the world's champion fancy skater, was also present, and gave an exhibition of his marvelous skating before His Excellency, at the end of which he was presented by President Hemphill to His Excellency, who expressed his thanks and complimented Mr. Rubenstein very highly upon his proficiency. The vice-regal party left the rink soon after six. The skaters were by this time all at the Victoria rink and anyone who peeped into the Dominion rink would find large numbers of skaters thoroughly enjoying themselves.

On the Day of the CRUCIFIXION!

Corner St. Catherine & St. Urbain Sts.  

**FURS!**  
THE LADIES' FAVORITE  
The Lansdowne Seal Cap, convertible in three shapes, is still in great demand at the FIRST PREMIUM FUR ESTABLISHMENT.  

**J Bordeaux and two children died and another child will die at Shelter, Mason County, from poison, all being seized with fits immediately after dinner. It is supposed they ate cabbage containing poison. The family came recently from Canada.**  

**The British Embassy, Washington, February 9**  
No information has been received at the State Department in regard to the appointment of a British minister to this country. The department has, however, been informed that Mr. Edwards, first secretary of legation at Washington, who has been in London for some time, has sailed for this country. On his arrival here he will assume charge of the affairs of the legation. His return at this particular time is understood by certain officials to mean that there is no immediate prospect of the appointment of a successor to Lord Sackville.  

**The Remains of a Noted Gang of Counterfeiters**  
Pittsburgh, February 9  
United States Detective Sweeney and Deputy Marshal Chambers arrived here today with thirteen counterfeiters, who were captured in Butler County during the past ten days. Several other members of the gang are yet to be apprehended. It took about twenty-five officers to make the arrests, as the men are desperate characters. The band was regarded as one of the most dangerous and successful in the country. Thousands upon thousands of dollars of bogus coin have been passed in different states by the counterfeiters.  

**Can Canada Equal This?**  
Reading, PA, February 9  
The sheriff of Berks County yesterday sold ten fine farms in this county, aggregating nearly one thousand acres. During the present winter the sheriff has sold some twenty other large farms, besides the stock of twenty farmers, all of whom had failed. This indicates that farming no longer pays, as a similar state of affairs exists in other counties in this section of the state.  

**A Fight for Life**  
Portland, ME, February 9  
The fishing schooner Herbert M. Rogers, of Gloucester, had a terrible experience on Wednesday night in the storm off Thatcher's Light. The crew were forced to chop all night at the rapidly forming ice in order to keep the schooner afloat. When they reached this port, the vessel and men plainly showed the effects of their fight for life in the blizzard.  

**Murder and Suicide**  
St. Louis, February 9

ascertained that the indebtedness of Dieckmann, the absconding member of the merchants exchange on the Moor, will be small. The total amount of his defalcations will approximate $200,000. It is rumored that Dieckmann has committed suicide at Windsor, Canada.

A Drug Clerk's Mistake
Lancaster, Pa, February 9 — Thomas Bradenburg, the Columbia drug clerk who caused John Wander's death by selling him morphine for quinine, and who was convicted of involuntary manslaughter, was sentenced today to twenty days' imprisonment.

A Tariff Bombshell
Fair Augusta, February 9 — A Washington dispatch says Congressman Randall has decided to report the tobacco tax repeal bill. This will be a bombshell in the tariff reform camp.

What is His Shortage?
St. Louis, February 9 — Edward C. Brock, assistant cashier of the Commercial Bank, committed suicide this morning by shooting. Cause unknown.

Minor Items
Prices of Lehigh coal have been cut down 25 cents per ton. The Ohio and Western Coal and Iron Company has failed. The Dakota Legislature has defeated the Woman Suffrage bill. The engineers of the Minneapolis Motor Street Railway are on strike. Minister Phelps and wife arrived in New York on Saturday from England. The ravages of pneumonia in Granite, Mont, are terrible. The doctors seem unable to control the disease. The bursting of a centrifugal machine in the works of the New York Tartar Company, Brooklyn, killed two men and wounded three others on Saturday. The Philadelphia Coal and Iron Company has been awarded the contract supplying the United States Government with three thousand tons of anthracite coal, delivered at Samoa. The managers of the Nicaragua Canal Company say they will begin work as soon as President Cleveland signs the bill incorporating the company. They have a preliminary fund of $2,000,000. 

At Hutchinson, Kansas, a pretty eighteen-year-old girl, who gives her name as Cora Wilson, has been arrested for passing counterfeit money. She says she is the daughter of a Presbyterian minister in Ohio. The Bronko Iron Company, of Birdboro, Pa, has reduced the wages of their puddlers from $3.25 to $3 per ton. This is the lowest figure paid since the panic. Nearly 200 men are affected and they do not seem inclined to accept. The mills at Pottstown and other places recently made similar reductions. Anillo Redmond, who was kidnapped from her parents in Chicago over a year ago, and whose father has gone insane over her loss, was recovered on Saturday. She had been abducted by a rascally captor, who brutally abused her. On seeing his child again, the father recovered his senses. The kidnappers were arrested.

A NEWSPAPER DEAL
The Winnipeg Free Press' Keen Resignation
Morning Monopoly, Winnipeg, February 10 — The air has been full of rumors the last few days in reference to the Morning Call as it was understood offers had been made for it by the local Government and the Free Press Company. Late on Saturday night it was announced that Acton Burrows, representing the Call shareholders, had sold the plant and franchise to the Free Press. The plant includes the whole outfit of the Morning and Weekly Call and a large job office, the whole having been put in new last summer after the Call's fire. The Call owned the franchise of the United Press and Press News, which combined with the Associated Press held by the Free Press, now gives that paper a monopoly of the morning field here. The consideration is said to be $64,400. Mr. Luxton will remain editor-in-chief of the Free Press. Mr. Burrows will wind up the affairs of the Call Company, and after that will probably take active charge of the Norwest Farmer Company, of which he is the principal stockholder. It is almost certain the local Government will get a paper established in their interest, but it will have to take an evening field. The Free Press contemplates getting out an evening edition at an early date.

18890214: H. Ottsman's Donnybrook has also been declared out of the Suburban, Sheepshead Bay and Bay Ridge handicaps. Despite the blizzard that was blowing yesterday afternoon, eight men stepped to the score on the Montreal Gun Club grounds. It was the eighth handicap competition for the club greeter, and as Cowicy had already two liens on it, he was looked upon as a probable winner, but he was not allowed to get the gun without a struggle for it. The scores do not come up to the average, but when the blustering weather is considered, they were very good indeed. The winners of previous competitions with their scores were: 1

18890314: We regret to announce the death of Donald and John Finlayson, of this town, sons of the late Donald Finlayson. They were overtaken by a severe blizzard and frozen to death. They were industrious farmers in that section and in good circumstances.

Montreal, Kingston, Ont, March 13 — Word has been received from Ottawa to the effect that the Orangemen employed in the penitentiary will receive permission to walk in the 12th of July procession on giving two days' notice that they wish to do so.

Commercial Gazette
Ottawa, Friday Evening — Ecerbohm's cable today says: Cargoes off coast, wheat, nothing offering; corn, quiet. Cargoes on passage and for shipment, wheat quiet; corn steady. French country markets, steady; Liverpool wheat and corn spot, rather easier. Liverpool mixed malt, 3s 11 'd; Canadian peas, 6s 7d; Mark Lane English and foreign wheat, quiet. Mark Lane American and Dominican maize, steady. Mark Lane English and American flour, quiet.

United States Grain Markets
There was more activity in the Chicago wheat market and a larger volume of trading was transacted but a weaker feeling prevailed, and prices declined slightly, closing at 60c May, 61 jo June, 60c July. Corn was quiet and easier, and fell off 1c, closing at 35c May, 35c June, 30c July. On the other hand, oats were stronger and moved up 1c, closing at 25c May, 26c June, 25c July. Today's inspection was 40 car winter wheat, 23 spring, 341 command, 108 oats. Macdongall Bros, stock brokers and members of the Chicago Board of Trade, have received the following dispatch from A. Geddes & Co., their Chicago agents: 

June weather in March has quite a depressing effect on all our markets. It is too good to last. Wheat broke at two cents, closing a cent lower than yesterday. At the moment there is no encouragement to buy. Our private advices report heavy sales throughout California and prospects excellent. Foreign markets are heavy. Corn dull; no marked change. Provisions dull and easier. Warm weather unfavorable for packing operations.

New York, March 14 — The blizzard which the bulls have been looking for got lost en route, and the finer weather than expected has thawed out more long stuff, with a consequent decline of 1c this morning. The wheeling is still very soft for the market, which breaks through at every step under the load of long stuff. The road still looks very muddy and full of pitfalls, with Chicago 2c higher than New York, instead of 8c lower than New York, as it ought to be on a normal basis. How this breach of 10c is to be adjusted with a foreign demand not in the calculation is the interesting problem which has already worn out many pencils and exhausted the patience of the $3 bulls, who are now watching with increasing interest the deepening color of the bluebird's wing and wondering what relation there is between the pussy willows now blooming in this vicinity and the unsold and at present prices unsaleable stocks of wheat and flour, while the sower already is going forth to sow.

The New York wheat market was weaker and declined 1c, closing at 91c March, 92c April, 93c May, 94c June, 90c July. Corn dropped 1c, closing at 42c March, 43c April, 43c May, 43c June. Oats closed at 30c April, 30c May, 30c June. Ocean freight to Liverpool by steam was strong and higher at 3d per bushel. At Toledo, wheat was weak and dropped 3c, No. 2 red closing at 95-97c cash, 92c May, 92c June, 80c July, 85c August. Corn was dull, closing at 34c cash, 34c April, 35c May. Oats were unchanged, No. 1 white at Detroit was weak and broke 1c, closing at 98c cash. At Milwaukee, wheat fell off 1c, closing at 80c cash, 80c March, 87c May.

Montreal Grain and Flour
Owing to the weak western markets and the continued quiet advices from abroad, there was little life in the local grain market. Buyers held off and showed little disposition to take hold. In wheat, business was quiet and prices steady. Corn was slow and unchanged. Prices were dull, with offerings light. Oats met with a moderate demand at quotations. We quote Canadian spring wheat, $1.20; red winter wheat, $1.23-28; white, $1.23-28; No. 1 hard Manitoba, $1.33-35; No. 2 do, $1.30-31; peas, 67-68c per 56 lbs; oats, 32-33c; corn, 45-46c in bond; barley, 50-53c. There was no important change in the flour market to note. The demand was slow and the market quiet with little business outside of a small jobbing trade. Prices were steady all around. Manitoba strong bakers' was fairly enquired for, but no large sales were reported. Patent winter $8.78-90; full patent spring $6.29-00; high patent roller $6.40-110; extra $6.16-26; straight $4.26-30; city strong bakers' $6.10-20; strong bakers' $5.80-8.30 (seconds) $6.00. 18890321: LONDON MONEY MARKET. The Economist of March 9 says: "Apart from the uncertainty that has been imported into it by the financial crisis in Paris, the condition of our money market has not altered during the past week. The bank return shows a falling off in the amount of the reserve, due to the expansion of the internal circulation of notes and coin, but that is only what was to be expected at the beginning of the month. And in the course of a week or two, we shall see a still larger expansion, for the Government payments are always heavy toward the end of the quarter, and there are other movements of money that draw coin and notes from the bank and put them into circulation. In ordinary course, therefore, the bank reserve should be considerably reduced between now and the end of the quarter, and this will serve to bring into greater prominence the fact that the bank has not yet succeeded in attracting gold hither from abroad. A considerable amount of the metal is now on its way to Europe, but it was always doubtful if much of that would find its way to the bank; and the doubt must be all the greater now, when the financial difficulties in Paris will make the continental banks anxious to strengthen their position. For although, with the help of the other grand banks, the Comptoir d'Escompte has arranged to meet the run upon it, and has satisfied the claims of nearly all its depositors, its difficulties have not been surmounted. Indeed, its most serious troubles have yet to be faced, for it is burdened with a load of copper which has fallen fully 20 percent in price during the past few days, and, what is still worse, with onerous responsibilities in connection with its guarantees of contracts entered into by the Société des Métaux. The position in Paris thus remains extremely critical, and although, in any case, there is no reason to expect much disturbance to our money market, still the situation is one which calls for the exercise of great caution."

COMMERCIAL GAZETTE OFFICE, Wednesday Evening. Europe. H. B. Stebbins' cable today says: Cargoes off east, wheat very dull. Corn, slow. Cargoes on passage and for shipment, wheat and corn very little demand. California wheat, off coast, 37s; California wheat promptly to be shipped, 36s; California wheat, nearly due, 37s. French country markets steady. Liverpool wheat, spot very flat. Corn do, weaker. Liverpool standard California wheat, including club white, 7s 4d-7s 7d. Mark Lane English and foreign wheat weaker. Mark Lane American and Danubian prices quieter. Mark Lane English and American flour weaker. Australian wheat off coast 88s; present and following month, 88s 6d. Chilian wheat off coast, 36s 3d; present and following month, 30s 3d. Walla Walla wheat off coast, 36s 3d; present and following month, 36s 3d. London, March 18. The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: English wheat values are lower. It is frequently impossible to effect sales. Prices in Scotland are even lower than in England. The sales of English wheat during the past week were 61,423 quarters at 30s 2d, against 77,228 quarters at 30s 6d, during the corresponding week last year. Most foreign wheat fell 1d. Flour is weak, although the supply of foreign is moderate. In London, barley has declined a fraction. In a majority of the country markets, prices have hardened. A large quantity of corn causes weakness in some cases, while in others prices are in sellers' favor. Oats have improved 3d-5d. The demand does not equal the hopes of holders. Rye is a trifle firmer. Beans are a little weaker. At today's market, English wheat was in moderate request at last Monday's prices. Foreign was weaker. There was no speculation. Flour was unchanged. The recent arrivals are not satisfactory, and drag. Barley was steady. Round corn was in fair retail request at the very low prices accepted last Monday. Flat corn was 3d cheaper on the week. There was a very small fresh supply of oats, and prices advanced 3d. Beans and peas were dull. Rye was steady. In the very latest dealings, breadstuff and corn were weaker. United States Grain Markets. In the Chicago wheat market, a stronger feeling prevailed and prices advanced 1-2c. The market was fairly active, and trading was more lively, closing at 83 1/2c May, 92c June, 89c July. Corn was quiet but firmer, and improved 1/4c, closing at 35c May, 36c June, 35c July. Oats were weaker and eased off 1/4c, except for the May option, which moved up 1/4c, closing at 25c May, 24 1/4c June, 24 1/4c July. Today's inspection was 14 cars winter wheat, 13 spring, 412 corn, and 124 oats. Macdougall Bros., stock brokers and members of the Chicago Board of Trade, have received the following dispatch from A. Goddard & Co., their Chicago agents: Wheat was firmer, though outside reports continue bearish. Our private cable reports that California cargoes arriving on French account are pressing on the English markets for sale. Hence we cannot look for much support from abroad. At the same time, there is danger in being short in the market. There is money under it, and the trade is liable to go a surprise any day. Corn was heavy, though there appears to be good buying orders at 35c for May. Provisions were stronger. Pork is seemingly well held and is likely to sell higher; closed at $12.25 May. James R. Barclay & Co., grain and stock and provision brokers, No. 18 St. Sacrament street, report the Chicago market as follows: 

Wheat - May, June, July. 
Corn - May, June, July. 
Oats - May, June, July. 
Pork - May, June, July. 
Lard - May, June, July. 

It was just about this time a year ago that contracts for May wheat were being kicked around. The April 10th Government report came out, and before anybody knew it, the price of May was up 10c or more. While this doesn't prove anything as to what will happen this year, it will do for a reminder. The great blizzard of last March got lost on its way here this year, although many people prepared for it; just as the same superstition is at work now in predictions of a big rise to follow the April crop report. Preparations for it will do much to avert it. However, good thinkers are going slow, at 62c for May wheat as sellers. It is the long wheat that is on top of the market now, and not the shorts. It broke the market down this morning. The shorts furnished the principal buyers, although some of the local traders bought for a turn. It looks as if there was too much long stuff in the market for any permanent or considerable rally. On January 1, 1889, France held in seaport granaries close upon 10,000,000 bushels of wheat; this during January was reduced to 12,000,000 bushels; but the receipts in February have been considerable, and the present stocks in "bond" cannot be far off 34,000,000 bushels. The ice and swollen state of the rivers have interfered with wider mills. The Indian market is quiet. Recent rains have improved crop prospects in the northwest, and an average yield is expected which would allow for shipment equal to the season now closing. There will be a short supply of Bombay soft grades; otherwise, the outlook is fairly satisfactory. Since January 1, Bombay and Karachi have sent to Europe about 3,700,000 bushels, of which about 1,410,000 were for the continent, against about 1,040,000 bushels for those ports during the same period last year. There is now on passage for Europe 2,206,000 bushels, against 604,000 bushels in 1888. The continued outpour of long wheat kept the market in weak and unsettled condition throughout the session. Exporters were moderate buyers (eight loads) of cash stuff; two loads for Scotch ports and the rest for Lisbon. At the seaboard, wheat was stronger and moved up, closing at 90c March, 90 1/2c April, 91c May, 92c June. Corn was weaker and fell off 1/2c, closing at 42c March, 42c April, 42 1/2c May, 43c June, 43c July. Oats closed at 30 1/2c March, 30c April, 30c May, 30c June. Ocean freights to Liverpool by steam were steady at 3d per bushel. In Toledo, wheat was weaker and declined 1/2c, No. 1 red closing at 91c cash, 90c May, 89c June, 85c July, 84c August. Corn closed at 33 1/2c cash, 33c May. Oats were nominal, No. 1 white at Detroit was weak and broke 1c, closing at 90c cash. At Milwaukee, wheat improved 1/2c, closing at 86 1/2c cash, 86c March, 87 1/2c. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:
