May - Montreal Grain Market - In the local grain market, business was quiet owing to the limited demand, and few sales were effected. Advice from abroad was quiet and weaker, with prices lower, while the western markets were stronger and higher. There was no change here, prices being steady all round. The demand for wheat was quiet, and only a few car lots were placed at quotations. Corn and peas were neglected and unchanged. There was a fair inquiry for oats, and car lots changed hands at 32c-32½c. Barley was dull and unchanged. We quote: Canadian spring wheat, $1.20; red winter wheat, $1.23-$1.25; white, $1.23-$1.28; No. 1 hard Manitoba, $1.33-$1.35; No. 2 do, $1.30-$1.31; peas, 67c-68c per 60 lbs; oats, 32c-32½c; corn, 45c-46c in bulk; barley, 50c-53c. The Winnipeg Commercial says: "In sympathy with the great weakness outside, prices in Manitoba markets were lower. Prices paid to farmers at provincial points were dropped about 60 cents during the week, and now average about 91c per bushel for No. 1 hard, against an average of $1 last week. In the different provincial markets, deliveries were very light, and business in wheat at primary points is thought to be about over until after seeding. Opinions, of course, differ widely as to the quantity of wheat being held for summer marketing, but it is thought to be even lighter than usual." The feeling in the flour market has continued to be easy, and holders generally were offering more freely at somewhat lower prices, but holders held off as they did not feel disposed to take hold. In consequence, the market was dull, with only a small jobbing trade in progress. There were no sales reported on 'Change. Patent winter $5.78; patent spring, $6.20; straight roller, $5.50; extra $6.15; superfine $4.85; city strong bakers' $6.00; strong bakers', $6.50; range bakers', bags, $3.80; napkins, bags, $2.00; extra bags $2.30; oatmeal, standard, per bag $6.00; oatmeal, granulated, per bag $6.00-$6.50; $5.80; $6.25; $4.75; $6.10; $8.00; $2.86; $2.26; $2.80; $2.00; $2.10. Receipts posted on 'Change today were as follows:

18890322: JOHNS Hope for Hay Ulmatu-Ayr A factory - The Military School (From a correspondent) The great motive advocated by those wishing to have the military school removed here is the lack of a rifle range. Now, we are not to understand, I hope, that there is no way of effecting a remedy. Long ago, in a report made by Col. d'Orsonnens to the military authorities, the fact of our being without a rifle range here was dwelt on, and this drawback was clearly demonstrated; but, on the other hand, a suggestion was made concerning the estate Langolior property, which is perfectly adapted for a rifle range. The Minister of Militia has had the matter in hand ever since, and he is the one to decide the time and place concerning this matter, the opinion of the correspondent of the Canadian Militia Gazette to the contrary notwithstanding. The suggestion of the commandant was at the time supported by some of the citizens here, and the Minister of Militia knows what offers were made in view of securing the property in question, which for a mere nominal rental can be utilized for a rifle range. The matter could be fixed very quickly yet, and as soon as the minister decides it won't take long to do it. Should any aid from the corporation be required, I have no doubt that our City fathers will extend their courteous support, as they have intimated they are ready to do. The school will remain here, and it is without any doubt the most advantageous situation, at any point of view, of any in the whole Dominion. At least the outlook is much brighter concerning the early settlement of the Hay claims. Mr. Charles Arpin has received a letter from an Oswego counselor-at-law, who is working on the claims, who says: "I have just returned from Washington, and I consider the outlook brighter as far as regards claimants in the United States." No doubt claimants in the United States will have the preference over Canadian claimants from their government, especially now that the latter has appointed Mr. Walter O. Blaine, son of the Secretary of State, to the high position of adjuster of claims against the United States government. But on the other hand, the question at stake is one of national honor and justice, and Canadians will not be long kept waiting. It looks now as if we were to be benefited by the business of the Messrs. Ayer & Co., of Lowell, Mass. Mr. Mansfield, the agent, who was interviewed a few days ago at the Balmoral by Acting Mayor Arpin, gave him to understand that between the shoe factory building and the Bertrand property, the house would make a choice site, and locate likely in St. Johns. Mr. Arpin suggested to Mr. Mansfield to offer to Messrs. Ayer an exemption from municipal taxes for a series of years if they would come here, and also to build at the corporation's expense a drain for either of those properties. No better place could be selected by the Messrs. Ayer than St. Johns. The labor is already centered here, where the firm carried on their business for a great many seasons. Labor is cheaper here than it would be in a large city. The properties in question are situated along the railway, from which a large amount of hauling can be saved every year. Freight rates are just as low here as from Montreal, and there is no better distributing point. Boxes for packing can be had at less than city prices, and the exemption from taxes alone is quite an item compared to what taxes would be on such an enterprise in a large city.

LOST IN THIS STORM One of our local editors clipped from a leading magazine extracts from a vivid description of a western blizzard which we take the liberty to publish and suggest to H. H. Warner & Co., the proprietors of the celebrated Warner's Safe Cure, the feasibility of an extract for the introduction of one of their telling advertisements. The following is the description: "At the close of a dark day in January, a solitary horseman wends his way across the open prairie in one of our western territories. He passes at long intervals the lone cabin of the hardy frontiersman. Two or three old settlers, of whom he has inquired the way, have warned him that a storm is approaching, and with true western hospitality, urge him to accept shelter for the night. But he declines the proffered kindness and urges his tired horse forward. The sky grows suddenly dark. The storm increases in its fury. The rider dismounts to warm his numb chilling limbs. He can scarcely breathe. Drowsiness steals over him. The end is near. He is lost in the blizzard." The terror which seizes the bewildered traveler is similar to that which overcomes one when he learns that he is suffering from an advanced kidney disease, and is informed that he is in the last stages of Bright's disease. At first, he is informed that he has a slight kidney affection. Later, he begins to feel tired (slight headache), fickle appetite, failure of eyesight, cramp in the calf of the legs, wakefulness, distressing nervousness, rheumatic and neuralgic pains, occasionally pain in the back, scanty, dark-colored fluids, with scalding sensation, gradual failure of strength. Any of the above symptoms signify kidney affection. His physician treats him for symptoms and calls it a disease, when in reality it is but a symptom of kidney trouble. He may be treated for rheumatic or neuralgic pains, heart affection, or any other disease to which he is most susceptible. Finally, the patient has pulling under the eyes, slight bloating of the ankles and legs. His physician informs him that it is but the accumulation of blood in his ankles for want of proper exercise. The bloat continues and reaches his body. Then he is informed he has dropsical troubles, and is tapped once or twice. He notices it is difficult to breathe owing to irregular action of the heart, and finally is informed that he has a slight attack of Bright's disease. At last, the patient suffocates, is smothered, and dies from dropsical trouble. Or perhaps the disease may not take the form of a dropsical tendency, and the patient dies from apoplexy, paralysis, pneumonia, or heart trouble. Or it may take the form of blood poisoning. In each form, the end is the same. And yet he and his friends were warned by the proprietors of the celebrated remedy known as Warner's Safe Cure, of the lurking dangers of a slight kidney affection: he did not heed the warning that a storm was approaching. He declined the proffered hospitality, and recklessly went forward into danger. He struggled manfully for a time, but his strength failed, he grew gradually weaker and he was lost to the world. Not in a blizzard, but from a terrible malady which is occurring in every community, and which is treated as a symptom instead of what it is—a mortal disease unless properly treated.

Ontario Items: Nearly $11,000 has been subscribed for the new St. Andrew's church at Perth. The oldest man in Canada, says the Perth Expositor, John Vaughan by name, died last week at Easton's Corners. No one seems to know just how old he was, but proof is said to have been made that he was at least 110. Large numbers of our farmers, says the Perth Expositor, are leaving for Manitoba by the Canadian Pacific railway colonist trains every Tuesday. Montague, Beckwith, Lanark, and Lanark townships have the Manitoba fever very badly. Archdeacon Bedford Jones, at Napanee, in his discourse on Sunday week, styled prohibition and total abstinence "quack remedies," and claimed that the grace of God should be relied upon, rather than the legislation of a parliament, to suppress the liquor traffic. The action of the trustees of the Methodist church, Bolingbroke, against the Baptist minister and Mr. Korry has been settled. The Methodists retain the church, the burying ground is to be used as a general burying ground, and each party pays their own costs. The South Lanark branch of the Dominion Alliance has issued an appeal to the electors in view of the coming election on the repeal of the Scott Act, setting forth that the repeal of the Scott Act means a return to license; that license is not only vicious in principle, but powerless as a remedy for the evils of intemperance; that those whose wills are weakened by a depraved appetite are entitled to the protection of a Christian state against that which leads them astray; that wherever the Scott Act has been fairly enforced, it has undoubtedly lessened the amount of drinking and all its attendant evils; and finally that the Scott Act has not had a fair trial in Lanark.

18890405: THE QUEBEC BRIDGE Another deputation is to wait today upon the Dominion Government to urge the immediate construction of a railway bridge across the St. Lawrence at Quebec. This work would, of course, in one way be of considerable importance to the Ancient Capital. The expenditure of the sum the bridge is expected to cost in its immediate neighborhood would give a much-needed temporary boom to its trade, and the facilities for reaching the city from the south shore would be permanently improved. But there is more than a Quebec view to take of this question. The country is asked to expend upon this scheme a sum estimated at the least at six million dollars, and certain, before the completion, to be largely enhanced. Are these advantages to the country such as would warrant the increase of the national debt by such a sum? Would the traffic presenting itself, at a reasonable toll, pay interest on the original cost and the charges of maintenance? Those are questions that have to be satisfactorily answered before Parliament can consent to vote such a heavy subvention. The Quebec people themselves have not shown their faith in their own claims; the company formed to undertake the work received subscriptions of only ten thousand dollars from the merchants of the city whose trade is presumed to warrant so vast an expenditure. That certainly is not an encouragement to the Dominion to invest in a structure the traffic of which may be estimated from the fact that up to the present it has never been sufficient to warrant the operation of an ordinary railway ferry. Two small steamers accommodate the freight and passenger traffic.

--- 

All OCR errors have been corrected while maintaining the original meaning and formatting as closely as possible. Here is the corrected text:

---

lic between the north and south shores of the St. Lawrence at Quebec. A memorial presented to the Government last year dwells on the importance of an unbroken connection from ocean to ocean over Canadian territory. But this connection already exists. At Montreal and at Lachute, bridges now built unite the Intercolonial system with the Western lines. Within a year, a bridge at Coteau will give a third available connection for an all-Canadian route from the Atlantic to the Pacific. There is no object in freight from the lower to the upper provinces, or vice versa, crossing the river at Quebec. Cars delivered by the Intercolonial to the Grand Trunk at Chaudière Junction are practically the same distance from Montreal and points in Ontario as they would be after crossing the river on the proposed bridge. Traffic from Montreal and Toronto to Halifax, or from Halifax to Montreal and Toronto, covers the bulk of the Intercolonial's through business. I would be actually disadvantaged by having to use the bridge. The tolls would be an unnecessary and serious burden, and the extra distance to be traversed would be a drawback. The coal and sugar traffic would not find the bridge route; it reaches its destination in Montreal much better and more conveniently by existing lines. The east-bound freight from the cities at Montreal and points west will follow the route taken by that coming from the lower province seaboard. No argument based upon the traffic requirements can justify the demand for so many millions from the country. These demands are amply met by existing lines. The traffic in coal, lumber, live stock, fish, grain, flour, and other foodstuffs that constitutes the growing bulk of the Intercolonial's business neither arises nor ends in Quebec. The men who handle this merchandise do not make their headquarters in the ancient city. They live east and west of it; they are among the consumers at either end of the railway system. They would not be benefited by the bridge. As for the local trade of the city, as has been said above, ferry steamers accommodate it, and the need for a car transfer boat has not yet become imperative. These are facts that the Government and Parliament should take into very serious consideration before pledging such enormous sums of public money to any scheme, let alone one of such doubtful public utility, even from a Quebec view; for it is not yet shown how a bridge for through traffic some six miles distant from that city will build up its importance or its trade.

ENGLAND'S FRIEND, KING JOHN

The reported death of King Johannes of Abyssinia recalls the remarkable part that Prince Kassai was called upon to play in one of England's great modern military enterprises. Some of our readers may remember the time when King Theodore was a daily subject of conversation on the streets and a frequent theme for comment, more or less to the point, in the press. At that time Abyssinia was one of the least known of countries, and the obstinate potentate who deeply resented a slight to his dignity as a sovereign as to defy the power of Great Britain was only known by name and by vague reports of his doings. His rise to supreme power was not, however, without features of romance, and though he closed his life under a cloud of defeat and ignominy, there was a stage in his career when his power and reputation made him not the least enviable of semi-barbarous rulers. He was of noble lineage, fairly well educated, and early began to show ability as a leader of men. Putting himself at the head of the organized opposition, he successively defeated all the troops sent against him and finally had himself crowned as Theodore III. In 1860, the British consul, Mr. Plowden, who was strongly attached to Theodore, was mortally wounded. The King took a terrible revenge on his murderers. Captain Cameron, the new consul, arrived at Massowah in 1862, and soon after reached Theodore's camp. In October of the same year, Consul Cameron was dispatched with a letter to Queen Victoria, which was handed to the officials of the foreign office in February 1863. For some reason, it was not answered. About August, 1863, Captain Cameron returned to Abyssinia, without the King's authority. At the same time, Theodore was chafing at the failure of the Queen to answer his letter. Doubly offended, therefore, he had Cameron, and Messrs. Stern and Rosenthal cast into prison. Intelligence of what had taken place reaching England, Mr. Hormuzd Rassam was dispatched with a letter to the King, but not for over a year did he receive any satisfaction. He was then invited to visit the King and treated with courtesy and hospitality, but a change occurred in Theodore's mind and the released prisoners were again thrust into confinement. About the same time, Mr. Flad was dispatched with a letter to the Queen asking for European workmen and machinery. For a time, the prisoners were well treated but latterly they suffered from both cold and hunger, as well as constant apprehension. Mr. Flad's return with a reply to Theodore's letter saying that the workmen and machinery would be sent as soon as the prisoners were set free produced no effect. In 1867, it was recognized that force would have to be used. Accordingly, an army was especially equipped for the service with Sir Robert Napier (now Lord Napier of Magdala) as commander. The story of the campaign has been often told. It has long been part of our military history. The landing took place on the 7th of January, 1868, the task to be accomplished being the transport of over 30,000 men over 400 miles of mountainous country to Theodore's fortress at Magdala. On the 11th of April, the storming of that stronghold took place and Theodore's dead body was found within. The success of the expedition was largely due to the timely aid of Prince Kassai of Tigré. Had he been hostile, instead of friendly, the issue might, indeed, have been sadly different. Before leaving the country, the English General showed his gratitude by a gift of ordnance, small arms, and ammunition, of which the happy receiver made such good use that he not only declared and maintained his independence but made himself Theodore's successor. In 1872 he was crowned King of Abyssinia at Axum. On the throne he never forgot that to England's opportune present he was largely indebted for his good fortune. England did not always reciprocate the barbarian's good will. His confidence in her friendship must sometimes have been severely tried. For years the Egyptians proved a thorn in his side, of late the Italians have given him constant anxiety on one hand and the fanatical Dervishes on the other. Whether England could have turned the opportunities opened up in 1868 to better account for the advancement of civilization in nominally Christian Abyssinia, it is needless to discuss. Practically she did nothing with her knowledge or with King John's friendship—agencies which might, if properly employed, have been used as levers for the moral elevation, as well as for the material and commercial development of all East Africa. Now the country is once more in a state of anarchy and rulers may arise who will only remember that England, while quick to avenge her slighted honor and injured citizens, is also quick to forget those who befriend her in the hour of need.

It was a very wet day in Ontario yesterday. The new states of Dakota are getting a baptism of fire. The Globe has found a new position on the Jesuits' bill. It is that Mr. Hurdler, being a Catholic, did right to pass it; but Sir John Macdonald, being a Protestant, did wrong to allow it. This makes things right for the Liberals both in Ontario and Quebec. The Pope in his letter to Cardinal Gibbons and the American Catholics seeks the sympathy of "those even who, though not in communion with us, are at least witnesses" of the Pontiff's loss of power. Standard is needed in Europe more than in Quebec. The Mail has published the portraits of all Toronto's detectives. They make the worst looking lot of countenances that has appeared in public since the Witness printed its pictures of Montreal's alibis. The average criminal would gladly go to prison to be out of their way. Lieutenant William Grant Stairs, who is doing such good service with Buller, is a Canadian, son of the former M.P. for Halifax, a graduate of '82 of the Kingston Military College, and a lieutenant in the Royal Engineers. With such a beginning as he has made, it is safe to say that his country will hear more of him before his career is ended. 

Patagonia has a plague for every season. Cyclones sweep it in the summer; early frosts parch its harvests in the fall. In the winter, its blizzards overwhelm the unwary traveler. The spring wind and rain combine to ruin its farmers. The only thing its people can do is to move up into Canada out of the ruin while yet some of them are spared. The United States Treasury is doing presently profitable business by buying two million dollars worth of silver every month and coining it into two million eight hundred thousand silver "dollars." This is a thing that can only go on for a certain length of time. By and by a United States dollar will only purchase 75 cents worth of goods, and then the silver kings will be deposed. 

Fleeing from France to Belgium has been like stepping out of the frying pan into the fire for General Boulanger. He is in imminent danger of expulsion from his present refuge, and his friends at home are divided. A number of them call him a coward. This is the worst appellative that can be cast at a Frenchman. Ordinarily it would kill him politically; but Boulanger is as hard to kill as he is to define. The annual fight before the commissioner over the "Oxford" license has resulted, as usual, in the success of the saloon in the contest between the application and the opposition as to which could be the more earnest without actually breaking the law. It must be acknowledged that the saloon did not by any means come out ahead. The commissioners never had better ground for their action than this year. The exhibition of the Royal Institute of Painters in Water Colors, which took place in the spacious galleries in Piccadilly a few weeks ago, while up to the usual excellence, did not rise above it. The drawings were extremely numerous, there being 823. There were few that did not mark a respectable degree of attainment, but works of really striking merit were comparatively few, and the artists showed a tendency to repeat themselves. As a rule, the pictures lacked individuality and freshness. The Herald says Mr. Merivale returned from his mysterious mission on Tuesday and is now at Quebec. This story is meant for the marines. The idea of the Nationalist Premier going to the capital like an ordinary public man is too much. Where were the tinpot demonstrations; where, the brass band; where Mr. Pacaud? Why, Mr. Morin would have had a bigger reception if the Premier arrived in Quebec without the sycophants turning out. Next, we will hear that the seal coat is only plush. The Arab report that Rumley and Euan Boy are marching on Zanzibar with several thousand of a following is not out of keeping with the explorer's letter published the other day. Euan then was apparently in doubt as to where his duty lay, but it could not have been hard to persuade him that no profitable object was to be secured by remaining in Central Africa as the representative of a power which long ago abdicated its authority over the province he was sent to govern. So large a body as the united forces will necessarily move slowly, but it has a shorter distance to travel than that over which the news came, and, unless some serious mishap occurs, it will not be long till the world welcomes back the gallant governor and brave explorer whose conduct has given full warrant for bracketing their names with those two great Christian heroes of civilization in Africa, Gordon and Livingstone. An explanation was recently given in the Monitor du Home, of a rumor which, it appears, had been circulated in parts of the continent, to the effect that Queen Victoria and the Empress Dowager Frederick contemplated embracing Roman Catholicism. The story seems to have originated somewhat obscurely out of some conversations that passed at Her Majesty's tea table. The subject of Italy and the Vatican coming up, the Empress Frederick repeated some remarks of her late husband after his return, when Crown Prince, from a visit to Pope Leo XIII.

The Isle Emperor expressed the utmost respect for the personal character of His Holiness. The Empress Dowager said that, ever since, she had entertained a sentiment of veneration for the aged Pontiff. The Queen at once recalled that she shared those sentiments, but nothing was said either of joining the Church of Rome or of the struggle between the Vatican and Italy. The Monitor bases its version of the incident on a communication from London to the correspondent of AW.

1889-04-11: F. Alloway, of Winnipeg. Mrs. Alloway and another lady were in the room and all were chatting pleasantly together. Mr. Rata had been saying that he was feeling so well lately, and the conversation had drifted to other subjects, when he suddenly fell from his chair and died almost without a struggle. The alarm was given, and in a very short time four physicians were in attendance, but it was a case where skill could avail nothing. The deceased was born in the Niagara district, and was for some years a resident at St. Cuthbert’s, having been a resident of Ottawa for a great number of years and filled the mayor's chair. In 1881 he built up a large grocery business here and amassed great wealth. 

Two Men Drowned: St. John, N.H., April 10. Word has been received that on Thursday last a sleigh containing Pahlel Harris, John McDougall, and a friend named Lambe, of Caraquet, while proceeding up the Restigouche River to O'Leary's lumber camps, when at a place called Two Finks, about 23 miles above Mclupedin, the ice broke through and they were drowned.

EXPLORING IN A BLIZZARD: Lord Lonsdale Has a Narrow Escape From Death in the North. T., April 9. The fishing schooner Cumberland, Captain Elliott, which arrived here today after a stormy passage of thirty-four days from Kodiak Island, Alaska, brings news of Lord Lonsdale, who started upward of a year ago on a trip overland to the North Pole. Lord Lonsdale and a number of Eskimo and Indian guides reached Kodiak about the middle of February in a famished and exhausted condition. They came from an isolated mission near the mouth of the Kuskokwim River, which empties into Bristol Bay, and encountered many hardships and privations during the journey of months' duration across the Alaskan peninsula. The explorer, Lord Lonsdale, was severely injured a few days after leaving the mission. While in the lead of his party, he slipped and fell into a crevasse. His left shoulder was so bruised that the arm was rendered useless and his hip was all but dislocated, incapacitating him for travel on foot. He was placed on a sled, and in that condition transported to Kodiak. The great stretch of territory between the mission and the island was covered to the depth of several feet with light snow. The terrible blizzard that prevailed caught up the light particles in clouds, obfuscating all tracks and landmarks familiar to the guides and making drifts through which it was next to impossible to make a passage.

A Terrible Experience: On February 3, the party reached a lake almost in the center of the peninsula. A stop was made to rest the dogs, which were in a worse condition than the men. A blizzard set in and continued for four days, during which time Lord Lonsdale, the guides, dogs, and all were huddled together under a shelter made by standing the sled on end. When the storm ceased, Lord Lonsdale was found to be so ill from fatigue and lack of proper nourishment and medical treatment that it was feared he would not survive the journey. The guides broke up one of the sleds and built a fire, over which they cooked some food and boiled water, with which they bathed the injured parts and reduced the swelling. Lord Lonsdale improved somewhat, and the journey toward Kodiak was resumed.

One Hundred Below Zero: The latter half of the trip was even more perilous and trying than the beginning. The temperature for several days registered 100 below the freezing point, and blizzards were continuous. Several of the dogs succumbed to fatigue, others wandered off and were lost in the snow, and just before reaching Cook's Inlet, two of the Alaskan guides died and were buried in the snow. The party was in the last stages of fatigue when they reached Kodiak, and had not food and shelter been found there, Lord Lonsdale would have died. Captain Elliott offered the erratic nobleman passage in the Cumberland to New Westminster.

1889-04-20: GOVERNMENT SAVINGS BANK'S: A year ago, the expectation was aroused by Sir Charles Tupper, then Minister of Finance, of a reduction in the rate of interest paid on deposits in the Government savings banks. The Finance Minister had taken authority from Parliament to reduce the rate below 4 percent, and at the same time obtained power to issue a large loan in the London market, a portion of the proceeds of which it was hinted might be required to pay depositors in the Government savings banks who desired to withdraw their balances because of the lowering of the interest rate. Nothing, however, has yet been done in this direction, and there continues to be paid to the public creditor in Canada a rate of interest unduly high when compared with that paid to the public creditors abroad, or to the rates paid by the chartered banks. In round numbers, more than forty million dollars of the people's money is held in the Government banks, upon which interest to the amount of $1,600,000 is annually paid. Now the last loan placed in London is costing less than 3 percent, and it is fairly presumable that money can be borrowed there to pay off the depositors in the savings bank at as low a rate, in which case the operation would effect a saving in the annual interest charge upon the public revenues of the considerable sum of $360,000. So long as the Government was required to pay 4 percent interest for its British loans, the argument that Canadian creditors ought to receive as much for their money as those abroad had force, but that argument no longer applies. Tomorrow, by a stroke of the pen, almost, the Finance Minister can make a reduction in the interest charge of the public debt of at least $300,000, a sum sufficient to pay the interest on a capital charge of $9,000,000; or, to put it in another way, the Government could make a capital expenditure of $9,000,000 in enlarging the St. Lawrence canals without adding a single penny to the interest account by simply equalizing the rate paid on savings banks' deposits to that paid foreign creditors. The fear that a large withdrawal of deposits would follow upon a reduction in the rate of interest is probably unfounded. In the first place, the Government savings banks are patronized by a good many people because they afford absolute security; in the next place, a considerable proportion of the deposits are drawn from localities where no chartered banks exist and where, therefore, competition for the money does not prevail; and, lastly, the rate of interest paid by the chartered banks during the past two or three years has been lower than by the Government institutions. No doubt the depositors would clamor loudly against a reduction of one percent interest, but after all the depositors are a small minority of the whole people, and it is to the general interests, to the greatest good of the greatest number, that the Government should look. It is manifestly unfair that one hundred thousand depositors in the savings banks should annually draw in interest from the revenues from general taxation three or four hundred thousand dollars more than would be paid if the money were borrowed abroad. It is well to encourage habits of economy and thrift among the masses, to place within their reach safe and convenient receptacles for their surplus earnings, but these objects may be quite as effectively attained with a 3 percent as with a 4 percent rate of interest on deposits, the more especially since the chartered banks, less widely distributed and affording less advantages in some respects, pay the lower rate. 

Another reason often urged for reducing the interest on deposits in the savings banks is that the present rate diverts money from the chartered banks and therefore from the channels of legitimate trade. If, however, this argument is worth anything, it means that no competition with chartered banks ought to be permitted, and that not only the Government but the private savings banks ought to be abolished. It is, of course, presumable that a lowering of the Government interest to 3 percent would cause the transfer of some deposits to the chartered banks, and thereby increase the resources and loaning power of the latter, but the amount that would be exchanged would, we are convinced, be unimportant. The chartered banks today have abundant resources; their deposits have never before been so large as now, and they have continued to augment in spite of the payment of a lower rate of interest than in the Government banks. The strong argument to be pressed upon the Finance Minister for a reduction in the interest rate is that all the money the Government requires can be much more cheaply borrowed abroad, that the continuance of a 4 percent rate to depositors constitutes an unfair discrimination, and imposes an unnecessary charge upon the public revenues for the benefit of a favored class. 

The body of another murdered babe was found on the street yesterday. There will be another inquest today. That will end the chapter in crime. It always does in Montreal. It must have been the Wilneim's fodder famine maker that discovered in the Municipal Reports evidence that "the population of the Eastern Townships has decreased, not increased." Here is Dakota with another plague. Mice are so plentiful in the blizzard district that the rat market has gone up, and turns and tabbies are being shipped west in carloads and sold at $2 apiece. How thankful the Ontario exodusters this year must be that they disregarded the Grit papers' advice and made their new homes in Manitoba. Someone in the West has started a scare over the danger of smallpox or other disease developing on ocean steamships between the time they pass the Gros Islet quarantine station and the landing of their passengers at Montreal. Somebody wants a situation. Are healthy immigrants more exposed to infection during a tool sail up the river than during the same time spent in crowded immigrant rams? Mr. Mercler objects to the settlement of the Ontario boundary as proposed by the Dominion Government, though it is accepted by Mr. Mowat. The chief principle of Mr. Mercler’s politics is that the removal of any subject from the arena of dispute in which the Federal Government is likely to be a party to the proceedings is a thing to be steadfastly opposed. But the public is getting tired of a party that can only curse its opponents' propositions. The proposed settlement of the Ontario boundary, accepted by the federal and local Government, will give the province a seaboard of some hundred and fifty miles on Hudson's Bay, and add to it a knowledge territory, an irregular area having a southern base of about four hundred miles, the eastern and western boundaries converging till the Hudson's Bay coast is reached, where they are about one hundred and forty miles apart. The eastern limit is a straight line drawn due northward from the head of Lake Temiscamingue, which is probably the part that excites Mr. Mercler's opposition. There does not, however, seem any good ground for dissent. The territory is not agriculturally valuable so far as the greater part of it is known. It is not a timber region, and its mineral wealth is problematic. Poor or rich, however, it may as well belong to Ontario as to any other member of the federation. If Quebec wants more, the Dominion can throw in any extent of territory out of East Maine.

The Hon.

1889-07-01: B. Cutler, of Salt Lake, a banker of unlimited wealth. Bid odds were given on the Brooklyn Handicap, and, as Exile won, the firm paid out only $100, but took in thousands. The firm made big money on the Suburban, while Whitney and his partner stood to lose on Spokane in the American Derby, and rather than pay anything to the lucky bettor, concluded to jump the town. It is said that Whitney acted in a similar performance. 

East Hue ins at Winnipeg; Wixkipko, June 10. At the races...

--- 

Please note that some names and locations were preserved as they were in the original text, given that they may be proper nouns. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

Here today, the 2:40 was trot won by Alice Withers, half-sister of Fanny Withers. The track was heavy, the best heat being made in 2:18. Billy The Rover won the pony race, and Gray Eagle the half-mile running heat. Blizzard was the winner in the military skirmishing race. 

A Curious Case in England: A curious question has arisen in English racing circles in connection with pony racing in the early part of the year. A racing filly, not up to Newmarket form, was let to an owner of dubious credentials for pony racing, in which she proved to be about the best in England, winning all she started for. Here comes in the extraordinary part of the business. She was entered in all those races as a three-year-old, though as a matter of fact she is only two years old, and the result is that the Pony Racing Club has warned the enthusiastic young owner off, and the mare is disqualified forever. The owner is now breathing legal fire, and he, in turn, is to be made a defendant by the breeder on the score of a breach of contract. It might be urged that there were not sufficient grounds for the warning off, insomuch as though it would undoubtedly be a crime to run a three-year-old in a two-year-old race and thus gain a great advantage, to run a two-year-old in a three-year-old race would be to gain the very reverse of an advantage. To this, however, it is replied, and with great force, "Yes, but if the filly had been kept until she was three years old, she would probably have grown, and thus, being over the stipulated standard in height, she would not have been qualified to compete."

The winter after the great fire in Chicago, I contracted bronchial affections and since then have been obliged to spend nearly every winter south. 18890913: Sept. 12. The storm in this vicinity is the worst known since the great blizzard. No lives have been lost, but the following properties have been destroyed: Mooch's house and pavilion, Dubow's cottage, Rodger's house and pavilion, Burke's two houses, and the houses of Dr. Hutchinson, Nedham, Babcock, and Lulu, and more may go if the storm continues. At Wildwood, the Wildwood hotel is a total loss, and part of the seawall is gone. Anglesea is not submerged and has thus far escaped with little damage. Sea Isle City, Ocean City, and Avalon are entirely cut off from communication, and the extent of the damage there can only be imagined. The storm this afternoon is still raging, with the wind blowing fifty miles an hour.

Sandy Hook: Rapidly Gaining Long Branch, September 12. The high tide of this morning threatened to topple several more summer cottages into the surging waves. The new inland cut through the Sandy Hook peninsula is being rapidly widened and deepened. The streets on the west side of Seabright are still under six feet of water. Railroad Tracks Washed Out. Point Pleasant City, N.J.

18891010: PHILIP WITHERS & CO, Real Estate Agents, 107 St. James Street (Imperial Building). Bronchitis Cured. After spending ten winters south, I was cured by Scott's Emulsion. 140 Centre St., New York, June 5th, 1903. The winter after the great fire in Chicago, I contracted bronchial affections and since then have been obliged to spend nearly every winter south. Last November, I was advised to try Scott's Emulsion of Cod Liver Oil with Hypophosphites and to my surprise was relieved at once, and by continuing its use for three months was entirely cured, gained flesh and strength, and was able to stand even the blizzard and attend to business every day.

18891023: "Local Provision: There was no important change in the local provision market to note, prices having continued steady all round. There continues to be a steady demand for pork in small lots on both local and country account, and the market was fairly active. The demand for lard was moderate, and a fair number of sales were effected at steady prices. Canadian cherry cut, per bbl $9.00; pork, western, per bbl $12.00; short cut, western, per bbl $10.00; hams, city first, per lb 12c; hams, canvassed, per lb 11c; lard, western, pails, per lb 10c; lard, Canadian, in pails, per lb 10c; tallow, commercial, per lb 6c. The demand for eggs continues good and the market was active and steady with a large volume of business being done. Buyers look to hold more freely and some large sales were made at 17c to 18c per dozen. The demand for game today was good, of which the offerings were fair, and the market was active with prices steady. Choice partridges sold at 45c to 50c, and culls down as low as 25c per brace. Butter: There is no change to note in the butter market. The demand is fair and there is a steady movement sufficient to keep stocks in order. Prices are maintained: creamery, late made 21c; choice 20c; medium to good 15c. Merchants 14c; 18c; 15c. Western, choice 18c; medium 14c. Cheese: "What will the morrow bring forth?" is still a question agitating the minds of operators, both of buyers and sellers. The former appear to be confident of better bargains later, while the latter hold to the stand they have adopted all along. A good many eyes are turned towards the country, and "how long are they going to hold out?" is a problem that is agitating a good many buyers' minds. That some have decided to come down from the stand they adopted, there is no doubt, but there is no pronounced intention as yet as far as can be learned. It must be understood, however, that this is not a sign of weakness to the market, which is a steady one. The difficulty has been that holders in the country have been asking away above what buyers consider figures for business, and the former are now giving signs that they realize the fact. The public continues unchanged at 52s and there was little to note on spot. Our special dispatch from Ingersoll says that there is no change and indicates that holders there continue independent, as there has been no business." 

Finest September 1903. All kinds of fine stock. The market remains steady. 

Commercial Hotel: Spot tin in London is cabled at £51, do three months at £51 12s 6d. Spot copper at £61 17s 6d, do, for delivery at £62 5s. Warrants at Glasgow are cabled at £41 8s. No. 3 Middlesborough iron is at £41 10s 6d, and Spanish £40. The president of one of the largest coal companies in Pennsylvania said today that there is a misapprehension as to the real state of the coal trade. There is but an unusual quantity of coal at the seaboard, and but little if any more than is generally kept there to respond to any demand. Here is the corrected text:

**Omergoncy:** It is true that there is a falling off in the production from last year of about 2,000,000 tons, but much of this will be made up during the winter months. The trouble is, people insist on comparing this year, which is a normal year in the coal trade, with last year, which, owing to a variety of causes, among them the March blizzard, was quite abnormal. All the coal producers are now mining their usual quantity of anthracite. The advent of cold weather will change the aspect of the market; consumers will at once buy, and the stock at the seaboard and stored at the mines will very soon be used up. 

The Philadelphia Record, discussing the iron market, says: "A more or less feverish condition exists in the iron trade east and west because of the apprehended scarcity of crude material before buyers have fully covered their forward requirements. In western markets, speculative purchases of over 100,000 tons of pig iron have been made within a few days, but in eastern and local markets there is nothing beyond a quiet, steady movement. Heavy transactions have been closed this week in western Pennsylvania and in northern Illinois for HcHse-mefplg, foundry, and forge, and rumors of a further advance are rife. The lake ore demand is extraordinary. Sales at Cleveland for the season foot up over 6,000,000 tons, and the output for the season will probably reach 7,300,000 tons. The demand for merchant steel is at a maximum limit. Steel rails are quoted at $32 to $33. Additional sales reported this week, 75,000 tons. Western quotations have advanced to $34. Mills are better supplied with business than they have been for some years, and by all present indications, a further advance will take place."

**Montreal, October 22:** Notwithstanding the fine weather and the improved condition of the roads, the gathering of buyers at Bonsecours market this morning was small; consequently, the tone of the market was quiet and the volume of business transacted was small compared with last Friday's market. The attendance of farmers was larger and the supply of grain offered was heavy. The demand was good and an active business was done, sales of round lots of oats being made at 75c per bag. The feeling was steady and prices were unchanged. There was a good supply of vegetables offered for which the demand was limited, and sales were slow in consequence, and up to a late hour considerable stock was left unsold. Lettuce was scarce and prices advanced to $1.00 per dozen. There was also a stronger feeling in cauliflowers and prices were higher at 30 to 10c each. There was no important change in fruit. The demand was quiet and sales were slow notwithstanding the large assortment offered for this season of the year. Dairy produce was plentiful for which the demand was fair at steady prices. There was a good supply of poultry and game offered, but the demand was slow and the volume of business accomplished was small at steady prices. The fish market was quiet as usual on Tuesday on account of the slow demand and values were unchanged.

**The Horse Market:**
Montreal, October 22: There has been a good inquiry from American buyers for a general-purpose class of horses, but owing to the small supply offering and the continued light receipts for this season of the year, buyers have not been able to fill their wants; consequently, the tone of the market has been quiet and the volume of business transacted small. However, as advices of several carloads to arrive have been received, the indications are that a more active trade will be done this week, and dealers generally are looking for a steady improvement in the market from this out. At the Montreal Horse Exchange, at Point St. Charles, business has been quiet and few sales have been effected. The receipts by the Grand Trunk and from the city at these stables for the week ending October 10 were 137 head; left over from previous work, 28 total, 165 shipped, 111; left for city, 54; on hand for sale, 20.

Mr. Duggan received by the steamship Aluddo 12 horses consigned to J.

1889-11-02: (I 14 00 Hll 42 fi lu oo iio 41 :ise 7 !i:i,oo :iei :iu4 HS r THE NAVASSA MURDER PLOT. Details of the conspiracy to kill the whites in cold blood. 

November 1: About 1 o'clock this morning the United States revenue cutter Ewing arrived in the harbor conveying the brig Alice, which arrived in the Capes yesterday with part of the Navassa rioters. The Romance, with the remaining rioters, was left down the bay in charge of the revenue cutter, Lot M. Morrill. The prisoners captured in the Alice were lodged in the city jail. examination of those on board the Alice Important facts were elicited. It was shown by some of the negroes that a conspiracy to murder the whites was planned some days before the 15th of September. The attack commenced in conformity to the plans by striking in the head Charles W. Ruby, the superintendent of the mines. He was left for dead. The crowd then proceeded to the quarters of the superintendent and before night, and after the whites had delivered up all their arms, men were murdered in cold blood. Mr. Foster was disemboweled. District Attorney Hayes, who has been since the 17th inst. on the Ewing, off Lewes, considers the Government has a strong case against a dozen or more of the ringleaders. The cases will be pressed for trial at once. There were 124 persons brought up by the brigs Alice and Romance, all of whom are held either as prisoners or witnesses. 

Mexican Mutiny  
Civok, Mexico, November 1. A mutiny occurred among the train escort on an up train from Vera Cruz, Tuesday evening. A corporal and four privates attacked their superior officers, severely wounding the lieutenant and killing a sergeant. The object of the mutineers seemed to have been to stop the train and make their escape. They first attacked the sergeant, and in the struggle, this officer was run through by a bayonet which pierced his left lung and stood out several inches beyond his back. The lieutenant attempted to engage the mutineers with his sword and wounded two of them. The mutineers then climbed over the tender to the engine for the purpose of making the engineer stop the train. The engineer was an American, and he and his foreman were armed. They prepared to resist the attacking party when the mutineers jumped from the train. One was cut in two and killed, and the others were injured but escaped. The greatest alarm prevailed among the passengers and several women fainted.

Washington, November 1. The report of General O. O. Howard, commanding the division of the Atlantic, calls attention to the lack of armaments of nearly all sea coast stations. He calls attention to an "Americanite," the invention of a young Russian, formerly a botanist of the Point Barrow expedition, which is the safest and best explosive. The General knows of it. It has been adopted by the Standard Oil Company for "shirting" its wells. "With such a powerful agent," the General says, "the problem of coast defense is solved almost into one of range, and our great seaboard cities can be made comparatively safe without excessive expenditure." Gen. Howard recommends that the present rifle for infantry and cavalry be exchanged for a magazine gun. 

First Blizzard of the Season  
Omaha, Neb., November 1. Heavy snow has been falling here since early this morning. The storm played havoc with the railway telegraph lines and the overland trains generally. The fall of snow is about six inches, as reported from several towns in Western Nebraska, while in Wyoming a blizzard prevails, and it is feared that a blockade will compel the suspension of trains. Telegraph wires on the Burlington are broken at several points west of Omaha. Trains on the Elk Horn branch were delayed more or less owing to the snow. Snow is reported to have fallen as far west as Valentine, where the mercury is rapidly falling and a cold wave prevails.

A Great Land Transaction  
Jacksonville, Fla., November 1. One of the largest transactions in land ever consummated in the South has recently been perfected. All the unsold lands in Florida of the Plant system of railroads and steamships, of the Florida Southern Railroad, of the Jacksonville, Tampa and Key West system, including the Florida Southern Railway, and of the Florida Commercial Company, have been consolidated under the name of the Associated Railway Land Department of Florida, with headquarters at Sanford. Over six million acres of land are thus brought under one management. 

Hill Contributes $730,000  
New York, November 1. The Evening Post says: A high railroad authority is responsible for the statement that the management of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad will contribute $775,000 to the world's fair of 1893. It is not known whether this will be given in addition to the $250,000 already subscribed or not. Of this amount $500,000 will represent the New York Central, $100,000 the West Shore, $10,000 the Wagner Palace Car Company, and the balance the horse car interests in the city controlled by the New York Central.

Arthur's Friends in the Majority  
Denver, Col., November 1. At the meeting of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers yesterday, the report of the special committee on federation, to whom had been referred the resolutions adopted by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, was received. The convention took the matter up, but made no progress. The eastern members who endorse Arthur are opposed bitterly to the Knights of Labor, while the western members desire to take in classes. The convention is nearly equally divided, the majority siding with Arthur.

A Professional Accountant at Work  
St. Louis, November 1. A professional accountant from England will examine the financial condition of the United Elevator Company here and report to the English Syndicate, which holds an option on a majority of the company's stocks. Should the expert's report be favorable, it is understood the syndicate will try to obtain all the stock. The allied companies are capitalized for $2,500,000 and carry bonds amounting to $1,200,000.

What the Hawaiians Want  
Honolulu, November 2. F. B. Finker, a member of King Kalakaua's military staff, was here yesterday and authoritatively denied the stories that the Hawaiian Islands want to be annexed to this country. He said the Hawaiians are merely trying to obtain a treaty with this country similar to those they have now with England and France, guaranteeing their independence.

Hymn Book Reinstated  
Washington, November 1. The Acting Secretary of the Treasury has informed Rev. J. P. McIntrow, rector of St. Mary's Church, Amsterdam, N.Y., that the hymn book has been reinstated.

1889-11-04: W. F. Harpo, treasurer of the Chicago and Pacific Elevator Company, said today: The cablegram was probably well founded. Negotiations for the transfer of the Chicago Elevator property to the English syndicate are in progress. The Keimont has information that the elevators belonging to Munder, Wheeler & Co. have been sold for $2,500,000 to the English syndicate. The Munder, Wheeler system is the largest in the city, having a capacity of 6,500,000 bushels. The amount paid is said to be $2,250,000.

Murderous Work of Revolutionists  
San Francisco, Cal., November 2. Advices from Guatemala regarding the revolution there state that Col. Ruana, who led the insurrection, and his two brothers, were shot four days after the trouble commenced, by order of President Barrios. The insurrectionists numbered 200, and their object seemed to be to turn the capital over to Ruana. Several of them were shot by order of the President. One of Col. Ruana's principal supporters, Reina Barrios, a relative of ex-President Barrios, and Manuel Hovia, formerly minister of finance and public instruction, are now in prison awaiting trial. Affairs are now quiet.

The Blizzard's Terrible Work  
Denver, Col., November 2. The snowstorm which has been raging for 48 hours has abated. The storm was the worst that has been experienced. All trains are delayed and telegraph communication with all eastern portions is destroyed. Three hundred miles east of here, over 15 miles of telegraph lines have been completely wrecked, while in Colorado the damage to fruit and shade trees is considerable. Reports from the south say the storm has drifted thousands of cattle and sheep off their ranges into the southeast, and that hundreds of the weak animals have perished in the blizzard.

Illinois and Missouri Shaken  
St. Louis, November 2. A perceptible shock of earthquake was felt in this city at 1:53 a.m. It shook tall buildings and frightened the inmates of many. It came apparently from a little north of east and lasted two seconds. 

Cairo, Ill., November 2. A heavy shock of earthquake, accompanied by a low report, was felt here at 11:30 this morning. It was about one minute in duration, the direction being from southwest to northeast. No damage is reported.

Jacksonville, Ill., November 2. The earthquake shock was felt here. It lasted several seconds and shook houses.

In Uncle Sam's Courts  
Baltimore, November 2. In the United States court today E. J. Waring, counsel for Henry Jones, charged with being one of the ringleaders of the Navassa Island rioters, obtained a writ of habeas corpus, returnable next Wednesday. This action is taken to test the constitutionality of the law which gives to the United States authority over Navassa Island. The latest reports from the West Indies indicate that the newly adopted constitution of Haiti declares that the black republic has jurisdiction over Navassa Island and the action of counsel Waring is to determine the continuance of jurisdiction.

General Grant's Remains  
New York, November 3. George V. Chichils says the body of General Grant will probably be removed from its present resting place in New York to West Point or Arlington Cemetery. Several years before his death, General Grant said his military superior, Winfield Scott, was buried at West Point and he would like to lie there. Influential Grand Army men have asked that the body be moved to Arlington, and special arrangements have been made to allow Mrs. Grant to be buried at the same place. United States army officers seem to prefer West Point.

Anthracite Prices Advanced  
Philadelphia, November 3. The anthracite coal shippers in the Schuylkill region have advanced the prices for furnace, lump, and steamboat sizes 15 cents per ton to $1 at the mines. The coal shippers from the Lehigh region will also advance the price of those sizes 10 cents per ton tomorrow, when the Lehigh Valley Railroad and Central Railroad of New Jersey will increase the rate of tolls 5 cents per ton on furnace sizes. These advances are due to improvements in the iron. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

Trade T1 r Continuing Involution Dramal Nkw York, November 3. Jacob Ilise, consul-general of Guatemala at New York, yesterday received the following telegram from the Minister of Foreign Affairs: "The rumors that circulate in the press of your city as to a revolution in Guatemala and the other Central American states are entirely false and of malicious origin, and should be contradicted. Complete peace reigns here and in all the other states. The relations between the several Governments are of the most cordial nature." 

A Washington Special. Washington, November 3. The arrest of Percy Dawson, son of the ex-Commissioner of Education, on a charge of stealing postage stamps from the safe in the Bureau of Education, was followed yesterday by the arrest of Mabel Davis, a young woman living in a disreputable part of the city, as his accomplice. She has been living with Dawson for thirteen months and was arrested on the charge of receiving the stamps.

1889-11-05: OVERCOME BY A BLIZZARD. Ten idle deaths of cowboys in a New Mexico snowstorm. C. Head, with several cowboys, camped near Sierra Grande with 1,000 beef cattle, which they were holding for the purpose of loading in cars. At four o'clock Friday morning, a blizzard from the northwest struck the herd, driving the cattle toward Panhandle, Texas, the cowboys being unable to hold the crew. The snow was so blinding that it was impossible to see fifty feet ahead. Miller called his men together, and they started to follow the herd and made an attempt to keep them bunched. The men became separated Friday night; one of them wandered into Head's home, almost half dead from cold and hunger. He told his story, and a rescuing party was immediately sent out. Saturday noon the frozen bodies of Henry Miller, Joe Martin, and Charles Jolly were found on the open plains not far from Folsom. The other men found their way to camp before being overcome with cold. 

A Watertown Girl Returned. New York, November 4. Willis M. Johnson, one of the stars in Johnson, Slavin, and McNich's minstrel troupe, and brother of Johnson, its chief proprietor, was arrested last night at a hotel on 10th Avenue where he had registered with a young lady as W. M. Carroll and wife. The young woman was Helen M. Souse, of Watertown, N.Y.

The winter after the great fire in Chicago, I contracted bronchial affections and since then have been obliged to spend nearly every winter south. 1889-11-09: THIS TOWNSHIP'S CAPITAL. A wire for the Canadian Pacific. From our own correspondent. Sherbrooke, P.Q., November 8. Some local contractors are sending in to the Canadian Pacific offices in Montreal, tenders for the construction of the new railway station which that company has recently announced their intention of erecting here. It is to be a handsome building of brick, some 100 feet long by 40 wide, is to be fitted with all modern improvements and to cost in the neighborhood of $10,000. Not long ago the Grand Trunk management announced the immediate construction of a handsome station upon the site of the present one, to cost something well up in the thousands. The Canadian Pacific, of course, are bound to see there, at least as far as announcements go, and the question as to whether both projects will not end in smoke is just now agitating the public mind. Lieutenant-Colonel Mattice, brigade major of this military district, visited the Bishop's College school yesterday for the purpose of inspecting the arms and accoutrements at present on hand, and also with a view of fixing what steps could be taken towards a reorganization of the cadet corps which formerly flourished in the school.

Death in New Mexico. Nonsileirm, Dayton, New Mexico, November 8. Unless the snowstorm which has been raging for eight days comes to an end soon, next summer will show a country covered with the dead bodies of animals. The depth of snow is now not less than 26 inches on a level, and in many places it has drifted seven feet high. When the storm struck this section, seven large herds of cattle, numbering from 500 to 2,000 each, were being held near this place awaiting shipment to eastern markets. The rain of a week ago was followed Thursday morning by blizzards of snow and sleet which sent the herds in a southerly direction. In vain did the half-frozen cowboys try to check the march of the cattle, but on they went through the merciless storm until, finding it utterly impossible to hold the cattle, the cowboys rode aside and allowed them to pass, and when nearly dead rode their exhausted horses into canyons or partially sheltered places, where they passed many hours without food or fire. Five cowboys and two Mexican sheep herders are known to have been frozen to death. It is estimated that 20,000 sheep have perished in this part of the territory. The hay supply is nearly exhausted and $100 per ton is offered by stockmen. At Texline, nine miles below Clayton, two passenger trains have been snowbound for a week. Provisions are running out and the passengers are compelled to venture into the storm and kill cattle, the quarters of which are taken into the cars and roasted for food. It is thought the snowplow will reach the stranded trains today and release them. 

Pecos, Col., November 8. Railroad men report more trouble on the Divide today. The wind is blowing a perfect hurricane and cuts are filled with snow. All trains are blocked again, and the Fort Worth travel has stopped altogether. The situation there is much worse, as another great snowstorm is raging evidently in the Ballon Mountains. 

THIS FIRE'S RECORD. Oxford, Mass., November 8. A large fire on Beach Court and Commercial Streets tonight caused a loss of $50,000. Columbus, Ohio, November 8. A fire in the Houston block tonight destroyed $40,000 worth of stock.

1889-11-11: VICTIMS OF THE BLIZZARD. Terrible experiences of cowboys on Colorado's plains. MORE JOHNSTOWN FLOODS. Fatal Boiler Explosion. Rescued from a burning train. Grand Trunk Eastbound Freight Train. Trinidad, Col., November 10. The bodies of John Martin and Henry Miller, cowboys, frozen to death near Sierra Grande in last week's blizzard, have been brought to Folsom for burial. Four other men belonging to the same party are missing, and it is feared they are dead. It is reported that at least twenty men are missing from this range, and it is feared many will never be found. Jolly and Wise, who escaped badly frozen, tell a heartrending story of suffering. When the blizzard struck them Wednesday night of last week, they were holding a herd of 3,500 cattle, finding refuge in a snowdrift. The wind became a hurricane before morning, and when Martin and Jolly went on the last guard, about 3 a.m., the storm was so blinding they could not hold the herd. Jolly started to the camp for help. In the meantime, Miller and Wise had left the camp to assist in holding the cattle. Jolly could not find the camp, and Miller and Wise could not find the herd. All three were drawn together by shouting, and they wandered around until daylight, when they found Martin. The cold was so bitter that the men entered a ravine, and after fastening the horses, took the saddle blankets and buried themselves in a snowdrift. Frozen to Death. This was at three in the afternoon. It was only by the greatest efforts that Jolly and Wise succeeded in keeping awake. They were slightly apart from Martin and Miller and had difficulty in talking to each other. The snow piled up on them to such weight that they were forced to seek another drift. About 4 o'clock Friday morning, Miller called Jolly and Wise and told them they had all better go. When they crawled out, they searched in the drift for Miller and Martin. The latter only could be found, and he was dead. They took the horses and started leading them. They found Miller on his knees, his horse standing in front of him as though trying to protect him from the cold. He was asked to get up and go with them, but he was unable to rise and was assisted to his feet, but could not walk. Jolly started to get assistance while Wise remained with their dying companion. Both of Wise's hands were frozen, and he was helpless and was fast becoming insensible when the Mexican sheep herder found him and took him to a ranch a few miles distant. The men returned and found Miller lifeless. 

The Storm Elsewhere. Kansas City, November 9. A fierce snowstorm raged yesterday in southern and western Kansas. Snow, hail, and sleet fell so thick and was driven so fiercely by the wind that in many places people did not dare to venture out of doors. Trains are somewhat delayed. 

Cameron, Texas, November 10. The deepest snow that has fallen here in twelve years is on the ground now. It is six inches deep. All trains on the Fort Worth & Denver are blocked north of here, and there are eight engines in snowdrifts 70 miles northwest of this place. The drifts are nine feet deep. 

Clayton, N.M.

Bronchitis Cured. After spending ten winters south, I was cured by Scott's Emulsion. 140 Centre St., New York, June 26th, 1888. The winter after the great fire in Chicago, I contracted bronchial affections and since then have been obliged to spend nearly every winter south. Last November I was advised to try Scott's Emulsion of Cod Liver Oil with Hypophosphites, and to my surprise was relieved at once, and by continuing its use three months was entirely cured, gained flesh and strength, and was able to stand even the blizzard and attend to business every day.

Frye, chairman of the Pacific Railway Investigating Committee, which has just completed an examination of nearly 10,000 miles of Pacific roads, says the committee is now convinced that the roads can eventually pay their debts to the Government in full. This corrected version maintains the original meaning and formatting while addressing OCR errors. Here is the corrected text:

Contemplate a surrender of the roads is shown by the fact that expensive improvements are going on everywhere. The senator says the Central Pacific is not profitable because it has to pay a very high price for coal. The road nowhere touches a coal field. It cannot get a bushel of coal that does not come from the east, and much of it is from Australia and New Zealand. On an average, it costs the road between $7 and $9 a ton, and last year 600,000 tons were used. Eastern roads pay about $1. 

Minneapolis, Pa., November 15. It is authoritatively announced that Miss Kathy Drexel will not remain in the Order of Mercy. She is merely making her novitiate in that order so that she may become a nun and found a new order. The sisterhood she will establish, it is said, will be distinctively American, and will have for its object missionary and charitable work among the Indians. Miss Drexel will build a house for the proposed order somewhere in the State of Omaha and will endow it handsomely. She will obtain recruits from the various orders to assist her in her work and will establish a novitiate for new members. The members of the new order will be expected to do all kinds of domestic work in addition to educating Indians.

The Blizzard in the Monument, Clayton, N.M., November 15. Don Luis Baca, a prominent sheep dealer of Pico Creek, speaking of the late blizzard in that region, says five Mexican sheep herders perished in his neighborhood, the bodies of four having been found. The snow completely covers the ground from Clayton to the Canadian River, a distance of 125 miles. Many Mexican families are in a destitute condition. Owing to the heavy snow, they are unable to leave their places to get food. Mr. Baca says other bodies will be recovered when the snow melts, as several men are missing.

Children Burned to Death, Damariscotta, Me., November 15. The four-year-old son and Kitty, the two-year-old daughter, of R. H. Ingraham, were playing with fire in their home this afternoon while the mother was hanging clothes in the yard. Both were burned badly; they died almost immediately. The third child, still younger, saw the suffering of the others and went out, bringing the mother in, but relief came too late.

Freedom of Speech in Mexico City or Mexico, November 15. The sermon of Archbishop Ryan of Philadelphia, at Baltimore on Sunday, has caused a great sensation here because of the Archbishop's support of the rights of Catholic writers to criticize the faults of priests, while here Archbishop Labastide has excommunicated a number of persons for such criticisms, and charges have been brought against him in Rome for so doing.

The First Fast Pacific Train, Chicago, November 15. The fast mail service overland from Chicago to the Pacific coast was inaugurated at three this morning on the Burlington road. It is expected to diminish the time between Chicago and Portland, Ore., nearly one-third. General Superintendent Bell and other post office officials were aboard the first train and go to the end of the route to observe the workings of the new plan.

Controlling the Non-Bessemer Ore Market, Manitowoc, Wis., November 15. A deal by which the Schlessinger syndicate purchases the Buffalo, South Buffalo, Queen, and Prince of Wales mines, near Negaunee, for prices aggregating about $500,000, has been closed. This gives the syndicate a foothold in the Marquette district and is an additional step in the direction of securing control of the non-Bessemer ores.

Battered by Gales for a Year, Washington, November 15. The American schooner David W. Hunt was dismasted November 25, 1888, in a gale off Hatteras. She was loaded with lumber and was waterlogged when her crew abandoned her. She drifted across the Atlantic and after making 3,000 miles in a year has been towed into Madeira. She has been a very dangerous obstruction to navigation.

New York's Latest Murder, New York, November 15. Isiah Brown and John Lear, young men residing in New Jersey, while intoxicated, about 1 o'clock this morning, quarreled. Lear shot Brown in the temple. Brown died at the hospital; Lear is under arrest. Brown was employed in the store of Acker, Merrill & Connelly and was a cousin of the junior partner.

Bastardly Whiteness, Chicago, Ill., November 15. Intense excitement was caused here yesterday by a bold attempt to burn the residence of Attorney.
