1889-11-19: WEST LAMBTON. The West Lambton election has resulted in a success for Mr. Mowat's Government. Mr. Mackenzie, the Liberal candidate, having been elected by a plurality of 37 over Mr. Fleck, the Conservative representative, or about 100 more than Mr. Pardee obtained in 1886. The figures are not quite complete, but can only be slightly changed. The vote was a heavy one for a bye-election, exceeding that of the contest in 1886 by more than a hundred. The largest interest, perhaps, centered in the candidacy of Mr. McCrae, the third-party candidate, who received the endorsement of the Equal Rights Association and of the Prohibitionists. The measure of his support will hardly be satisfactory to either of those organizations. Any strong independent candidate could have done at least nearly as well. The Conservatives, who, so far as provincial affairs are concerned, have least to blame themselves for such an Equal Rights standpoint, suffered most from the Equal Rights candidate, their loss of votes compared with the last election being about 300, against about 210 taken from the Liberal total. This would indicate that the Liberals are considerably less inclined to disregard their party affiliations when invited to take up the banner of "truth and righteousness" than are the Conservatives. Perhaps they know why.

The fairs of the late season have had throughout the country an unprecedented success. The interest in them was enhanced rather than diminished by apparently rival attractions in nearly all the provinces, which, though they did not all happen simultaneously, were nevertheless of a character to compete with them in drawing persons who take only one holiday in the year. The fairs, however, showed that the variety of entertainment furnished only served to whet the public appetite for more and more. Certainly the attendance at the local as well as the more central fairs was extremely large, and Canada has reason to congratulate herself on the enterprise and enlightened interest in her progress thus manifested.

There has been just one noteworthy exception to this manifold ground for felicitation—the absence of any effort on Montreal's part to hold an industrial exhibition. We are glad that the question has been raised, and hope that hereafter Montreal will not be the only defaulter among the important cities and towns of the Dominion. No place in Canada has better advantages in the way of inter-communication, by land and water, of industrial activity, economic life and, when once established, of generous public spirit. 

What is to be done is the taint of elitism or the pollution to unfold the discussion of the assignment of functions. This is a subject in which party, creed, or race, as such, has no concern, and any attempt to introduce such elements of discord into the discussion or arrangement for it should be promptly frowned upon.

Not much anxiety need be felt for the Champ de Mars in connection with the reported intention of the Provincial Government to proceed against the Federal authorities to obtain possession of the ground. When the other real property of the Jesuits' estates was handed over to the colony, the Champ de Mars was retained by the Imperial Government for military purposes. It was held as ordinance land up to the time of the departure of the British troops and then handed over to the Canadian military authorities to be used for the same purposes. It is to be held now, and it would seem that the only power that can dispose of it is the Federal Government. Mr. Mercier never set up a legal claim on behalf of the Jesuits to their other estates, and the Federal Parliament, after what has happened within the past six months, will surely not recognize one of conscience in this matter. Appeal to the courts can only be made on legal grounds, and the most ardent friends of the Jesuits have not set up any such, nor does the Quebec Jesuits' Estates Act establish any.

Altogether apart from its controversial value, the collection of documents touching the Roman question, which, according to the Città Caldera, the Vatican signifies its intention of publishing, would be of the utmost historic interest. The manuscripts in question are now in the archives of the Vatican. They include diplomatic notes, letters from sovereigns and ministers, confidential communications, etc., covering the period in the pontificate of Pius IX from the first outbreak of the revolution till the military aspirations had found their goal in the occupation of Rome. The object of the Curia in giving those documents to the light would be to show that the movement from first to last was a conspiracy to despoil the Sovereign Pontiff of his morally inalienable possessions. The Italian Government, doubtless, has documents bearing on the same questions and succession of events.

At the solemn requiem for the repose of Kiel's soul held in Montreal in 1889, and attended by Mr. Mercier and some thousands of Nationalists, the contribution for the family of the dead rebel averaged less than two cents for each person present. The champagne bill at the little blowout with which Mr. Mercier celebrated the third anniversary of the execution on Balima must have far exceeded the sum total of the faithful's charity then Nationalism was young. Things have changed for the better with the Quebec Premier.

The chief justiceship of the Superior Court of the province has been rendered vacant by the resignation of Sir Andrew Stuart. Public opinion with one accord points to Mr. Justice Johnson as the rightful successor to the honor. He is the senior justice for this district and one of the ablest occupants of the bench in the province. It would be difficult to adduce stronger claims than his for the position, and the Government would, we are convinced, be doing both a wise and a popular thing by making the promotion.

Has Mr. Mercier's jury commissioner, Mr. Cloman, fallen into a Manitoba muskeg, been swept away in a blizzard, or is he waiting for some ill-disposed Norwester to commit a felony so that he may get a real Western jury to investigate? He has not been heard of since he undertook to convince Liberal Statesman Martin that it was wrong to do on the prairies what the Liberal Statesman Mercier does on the St. Lawrence. This suspense is becoming painful.

The statues of Guzman Blanco, thrown down by the Venezuelan mobs on Friday, were erected by that politician himself when he was dictator of the republic. From his comfortable quarters in the French capital, he can regard the incident with considerable equanimity. It is only his pride that suffers. Had he been at home it would likely have been his neck.

The English registrar of bankruptcy in his last report remarks upon the frequency with which the debtors admitted that their chief losses had been due to speculations which had nothing to do with their regular business. The grocer who thinks he can manipulate the world's grain market is not a product of this continent alone by any means. The proceedings in the Court of Queen's Bench yesterday recall the fact that the M.I.R. is fastened to Mr. Mc. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

Slmno's name by a very slender tie those days. It would be awkward indeed if the ex-"Lad" had to be prefixed to this title as well as to the "Hon." and the "Aid" the distinguished gentleman liked to lengthen his cognomen with. In referring to the Klmouski local election yesterday, it was stated that Mr. Tessier, the Liberal candidate, had been unseated by the courts. This was an error, unintentionally made. The present is Mr. Tessier's first candidature for legislative honors, so that he could not have been before the courts in the connection indicated. The gentlemen applying for incorporation as the Montreal Exhibition Company ask for the right to hold exhibitions of "any and every variety of thing and being found in the animal and vegetable kingdom." Not much that is worth looking at can escape such a broad net as this. In spite of that resolution of the Montreal Finance Committee, New York is going on collecting funds for the Columbus exhibition of 1902. New York does not seem to appreciate the force of Montreal's views in this matter as well as Chicago. Mount must go, but he is taking his time about it.

18891128: H Total mileage, wind on the 20th, 18; greatest in one hour 7. Snowfall, 7.8. 

And Prospects In the States. Washington, November 27. The following has been issued by the Signal Office: Special Bulletin. A general storm now prevails over the country east of the Mississippi with gales on the lakes, and a cold wave advancing from the Northwest, which will cover the Ohio Valley tonight and Thursday. The rain will turn to snow in Western New York, Western Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Indiana tonight and Thursday, with decided prospects of interruption to telegraphic communication in those sections, and interference with railway travel. These conditions will probably move eastward Thursday with possibly increasing severity. Another Eastern Disturbance Impending. Lieutenant Thompson, the director of the Signal Service Bureau, said tonight that the weather map resembled more closely than he has ever known before the conditions that existed on the night preceding the great blizzard a year ago last March. Out in Dakota, the thermometer is already down to 11 degrees zero, and he says it may possibly go down to 2. The rainstorm in this locality will stop the cold wave for a time, but afterwards the people will have to look out. He thinks there will be little snow as far south as Washington.

18891130: W Dwyer, a stock raiser of Colfax, N.M., states that thirty Mexican shepherds and five American cowboys lost their lives in the blizzard which raged in his section during the first fifteen days of November. 

Havoc to Quebec's Electric Wire. (From our own correspondent) Quebec, November 29. The Quebec & Levis Electric Light Company are perhaps the heaviest sufferers from yesterday's storm. Yesterday afternoon, the lofty transmission towers recently erected on Dorchester Bridge for carrying the electric light wires into the city were blown over into the River St. Charles on the upper side of the bridge. With them were blown down all the poles of the Electric Light Company from the bridge to Hedlryville. The loss to the company will be very large. These towers were supposed to be exceedingly firm and strongly built. They were 110 feet in height. The city was in darkness last night and must remain so tonight also. The manager, on hearing the news of the accident, notified the electrician at the Falls and instructed him not to turn on any of the dynamo. One hundred men in two gangs of fifty each were set to work to repair the damage, and though it will be impossible to have any of them in working order for tonight, it is hoped the light will be turned on again after another day or two. 

A Train Wrecker Sentenced. St. Thomas, Ont., November 27. Henry Weaver, who wrecked the Michigan Central train at Stevensville, pleaded guilty this morning and was sentenced to seven years in the Kingston penitentiary. 

To be Consul at Hamilton. Hamilton, November 27. President H. then today appointed William Monsghetti, of Ohio, to be consul at Hamilton, Ont. Mr. Monsghetti was appointed commercial agent at Chatham, Ont., last June. 

Mawmill Fire. WAi ilt issrut, Ont., November 27. At 10 o'clock tonight, fire was discovered in Wm Patterson's sawmill. It spread very rapidly and is still burning. The fire will be confined to the mill, the wind is blowing in a favorable direction. The loss will be about $10,000, partly covered by insurance.

Bronchitis Cured. After spending one winter south, I was cured by Scott's Emulsion. 50 Cent St., New York, December 31, 1901. The winter after the great fire in Chicago, I contracted bronchial affections and since then have been obliged to spend nearly every winter south. Last November I was advised to try Scott's Emulsion of Cod Liver Oil with Hypophosphites and to my surprise was relieved at once, and by continuing its use three months was entirely cured, gained flesh and strength, and was able to stand even the blizzard and the cold.

18891221: C Colby, M.P., President of the Privy Council. Mrs. Colby, who was descended from the Hollidays, an old and honored Connecticut family, was among the oldest residents of Blainsford County. Her husband, Dr. Colby, who died in 1863, came to Blainsford in 1843, after having served as surgeon of volunteers in the troubles of 1837, and soon became known as an able and public-spirited citizen as well as a skillful physician. Mrs. Colby survived him for twenty-five years as his fitting helpmeet and lived to see her son win even greater honors than had been accorded to her husband. She has died at a ripe old age, esteemed as much for her social qualities as for the public services of her family. 

The Cabinet Government has taken a step that will have an important influence on the movement for the abolition of exemptions from taxation in that province, and possibly elsewhere as well. If the views of the municipal councils, which have been asked for throughout the province, are generally against exemptions, legislation will no doubt be had in conformity therewith; if opinion is fairly even, it is possible a solution may be had by leaving the question of exemption or no exemption to the municipalities. There is, indeed, something to be said for this on general principles. It is the municipalities which are directly interested. It is they who provide and pay for the services which the provincial laws say certain institutions shall enjoy for nothing, and it is reasonable that with them shall be left the decision. 

After all, L'Electeur's reading of the Globe cut of the Liberal-Nationalist party is something of a compliment to the Toronto organ. It implies a belief on the part of L'Electeur that its contemporary's views are the result of conviction and that what it says is really of importance. Not many who watch the Globe are willing to admit this. And then L'Electeur might have waited a little. The Globe is flopping around a great deal these days and is just as likely to flop over to L'Electeur's views as anywhere else. The unseasonable weather is nowhere more seriously felt than in the coal region. The twenty-five thousand Schuylkill miners now threatened with reduced wages and loss of work would bless a blizzard if it would bring a long spell of zero weather and reduce the consumers' coal piles throughout the continent. 

The Wilkes-Barre persists in saying that the Kingston result was satisfactory to the Equal Rights people; but there is a hysterical jerkiness about its sentences that looks as if there was a sore heart behind the brave front.

18891225: ITS RAVAGES IN EUROPE. The Influenza Reaches Many American Cities. 

From our correspondent, December 24. The influenza epidemic reigns and rages. The conference of lawyers which was to have convened yesterday did not do so because the majority of the speakers were ill. Reports from Berlin are that there is no abatement of the evil there. In Brunswick, it has assumed a malignant type, and there have been many deaths. At Stuttgart, it is increasing. Tramways have tested operations because the employees are all ill. Mayence has been very severely visited. At Munich, the cases increase and the transaction of business is interfered with. Theatres announced that the programmes of the plays are not to be depended upon as the illness of the actors may make it necessary to change names at any moment or even to change the piece. At Antwerp, the gloom is increasing, but it is diminishing among the garrison and the people at Amsterdam. It has appeared at Dordrecht among the soldiers and sailors and in the factories. It is very serious in the barracks at Brussels and half the carbineers and grenadiers of the Corps des Guides are ill. 

A physician named Dr. H. Dunmflchino, a prominent physician, is dead. He succumbed to an attack of influenza, complicated with an old affection of the lungs. Four other deaths have thus far been traced to the influenza epidemic, three at the military school of St. Cyr, and one at the Royal Technical Institute. 

London, December 24. Among the victims of the influenza epidemic are Count Von Taff, the Austrian Prime Minister, Archduke William of Austria, and Princess Stephanie, widow of the late Crown Prince Rudolf. The queen of Sweden has also been attacked. The disease is spreading rapidly in Western Europe. 

Vienna, December 24. A frequent sequel to cases of influenza here is an attack of inflammation of the lungs. A number of persons in the hospitals who had been suffering from the influenza were stricken with inflammation of the lungs, and several of them have died. Influenza has appeared in a Jesuit school at Fulksburg, the pupils of which are the children of conservative aristocrats. Sixty-eight of the scholars are ill. 

Pittsburgh, December 24. The influenza has its grip upon Pittsburgh, and it is estimated that there are many hundreds of cases throughout the city. Pittsburgh long ago established a reputation for what is known as the "Pittsburgh grip," a cold in the head peculiar to this town of smoke and damp atmosphere. The influenza thus far seems to be an exaggeration of this grip. Businessmen, clerks, letter carriers, and school children appear particularly to be affected, and a tour of the big stores disclosed that many fair shoppers were suffering. Local physicians ascribe the epidemic to the unhealthy atmosphere consequent upon the continual murky weather. They do not consider the disease in its present shape dangerous, though they admit that it may lead to pneumonia or consumption in some cases. 

A Highly Notable Scene. Philadelphia, December 24. Much as the blizzard two years ago swooped down upon Philadelphia and all this section of the country, so has the influenza come. It is infectious but not contagious. A medical expert said tonight there were over two thousand cases already in Philadelphia, and another high authority said it had reached the city within twenty-four hours and had come with such a rush that he expected within another day to see hundreds and thousands attacked. The epidemic...

In this city seems to be somewhat mild, and has a duration of from two to seven days. It is not limited to any section of territory, but is raging severely along the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad. Hospital Report: Fourteen of the nurses in the Philadelphia hospital are now in bed, three more having succumbed early this morning. The condition of more who were taken down on Saturday remains about the same. One or two of the nurses tried to get up yesterday, and after a little struggle thought it best to remain where they were. Two of the resident physicians have had slight attacks, but they have kept at their duties.

1890-01-16: D, January 15. A farmer's wife, having learned that the proceeds of a mortgage on her husband's farm had gone to defray a whiskey bill, at one of the numerous blind pig places here, collected seven more women yesterday and the lot sallied forth with pickaxes, hatchets, and other weapons and broke up several "blind pigs" and destroyed their fixtures and furniture. The proprietors offered but a feeble resistance. A large crowd cheered the women on. Fatal Steam Shovel Explosion. New Brinton, Pa., January 15. At 3:10 o'clock this afternoon, the boiler of a steam shovel used in excavating at Failston, Pa., exploded with such force that several pieces were blown across the river and driven into the ground a fourth of a mile away. The regular force employed in running the machine, a number of Italians, and the conductor and engineer of a train sitting in a tool car were all more or less injured. Wesley Emm, of Pittsburgh, was so badly mangled that he died on his way to the hospital. Nine men were badly hurt and four slightly. Uncle Sam for Peaceful Arbitration. Washington, January 15. Mr. Sherman, from the Committee on Foreign Relations, reported the following concurrent resolution: Resolved, That the President be and hereby is requested to invite from time to time, as circumstances may arise, negotiations with governments with which the United States has or may have diplomatic relations to the end that any differences or disputes between the two governments that cannot be adjusted by diplomatic agency may be referred to a friendly arbitration and be peacefully adjusted by such means. An Unreliable Rumor. New York, January 11. Dunlop's cable news special from London says: "There is a rumor here that the Czar has gone insane owing to the chronic state of fear and worry in which he lives and the events of the past three weeks. He is said to be sunk in a condition of the deepest despondency and insists that his death is drawing near. It is also alleged he is in the habit of soothing his nerves with morphine." Meeting of Civil Engineers. New York, January 15. The American Society of Civil Engineers held their thirty-seventh annual meeting here today. Among those present was Sandford Fleming, of Ottawa. The Secretary's report showed a membership of 180 residents, 130 non-residents, and including honorary, corresponding, associate and fellow members, a total of 1,335. A Death Sentence Commuted. St. Louis, January 15. The death sentence of Madison James, one of the nine Choctaw Indians sentenced to be hanged at Fort Smith, Ark., Thursday, was commuted yesterday to imprisonment for fifteen years. This leaves eight of the nine to hang. Charlie Bullard confidently expects to be reprieved. The others have given up hope. A Historical Barn Burned. Groton, Massachusetts, January 15. The barn on the old Pierce farm, now owned by Osman Gibson, was burned today. The building was erected about the year 1780 as the first Universalist church in America. At the centennial celebration of Universalism in America here in 1870, thousands of Universalists visited the old barn. Another American Blizzard. St. Paul, January 15. Severe weather is reported generally throughout the Northwest. A blizzard is raging at Beardsley, Minn., the drifts being twenty feet high. The first great storm of the season has struck Grand Rapids, extending all over the upper Mississippi region. Trains are delayed; 1,500 miners suspended. Scranton, Pa., January 15. Work at the Henry Clay shaft, the largest mine of the Reading Coal and Iron Company, employing 1,800 men, has been suspended indefinitely this evening because of the stagnation of the coal trade. Brutally Treated by Colombians. New York, January 15. Members of the crew of the American schooner Julien, seized for alleged smuggling by the Colombian gunboat La Papo, have arrived here, and state that they were brutally treated by their captors. Hoosac Tunnel Gas Overcome. Adams, Massachusetts, January 15. Men were overcome by gas in the Hoosac Tunnel today and several barely escaped suffocation. They were brought here and it is thought they will recover. Epidemic of Black Measles. Fort Smith, Kentucky, January 15. The black measles is epidemic here. Mrs. Mitchell and two children have died and Mr. Mitchell is in critical condition. Over one hundred cases are reported. Earthquake in North Carolina. Columbia, B. 

1890-01-22: T, January 21. In the western end of the Territory, hay sells for $20 to $25 a ton, and the holders are not very anxious to dispose of the commodity even at those figures. Dozens of range owners who were reckoned wealthy when winter set in are now practically paupers. In Millinta County, about twenty stockmen have formed a pool for the purpose of rounding up their cattle and sheep and shipping them to Nebraska, where food is plenty. It is estimated that from forty thousand to sixty thousand head of stock will be driven into Kansas and Nebraska for feed during the next month. This is the first season in many years that the range hasn't been open, with plenty of feed. Two thousand head of snake river cattle in Carbon County are reported to be in a starving condition. All game has been driven from the mountains, and there has been an appalling amount of sport hunting. While helpless calves tried to rise to their feet, a cowboy named "Mott" was compelled to take to his heels, leaving a mountain lion to feast on his prey. Heavy Loss of Life. Tacoma, W.T., January 21. At least ten human beings and thousands of cattle and sheep perished in the blizzard which began with the year and raged over Washington for a week. On the Colville reservation, cattle are dying by the hundreds from starvation and thirst. The ground is covered with over two feet of snow on the level, and in some places is drifted mountains high. The keeper of the stage station, twelve miles from Alma, started to walk to town Thursday, and Sunday his body was found on the prairie only a mile from his home, frozen stiff. The mail carrier at Wild Goose Creek perished on the same day, and eight teamsters are known to have lost their lives in the storm. Cattlemen estimate that they will lose one half of their herds this season. The Great Prospects. San Francisco, January 21. The prospects are that the great snow blockade on the Central Pacific will be cleared tonight or tomorrow. There are now three feet of snow at Colfax. At Cisco, the snow is over fifteen feet on the level and in the drifts three or four times as deep. Last evening the Central Pacific opened the road in the Sierras to the five dead engines near Chorlton's Spur. One hundred and fifty snow shovellers digging a trench were surprised and completely buried by snow from a rotary plough, pushed by eleven engines. Nobody was hurt. Ploughs are at work at various places. It is expected the two imprisoned trains between Blue Canyon and Alta will be reached tonight. None of the snow sheds have fallen. The average depth of snow along the sheds is twenty-one feet. Over 1,000 snow shovellers and workmen are on the mountains tonight. A passenger named Lanford died of pneumonia superinduced by an attack of la grippe and was buried by men on snowshoes at Truckee yesterday. Jacob Duta, a snow shoveller, was killed at Colfax. 18900129: W. Evans, managing director and secretary-treasurer. Thirty-four shares of stock, which had been forfeited to the company, were sold at the close of the meeting and realized 107 to 108. Headlines: The Gophers, Winnipeg Free Press. We in Manitoba and the Northwest have reason to be thankful. In a state across the border, we read of blizzards that lasted five days, "caused a large amount of damage, killed much livestock, and caused the death of at least ten men." "Ranchmen calculate they will lose half their stock, but 75 percent would be nearer a true estimate." That beats the gophers. Always ask for Robinson's Phosphorized Pabulum and be sure you get it.

18900130: T. (Montreal, Jan 7th, 1880) (28) Bronchitis Cured. After spending ten winters south, I was cured by Scott's Emulsion. 140 Central St., New York, Jan 26th, 1898. The winter after the great fire in Chicago, I contracted bronchial affections and since then have been obliged to spend nearly every winter south. Last November, I was advised to try Scott's Emulsion of cod liver oil with hypophosphites and to my surprise was relieved at once, and by continuing its use for three months was entirely cured, gained flesh and strength, and was able to stand even the blizzard and attend to business every day.

18900204: 4R: Heavy field ice was run into, the ship having to be turned to the east-southeast. She remained in the lee all that night, and the next morning it became much heavier, the ship having to go dead slow through it. When daylight broke, nothing but ice was to be seen extending on all sides as far as the eye could see. A tremendous iceberg was in sight about nine miles distant, in lat 47 4.1, long 48 35 west. It appeared to be about eight hundred feet high and a quarter of a mile long, having a high peak which looked like a castle. There was a heavy swell at this time and the large cakes of ice around the ship were surging about the side in a dangerous manner, threatening at times to crush her. By evening, the ship entered clear water, but owing to the proximity of ice, the engines were stopped and the ship lay to till daylight. On the morning of the 27th, there was less wind and a more moderate sea, but nothing could be seen on all sides but ice and icebergs. The ship's head was turned west, and it was not until noon that she got into clear water. The wind then commenced blowing again from the northwest, and large bodies of ice were tossing and crashing dangerously near the ship. At 4 o'clock on the morning of the 28th, the wind changed to east, the glass going down rapidly. It commenced snowing heavily and the sea began rising. By 6:30, the ice began to get thinner, and half an hour later clear water was reached. On the morning of the 29th, the wind and sea increased with thick snow and by 10 o'clock the gale was at its height, with a tremendous sea which swept over the deck from stem to stern, several of the crew being knocked down and badly injured. The tarpaulins were torn from the hatches and it is thought the cargo is badly damaged. At one o'clock, the ship was obliged to lay to. It was then a regular blizzard, it being impossible to see the length of the ship for the dry blinding snow. On the afternoon of the 31st, heavy field ice was again met extending from Sable Island to the Nova Scotia coast. She stemmed through it all night and the next day, only leaving it when twelve miles off Beaver Light. Oil was used for twenty-four hours during the hurricanes of the 17th and 18th, but the wind was so strong that it had no effect. The lowest barometer during the voyage was 28.50.

TWO OR SIX ROWED BARLEYS. Test made at the Experimental Farm and their results. Barley as a throwing country. From our own correspondent! Ottawa, February 3. Bulletin number 6 of the Central Experimental Farm is issued this evening. It is devoted to a report of experiments with barley with a view of proving that two-rowed barley, which is the only kind valuable for export to Great Britain, can be successfully grown in Canada. Professor Saunders, in his report, says that the barley crop is one of great importance to the farmers of Canada. The annual product of this cereal for the past seven years in Ontario alone is estimated by Mr. Illus, in his agricultural statistics of Ontario, at nearly twenty million bushels, while the crop for 1888 is put at over twenty-three million bushels. Statistics from other provinces in the Dominion are not available, but their products would largely augment the figures given. Canadian barley is usually of good quality, and the surplus not required for home consumption has heretofore commanded a ready sale at remunerative prices to maltsters in the United States, and such sales have averaged, during the past eleven years, 6,015,115 bushels annually, yielding an average yearly revenue to Canadian farmers during the period of $5,087,812. The export of barley has materially increased in recent years, and as the country becomes more thickly settled and a larger area of land is brought under cultivation, there will no doubt be larger quantities of this grain to dispose of. During the eleven years referred to, the production of barley in the United States has increased from about 42,000,000 bushels in 1878 to 58,000,000 in 1888, but increasing consumption has kept up with the increased supply and hence the demand for Canadian barley has until recently been maintained. The demand for barley for the manufacture of beer in the United States has of late been materially lessened by the use of various substitutes. From the official returns published in the United States, it appears that while 2.3 bushels of barley were used in the manufacture of a barrel of beer in 1888, only one bushel was used for the same quantity in 1889, the balance chiefly being made up of corn, rice, and sorghum. As these ingredients enable the brewer to make his beer at less cost than from barley alone, it is scarcely probable that Canadian barley, however good it may be, will continue to find a market in the United States in such quantities and at such prices as in the past. It is important, then, for Canada that other outlets be provided for her surplus barley, and the only other country which requires more barley than it produces is Great Britain. The average importations of barley into the United Kingdom for the past eleven years have been about 6,000,000 bushels, the import for 1888 having been over 4,000,000 bushels. A considerable quantity of this is six-rowed barley, but that is used only for brewing.

SHIP MARINE ENGINES - AGME MODEL! COAL - OIL, FOR FUEL.

18900207: H, February 6. The Furnas line steamship "Claudia," eighteen days out, arrived from London to-night. The Allan's steamer "Peruvian," Captain Wallace, from Liverpool, January 21, with mails and passengers, arrived today after a stormy voyage. On January 20, a tremendous sea boarded the ship on the starboard side, carrying away part of the bridge and badly crushing First Officer Goodwin. He has been confined to his room ever since. The ship also received other damage about this dock during the passage. Two icebergs were passed on the way, but the ship kept south and saw no field ice. When three days out from Moville, she sighted an abandoned Norwegian barque, but did not ascertain her name. The Peruvian's passenger list was as follows: H. O. Bowers, Mr. McLemont, James Olney, Mrs. Olney, and 23 intermediate and 68 steerage passengers. A representative of the English syndicate that is acquiring the principal breweries in Canada was at Halifax and opened negotiations for line Dougall's distillery. While in this city, the syndicate representative inspected S. Claud & Sons' brewery and the brewery of Keith & Sons. The agent was given the prices at which the establishment could be purchased. The Nova Scotia Fruit Growers' Association is in session at Wolfville. It was stated that speculators had made $20,000 profit on apples purchased in Annapolis Valley last season and that by ignorant and dishonest packing, our fruit growers had only received three-fifths of the actual value of their product and had lost $200,000. It was stated that prior to the Government giving a subsidy to the Furnas line, the freight steamers from Halifax and St. John to London, the fruit growers were afforded competition by the Anchor and Furnas line, with the freight at seventy cents a barrel, but the $25,000 subsidy to the Furnas boat had driven the Anchor line out of this region and consequently the rate had jumped up to over one dollar a barrel. The association passed a resolution that "a Government subsidy to any line of freight steamers to London is prejudicial to the interests of the shippers of apples to Great Britain."

BLOW OF RAIN. Fine today, with easterly wind and rising temperature. Toronto, February 6, 11 p.m. To-night the pressure is highest over the Ottawa Valley, and there are two storm centers to the westward, one in Minnesota, moving southeast, and the other in Texas, moving northeast. The weather has been fine and cold from the lake to the Atlantic. A heavy snowfall has occurred in Manitoba and a northwest blizzard is reported this morning from the Northwest Territories. Minimum temperature: Calgary, 4 below; Winnipeg, 14 below; Toronto, 13 below; Montreal, 8 below; Halifax, 14 below. St. Lawrence: Increasing easterly winds; increasing cloudiness, followed by snow or rain tonight; rising temperature.

MONTREAL RECORD, OBSERVATION TAKEN AT 6 O'CLOCK.

Pittsburgh, February 7. The worst storm in years has been raging throughout western Pennsylvania since noon today. Snow, hail, rain, and wind have been playing havoc. Mr. Burney's body was immediately taken from the wreck. It was mangled almost beyond recognition. Many houses in Kiowa were damaged. At Uniontown, the roof was blown off the M. E. church, a part of it alighting on the house of John Brown, just north of the church, crushing it to pieces. The lower part of the church is so badly shattered that it will have to be taken down. The roof of the large new building lately built by the Pennsylvania Construction Company was also blown off. A wagon driven by James Bush was blown over Gray's Hill. The wagon is lying on its back, with the wheels whirling in the air. Postmaster Linker's new house was nearly demolished; also James Fratikenberry's house, and John Wringer's house was leveled to the ground. The telephone and electric light wires are all down. 

Narrow Escape: None of the coke works are running south of Uniontown. The Bodstone Coke Company's offices at Brownfield were demolished. The end was blown out of the engine house at Leith and Warren's glass works. The roof of the Lutheran church was also blown off. 

At Connellsville, J.D., February 7: A severe snow and wind storm is raging here. The roof of the courthouse has been blown off. 

Kitpokn, Minn., February 7: The worst blizzard within the recollection of the oldest inhabitant is raging. The wind is from the north, and the air is a cloud of snow. The thermometer registers 10 degrees below zero, and it is growing colder. 

Winnipeg, February 7: The worst storm experienced here for a decade is now raging, and Winnipeg may be said to be completely snowed in. The blizzard began last night and shows no sign of abatement, but as the temperature is comparatively mild, no serious or fatal results are feared. Houses are snowed in, and the occupants have to dig their way out. Sidewalks and roads are in many places impassable, schools are shut down, streetcars drawn by four horses make trips only at long intervals, trains are behind schedule, and business is generally suspended.

1890-0219: 1887 Wheat and Flour: 2,101,000; 1,848,000; 2,170,000 Corn: 400,000; 847,000; 831,000. 

The following were the amounts of grain on passage to the continent on the dates mentioned: Feb 15, Feb 18, Feb 10. 

Wheat, qrs Corn, qrs Wheat, qrs Corn, qrs. 

The amount of wheat in sight on this continent and afloat to Europe is 51,037,000 bushels, an increase of 603,000 bushels compared with a week ago, an increase of 127,000 with two weeks ago, an increase of 67,000 with three weeks ago, a decrease of 302,000 with four weeks ago, and a decrease of 2,408,000 with a year ago. 

The following table shows the total quantity of wheat in sight according to the Chicago statement of the visible supply and the amount afloat to Europe. 

January 4, 1890: 64,436,000; February 10, 1880: 63,134,000; February 18, 1888: 63,106,000; February 10, 1887: 81,084,000; February 20, 1889: 70,001,000. 

United States Grain Market: Wheat in Chicago today was about steady, closing at 74c for February, 76c for March, 77c for May, 77c for June, and 76c for July. Corn closed at 25c for March, 28c for April, and 30c for May. Oats closed at 19c for February, 19c for March, 21c for May, and 20c for July. 

Irwin, Green & Co.'s Chicago special to the Gazette says: The abnormal weather conditions have furnished reasons for a further heaviness in grain, and especially in wheat, while lower freights have mostly operated to depress corn and oats. The argument for the latter was overwhelming because of the small consumption on the farm, which was the direct consequence of the season. The almost unprecedented absence of winter weather in months when it is expected to put in an appearance is one of the chief causes of weakness in all cereals, and every day that the cold wave holds aloof lessens the probability of its coming at all on this side of summer heats. Already some are counting confidently on the uninterrupted enjoyment of spring weather during the next three months, to be followed by an early and abundant harvest. It is, however, dangerous to commit oneself to this theory, as nature has always furnished her own compensations in the past and can be trusted to do so this time, and the only trouble is nobody can tell when. 

It is a historical fact that most mild winters have been followed by severe weather just at the time when it was not wanted, and the crops have suffered in consequence. This may be an exception to the rule, but analogies are against it, as the sun is gathering strength daily but is a long way below the equinox, although the month in which it reaches that point has ere this been marked by blizzards of fearful intensity. We are so nearly out of the wood now as to justify a shout of joy at having escaped its perils, and it goes without saying that if heavy frosts should come, each day's delay will only make the evil worse in the winter wheat fields, and if deferred till the end of this month it means the failure of half the crop. If the frosts hold off till the middle of March, the result would probably be even more disastrous as the stalks, full of precociously formed juices, would burst asunder by the act of freezing, leaving the roots too much exhausted of their vitality to be equal to the task of forming another ear-bearing stem, and nothing would be left but to reseed for another crop. 

Of the prospects in the spring wheat regions, no more can be said than that all is problematic, but a cold summer following a warm winter would find large quantities of grain unmatured on the arrival of frosts next winter. The recent news from other continents certainly does not favor the weakness in wheat here. The stocks in the United Kingdom are low, and there is an official endorsement of the sometime since reported heavy falling off in the Russian yield, as also in some other parts of Europe. The acreage in India is conceded to be less than that of last year, and according to the latest mail advices, the average yield promises to be poor for want of sufficient rain, and now comes the confirmation news that the Australian crop has panned out far below expectations. For this reason, several ships under charter to carry wheat have been diverted to other services. It is expected that the twelve million bushels to be received in Western Europe from Australia will not be delivered, and more heavy rain in California threatens to leave a small export surplus there. 

As was noted in our letter of a week ago, the future of the wheat market hinges mostly on the weather, and that statement holds good now. If we have no winter, the price of wheat may sink farther; if we have yet to experience any really cold spell, for the bulls will not need any further encouragement to hold. In that event, there would probably be such a rush to buy as has seldom been witnessed in this or any other market, and I can only suggest that it may not be wise to run the risk of getting caught on the short side in such a storm. 

Corn is stated to have reached the lowest point known since August 1862, and it was only brought over short distances to this market. Some men in trade say they expect a reduction in the rail rates to bring a large increase in the receipts, sufficiently so to force a further decline. There may be some mistake about this, but in any event, the visible supply decreased last week, and there was probably a much larger decrease in the quantities in transit by rail, which are not included in the statement, and a good deal of covering by the shorts was done this week on the idea of larger receipts, and have been fully discounted before arrival. Corn has "had no friends" for a long while past, but that fact does not prove an awakening to be impossible, and there is room for a short. 

Provisions are staggered by the fact of big stocks and the fear of larger receipts of hogs, the latter being favored by better country roads and good prices paid for hogs compared with corn, but there are willing buyers of the product on every slight decline, and the stuff is already so low as to make it easy to carry large stocks, pending the arrival of orders from willing consumers of cheap meat.

TRAINS DELAYED BY THE STORM: All trains are very much behind time today on account of the storm. The Montreal train this morning arrived at Belair at 7 o'clock but was stopped there two hours by snow. Mr. McShane and two other gentlemen, getting tired, got out and walked to Lorette, a distance of three and a half miles, through the blinding blizzard. All three were more or less frozen, and when they arrived at Lorette they had the satisfaction of learning that the train had passed through some time before. They telegraphed to Quebec for a special train and arrived here not long after the regular train. The train for Montreal, which should have left here at 10 p.m., had not left at midnight, but the officials hoped to get it through. 

THE TIMBER DEFALCATION: At the request of Messrs. Bryant, Powell & Bryant, the London timber merchants, Judge Bouthier has named John Y. Welch, of this city, provisional guardian of their establishment here, left vacant by defaulter C.

A New Departure at the Thistle: Midwinter would seem an unpropitious time for plants of any sort to bloom outside a hothouse. Now a curling rink, by no stretch of imagination, can be written down as a hothouse. Scotland's natural plant is a hardy and rugged one that persists in growing and making itself felt under the most adverse circumstances. There was a blizzard all day; an inconsiderate wind blew one around corners and blew nicely granulated snow into every unprotected corner of one's anatomy. It was wretchedly uncomfortable outdoors, and the evening was worse than the day. Under these conditions, it was strange that even such a hardy growth as the Thistle should prosper. But the Thistles not only bloomed, but actually out-bloomed themselves last night. While candy snow was quietly filtering down, innumerable necks and black-haired men wore white moustaches and were forced to breathe through their mouths; while fur collars were no protection against the winds and galoshes were not impervious to impassable snow banks, there was one possibility where disagreeable elements could be converted into actual enjoyableness. That possibility lay in the curling rinks. 

Never before in the history of Montreal have what are generally looked on as the young men taken so active an interest in curling as during the present season. Not very long ago, the young men looked at the game as one only fitted for their older counterparts. That was because they had never tried it, knew nothing about it; but from the superiority of their ignorance found themselves competent to speak. Then a few more daring than the rest thought they would try it. They came, they saw, they tried it, but they did not master it immediately to any great extent. But they found out one bit of valuable information, and that was that curling was a game adapted to men of all ages who appreciate good, healthy, sturdy exercise. It only required a beginning. 

One by one the feeders came in. Their arms got sore, their legs got sore for the first few days, and without thinking of the tee, they thought the right side of the hog line was a consummation devoutly to be wished for. That was the hardest stage, and it was soon over. A little later they wicked, and drew and raised and guarded and made ports and swept and finally were curlers, and most of them very creditable curlers, too. Now there are none more enthusiastic than the young members, and the older and sturdier hands are glad to see it. With the infusion of new blood, there will necessarily be some innovations, not in the game, for that would savor of the sacrilegious. 

Among the young curlers, the members of the Thistle club are perhaps the foremost. Somebody who is an admirer of the gentler sex got an idea that maybe the ladies would appreciate a gala night. The mere mention of it was enough to start between fifteen and twenty young men working heart and soul. The older members of the club nodded their heads sagely; they remembered when they were young themselves, and of course they approved of the idea, and the use of the rink and club rooms was turned over to the young members for last evening. Reception, decoration, and refreshments committees were appointed, and how well those committees did their work could only be fully appreciated by being present at the rink. Everything seemed new. The dull monotonous white of the walls was made bright with the colors of miscellaneous bunting. It seemed as if the building had been rigged out for a ball; and on the cold, unsympathetic air, under the deft hands of "George," was laid with a silken design in blue. The ladies were to be there, and of course nothing was left undone. Even the creamy hila pipe and the fragrant cigar were to be on hand. 

The rink was crowded, but not uncomfortably; there were over 100 ladies and an equivalent number of gentlemen present; the ladies even got excited and many left the warm precincts of the club room to get a better view in the chilling rink. Pretty feet were tipped resolutely on the platform to keep them warm; dainty hands clapped warmly to encourage the players. With their natural aptitude, they soon discerned a nice bit of play and applauded accordingly, which applause was frequently ornamented with just the suspicion of a scream. Then willing swains insisted that the ladies have refreshments, and the keen cold air and the excitement of the game gave a sense of appetite that Crosse & Blackwell would give a fortune to patent. 

Under the circumstances, is it to be wondered at that the keenest rivalry prevailed among the players? Why, in olden times, knights entered the jousts, splintered lances on each other and died happy for less than half the smiles that were showered on the contestants last night. And was any conquering hero ever prouder than the winning rinks when one of the fair ones whispered, "I'm so glad you won; that game was just lovely," or some other phrase equally pleasant? There was some splendid play, too, that called forth the plaudits of the more experienced and less impressionable ones; for instance, the last shot made by Mr. Stewart. His opponent was laying shot and well guarded. There was an almost impassable port, not two inches to spare, and down the center line came the iron. There was no occasion to sweep for that shot. Clean through the port it came, drove out the shot stone with a bang and lay almost in the center of the tee. That was a beauty, and amid well-merited applause, the match was over. 

The news was: 

LINK NO 1 B, February 20: The provincial Legislature opened today in the midst of a blizzard, which raged with great violence. It was the worst storm of the season. The snow drifted badly, and business was practically suspended. Governor McLellan delivered a lengthy speech from the throne. The Grit Government, on the eve of the election, has become quite hopeful, and the speech congratulated the Legislature on the large measure of prosperity that our province has enjoyed during the last year. Our fishermen in some localities do not share in that prosperity as fully as other classes, but get compensated in some degree for a shut down in that branch of industry. There was gratifying activity. Good harvests rewarded the labors of the farmer. Coal mining operations were extensively carried on. Gold mining was prosecuted with much success. The condition of business throughout the world gave prosperity to our shipowners and revived our shipbuilding industry, and trade and commerce generally were much improved. The Nova Scotia Central Railway from Middleton to Lunenburg has been opened. The local government will subsidize a railway from the Intercolonial to Ironfield at East River Pit, where smelting works are to be established.

I lost the train. 

Ashtabula, Ohio, February 22. Michael. Here is the corrected text:

---

Hdc; McDonough, aged 60, discovered a rail which had been placed across a track just outside of the city limits yesterday. A train was in sight and McDonough had only time to lift one end and drag it from the track when the engine struck the other end and the rail was dashed against his head, crushing his skull like an eggshell. The engine and cars did not leave the track.

**The Fight for the Fair**  
Washington, February 23  
The eve of the great free-for-all race for the World's Fair has been used by the friends of the four contestants in getting into the best possible position for the opening tomorrow and in arranging plans and counterplans. It is on all hands conceded that Chicago will bring prominently to the front, and that the Lake City will capture the first heat, but there is a wide difference of opinion and a great amount of uncertainty as to how many heats it will require for any one of the four rivals to distance her competitors. There is speculation as to whether any fair will be held. The opposition to the holding of a fair is gaining ground, and many predict that a formidable array of members will be found opposed to any fair before a site is chosen.

**The Meetings the Other Day**  
Jackson, Miss, February 23  
Minority and majority reports were made by the Legislative committee appointed to examine into the office of state treasurer. The reports do not differ materially. They express the opinion that when ex-Treasurer Hemingway is credited with $1,505 paid out by him for coupons in 1870, and for which no entry can be found on his general books, it will be found that the state owes him over $2,000.

**Put Dynamite Into the Stove**  
Remington, Pa, February 23  
W. M. Crock, of Adamsburg, took to his home this afternoon a stock of dynamite and placed it in the stove. In ten minutes a terrific explosion occurred, the kitchen was wrecked and a piece of the stove shot into an adjoining room, striking Wm Steinets on the breast and killing him. Flying missiles struck Crock and his wife and child who were in the room, and it is thought they were fatally hurt.

**A Fearful Texas Epidemic**  
Argos, Texas, February 22  
A fearful epidemic is raging here. The disease is pronounced meningitis, or spotted fever, and several persons have died of it. The people are terror-stricken and many are leaving. An appeal to Fort Worth for physicians and nurses was responded to.

**Snowstorms Thick as Fog**  
New York, February 23  
The steamship Mohawk, from Gibraltar, reports an unusual passage. The voyage was one continual rain or snowstorm. The snowstorms were of the same character as the prairie blizzards. The steamer's whistle was kept going as in a dense fog.

**18900227: CYCLONES AND BLIZZARDS**  
Tennessee Towns Nearly Wiped Out by a Violent Wind Storm  
CLOUD BURSTS AND FLOODS  
The Great Vantage in Many Hints - Railroad Washed Out and Farm Houses Destroyed  
Memphis, Tenn, February 20  
Brownsville, Tenn, six miles northeast of Memphis, on the Louisville & Nashville railroad, was struck by a cyclone at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. Half of the business houses of the town were unroofed and many were materially damaged, while several buildings were totally destroyed. Following the cyclone came a flood of rain that completely drenched the goods in the unroofed houses. The losses will aggregate $50,000. The only loss of life reported is that of a woman living three miles from Brownsville, who was struck by a falling tree and killed. Her two children were severely injured.

**Madden, Terrible Work**  
The woman was Mrs. James Cooper. The storm struck Brownsville while its inhabitants slept and had done its terrible work before the real situation was realized. It came from a southwesterly direction and was preceded by a rumbling noise, which lasted a few seconds and then burst upon the town in a sprawling fury. Residences rocked like cradles and heavy brick buildings trembled like leaves as the storm swept by. The storm did much damage at other places.

**Marvelous Escape of School Children**  
At Marianna, Ark, the new Christian church was completely demolished, Lester's cotton shed was blown away and the roofs of several other buildings were lifted off. Three miles from town, a negro schoolhouse, with 65 children in it, was blown from its foundation, but no one was hurt. The White River at Batesville, Ark, rose eight feet in a few hours, washing away culverts and delaying trains badly. Three houses were blown down near Pleville, and several buildings flattened in the southeastern portion of the country. The Hot Springs old observatory, which had stood for several years on the summit of the Hot Springs mountain, was leveled by the gale. 

**Farm Houses Mown Down**  
The storm played havoc with the entire country between Hot Springs and the Ouachita River. Many farm houses were torn to atoms and the path of the storm is one mass of wrecked timber. Large trees were uprooted and in many places the roads are completely blockaded by fallen timber. That lives were lost is more than probable, owing to the destruction of so many farm houses. Considerable damage was done to buildings and fences at Little Rock and at Alexander. A school house was blown down and nine children injured.

**Great Damage by Flood**  
Cincinnati, February 28  
A serious flood is threatened in the Ohio River. Lima, Ohio, February 26  
Many country bridges in this section have been swept away by a flood and also the railroad bridges of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton railroads. Heavy damage to houses and crops is reported. Indianapolis, Ind, February 20  
Considerable damage has been done to railroad property all over Indiana by heavy rains. Nashville, Tenn, February 26  
Two spans of the Tennessee River bridge at Johnstown were blown out during Monday's storm.

**Cloudburst and Tornado**  
Cambridge City, Ind, February 20  
A cloudburst on Monday night caused Martindale Creek near this place to rise so quickly that a woman and three children named Hull were drowned. They belonged to a party of gypsies. Casselberry, Ill, February 20  
Monday night this place was visited by the heaviest rainfall that has occurred for fifteen years. A tornado at Bainbridge, fifteen miles east, completely demolished the residence of J. T. Sweeney. There were several persons in the building and all were injured. Several buildings were blown from their foundations.

**Blizzards in the Northwest**  
Ashland, Wis, February 26  
The worst snow and wind storms of the season are prevailing here. It has been snowing and blowing ever since Sunday night. Osceola, Wis, February 26  
Yesterday afternoon a blizzard of great violence swept down upon this city. Watertown, Wis, February 26  
The most severe snowstorm in two years raged here yesterday and last night. Railroads are blocked to some extent. 

**Macon City, Iowa, February 26**  
A blizzard set in yesterday, covering the entire northern part of the state. All trains are delayed.

**Chicos, Nev, February 21**  
There was a terrible storm at Lake Tahoe Monday. Small crafts were smashed to pieces and the wharves severely shaken. Trees, houses, and wood piles were blown to pieces. The snow is drifting along the road here, covering the station houses and burying logging camps.

**A LITTLE COLDER today**  
Vila I have no rain-fall cold in the Northwest.  
Toronto, February 26, 11 p.m.  
The depression has moved with decreasing energy from Ohio to Western Nova Scotia, giving a continuance of dull weather, with local rain and sleet in Quebec and the Maritime provinces. The high area has spread from the Northwest to the lower lake region, but with much diminished energy, causing only a small change in temperature. The weather continues fine in the Northwest and the temperature is rising slowly. 

Minimum temperatures: Calgary, 30 below; Prince Albert, 40 below; Winnipeg, 30 below; Toronto, 36; Montreal, 34; Quebec, 30; Halifax, 28.  
River St. Lawrence: North to east wind, mostly cloudy, with light snow or rain, stationary or a little lower temperature.

FEBRUARY 26, 1890

**18900304:**  
If they fail in compelling the board to continue to furnish quotations, they will have to devise some other means of getting the prices made on the board. Just what plan they will adopt has not been determined upon, but they declare they will trade in produce in spite of anything the board of trade may do. The telegraph officials do not wish to say anything about the matter, but they are largely interested in the fight. It means the loss of a great business by the companies if the board succeeds in its present intentions, unless they can meet the contingency in some manner. A bitter fight is in prospect.

**A MARCH BLIZZARD**  
Visit the Eastern and Atlantic States. Train and Mails Delayed.  
Boston, March 3  
A very heavy snowstorm has prevailed in the greater portion of New England since yesterday. At noon today, despatches indicate a practical cessation of the storm. Highways are in bad condition and trains are somewhat delayed. Advices from points on Cape Cod report the worst storm of the winter, accompanied by a severe northeast gale. At Newport, it...

After spending ten winters South, I was cured by Scott's Emulsion, 150 Centre St, New York, June 11th, 1888. **18900322:**  
Y, March 21  
Provincial Detective Murray of Ontario arrived in Buffalo yesterday and left again today. He stopped at the Stafford House, where Mr. and Mrs. Burchell, Benwell, and Pelly stopped on their arrival here February 16th, and from where Burchell and Benwell started together on the morning of February 17th on that fateful journey to the Blenheim swamp. Mr. Murray came to Buffalo to trace back the line of Burchell's movements and to make available at the trial certain interesting evidence. It will be remembered that Burchell on Thursday, February 27th, sent a despatch from Buffalo to himself at Niagara Falls and signed it "Stafford," as if coming from the Stafford House. The evident purpose of the bogus telegram was to substantiate statements made by Burchell at Niagara Falls and to induce Pelly to start on that wild goose chase to New York, after Benwell. Mr. Murray heard the statements of the Stafford House people and then gave it as his unhesitating opinion that Burchell had sent the telegram to himself. The original of the dispatch is in the possession of Manager Burnett of the Great North Western Telegraph Company here, is carefully guarded, and will be produced at the trial. Mr. Murray, being interviewed by a reporter, said: "I shall go to New York in a few days and trace the movements of Burchell and his party there. Perhaps I shall be compelled to go to England. There are many gaps here and there that must be filled. There is one of three years in Burchell's life I must know all his transactions during that time." "Do you still think that others beside Benwell have been lured to their death in Canada?" "I have not the slightest doubt of it. Only yesterday I received some very important evidence on this point. I got a letter from a gentleman in New York, a very prominent business man, speaking of five young Englishmen...

--- 

This corrected text maintains the original meaning and formatting while addressing the OCR errors. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

Englishmen who, to gain his knowledge, came to this country to become farm pupils. Two of them disappeared at Niagara Falls. They gave directions to have their letters sent to the Falls for two weeks, but their letters were never called for, and the two young men have never been heard of since. I know that Burchell has been out to this country several times, and I have very little doubt that he is one of a gang of conspirators who were in league to first rob and then murder their victims. Besides, after looking up Burchell's movements in New York, I shall investigate the statement of the New York businessman, and perhaps may be compelled to continue the investigation in England. 

"Then, Mr. Murray, it may be said that you are not working on Burchell's case, then?" 

"That is true," he answered; "I am working on both ends of the case now. There may be some surprising developments." 

"Another of Burchell's lies was discovered by Mr. Murray at the Stafford House here. When the English party were leaving for the Falls February 18th, the clerk asked Burchell where he intended stopping at the Falls, with the idea of advising him of a good place to stop at. 

"Oh, that's all right," returned Burchell, briefly; "I have a place down there." 

Detective Murray is firmly convinced that Mrs. Burchell was cognizant of her husband's intentions to despoil his victims of their money, though he will not go so far as to say she was in the conspiracy of murder. The manner in which she coincided in many of her husband's lies strengthens the conviction in the mind of the detective. He says Burchell is the coolest, most wonderful man he ever saw. 

**News from Down East: The Peruvian's Nonappearance**  
**Halifax, March 21**  
The Furness Line steamer Boston City arrived today, twenty-two days out from Hamburg, for New York, short of coal. She experienced heavy weather, had her decks swept, and had a rough time generally. She could not make Sydney on account of ice. Wednesday night she encountered a snow blizzard. She takes 500 tons of coal and proceeds to New York tomorrow. Nothing has been yet heard of the mail steamer Peruvian, now sixteen days out. It is feared some accident has happened to her machinery. The palatial residence of the late Hon. James Butler has been purchased by Archbishop O'Brien for a globe house.

**18900417:** D's diploma is as good as a saloon license. It will not be long before the ranks of medicine in Iowa are reinforced by hatches of "doctors" whose knowledge of mixed drinks and bone races will be rather more marked than their acquaintance with the materia medica. A Scotch Catholic, a gentleman from Washington, DC, and two other correspondents have sent letters bearing on the French evangelization mission. Though there is no fault to be found with the character of the communications, it has been deemed better not to insert them. The issue is an unprofitable one for newspaper discussion, and like others of a similar character, has a tendency to drift away from the point at first raised into subjects that have ever been and probably always will be occasions of difference between Christians. And, it may be added, such discussions never made converts, one way or the other. The nomination of Mr. Landry, MP, to succeed Judge Botsford, besides putting an able man on the bench, will necessitate an election in Kent County. This is a New Brunswick constituency, with few manufacturing interests. Its industries are fishing, shipbuilding, lumbering, and agriculture, those the Opposition hold, most injured by the present Government's policy. If this contention were true, the Liberals should carry the county; but they will not. The Liberals are not in touch with the real sentiment of Canada. Elsewhere we republish from the Times of April 2 an account of the mission to this country of the Hon. Henry Boyle in search of his brother, Lord Boyle, who had for some years been ranching in the Northwest, where he was well known for taking an interest in the country's affairs and as a member of the Northwest Council. By his father's recent death, he has fallen heir to the earldom of Shannon, and his family is naturally uneasy as to his whereabouts. The Hamilton Spectator says there is a growing suspicion among thoughtful Reformers that Archbishop Cleary is subsidized by Mr. Meredith. There is enough in the politico-religious situation in Ontario at the moment to give point to the Spectator's rather irreverent remark. The Archbishop's utterances have made as many votes against as for the separate school system as it exists in Ontario today. The last storm down in Nebraska blew the farmers' crops out of the ground. This is a variation of the plague, but it is just as distressing as the blizzard, the cyclone, the sandstorm, or the drought. It looks as if the one salvation for the deluded United States agriculturists is to move up to Canada while there is yet room. The movement to exclude the English members from office in the Montreal Bar has the appearance of a case of Satan finding mischief for idle hands to do. Not many of the authors are in the running for the Banco. Expenses of four years of Mercier rule: $15,163,111; expenses of four years under Conservative administration: $13,190,904, an increase of three million to the expenses of the province. It is a pity a United States contingent could not be arranged for Sir Richard Cartwright before the next parliamentary elections; he would be sure of a walk-over. Within a fortnight, two murderers have been sentenced to death in Ontario and Quebec. Justice is beginning to catch up with the homicidal outbreak.

**18900703:** I believe the gathering separated about 3 o'clock, singing the National Anthem and Vive la Canadienne. NOTES OF THE EVENING. Mr. Pacaud presided at the press table. Mrs. and Miss Pacaud presided in the gallery. Mr. Laurier applauded all Mr. Mercier's condemnations of the veto power. Mr. Herder's mention of Mr. Laurier as "my chief," elicited rounds of cheering. About 200 ladies came into the gallery during dinner and remained until midnight or after. The Harmony band under Mr. Edmond Hardy rendered a good programme during dinner. Madame Mercier and party got a hearty welcome upon entering the gallery, the band playing "Vive la Canadienne." The Premier spoke clearly and slowly but was apparently much fatigued and did not appear at his best. The hall was handsomely decorated with flags and bunting and reflected much credit upon the good taste of Mr. Deullao. There was a fair attendance of English Liberals of the "Old Guard," the recent victory having evidently brought them back to the fold. Mr. McShane distinguished himself twice. Once was when he led off the cheering for "My Premier," and the other when he started the recognition of Mr. Shehyrl. It was noticeable that while Mr. Mercier was most particular in his emphasis about the Parti National and the Parti national, Mr. Laurier and the English speakers of the evening all spoke of it as the Liberal party. President Gouin's complaint that the Government had no "organ" in Montreal must have been refreshing to Mr. Beaugrand, who was present, and to Hon. Victor Mitchell, who was not present, although announced to speak. Mr. Prefontaine's declaration in favor of unrestricted reciprocity is held by some to confirm the rumor that Mr. Erastus Wiman is coming to the rescue of both the Elevated Railway and Longueuil Bridge schemes, in both of which the member for Chambly is interested. Those among us who are suffering with bronchitis or weakness of the throat or lungs should not delay but take Scott's Emulsion regularly, according to the advice of their physician or the directions on the bottle. Always ask for Scott's Emulsion and be sure you get Scott's Emulsion.
