18900925: B. Fredericton school going to Toronto, and Toronto coming here. The decision of Sir Adolphe is supreme; only if we could be heard we would say please leave to carry out the advantages you have conferred on this town and county by establishing a military school here with a French-Canadian commandant. The St. Johns school is considered the French school of the country; it is nearly so; the two nationalists agree well together. It is hoped the Hon Minister will coincide in these views coming home. "A large number of Canadians who settled in Dakota and other parts of the United States are daily returning to Canada convinced that they can do better at home than abroad." 

From black Dakota's blizzards, From Kansas' arid plains; From retrograde New England, They're coming home again. Home to that fair Dominion Where plenty smiles on toil, Where to labor's honest effort Responds the fertile soil: Where nature's gracious bounty Extends o'er land and main. To their own fair country, Canada, they're coming home again. Misled by false pretenses They strayed away from home, Imbued with futile fancies, In lords and lands to roam; Fair fortune seemed to call them To some more favored shore, And they left their own Dominion To return to it no more. In fancy's dream they pictured A country rich with grain, But the picture proved illusive And they're coming home again. Far sadder, wiser, poorer, By experience dearly taught, Their fancy's visions faded, And their daydreams come to naught; They turn their backs on labor Which would not repay their pain, And with hope once more rekindled They're coming home again. To the land of their adoption, From it no more to roam, To their own fair country, Canada, once more they're coming home.

18901110: STEWART MUNN & CO., 8 ST. JOHNS STREET, Montreal. Bell Telephone 113. A BIG BOOM FOR CLEVELAND. The Democratic Victor is as Much as the Party's. NO USE FOR A FAMINE FUND. The Snow Storm in the Northwest States - Heavy Mexican Earthquake. Jersey Anarchists in Jail. Columbus, Ohio, November 9. Allen W. Thorman, in an address at a Democratic jollification meeting at Hamilton, said: "Yet this was the issue plain and simple brought about by the McKinley bill; and to the man Grover Cleveland, who three years ago boldly and fearlessly attacked the whole system, more than to any other do we owe this victory. Never for one moment, amid all the abuse that was heaped upon him did he falter or his courage fail. Believing in the truth and justice of his position, believing that the Government had no right to take money from the pockets of the people solely for the benefit of a particular class, he continued year after year when others hesitated to battle for the right and now, when all are eager to join in the fray, certainly this fact that he dared to lead, when scarcely any dared to follow, shows the mettle he is made of, and I believe the people will see to it that he shall be again chosen as their leader in 1892. If ever a man spoke the truth surely he did when he said a few days ago: 'No one has a greater right to rejoice than I have.'" 

Heavy Snow in Northwestern States. St. Paul, Minn., November 9. A snowstorm raged yesterday morning in the southeast of this state and has kept up since. A Yerkes, SD, despatch says that a heavy snowstorm began there yesterday morning. Old settlers and Indians say that winter has set in and the ground will be under snow from now until spring. Colder weather is also expected by them. A high wind accompanied the snow at Rice Lake, Minn., and Lakefield, Albert Lea, St. James, and Willmar. All report heavy snow, with prospects of its lasting some time. Some light flurries of snow had been reported before this season, but this is really the first snow of the season throughout Southern Minnesota and South Dakota. Lincoln, Neb., November 9. Reports from Brown County, in Northwest Nebraska, tell of a very heavy storm. It has been snowing continually for fourteen hours and the wind is all that is lacking to make a mild form of a blizzard.

Newark Gets Tired of Anarchists. Newark, N.

18901217: LOST IN A BLIZZARD. An Aged Couple Edward and Cawl Terrington Charlottetown, PEI, December 16. Last Friday an elderly couple by the name of Higglint, living in the West Royalty, left their home to attend market. After transacting business in town they started for home about 5 o'clock. It had been snowing all day, and toward evening the storm had assumed the character of a blizzard and the drifting snow was blinding. They struck off the road to take a short cut for their home and wandered into a forty-acre field, got bewildered and lost their way. Battered with snow and benumbed with cold they tried in vain to get their bearings until completely exhausted when both lay down to die within a few minutes' walk of home. On Sunday morning search was instituted and about noon Mrs. Higglint was found sitting on the sleigh still living. She was carried to her home but she soon succumbed. Mr. Higglint was also found a short distance from the sleigh. He was not so badly frozen as his wife and he was taken at once to the hospital and his condition is considered very critical. The suffering and exposure have affected his mind and he is unable to give any account of his wandering and experience of the two nights and day and a half he had spent in the snow.

18910109: AOO London, January 8. Mr. Balfour's fund for the distressed poor in Ireland now amounts to £10,000. Many contributions of clothing have also been received from across the Atlantic. London, January 8. Cable messages received here from Buenos Aires today announce that a revolution has broken out in Chile. 

A FIERCE BLIZZARD. Mere Traffic and Close up the Railways, while People are Forced to Remain Indoors. London, January 8. At Fiume and Trieste in the Adriatic, the storm rages with unabated severity. In both cities all the theatres and other places of amusement are closed and the streets have stopped running. The blizzard is so fierce that it is dangerous to venture out. Traffic is at a complete standstill and the streets are almost totally deserted. 

Berlin, January 8. The severe weather here and throughout northern Germany is causing much suffering. A number of fishing vessels are icebound in the lower Elbe, many of them are known to be short of provisions and there are no means of rendering assistance. Twenty ships are now drifting about in the ice helpless under the fury of a bitter nor'easter. 

Paris, January 8. Bitterly cold weather prevails here and is causing much distress among the poorer classes. The bodies of three persons who had been frozen to death during the night were picked up in the streets this morning. 

London, January 8. The body of a man, frozen to death, was found this morning in the streets of Preston. The 200 clerks in the London Postal Savings Bank, suspended for refusing to work overtime, have apologized and have been reinstated. 

A MYSTERIOUS GHOST is Wanted Badly Just Now by Crazy Manitoba Indians.

18910112: A foot of snow is in the city. Twenty Bore ship laborers have returned from the Southern States, having been unable to obtain work owing to the boycott. Le St. Laurent, the official organ of Cardinal Taschereau, publishes the full living article regarding the situation in Ireland: "I am one of those men who, when they fail, drag down with them to their ruin all those who come within the orbit of their influence. In spite of his ability, the prestige and the incredible energy he displayed, his political death is a matter of a few months only. He preferred eating the forbidden fruit to being the liberator of Ireland, and now let him accept the consequences of his acts. In the end, it will lead him to the declaration of his episcopacy which has just said: 'Assuredly Catholic Ireland, which is distinguished by so high a standard of virtue and purity in its social life, will not accept for its chief a man so utterly dishonored and so unworthy of the confidence of Christians.'" This article has in all probability been published in view of a meeting of Irishmen that is to be held this week to decide what stand they will take. The chances now are that they will repudiate Parnell, although up to the present they have been strongly in his favor. The Inquest on the victims of the recent accident on the Intercolonial will be resumed tomorrow, when Light and Scott, the engineers, will be examined. The Inquest will probably be concluded on Tuesday. A fire broke out this evening in Robitaille's hotel, St. Vallier Street. The upper flat was gutted, but the flames were prevented from spreading. The loss will be about $400. A blizzard set in tonight about 8 o'clock, and the streets are well nigh impassable. At midnight the Montreal train had not yet arrived. 

FROZEN TO DEATH. A Farmer Leaves His Sled on the Continental Road and is Never Seen Alive Again. Ottawa, January 10. A sad case of death from exposure to the severe cold of some days ago is reported from up the Gatineau. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed while preserving the original meaning and formatting:

**Ait Road**  
A respectable farmer named Fabian Auger, the father of a large family, who resides at Lacroix Lake, was returning home from church in a sleigh with his wife and several children on Sunday last, when he decided, after riding part of the way, to walk the rest of the journey, telling his wife to drive on, as he had quite a piece to go. Nothing was thought of the father not reaching home by night as it was imagined he had called into some neighbor's on the way. Becoming alarmed on Monday morning at his continued absence, a messenger was dispatched to hunt up Auger. The body of the missing man was found frozen stiff in the middle of the road only two miles from home.  

**Everything Lovely**  
The **KII Wfzniri** National-ed with the Morning of the Railroad Conference  
New York, January 10  
Shortly after 11 o'clock, Jay Gould said everything was progressing smoothly in the railroad conference and that in all probability the work of the whole conference would be ended inside of two hours. The advisory board was in session all the afternoon, and upon the adjournment at 6 p.m., Roswell Miller, the Chairman, announced that the board agreed upon a form of organization and adopted by-laws to govern the same. The only other business accomplished was to elect the following officers for one year: Roswell Miller, president; members of the finance committee, Messrs. Hughitt, Gould, Cable, Oakes, and Manvel. The board adjourned to meet on Monday morning. The by-laws adopted today are designed to carry out the principles of the President's agreement, entered into at the meeting here December 10 last. This agreement has been formally ratified by the directors of the following companies: Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe, Chicago & Northwestern, Chicago, Burlington & Quincy, Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul, Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific, Denver & Rio Grande, Great Northern, Illinois Central, Iowa Central, Missouri Pacific, Northern Pacific, Rio Grande, Western Southern Pacific, Union Pacific, and Wabash. The Wabash company is represented for that portion of its line from Chicago to East St. Louis and west of said line, and the Southern Pacific only for that portion of its lines west of the Mississippi River. The tenth and last section reads as follows: The board of directors of any company, a member of the association, may fill any vacancy which may be caused by disability, absence, or resignation of either of its members, which action is to be properly certified to the advisory board under the seal of the company.  

**France's Possible Ally**  
The Funeral of the Duke of Leuchtenberg  
Paris, January 10  
The funeral of the Duke Leuchtenberg took place today at the Russian church. The funeral cortege was headed by detachments of cavalry and artillery. Prince Orloff and Baron Pivcholf preceded the funeral on foot, bearing richly embroidered velvet cushions, upon which were placed the duke's many decorations. The car itself was covered with the golden pall, used only in the case of the burial of members of the Russian Imperial family. Following the car was President Carnot's military household in full uniform. The duke's two aides, members of the Russian embassy, M. Fiquet, president of the chamber of deputies, M. Rlhot, minister of foreign affairs, M. Barbery, minister of marine, M. Dovellfi, minister of agriculture, and Generals Saussiere and Appert. A number of senators and members of the Chamber of Deputies were also present. The route from the duke's late residence to the Russian church was lined on both sides with troops and every window was filled with spectators. Hundreds of thousands of people are estimated to have crowded the streets near and through which the cortege passed. The presence of the French ministers, generals, senators, deputies, and troops at the ceremonies is looked upon as a mark of sympathy for France's possible ally in case of war.  

**Ketea from St. John**  
From our own correspondent: St. John, N.B., January 11  
Mrs. John Wallace, wife of the collector of Hillsboro, who for many years represented Albert County in the Commons, and was at the date of retirement the oldest man in the House, died suddenly on Saturday.  

**1891-02-09: Swept by a Big Blizzard**  
The American Northwest Ravaged by Tempests and Snowstorms  
TOWN DESTROYED BY VIOLENCE  
A Steamer and Schooner Sunk Off the New Jersey Coast - No Trace of Their Crews  
St. Paul, Minn., February 8  
At noon today, snow began to fall in this city, and there has been the promise of a blizzard during this afternoon. The storm is pretty general in the Northwest, although North Dakota seems to have escaped to a considerable extent. A storm was reported at Minto, in the northeastern part of that state, last night, but there is said to be no storm at Grand Forks, Fargo, or Bismarck. In South Dakota, the storm that was raging at Rapid City has extended over the entire state. Aberdeen, Huron, Pierre, and other points report a very severe blizzard. A dispatch from Pierre says the worst blizzard since 1888 has been raging there since last night, with little prospect of cessation. The thermometer went as low as 20 below this morning, and it has been freezing all day.  

**A Gigantic Blizzard**  
At Huron, that snowstorm which has prevailed since midnight last was in progress at 6 o'clock tonight and had developed into a gigantic blizzard, almost equal in fury to that of January, 1888. It has raged all day, the wind blowing at a velocity of from thirty to forty miles an hour, driving the snow in blinding clouds and drifting it as high as the fence tops. The storm prevails throughout South Dakota and will probably interrupt railroading to a considerable extent. At 7 o'clock, the thermometer in this city was 24 below zero, but much colder weather is predicted for tomorrow. It was 15 below at St. Vincent, 18 below at Minne-dora, 4 below at Moorhead, 2 below at Bismarck, and 8 below at Fort Buford. The blizzard did not appear in North Dakota tonight, but is confined to South Dakota, Nebraska, Minnesota, and Wisconsin, being severest in South Dakota.  

**Man Left to Tell the Tale**  
New York, February 7  
Another steamer is reported sunk almost on the spot where the Vizcaya went down a few months ago. The vessel is supposed to be the Norwegian-built steamer Simon Damols, which left this port Wednesday last for Matanzas, Cuba. As yet, nothing has been heard of any of the crew. They may have been lost or may have been rescued by some other vessel. The first tidings of a disaster were brought here today by Frank Kelly, a pilot on the boat Ambrose Snow. Kelly reports that on the 6th inst., he passed close to the wreck of a vessel with three masts standing about 20 feet above the water. The position of the vessel was in longitude 7.  

**1891-02-11:**  
"I have never heard of the stars in their courses fighting against me." Mr. Judge's declaration that, though a Liberal, he cannot support his party in its present policy has brought upon him the ire of the local Liberal organ. Mr. Judge will probably feel that he is in thoroughly good company alongside of Edward Blake. He is not supporting the party in its present policy either. There are a great many Blakes and Judges in the Liberal party this year. The announcement that five thousand people were present at the Bonsecours Market hall to hear Mr. Mercier speak on Monday night would allow a space of about half a square foot for each person. Nothing could indicate better the smallness of the average Canadian Grit. A New York prophet predicts that this year will be one of great tornadoes, blizzards, and cold waves. A combination of the three is due in Canada on the evening of the 5th of March. They are lucky who have fur coats. The Herald urges its party not to put a candidate in the field in Montreal West, where he would surely be beaten. The hits are on the run.

**The States Grain Market**  
Irwin, Green & Co.'s Chicago special to the Times says: "The current receipts of wheat constitute the enigma with which trade is wrestling. The estimates allow that 78.560 percent of the commercial surplus from the crop of last year has left the hands of the farmers in the first seven months, and the visible supply is a quarter less than at this date in 1890. The mild weather and perhaps the pressure for money may be advanced as explaining the freedom of movement now, and to this is added the fact that a considerable percentage of the daily receipts at St. Louis and Kansas City as well as in the Northwest come from the Pacific slope. So long as wheat comes out thus freely, speculative buying is not apt to be brisk except on the threat of a cold wave, and the market turns back when the cry of a 'blizzard' turns out a false alarm. The fact that selling from first hands is all the time less than the contemporaneous consumption, and strong cables from abroad have been counterweighted by the news of good rains on the California slope, that Russian ports are on the point of opening, and that shipments from India to the United Kingdom are slightly on the increase, the trade seems reconciled to the fact of light stocks here, which would certainly be cause for alarm in case of a scare about the crop for this year. But any such scare is not likely to occur before the latter part of next month, as it is generally understood that March weather is what determines the yield of wheat at the succeeding harvest time, and little importance is attached to the reports of a poor outlook at the moment for crops in Germany and Russia. We regard the situation in wheat as slowly strengthening, and it is bound to assert itself in the spring and early summer, the magnitude of the rise to be gauged by the prospect for the next harvest. If the market were a little less in control of the professional element, it could not stay down much longer. The floor operator looks askance at the record of failures in each of the several past years to sustain wheat long near the dollar mark, and this will probably act as a sufficient drag to hold it near the present level till the trade wakens up some morning to the conviction that the...

--- 

Please let me know if you need any further adjustments or corrections! Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

Outside is buying at a rate which cannot be resisted by the bear element. It is legitimate to expect that an impetus for this will come from abroad. Stocks of both wheat and flour at the leading points there are unusually low and are already recognized by some as being close to the danger mark, but of course they don't want to put their market upon themselves by admitting the truth. Besides, they have more than once found that quick steam transit helped them out when close to the point of exhaustion, and naturally hope the rule will hold good this time. But it is impossible to conceive of getting enough during the next six months without paying a great deal higher prices for the property. The corn market is comparatively steady, with rather less interest taken in it than heretofore. Advices from the country say stocks in many sections are good, with numerous full cribs, but are being drawn upon only to meet the current demand in market supplies, at which they are a trifle smaller than a week ago. It is said this corn will be marketed more freely when farmers get through sending in hogs, but the end of that process is not yet, and in the meanwhile cash demand here and at other points is about equal to the supply. An important feature of the market is the fact that we are about on an export basis, and foreigners are taking fair quantities, which they have hardly ever done before at anything like these prices. The circumstance shows that they want our corn and feel they must have it, the experience of many of them last winter for the first time having opened their eyes to its value as feeding stuff for livestock. Of course, there is no real reason for weakness in our market while this condition continues, but the feeling both with regard to corn and oats is very nervous, being born of the conviction that prices are too high for a healthy market, for which cause many stand ready to sell on the first signs of an important increase in the movement from interior points. They are all the more disposed to this as they know farm consumption has been unusually small, both because of the mild weather and for the reason that at relative prices it does not pay to put corn into pork in the West. This will make the summer supply much more liberal than might be expected from the size of the crop. Provisions have not settled in price so much as might have been thought, due to the excessive run of hogs and big stocks of product. They have been sustained by the country buying on the theory that a short corn crop always means dear pork, and packers are the principal shorts. A few days ago some longs got tired, but at the resulting decline in the market turned on active cornering, and it is evident the bears do not feel ever confident of their ability to send prices down much further. The product is not so much of a sale as it was a few weeks ago, but we should still recommend caution in buying except on extreme breaks. From all accounts, the stock of hogs in the country is still a big one, and holders are willing to sell rather than feed high-priced corn, but young stock is being drawn on too freely for the large summer supply. 

At New York, wheat closed at a further advance, 1c on the earlier options to 2c on the later, closing at $1.11 March, $1.06 May, $1.04 June, $1.00 July, 86c August, 86c September, 88c December. Corn closed at 63c February, 62.5c March, 60c May, 60c July, and oats at 52c February, 62.5c March, 61.5c May. At St. Louis, wheat closed steady, the later options gaining 1c. The closing prices were as follows: 86c-97c cash, 96c February, 96c March, 67.5c May, 88c July, 86c August. Corn closed at 60c cash, 60c February, 60c May, 50c July, and oats at 45c cash, 46c May. At Toledo, wheat was quiet and closed stronger at 1c advance at $1.00 cash, $1.01 May, 83c July, 80c August. Corn and oats were unchanged. At Duluth, wheat closed steady at 94c cash, 94.5c February, $1.00 May. 

Hot meats. 

At Chicago, the receipts were 10,432 flour, 21,000 wheat, 149,000 corn, 241,000 oats, 10,000 rye, 65,000 barley, and the shipments 16,267 flour, 49,000 wheat, 122,000 corn, 15,000 oats, 7,000 rye, 21,000 barley. At New York, the receipts were 12,324 barrels, 18,184 sacks flour, 88,200 wheat, 52,000 corn, 61,000 oats, 1,300 rye, 6,300 barley, and the shipments 3,187 barrels, 69,654 sacks flour, 11,570 wheat, 18,302 corn, 48,000 oats. At Milwaukee, the receipts were 12,070 flour, 18,000 wheat, 5,000 corn, 8,000 oats, 8,000 rye, 25,000 barley, and the shipments 37,450 flour, 3,000 wheat, 10,000 corn, 6,000 oats, 6,000 rye, 6,000 barley. At St. Louis, the receipts were 22,000 wheat, 77,000 corn, 33,000 oats, and the shipments 8,000 wheat, 68,000 corn, 10,000 oats. At Toledo, the receipts were 3,000 wheat, 31,000 corn, 1,000 oats, and the shipments 109,000 wheat, 32,000 corn, 1,000 oats. At Minneapolis, the receipts were 123,000 wheat, and the shipments 60,000. At Detroit, the receipts were 3,000 wheat, winter wheat prospects. The reports of the condition of winter wheat are generally good throughout the Ohio Valley states and the Southwest. Lack of sufficient moisture is the complaint in some parts of Missouri and Kansas. The promise on the Pacific coast is not of the best, and a great amount of moisture is required in the Northwest spring wheat states to assure a full crop. In Europe, unusual cold has done great damage to the uncovered plants, and in some parts of France farmers are preparing to resow their wheat fields. Russia reports serious damage by frosts, and in Asiatic countries there is nowhere a prospect of any more than an average crop. 

Local grain and flour. 

The local grain market continues quiet and without feature, the ruling quotations being as follows: No. 1 hard Manitoba, $0.00; No. 2 do, $1.00-$1.02; No. 3 do 90c-$1.02; No. 2 Northern, 91c-93c; feed do 60c-70c; peas, 75c per 66 pounds in store; Manitoba oats, 48c-58c; Upper Canada do, 48c-49c per 34 pounds; corn, 70c-77c, duty paid; feed barley, 50c; good malting do, 60c-65c; rye, 60c-62c. The flour market is steady and as we noted yesterday, a somewhat better feeling is noticeable, and although prices are nominally unchanged, some advance is anticipated in the near future. Local demand is for immediate wants, but it shows some signs of picking up; while in the case of export trading transactions occur occasionally, although as a general thing bids are below holders' ideas. Today we note sales of 1,480 sacks strong bakers at $5.00, and 900 sacks patent spring at $5.30. Recent sales on export account are also noted comprising 4,200 sacks patent spring, $6.30; $6.60 patent white; $6.34 straight roller, $4.60-$4.76; extra $4.10-$4.86; sunbrittle $3.75-$4.10; fine $3.30-$3.60; city strong bakers' $6.00-$6.00; strong bakers' $6.00-$6.00; sunbrittle bags $1.75-$1.90; extra, bus $1.30; fine bags $1.00-$1.10; glabral, standard, per bag $3.96-$3.30; oatmeal, rolled $3.40-$3.60.

1891-02-26: I.e. Lepine last evening it was as a May snowstorm is to a March blizzard. Five hot sounds and throats proclaimed the fact that Lepine was the coming man. The cheering could be heard away up St. Denis street, and every Liberal sneaking home from the poorly attended committee meeting held by the candidate of their party last evening heard them and went home convinced that their struggle was in vain and that the workingmen of the East end would only consent to be represented by a workingman in practice and not in theory. Mr. Lepine himself opened the ball. He was received with perfect ovation, such as is only accorded generally to the leader of a party. When it had subsided, Mr. Lepine, in clean, well-chosen language, briefly sketched his career as member of the House, showing that his vote and voice had always been on the side of the workingmen whose interests he had been elected to represent. He showed how the National policy had given them the remunerative labor they were now enjoying, and that its repeal meant ruin and disaster to the manufactories in which they were employed. He thanked them for the confidence they had in the past reposed in him and requested them to continue it by returning him once more at the head of the polls, a request that was met by a storm of applause, not one dissenting voice being heard. He was followed by Mr. 

1891-03-10: NI Sir Charles Dilke Anointed - Spain Sends Troops to Cuba - A Sketch of Marine Disasters. Dublin, March 9. Most Reverend Bartholomew Woodlock, Bishop of Ardagh and Clonmacnoise, who has been preaching at Athlone, exhorted his hearers to shun treasonable follies, as an immediate attempt was being made to entangle young men in the renewal of plottings which have been the curse of Ireland. He was grieved to have to state that certain Catholics of his diocese had broken into a meeting house while services were being held and had insulted and assaulted the minister who was conducting the services. The Bishop of Cork denounces the promoters of the proposed Parnellite meeting to be held in Cork on St. Patrick's Day. He says he will not administer to the needs of the souls of his people unless they protest against the desecration of the holiday, as the demonstration would be an insult to the great apostle of Ireland. The National Press says the upshot of the controversy over the Paris funds is that Parnell, after denying the title of the Nationalists to interfere, acknowledges their authority and awaits their judgment. The same paper asserts that the Irish National Federation is welcomed everywhere and becomes the heir of the defunct National League. The Nomination Offered to Dilke. London, March 9. At a meeting held today, the council of the Liberals of the Forest of Dean decided to invite Sir Charles Dilke to become the Liberal candidate for member of Parliament for that constituency, and said they felt confident of his moral integrity. Sir Charles spoke and said he had often announced his decision not to return to public life until he had cleared his character. No legal process existed by means of which he could prove a negative, but the vindication published in the pamphlet recently issued enabled him to prefer the troubles of a political life to the ease of a literary career. He would, therefore, consent to become a candidate if the constituency ratified the invitation which the council had extended to him. A Sketch of Marine Disaster. London, March 9. The steamer Strathendrick, from Cardiff for Kourabaya, collided with the steamer Devonshire at Bourabiya and sank in thirty-six fathoms of water. The engineer of the Strathendrick was drowned. The Devonshire was badly damaged. Here is the corrected text:

---

The Clan Mack while leaving Guile shuck on the rocks and filled with water. The steamer Salient, while on a voyage from Rotterdam for Houndoland, broke her shaft and drifted helplessly in a dense snowstorm. The vessel eventually stranded at Filey, a watering place of England, and filled with water. Her captain and crew escaped. 

Brussels, March 9. A dispatch from Madrid says the Spanish Government is about to dispatch 6,000 troops to Cuba on account of the increasing political agitation on the island. If the situation becomes worse, Gen. Campos will be appointed viceroy. The Spanish press protests against Americans encouraging the Cuban separatists in connection with the proposed treaty of commerce.

A Blizzard in England

London, March 9. A terrific blizzard prevails throughout the southwestern part of England. The storm is the severest on record in that section, and it is feared enormous damage has been done. Reports already received show that many small vessels have been wrecked off the coast. Hundreds of sheep and lambs have perished.

A for Pontiac, March 9. The diplomats and politicians are still discussing the visit of the Empress Frederick to Paris. Count von Münster, the German ambassador, attributes the moral check sustained by Germany to the influences of Baron de Mehrenheim, the Russian ambassador, whom the Count designates as an "old monkey."

Murdered Abyssinian Merchant

Ofnkva, March 9. Lieut. Levraghli, the Italian officer charged with having murdered Abyssinian merchants, has been arrested at Lugano.

Horrific Incident at the Hippodrome

March 9. Beets, a noted lion tamer, was fatally mangled by an enraged lion at the Hippodrome today.

PRINCE JEROME DYING

His Death a Question of Few Hours—A Family Skeleton

In Opposition to the Church

March 9. The physicians in attendance upon Prince Jerome Napoleon have announced that both of the Prince's lungs are in a congested state, and they have informed the family that a fatal issue to his illness is only a question of a few hours. The Prince refuses the repeatedly proffered consolation and the administration of sacraments from the priests who have been called to his room. The sister of Prince Napoleon, the Princess Mathilda of Sandenata, learning of the presence of Madame Canisy at the Prince's bedside, refused to go to his room, though informed that her brother was dying. The refusal of the Princess explains the relation of Madame Canisy with Prince Jerome Napoleon. The members of his family, with the exception of Prince Victor, are hurrying to Rome. Prince Victor declines to make submission, which is the only condition on which his father consents to receive him. Cardinals Bonaparte and Mer-millod are in attendance upon the Prince, but they refrain from asking him to become reconciled with the church. Later, Prince Jerome is sinking fast. King Humbert and the members of the royal family are at the Prince's bedside. A silent crowd fills the street. Prince Victor had a touching interview with Princess Clothilde this evening and requested permission to see his father. The doctors, however, forbade an interview with the Prince, fearing it would excite him too much.

1891-03-11: ALL ROADS SNOW-BLOCKED

The Channel Almost Unnavigable

Life Savers and Fishermen Drowned

Mail and Telegraph Services Impeded

London, March 10. A snowstorm has been raging in Scotland and the north of England for a week past, while in the south of England the weather was mild until Sunday. Sunday’s gale, which was totally unexpected, advanced in a northeasterly direction across the Bay of Biscay. A blizzard prevailed over the whole of the south of England; it commenced in London at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. The storm increased in fury at night, and there was an unusual rise of the tide. All the channel steamers had boisterous passages. Even in the harbors, the water was so rough that it was difficult to hold vessels to their moorings. The Dover mail boat nearly sank in the harbor; her paddle box was completely smashed. The mail service steamers cannot cross the channel. The sea makes a clean breach over the Admiralty pier, where the telegraph clerk and a signalman are practically prisoners. Similar reports come from points all along the coast. Throughout Great Britain, telegraphic communication is interrupted by the blizzard.

Railroads Completely Blocked

The railroads of Kent and Sussex are completely blocked, and the neighboring country is deep with snow. The hurricane which accompanied the snowstorm piled snowdrifts on all sides, stopping all traffic, railway lines, and country roads. Two trains full of passengers in the Midlands were snowed up last night, and the passengers were not rescued until this morning. The rescued people suffered terribly from cold during the night, owing to the unheated condition of the cars. A train on the North Kent railroad, bound for this city, was snowed up last night and still remains in the rail cut, where it was stopped by a drift. A number of engines have been sent to the scene, but they have been unable to move the train.

A Mail Car Lost

The Sheeuse's mail car cannot be found. It has been lost somewhere along the line of the railroad between this city and Sheerness. A searching party sent out after the missing mail car rescued the clerk. He was found half frozen in a snowdrift. Two clergymen were snowed up in a carriage on the Faversville road last night and were rescued with difficulty after having suffered severely. A for Pontiac was in town today and left for home this afternoon. The special committee appointed by the Council of Agriculture to meet two government veterinary surgeons in reference to the proposal of the latter to appoint seven deputies in various parts of the province met this afternoon and heard explanations from Drs. McEachran of Montreal and Couture of Quebec. These gentlemen strongly recommended the appointment of the deputies so that, in case of an outbreak of disease among cattle or horses in any part of the province, the farmers would be able to reach the government inspector at once. The committee, after a careful consideration of the matter, decided to recommend the appointment of seven deputies to the Council of Agriculture, which meets tomorrow. Dr. McEachran left for home tonight.

Le Courtier du Canada and the Mercury call upon L'Electeur to fulfill the solemn pledge made to suspend publication for a month if Dr. Quay did not secure 400 majority in Laval. 

Proulx de St. Maurice has returned from Chicoutimi suffering from a severe attack of pneumonia. He had every reason to be proud of the gallant fight he made there, having defeated the Liberal majority of 617 votes. That the Liberals thought it would be impossible to beat Amyot; many of them would have voted for Faucher, and the majority would probably have been on the other side.

Homesteaders Perish in a Storm

Ashland, Wis., March 10. Sunday’s blizzard was the worst of the season. It was reported last night that two homesteaders on the newly opened land perished in the storm.

1891-03-13: A for Toronto, yesterday read a statement of the vote cast at the late provincial elections, which proves that the result was a popular condemnation of the Mowat administration. Though the Government has a large majority on the floor of the House, the votes in its favor placed at the polls were only 157,441, while those given for the Opposition candidates numbered 158,802. The Opposition majority among the electorate was 1,458.

The Ontario government accounts for the power of the government in the House in the face of such a state of affairs.

THE THEATRE RECORD

At Welland, Ont., March 12. The building owned by the Farthing estate and occupied by Marlatt & Sherk, grocers, and Pelstrop & Mann, furniture dealers, was burned today. Loss: $6,500.

Omaha, Neb., March 12. The Bohn sash and door factory was burned this evening. Loss: $150,000.

Acquitted for Murder

Bancroft, March 11. The jury in the case of Thomas Pliass, who was charged with having murdered Prescott in December of last year, one Oscar Vancamp, and afterward placing the body on the railway track to be run over by a train and so hide the crime, returned a verdict late last night unanimously acquitting the prisoner.

As you do not know the anguish of being betrayed by your best friend until you begin to live yourself.

Elireira Gazette

THE BIG BLIZZARD DEAD

At least Seventy Lives Lost off the Coast of England

WHOLE CREWS DISOWNED

The Storm Breaks Out Afresh—All Roads Again Blocked—A Water Famine Feared at Plymouth

London, March 12. A foreign steamship, the name of which is unknown, was wrecked off Start Point, near Dartmouth, Devonshire, during the recent blizzard. All the crew and passengers were drowned. The British ship Dryand, Capt. Thomas, bound from Shields for Valparaiso, has also been wrecked off Start Point. Her crew, consisting of 24 men and officers, have been drowned. Among the schooners lost off Start Point was the Lannendale; four of her crew were drowned, but her captain was saved. The schooner Lizzie Ellen was also lost, and two of her crew were drowned. It is known that at least seventy lives have been lost off the coast during the blizzard, and in addition, at least ten men perished from cold and exposure after reaching the shore. It is feared the list of wrecks and the record of lives lost is far from complete, as several vessels are missing.

Many Points Still Isolated

Many points inland, where the storm was most severely felt, are still isolated from the surrounding country, and days must elapse before through freight and passenger traffic is entirely restored on the branch lines of the railroads. The severity of the storm and the difficulty of restoring the lines of communication to their usual state of usefulness may be judged from the fact that an express train which left Plymouth on Monday is still blocked up near the Brent River. The passengers are suffering from exposure. Gangs of laborers numbering hundreds have been sent from all directions to clear the railroad lines in Devonshire and Cornwall, where the snowdrifts have piled up so heavily that cuttings twelve feet deep have to be made through the snow, which is now frozen into an almost solid mass. The loss to farm stock is enormous and will entail much suffering among the farmers, who have already lost considerably by the terrible weather experienced at the end of last year.

Water Famine Threatened

The water mains at Plymouth are snowed up to such an extent that a force of 200 soldiers from the garrison has been sent to assist the waterworks employees in clearing them to an extent which will enable them to be used. No water has passed through the mains since Monday, and a water famine is now added to the other sufferings which the people of Plymouth have had to endure through the terrible blizzard which has caused so much distress in England. Following the blizzard, a severe frost has set in all over England. The frost is greatly hindering the clearing of the railroad lines which were blocked by snow drifts. Cornwall continues isolated from the rest of England. While a gang of men were working today on a train which had broken down on the Great Western Railway, they were run down by a relief train sent to the scene. Two men were killed and seven others fatally injured.

Lost Off the Welsh Coast

Cardiff, March 12. It is rumored at Newport that the steamer Trinidad has been lost and that all the crew have been drowned.

The Storm Again Sets In

London, March 13. Snowstorms have again set in in the west of England, and all roads and railways are again blocked.

A Lively Debate Follows the Speech from the Throne in New Brunswick

(From our own correspondent)

St. John, NB, March 12. This was the first day of the session of the New Brunswick Legislature, and a hot one it was for the Government. The speech from the throne practically...

**1891-03-17: THE STORM**  
During the present week, England has been excited by another kind of invasion. At last, these good islanders fancy that they know what an American blizzard, of which they have been reading for years, is really like. They don't want any more. The storm of Monday and Tuesday was, in truth, about an average rough winter snowstorm in the Middle States, but it threw Great Britain into literal consternation, and the train service in the provinces has not gotten right again yet. Great damage has been done to lambs and fruit in the southern counties, but it is not thought that the grain crops have been hurt very much. The price of wheat has advanced here during the week, more upon the immediate shortage of English supplies and reports of increased destruction of young crops throughout the northern belt of the Continent, where the storm wave was accompanied by greater cold and less snow. Today's news from Kiev that in some parts of southwestern Russia fully one half of the growing wheat crop is destroyed is the first real information about the Russian prospects we have had, and it fits rather gloomily with the tidings from Bengal.

**1891-03-25: MONTREAL WEDNESDAY MARCH 25, 1891**  
**THE LIVE STOCK TRADE**  
The British cattle markets maintain a steady feeling. The cold snap helped them. Both Birkenhead and Deptford benefited. Sheep and Scotch farmers—our trade hole (from our own correspondent)!  
March 14. A snowstorm of considerable intensity passed over the southern regions this week, interfering considerably with the supplies of many local markets. As regards trade, the cold snap has helped sellers out marvelously, both here and over in Birkenhead. The threatened congestion at London didn't amount to a row of pins (thanks probably to the aforesaid blizzard), and, beginning with a steady trade at 6d for good States beef, the week closes with a top quotation of nearly 7d current at Deptford. The moderate arrivals to Birkenhead, of course, enabled our salesmen to hold fast, and as the Central Meat Market had a good "redding up" on Monday, inquiries were coming in quickly all day Tuesday for lowest prices on London account. The result being that country buyers were bustled into paying 5d-3d, while the London men were filled at an eighth to a sixteenth less. Arrivals for the ensuing week are a trifle stronger, and while it is just possible, should the cold weather hold, the rates named will be sustained, I am inclined to think less money will have to be taken.  

**DELEGATES**  
That if in recent years much has been accomplished in removing false impressions and prejudices regarding the Dominion, there is still occasion for earnest and persistent effort directed to that end, is very clearly brought out by the reports of the tenant farmer delegates who visited Canada last year. Almost every one of them begins the record of his experiences by the avowal, expressed or implied, that in the British Isles much ignorance prevails as to the extent, resources, climate, and people of this country. "Until lately," writes Mr. George Brown, of Watten Mains, Caithness, Scotland, "Canada was believed by the majority of people in this country to be a land covered for nearly two-thirds of the year by snow and frost, with few and brief glimpses of sunshine during the remaining third, which was followed again by a covering of eternal snow; a land of ice and Indians, bears and blizzards, unfit for the abode of the Anglo-Saxon race, except upon the seaboards and in the vicinity of the great Lakes." If there are still among our old country compatriots (and doubtless there are) many persons who hold views concerning Canada so inconsistent with reality, the conscientious and impartial statements of Mr. Brown and his fellow delegates will correct their misconceptions and make any widespread ignorance on the subject without excuse hereafter. The idea of inviting representative agriculturists of England and Wales, Scotland and Ireland, to come and see for themselves what Canada has to offer to the immigrant originated with the Hon. Mr. Carling, Minister of Agriculture, and was carried out with his usual judgment and vigor by our able High Commissioner at the metropolis. The selections seem to have been admirably made, and the reports now published by the Department of Agriculture for distribution in the United Kingdom contain a mass of multifarious information, obtained at first hand by intelligent and independent observers, which cannot fail to influence for their own advantage and cure the classes especially concerned. Our readers may recall that in the year 1876 a number of farmer delegates visited the older provinces and a considerable portion of new Canada, and that the results of their inquiries were published in a good-sized blue book, to which reference has frequently been made in our columns. During the interval between then and now, reports were also compiled by Professors Sheldon, Tanner, and Fream, who dealt exclusively with the agricultural capabilities of the Dominion. Several capitalists, manufacturers, and members of Parliament made the tour of Canada and, in pamphlets or magazines, have given the world their impressions of the country's resources. While some of these memorials have been widely circulated, others have reached but a limited number of readers. The reports just issued, which, if what I hear today, after twelve years of unexampled development, are...

**1891-03-26: A BIG KANSAS SNOWSTORM**  
Trains Stalled and Many Cattle Killed in the Blizzard  
**THE CASE OF THE SAVAGE WAR**  
The Alnuha Court Heard From  
A Mail Dog Panic  
Kansas City, March 25. Despatches from Kansas say the worst snowstorm of the season is raging in that state. The country from Eastern Kansas to Denver is covered with snow five to eighteen inches deep. A biting wind is whirling the snow into great drifts, and railroad tracks everywhere have disappeared from sight. A despatch from Atchison says the Central Branch division of the Missouri Pacific did not move a wheel today on account of the snow blockade. Several trains have been caught between stations, among them the pay train and a passenger train. The company with difficulty manages to provide crews and passengers with food. A snowplow was started out this afternoon, but as fast as it cleared a pathway, snow drifted in behind, and the attempt was abandoned, leaving the plow engine to "die" in the drift. Superintendent Rathbun says it is the greatest snowstorm the road has experienced in ten years. A despatch from Wichita says the Frisco passenger train is stuck in a drift near Bentley, and near Ellsworth a Union Pacific train is fast. There will be considerable loss to stock unless the snow disappears rapidly.  

**Nerd Distributor Allowed in Texas**  
Kansas, March 25. Reports received at the Rock Island General offices say that one of the worst snowstorms ever known in Northwestern and Southwestern Kansas is raging. The railway committee who went to the Northwest to distribute mill grain have wired that they are snowed in and must temporarily abandon the work.  

**A Dog Panic**  
To-day, so terrorized the residents that tonight the streets were deserted, except by men armed with revolvers, who were in search of the brutes. Early in the morning, Chief of Police Turnbull killed a dog which had bitten several others. Later, a man was bitten on the wrist in Tasealc Avenue and afterward killed the dog. In the afternoon, eighteen-year-old Mamie Exton was bitten on the hand after having a desperate ten minutes' battle with a mongrel dog. After this, another dog began snapping at pedestrians and was finally killed, and at night excitement was caused in Kearney by the rabid actions of a dog. Men patrolled the streets until late at night with revolvers, and the police were ordered to kill all stray dogs, as many are believed to have been bitten. The man and woman had their wounds cauterized.  

**Soldiers Suffer in a Blizzard**  
Omaha, Neb., March 25. Reports from all sections of the state show that the snowstorm today was very severe. In the southern part of the state, the snow is reported to be 18 inches deep on the level and drifting badly. The storm was almost a blizzard in the northwestern part of the state. Col. Henry and four troops of the Ninth Cavalry left Fort Robinson this afternoon from Pine Ridge. Many troopers were snow-blinded and exhausted from the long march during the storm. Railroad traffic is badly delayed, the most trouble being on the Burlington.  

**A Steamer's Perilous Trip**  
New York, March 25. The steamship Caledonian, which arrived here today from a Mediterranean port, had a very rough voyage. On the night of March 11, she struck a norther. A big sea was soon running, and before long the decks were swept by the waves. The wheelhouse was smashed and the helmsman injured. The sea also carried away the booby hatch and all the loose spars on the deck, and knocked down several Italian immigrants, injuring some of them severely. The second officer, who was on the bridge, was knocked off to the deck and badly hurt. On March 20 and 21, the Caledonian passed several icebergs far out of any hitherto reported. Nineteen of her crew were lost.  

**NORFOLK, VA., March 25**  
The steamer which went ashore a mile below Chicamacomico life-saving station, on the North Carolina coast, yesterday morning, is the British steamship Strathairly, bound from Santiago de Cuba for Baltimore. Out of a crew of twenty-six, nineteen were lost, including all the diners except the second mate. The steamer will be a total loss. The steamer was a British vessel of 1,236 tons. She was commanded by Captain Wylie. She left Baltimore February 23rd for Havana, where she arrived March 7th. She proceeded from Havana on the 13th for Santiago de Cuba, where she arrived on the 16th. She was on her homeward trip from Santiago to Baltimore when she went on the North Carolina coast with such fatal results.  

**The California Senatorial Bribery**  
Sacramento, Cal., March 25. The committee appointed to investigate the charge of bribery in connection with the finding of certain papers in the State library during the recent senatorial contest reported to the Senate last evening. They found that money came from the Southern Pacific Company, and that within sixteen hours after it arrived here it was in the State library, but who handled it there and for what purpose it was handled the committee could not determine.  

**Heavy Flood in Iowa**  
Des Moines, Ia., March 25. The Des Moines River has been rising rapidly, and with the large masses of outgoing ice is destroying much property. Several bridges above this place have been washed out and the timbers are floating down the stream, increasing the danger to city bridges. The belt line railroad bridge has been carried out. The Des Moines Union Railway bridge operated by the Wabash, Chicago, St. Paul, and Kansas City and other roads has been rendered useless.  

**Texas Sheriff Shot**  
Clarksville, Texas, March 25. Sheriff Whitman was killed last night while trying to arrest Sam Cookstone and others for theft.  

**Rio Grande City, Texas, March 25**  
Marcus Ortega, deputy sheriff, while trying to quell a disturbance at a dance last night, was fatally shot by Private Patrick Hogan, Troop C, Third Cavalry.

**1891-03-27: MANY VICTIMS OF THE GRIP**  
The mortality rate in big cities is increasing alarmingly.  
**THE KANSAS BLIZZARD**  
Rations too exhausted to accept proffered assistance.  
Swift Tennessee Justice.  
Several heavy failures.

of every thousand; last week it was thirty-four and this week it will rise far above that. Since the beginning of the week the deaths have averaged over a hundred and fifty per day, the majority of them being due to the sudden changes in the climate. One peculiar feature of the situation is that scores of physicians are too ill to attend to their duties. All classes are attacked, and the death rate among those who are well fed, well clothed, and well cared for in every way is alarming. The undertakers are being rushed and the stock of coffins is being rapidly depleted. The fact that there is a coffin shortage leads many undertakers to believe that prices will soon be forced up, owing to the great demand not only from here, but the other cities in this section of the state as well. The Health Commissioner says that if people do not take better care of themselves the death rate will continue to grow right along, the weather at present being a great breeder of pneumonia. 

18910403: 1H01 Wheat, qrs 100 to 110,000 270 to 240,000 Corn qrs under 2ri,t)00 25 to 50,000 Flour, brl 400 to 120,000 840 to 800,000 April 1, 1890 Wheat, qrs 100 to 120,000 Corn, qrs 100 to 110,000 Flour brls 000 to 025 000. United States grain market. At Chicago the grain market was strong today. Wheat opened firm and closed at a 1c advance at $1.05 May, $1.04 July. Corn was stiff all day but gathered strength towards the close, and closed at a 1c advance at 66c May, 65c July. Oats closed firm at a 1c advance at 65c May, 52c July. Irwin, Green & Co.'s Chicago special to the Gazette says: "The strength in wheat may be attributed to the advancing European markets. Cables being strong and higher on cargoes there was a better inquiry for cash wheat. One hundred and thirty-five thousand bushels are reported as having been worked for export there. Doubtless the weather also had a strengthening tendency, as low temperature and a blizzard prevail in the West and Northwest. Corn was fairly active and closed nearly 1c higher than yesterday. The buying was to a great extent based on wet weather which prevailed over the whole country. The receiving interest sold moderately early, but late bought considerably. The demand for cash continues strong. Although stocks of provisions were larger than the trade expected, the market opened steady at a small advance, and ruled quiet and firm during the day, closing, however, at dull or easier prices. The strength in corn did much to support the market, while heavy selling of lard by foreign houses was the chief element of weakness."

18910404: Wellington Canon, the new pastor of the Jefferson Avenue Presbyterian Church, will stop for the next few days at the Hotel Normandle. He will assume the responsibilities of his new charge today. When Mr. Carson was visited last night by a representative of the Free Press, he had just placed on the stand several fine photographs, among others those of Sir John A. Macdonald and Lady Macdonald. "Yes," said Mr. Carson, "I know Sir John well. I have known him for many years. For a long time he has been a member of my church. In his daily life, Sir John is one of the finest and most genial men in all Canada. He invests himself with a personal magnetism that attracts everyone to him, if not to his cause. I have often heard his rivals say, after an interview with Sir John, that they had better not become too intimate with the old man, or they might possibly be converted to his political faith. His personal magnetism is so great that everyone who comes within the circle of his influence is bound to become a friend of the great leader." "Are the people of Canada satisfied with the result of the recent election?" "Presumably, they are. As a matter of fact, both Liberals and Conservatives are filled with loyalty to the Canadian Government. The idea of any political policy shaking the patriotism of the Canadians is absurd. The cry of loyalty was taken up by Sir John and used with telling effect, but after all I think both parties are equally true to Canadian interests." "Then we shall never have Annexation?" "As that term is understood in the United States, I should say it will never come. The simple reason is found in the fact that there is no sentiment in favor of Annexation in Canada. This opposition to Annexation is found, as intimated before, in the loyalty of Canadians to the home government. For illustration, the eastern provinces are settled largely by Scotch and English. These people are still ardently attached to the home government. In Quebec, the Norman French or Roman Catholic element predominates. The great corporation of the Roman Catholic Church has its holdings under treaty stipulation. If Canada should be annexed to the United States, these great claims would be forfeited, or would in large degree be annulled. So you can see that Quebec is not anxious for Annexation. Thus the sentiment goes from province to province. The only people who really favor Annexation are the young men in some of the bolder towns. And even these supporters are not very numerous. Then again those whose business dealings bring them in contact with the union are anxious for Annexation, or at any rate for reciprocity. But you can set this down as an established fact: That there never was, nor is, nor perhaps ever will be, a sentiment in favor of Annexation." "And in regard to reciprocity?" "Canadians are beginning to see that they can get along without reciprocity. It was all right enough until along came the McKinley bill and placed a heavy duty on many articles whose natural market was in the United States. This was particularly true of eggs, barley, and horses. For eggs, we have since found another and an equally good market, Liverpool. We ship Canadian eggs across the sea and obtain good prices and a ready sale. No doubt, too, we will adjust things in regard to the other articles of export. So you see, we are not in a hurry for reciprocity in Canada." Mrs. Chas Smith of Jones, Ohio, writes: "I have used every remedy for sick headaches I could hear of for the past fifteen years, but Carter's Little Liver Pills did me more good than the rest." 

ETCHINGS: My Hippogriff has had a long rest since I turned him out on pasture. In case he might grow lazy, I will bridle and saddle him once more. While ransacking the antiquated ware of the past, I purchased a pillion for my Hierophant, and now that we are more comfortably equipped than heretofore, we may venture upon a hurried gallop over the mountains of the north off in the direction of the Aurora Borealis. I once before mentioned the fact that ours is a country free from earthquakes, volcanoes, pestilences, tornadoes, simoons, and other natural visitations that convulse, overwhelm, wither, devastate, or infect less favored regions. However, the people who live south of the great barrier of the Laurentians, in the valleys of the Ottawa or St. Lawrence, have little conception of a storm in the land of the moose and caribou. The blizzards of the Northwest are but child's play in comparison. These hurricanes never reach, in full force, the valleys or cities of the center; they are shattered into fragments by the mountain ranges, against which they dash in headlong fury and fall prostrate with the shock. My Hippogriff had carried me to an almost unknown spot by the Jean-de-Terre; my Hierophant had warned me of the near approach of one of those terrific storms. We took refuge in an old shanty by the side of a hill, and almost in the center of a pine grove of second growth. Timber had been made there twenty odd years before and all the indications of overgrowth on the main roads, underbrush around the fallen stable, mosses, and fungi on the logs of the shanty were there to tell of the scenes that once were enacted amidst the vast wilderness of trees. Uninviting as the shanty might seem, chill and bare as the camboose might be, yet it was our only refuge from the approaching danger. The sun went down in a red haze; and the stars one by one came out from their hiding places, and gazed down upon the scene of a coming strife. Calmly they appeared to contemplate the ravages of an approaching hurricane, like Infinite Power, sublime, tranquil, and omnipotent, looking upon the petty wars of man. How silent everything became! There was not a breath of wind to waft the smoke from our fire to one side or to the other. Lastly the smoke curled aloft, and appeared too weak to rise into the air. In a short time a loud and distant booming could be heard, a mighty noise like the roar and splash of giant floods. On it came, growing louder and louder. On it came, like the tide upon the Atlantic when its tempests lash the shores of the north. On it came, like the hurried march of a hundred thousand men, rushing to the destruction of a whole country. On it came, like the legions of Hyder Ali and Tipu Sahib, when they swept down upon the devoted plains of the Carnatic. The wind howled and hissed through the endless corridor of the forest; it raged and shrieked above and around the trees; it squealed in agony as it struck headlong upon a projecting rock. The giant of the North was on his march. The specter of the Arctic seas was approaching; white were his garments, like the shrouds of the dead; cold was his touch, like the embrace of the dead, and wild was his voice and hollow his tones, like the sepulchral cries of the dead. Down he came, and all things bent before him. He crushed the maple, the birch, and the poplar in his march; he grasped the dry pines and snapped them off and flung them upon the earth; he grappled with the living pine and shook them, as Sampson shook the pillars of the temple, until their lofty heads bowed, swayed, reeled in the blast of his breath; and, finally, he wound his arms about them and wrenched them by the very roots from the earth. Acres upon acres of forest were laid low; windfalls filled every open space for miles around. There the tempest of the north can be seen in all its fearful vigor. The partridges hid themselves away in a snowbank; the rabbits made for their burrows; the foxes crouched in their holes; and the majestic moose, forgetting their own dignity and their own strength in the presence of this dread giant of the skies, sought the shelter of some rocks in the lowland, and there trembled before the terror of the storm. How like the mighty and powerful of earth! Proud of their own strength and power, until the fearful hand of the unseen and more terrible power comes upon them. Exulting in their own vigor and independence, until the pent-up wrath of the Omnipotent is let loose, until the hand of death touches their frame and the trumpet-voice peals a note of warning in their ears! In half an hour the fury of the tempest was over, and going to the shanty door I gazed aloft. A slit in the clouds for a moment appeared, and through the rent I caught a glimpse of a solitary star that shone as bright and as calm as if no war of the elements had taken place. So like the rage and fury of political, moral, social, and physical strife here below, truth undiminished in splendor and unmoved in serenity, shines above all, and smiles upon the million combatants—fools that destroy each other for nothing, that crush each other for the sake of a moment's triumph and, finally, exhaust their effort and strength, and must still leave things as they found them. The storm passed on and left a track of desolation behind. Everywhere were the works of its rage; but, like the army of Sennacherib, its triumph was but transient. It is in vain to attempt, in English, to paint the majesty and power of a storm as it passes along the pine ridges of the North, leveling all before it with as much ease as the mower levels the hay. Perhaps had I the wild, weird imagery of Ossian, and a command of the glorious Celtic tongue, I might strive to give a word etching of such a scene. But otherwise all attempts must fail. It was not merely to see a storm that I invited the reader to take this short trip with me. However, like many other travelers in life, we had to meet with this momentary obstacle. We have no control of the elements, so we have, like other mortals, to pay for our pleasures by often encountering and enduring certain hardships. When the blizzard had disappeared southward, and rushed off scampering over the hills in all directions, like the detachments of a conquering army after victory, chasing and capturing, laying and pillaging the vanquished, we Hippogriff... Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

Uierophant and in; self started off in the wake of our thundering precursor. We swept swiftly southward over the Grand Lacs; thence southeast towards Seven League Lake, on the Coulonge; thence due south to the mouth of Victoria Creek; thence over Victoria Lake; past Fillion Lake, Dorion Lake, Lw a Tom, and finally we halted at Banger's old shanty upon a little track that flows into Beaver Lake, which latter is the source of the great east branch of the Black River. Along this creek, and sometimes over it, Caldwell's men had built their main road in the days when he lumbered there. The creek was "driven" sometime in the seventies. While making the improvements in the bed of the jam, a considerable amount of blasting was done, and one stone or chunk of rock, weighing about five hundred pounds, was dislodged. This curious rock is at the door of the little twelve-foot sapling or balsam shanty built by Banger, the trapper. There it is, and then it will remain until lumbering operations are recommenced, if ever they are, upon that part of the limit. To carry it otherwise, turn on some portage sleigh in winter would be impossible; the Indians have no use for it, and very likely in a few years old Banger's shanty, like himself, will be gone and forgotten. In rare sense, a reader might think I was inventing—or at least, drawing upon my imagination. I wish, before describing the peculiarity of the rock in question, to state that I visited the place in 1884 with Michol Lesort, of Pembroke, and old bushranger, Hon. Dieu "St Jean," of the Allumette Island. Both these men are alive and at their respective homes. In 1885, Pierre Miron, of the "Grand Marais," on the Black River, had otter, beaver, and mink traps set in the creek, and he and I went to hunt for any old trap that might have been hidden in Banger's shanty; the rock was there still. It was the late Mr. Sorensey, of "Fraser and Sorensey," who first spoke to me of it the year he was drowned. He had seen it, in one of his rambles, when agent for Capt. Young on the Coulonge, if I mistake not.

1891-05-14: Dairy Market. The Utica Herald of Tuesday has the following: Notwithstanding the disbelief expressed in New York concerning the amount of cheese disposed of at interior markets last week, the receipts in that city more than bear out the quotations of amounts given last Tuesday morning. Receipts are much larger than heretofore this season, enough so to give exporters the opportunity for which they have been looking to stand out against prices until they obtained a decided modification of them. Until Thursday, 11c stood as an outside quotation on best new cheese, but very little business was accomplished. Then the foreign buyers made a unanimous stand and refused to pay over 10c for anything whatever, and only allowed that on the best quality of white stock. The Bern trade did little better, as it always does, and paid 11½c for the special stock it wanted. But the exporters accomplished their object and obtained their goods at 10c and downward. Small light skims were in first-rate demand and sold well up toward the limit of large, full creams. In the latter, white stock has the preference at present. The experience of last spring, when the make of white cheese was largely overdone, made factorymen shy of producing it this spring, and the result is that just now it is a trifle scarce. Northern New York will soon restore the balance, however. The snow blizzard of a week ago this morning was succeeded by three or four days of quite cool weather, but without any rain worthy of mention. The ground is already very dry and is daily growing drier. A hot wave struck the country last Saturday, and under its influence, the foliage of trees has rapidly developed. Many dairies were turned out last week, and those that were not will be this week. Grass, however, needs rain in order to give it good growth. What there is of it is good in quality, but it is yet thin, and will not thicken up until considerable moisture has fallen. Still, there is enough to show its good effects on the milk, and probably what may be called "grass cheese" will begin to date from last Thursday or Friday. Three weeks from yesterday it will make its appearance on the market. This will be quite as early, probably a little earlier, than it appeared last year, but the full grass make will not begin to come forward earlier than four weeks from yesterday, or the second week in June. Butter retains a firm hold on prices and is quotable at higher figures than last week. Choice state creamery is worth 19c in New York, and even dairy stock has sold as high as 29c, although the general price for choice is 28c. These figures compare with 15c-18c a year ago and ought to be pretty satisfactory to dairymen. Receipts were taken up about as fast as they could be had in the market, and no surplus was left over. There is an increasing accumulation of evidence that milk is comparatively scarce even in the West, where grain is much more plentiful and cheap than it is in this state. And high-priced grain makes light yield of milk always, previous to turning the cows to pasture. Following is our usual comparative table of cheese quotations and receipts:

Export May 1, 1890: 14,311 21,600
May 10, 1890: 16,480 11,000
May 9, 1891: 16,038 7,849

Cable for Price:
May 11, 1890: 66c 80c 10c
May 10, 1890: 64c 80c 11c
May 9, 1891: 61c 20c 10c

1891-09-12: W. Adams, who was formerly attached to the Bengal ecclesiastical establishment, was one of the most heroic in the annals of English cavalry. — Manchester Examiner. The Oyster. It is the highly digestible quality of the oyster that makes it so desirable as food and gives it the foremost place at feasts. Like Sir John Falstaff, who was not only witty himself, but the cause of wit to other men, the oyster is not only digestible itself, but it is also the cause of digestibility to others. They are recommended as a sovereign cure for the grippe, and they are good for old people when other food fails. They are equally good for young people and for the middle-aged, and for those who are neither young nor old. The cookery books devote five spaces to the precious bivalve and give many recipes for its kitchen treatment, but as the aphorism remarked, "the best way to cook an oyster is to eat him raw." — Chicago Herald. Telephone Girl: No, but Deacon Long-face down at the tract society said "d-n" because his phone won't work. — Dunsey's Weekly. 

English Sanitary Regulation. Sanitary regulations, both Imperial and local, are coming more and more to be based on the results of accurate scientific research into the causes of disease; philanthropists are working on the lines of sanitary reform; and, behind it all, there is the invaluable stimulus of the intelligent public, who have learned that there is at least a substratum of truth in the old adage that "health is wealth." And what is the result? Take this metropolis alone. In the ten years ending 1869, the inhabitants of London died at an average annual rate of twenty-four for every thousand living; in the ten years ending 1889, that rate was only twenty. In other words, over 17,000 lives were being annually saved in that decade in London; and the mortality is still far too great. The saving affected has been largely from the preventable diseases—a class of disease so especially fatal to men and women during the wage-earning period of life, a period when death casts upon the surviving public the onerous burden of supporting those whom it was the pride and happiness of the breadwinner himself to support. Besides which, prevention of these diseases means a diminution of preventable sickness, and this carries with it a lessening of domestic misery and an increase of individual vigor and happiness. It is no vain insular boast when we say that Great Britain stands first among the nations in this matter. The palm of preeminence has thus far been generally conceded to us, and we wish, if we can, to retain it. But we are being hardly pressed, and by none more closely than by our fellows, the English-speaking nations of both hemispheres. But in these days of rapid transit, the sanitary condition of any one nation is more than ever a matter of concern to its neighbors. This is especially exemplified in the matter of quarantine. It was long the universally recognized custom in the case of epidemics of cholera and plague to pretend to protect people from the incursion of these diseases by drawing imaginary lines around the populations. In fact, so-called cordons and quarantines instead of taking steps to provide a complete system of sanitary administration. We in this country have discovered that, if we give our seaports and our country generally an efficient sanitary administration and keep our towns clean, it is unnecessary in the presence of cholera to revert to an empty and antiquated form, which does untold harm by giving a feeling of false security, and which operates mischievously both in health and in commerce. Since this attitude was definitely adopted, we have in England and Wales spent nearly nine million sterling per annum upon measures for promoting public health and in removing the causes of disease. The result is that, while cholera, when imported, has gained no footing among us, hundreds of thousands of valuable lives have been spared, the remunerative capacity and the vigor of the people have been improved, and the costly item of preventable disease and death has undergone a diminution that could hardly have been anticipated. — Sir Douglas Galton in the Nineteenth Century. 

The Coming Winter. It is just as well to lay in a supply of coal and stove wood and warm funnels. Professor Foster, who is Iowa's weather prophet, says of the coming winter: It will be the coldest and most stormy, with the greatest snowstorms, especially deep and drifting snows, that has been experienced for many years. Cold weather with blizzards and drifting snows will begin early in October in the elevated region of Colorado and the Dakotas, and very cold weather, earlier than usual, will cover the states and territories of the Northwest and the Missouri River valleys. While the very deep snows that will fall and the numerous fierce storms that will occur, travel and transportation will be greatly impeded. About the middle of December, the weather will become warmer and average so till about the 1st of January, 1892, when the cold waves will come again and January and February will average colder than has been experienced in many years past. In effect, I have made these statements heretofore through the public press and in my lectures, and my reasons for making these predictions are based on identically the same causes as were my predictions that proved to be so accurate for the winter of 1890-91. — Chicago Tribune.

Achievement of the Commercial Cable. New York Evening Telegram. That the Commercial Cable Company is something other than an instrument for quick jobbing purposes and nobody has ever made that charge against it was demonstrated yesterday. The Commercial Cable lines saved the international business of Wall Street, and of the commercial exchanges of New York and other American cities, from paralysis. All other cable lines were disabled by the storm which raged on both sides of the Atlantic. Messages had to be withdrawn from the offices of the other lines and sent by the Commercial Cables. Thus, this company once again demonstrated the advantages which a well-built, strictly business-like enterprise has over its competitors. It has simply repeated its achievements of the time of the blizzard in March 1888, by saving two continents from the disasters of stoppage of international telegraph business. That the business public appreciates the advantages of a more modern plant, improved terminal facilities, and superior service, is shown by the fact that more than half of all the cable traffic between this country and Europe is handled by the Commercial Cable Company. That the stock of an enterprise so founded and so managed should have steadily advanced in the face of formidable assaults upon other financial values, is...

Therefore, not at all surprising. The fluctuations and scares of Wall Street affect this investment property as slightly as the surface storms of the Atlantic affect its well-laid lines. M.
