1891-11-24: MAY ALL BE DISMISSED. Regular consultations in the Nova Scotia contested mention (causes - Utility Centre) Prohibited, Halifax, November 23. There is a possibility of the petitions against the members for Antigonish, Pictou, Annapolis, Shelburne, Lunenburg, Cumberland, and Inverness being dismissed without going to trial. The petitions in the above cases were filed on the 27th day of April last. The law requires that cases of such a nature must be settled within six months. Six months, however, have elapsed, and the cases have not yet been disposed of. Mr. Ritchie, counsel for the respondents, signed on Saturday and today that the dates of bonds could not be fixed to the above cases because the specified term has expired and the petitions should virtually be dismissed. Mr. Congdon claimed that the reason the dates of the trial had not been fixed within the six months specified by law was owing to a stay of proceedings having been granted by the court; therefore, the time was legally extended. Mr. Ritchie contended that the stay of proceedings on the preliminary objections was granted by a full court, whereas the order staying the proceedings was granted only by a judge. The issue of the petitions remains pending from our own correspondent. 

Quesnel, November 23. The election petition against the sitting member in 'Utility Centre', Hon. F. Langille, was this morning dismissed, the attorneys for the petitioner declaring that they had no evidence to offer. 

New Brunswick, St. John, N.B., November 24. The trial of the Charlotte County election petition against Mr. Gillmor has been set down for January 6, and that against G.G. King, M.P. for Queens, for January 12. 

LOST IN THE BLIZZARD. 

The News Record, Northwest Prairie. 

Winnifred, November 23. The first deaths on the prairie this year are reported from Tisdale. A dispatch from which place today says: A sixteen-year-old son of L.B. Cochrane and a ten-year-old son of K. Walton, merchants of this place, whose ranches are just outside of town, were caught in Friday night's blizzard while looking for some cattle. The storm being so severe and so sudden, they were unable to find their way home that night, and searching parties organized the following morning found no trace of them until last night. The Cochrane boy was found sixteen miles from home, frozen to death beside a haystack, his shirt eating hay over his dead body. The police are now scouring the country for the other boy. The wheat receipts at all provincial points continue very large, and good prices are paid. As high as 65 cents is paid for front wheat, which is very satisfactory. Railroad work in Manitoba has been impeded for the season, frost having taken too much hold of the ground. It was eighteen below zero this morning, which is the coldest of the season. General Superintendent Wbyte will shortly go to Calgary to consult with the city council regarding the shipping of cattle from that point over the Canadian Pacific to the Pacific coast. It is thought better and more profitable trade can be developed in shipping carcasses than in sending the cattle on the hoof. The provincial elections will be brought on very shortly, according to rumor. The city council will on Wednesday open proposals for Winnipeg's greatest scheme, the development of the Assiniboine River's water power for manufacturing purposes. 

NEW BRUNSWICK NEWS. 

A Shoe Dealer's Mysterious Departure. 

St. John, N.B., November 23. James A. Reed, proprietor of the Twentieth Century boot and shoe store, assigned quietly to one Thomas F. Sutherland, of this city, a few days ago, and on Sunday night took his departure on the Boston express. He does not owe over $1,000 in this city, but in Montreal and Quebec, particularly in the latter place, he owes, it is said, over $10,000. His brothers are proprietors of the Tryon Woollen Mills of Prince Edward Island. Two carloads of immigrants, landed at Halifax from the steamship Caspian, took the Canadian Pacific express here tonight for points in the Northwest.

1891-12-04: NEWS OF THE NORTHWEST. 

Found Frozen on the Prairie. A Surprised Murderer. 

Winnifred, November 25. The appeal against the conviction of Archibald Chitholm for assaulting girls under 14 years of age will be heard by the full court next Monday. The body of the boy Walton, who was lost in the blizzard last Friday night with his companion Cochrane, has been found on the prairie frozen. Pettenden, sentenced to be hanged for the murder of Mrs. Rodway last June, was apprised of his reprieve today. He manifested no signs of gladness at the good news, taking it as a matter of course. Lefebvre & Co., Montreal, have donated a $250 trophy to the Caledonia Association for an international competition at the curling bonspiel. There have been large payments of taxes during the past couple of days, and the city's indebtedness at the Bank of British North America, which caused some trouble recently, has been entirely liquidated. A few Protestants protested against the payment of school taxes, owing to the state of the school law, but only as a matter of form. A family of Russian Jewish refugees who came here from Montreal attempted to make their way into the States but were arrested at Grand Forks under the Pauper law and sent back. Many of the Jewish refugees who started employment on farms have been successful.

1891-12-04: D, reports a blizzard with drifts fifteen feet high and the thermometer at zero. Heavy snow is now falling in other parts of Dakota, but there has been no delay to trains in Minnesota. Hard and general rains prevail, although nine and one-half inches of snow fell at Hallock, and a heavy snowfall was reported elsewhere. 

In Railway Wreck. 

Trenton, N.J., December 3. The four o'clock train from New York on the Reading railway collided with a construction train in Pennington this afternoon and made a terrible wreck. Frederick McLaren, of Philadelphia; Michael Maloney, of Trenton, and Thomas Fitzpatrick, of Philadelphia, the crew of the gravel train, were killed. All were unmarried. Seven others were injured. 

Low Water In Lake Michigan. 

Chicago, December 3. The low stage of water in the river and the large number of vessels in the harbor have almost resulted in a general blockade. A number of boats are aground, some of them having been fast for three or four days. A large number of vessels are on their way here to load grain, and the harbor master fears that it will be impossible to get them all through the river to the various elevators. 

The Threatened Mexican Famine. 

City of Mexico, December 3. The bill granting the President power to decree the suspension of duties on cereals and all classes of animals coming from foreign countries to meet the emergency caused by the loss of crops in various states has passed the Chamber of Deputies without dissenting vote and was at once sent to the Senate, where it will be passed through. 

A Jury at Last to Try Dr. Graves. 

Duncan, December 3. After tedious work, the trial of Dr. Graves for causing Mrs. Barnaby's death was concluded today. The judge, after swearing the jury in and giving them some advice as to how they were expected to act, adjourned court till tomorrow. 

Wage Workers' Trouble in an Out. 

Washington, December 3. A telegram to the War Department today from General Brooks says that there have been no Indian outrages known in the region, as he is able to learn, and that the coroner's inquest in the case of McDaniel showed that he was killed by white men and not by Indians. 

A New Coal Workers' Organization. 

Pittsburgh, December 3. A new coal workers' organization has been formed in the mining district. This new organization that has been formed will compete with the United Mine Workers, which for years has had the controlling power, and lively times are expected. 

The Alton Boycott Off. 

Kansas City, December 3. General Manager Furlong of the Milwaukee road has arrived here from Chicago. He told a reporter today that it had been decided in Chicago to declare the Alton boycott off and that the announcement would be made publicly today or tomorrow. 

A Disastrous Prairie Fire. 

Emporia, Kansas, December 3. A disastrous prairie fire swept over the northern part of this county yesterday. Many haystacks, granaries, and orchards were destroyed, and the loss will amount to several thousand dollars. The fire was checked last night. 

Stole the County's Money. 

Charlotte, N.C., December 3.

1891-12-07: D, says: "The greatest snow blizzard experienced for many years quit active operations Saturday morning after a forty-eight hours' rage, depositing a greater quantity of snow than has fallen in the entire three past years. The thermometer at no time during the storm was over zero." 

Pembina, N.D., December 5. A terrible blizzard set in Thursday morning, continued all day Thursday, Thursday night, Friday, and is still howling with increased velocity. Business is at a standstill. No one can get in or out of the city. The sidewalks and streets are blocked with snowbanks 10 or 15 feet high. 

Eldridge, N.D., December 5. One of the worst blizzards ever experienced in this section of the Northwest has raged since 11 o'clock Wednesday night. Business is almost entirely suspended. Stock on the ranges is in a bad plight, and great loss is feared. 

ONLY TWO NOW MISSING. 

The Reported Red River Disaster Dwindles Day After Day.

On all railroads in the state were seriously retarded, and in many cases along the western division of the Union Pacific trains were blockaded. The farmers feel partly compensated for the loss of their stock in the fact of having their winter wheat well protected. The term extended throughout Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, and the Dakotas. In Wyoming, the loss of stock is reported annually large, with a complete train blockade. Portland, Ore., December 28. Advices from East Oregon and Washington state that snow has fallen throughout that region to a depth of from five to twelve inches. Along the Columbia River, the wind is blowing hard and the snow is drifting.

MADE INSANE BY FAMINE

A famished Russian peasant's crime. Prisoners doomed to despair. St. Petersburg, December 26. A famished peasant in the Tcheliabinsk district killed five men recently for the purpose of robbing them and buying food with the money obtained. He was arrested while hiding the bodies. He told the prosecutor he murdered the men while they were sleeping and that he only got four roubles. The prisoner seemed to have been driven insane by excessive hunger and cold. The prison at Samara, which was built to hold 200 inmates, is now crowded with thousands of unfortunates, among whom dysentery and typhoid fever are rife. The doctors, whose duty it is to attend sick prisoners, are in despair and have not visited their charges for a month. A rapid increase in the number of deaths, due to the famine, is reported to the authorities here.

The Minister of Finance has issued a report regarding the condition of the winter wheat crop recently sown. According to this report, the condition is satisfactory in the whole of the Russian provinces in Central Asia, including many of the panic-stricken districts in Northern Russia, and in the Crimea this crop is in a medium condition, while in Southern Russia, below the latitude of 42 degrees, it is unsatisfactory.

18920108: The Khedive's Bold Should Tighten

The Times, in commenting on the death of the Khedive, says that the accession of a youthful ruler affords a good reason why England should have a tighter hold on Egypt. The Standard says: "Should the Sultan consider the time opportune to reopen negotiations, he will find that while we entertain a punctilious respect for his suzerain rights, we cannot expose both him and Egypt to a repetition of the dangers from which England alone rescued them." The Dictionnaire de la République of Paris, foreseeing that arguments like the foregoing would be advanced by the British, demands that the powers combine to prevent the placing of Abbas Pasha under English tutelage.

The Khedive's Career

Tewfik Pasha (Mohammed Tewfik), Khedive of Egypt, was born November 10, 1852, being the eldest son of the late Khedive Ismail. He succeeded to the Vice-royalty of Egypt by a decree of the Ottoman Empire, August 8, 1879, upon the joint abdication of his father, and received the investiture on August 14. He was the sixth ruler of Egypt in the dynasty of Mohammed Ali Pasha, who was appointed vail or governor in 1806, and who in 1841 got the Sultan, with the five great powers of Europe, to settle the hereditary principality in his own family. He was succeeded in 1848 by his son, Ibrahim Pasha, who lived just two months after his elevation. The next ruler, Abbas Pasha, a son of Mohammed Ali's second son, reigned six years. In 1854 he was strangled. Said Pasha, a third son of Mohammed Ali, succeeded on the death of Abbas; but Said also "died" in 1863, whereupon his nephew, Ismail Pasha, the second son of Ibrahim, became ruler in his turn. In 1888 the law of succession was altered from that which had been established in 1841. Instead of succession devolving, as heretofore, according to the usual principles of Mohammedan law, upon the senior male descendant of the founder of the dynasty, it was to go to Ismail's eldest son, and thenceforth in the same order of primogeniture, excluding the other branches of Mohammed Ali's family. The consequence of this arrangement was the accession of Tewfik in 1879, instead of Halim, the fourth son of Mohammed Ali. Prince Tewfik was president of the council at the time of the coup d'état of his father, but resigned the post immediately afterwards. In September 1881, Arabi Pasha appeared at the head of a military and popular revolt, compelling Tewfik Pasha to dismiss his former ministry and to convene a sort of Parliament called the Assembly of Notables, which met about the beginning of 1882. Arabi was appointed under-secretary for the War Department and was raised to the rank of Pasha. The Khedive was forced to accept a National ministry, and the Organic Law, adopted in defiance of the protests of the Controllers, placed the Budget in the hands of the Notables, thus subverting the authority of England and France embodied in the Control. Arabi, now substantially dictator, and supported almost universally by the Sultan, proceeded to more daring measures. Eventually, the English Government felt obliged to intervene by armed force. Then followed the bombardment of Alexandria by the fleet under the command of Sir Beauchamp Seymour (July 11, 1882), and subsequently (September 13), the decisive defeat of Arabi and his army at Tel-el-Kebir by the British troops under Sir Garnet Wolseley. Arabi and his lieutenant, Toulba Pasha, fled to Cairo, where they surrendered to General Drury Lowe. He was condemned to death, but the sentence was commuted by the Khedive to perpetual exile from Egypt and its dependencies. Ceylon having been chosen as the place of banishment, Arabi, with other leaders in the rebellion, were taken to Colombo where he died, September 6, 1884. After the banishment of Arabi, Tewfik acted in close harmony with England. He was a loyal and, as Egyptian rulers go, an honest man. He was neither cruel, vicious, nor extravagant, nor was he an intriguer. He married, in 1873, Princess Emineh, daughter of the late El Hami Pasha, and had two sons and two daughters. One of the sons, Prince Abbas Pasha, born July 14, 1874, succeeds him.

The Tuaregs with the French

London, January 7. Advices from Tangier state that the Moorish mission sent to Fez in order to arrange for the formal annexation of the Oasis to Morocco failed to accomplish their object. The Tuaregs told the Moorish envoys that they had reconsidered their desire to have the Sultan of Morocco as their protector and that they now preferred to form a connection with Algeria, in other words, with the French. When the envoys returned and reported this failure to the Sultan, the latter was greatly infuriated. The envoys were thrown into prison and subsequently, by the Sultan's orders, they were strangled.

London, January 7. A telegram from Tangiers says that the British men-of-war are anchored in the harbor and that the rumor of the landing of British marines is without foundation.

Henry Irving's Son Shoots Himself

London, January 7. Henry Irving's second son, Lawrence, who has been playing Shakespearian characters in Benson's company in Belfast, accidentally shot himself in the right breast with a revolver in his lodgings yesterday. The ball penetrated the apex of the lung. The doctors in attendance upon the wounded man held a long consultation this morning and discussed the sufferer's chances of life. They announced that there was no immediate danger but that the patient must be kept quiet and away from all visitors likely to put irritating questions to him. The bullet has not yet been extracted.

Italy Doesn't Like the Zollverein

London, January 7. The Rome correspondent of the Times says: "Strong opposition is manifested throughout the country to the Zollverein, in which it is now seen that farming interests are sacrificed to benefit a few manufactories in the north. The Italian Cabinet is divided on the Government's commercial policy. Premier Rudini is trying to resist the overwhelming protectionism, but the influence of the Lombard manufacturers in Parliament is so great that a commercial rupture with Switzerland is likely."

Plenty of Cotton in Liverpool

Liverpool, January 7. There is an unprecedented quantity of American cotton at this port. It is estimated that two docks alone at the south end received 200,000 bales for the month preceding Christmas. All the warehouses are taxed to their utmost capacity.

A Blizzard in the German Capital

Berlin, January 7. A blizzard set in here Tuesday night. There was a heavy fall of snow and great damage was done throughout the city. Many persons were injured by falling debris.

Foreign News in Brief

The Earl of Lichfield died yesterday. The Czarina is ill and unable to leave her apartments. There are 20 cases of yellow fever in one hospital at Santos. Ernest Wilhelm Brucks, the well-known German physician, is dead, aged 72. Eleven persons belonging to one family have died of trichinosis in New Silesia. Five thousand cases of influenza have been reported on the Island of Guernsey. The ravages of influenza are increasing throughout Europe. Hundreds are dying. The French Tariff bill has been finally passed by the Chamber of Deputies by a vote of 304 to 114. The French revenue returns for 1891 show a surplus of one hundred million francs over expenditures. An outbreak of trichinosis has occurred at Lodz, near Warsaw. Fifteen persons have died of the disease and forty are dangerously ill. A railway train from Hastings for London was derailed yesterday near London Bridge. One person was killed and six injured. The Journal de Bruxelles semi-officially denies the truth of the Paris Temps story of the purchase of slaves to work on the Belgian Congo railway. The London Board of Trade returns for December show that the imports increased 3,830,000 and the exports decreased 151,000 as compared with the corresponding month of 1890.

A BLAZE AT ARGENTEUIL

The Argenteuil Hotel and Outbuildings in Ashes

Argenteuil, January 7. About 3 o'clock this afternoon smoke was seen coming through the roof of the kitchen of the Argenteuil Hotel, P. Bodinque, proprietor, and in a short time the hotel was enveloped in flames, which also reached the outbuildings. Before 6 o'clock the hotel and buildings were in ashes. Part of the stock of liquors in the bar room was saved, as was also some of the furniture. Here is the corrected text:

6, 1838 II made his theological studies partly in his native country and partly in Rome, with great success. After his return from Rome, he was professor in the College of Fribourg, and then studied philosophy and theology. When the Jesuits were driven from Switzerland, he came to America and finished his studies in St. Louis, Mo. His first place as a ministry was Green Bay, Wis. In 1851 he returned to Europe, and after having undergone the last probation in Tionchtomea, Belgium, he was employed in giving missions in Germany, where he proved to be an excellent preacher. But, on account of his failing health, he was soon removed from missionary work and appointed rector of the College of Cologne and Paderborn. In 1869 he became provincial of the German province and remained in this office for six years. Then he was appointed professor of moral theology in the College of Maria-Laach, and in 1899 rector of that college, whence he was called to Rome to be assistant of the General for the provinces of Germany, Galicia, Austria, Belgium, and Holland, and the missions belonging to this province in North and South America, Asia, Africa, and Australia. He was an able theologian and excellent linguist, and had great experience in administration, to lay nothing of the excellent qualities of his character. Hence he was, in every respect, the right man as successor of Pope Becks. Father Anderledy was one of the cleverest and most adroit superiors the society has ever had. He was a Jesuit for fifty years, yet he was much more a man of the world than a priest. A born diplomatist, he knew how to commence an intrigue by the most innocent agents, and how, without any seeming interference, to check it when it was going too far or in the wrong direction. He was a man of polished manners and an sociable temper; among his many accomplishments, not the least was his knowledge of languages. He spoke with remarkable ease and fluency French, Italian, German, Spanish, and English. Father Anderledy was very prominent in the Ultramontane league agitation in 1847, and shortly after the league came to an untimely end, he was appointed superior of the province of Prussia. His acquaintance with the political and religious situation in the German-speaking countries, which had before been extensive, rapidly increased, and he was promoted to the high post of "Assistant for Germany," with jurisdiction over Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, Holland, and Scandinavia. There are only some half-dozen of these "assistants" to the superior, and the appointments are always for life, although the general assembly of the society has the power to dismiss them, a power most rarely used. Father Anderledy's long connection with Germany had an important influence upon negotiations between Berlin and the Vatican.

New York State Canal Tonnage Albany, January 18. The whole number of tons of freight carried upon the canals of this state during the season of navigation was 4,563,472 tons and was composed of the following described classes of articles: Product of the forest, 1,206,986; agricultural, 1,171,192; manufactures, 109,387; merchandise, 250,093; other articles, 1,625,826. Of the total amount of freight moved, 3,190,331 tons were carried east, and 1,373,111 tons were carried west. Of this amount, 2,851,838 tons were through freight and 1,911,634 tons were way freight. Comparing the tonnage of 1891 with that of 1890, there is shown to be a loss of 682,830 tons. But during the year 1890, much ice was transported upon the canal, so that the loss this year as compared with the tonnage of last year, exclusive of the ice, is 215,093 tons.

A Startling Arkansas Lynching Fort Smith, Ark., January 18. United States Marshal Liggett has just come in from the northern part of the state, where he has been chasing moonshiners, and reports a double lynching which occurred recently in the mountains. Peter Baker, a farmer, was found murdered in his house. His wife and a man named Johnson left the country, but both returned a few days ago. The neighbors suspected them of putting Baker out of the way. An assault was at once made on the house, and the couple was captured. They were lashed together, back to back, and then hanged on the same limb with the same rope.

Silver City, N.M., January 18. A Mexican named Juan Lopez, living on a ranch northwest of this place, four years ago caught a young mountain lion and raised it as a pet. He had the animal completely under subjugation, and it was as docile with him as a house cat. Lopez was recently married, and the lion took a dislike to his wife. During the man's absence last week, the animal attacked Mrs. Lopez and tore her to pieces. He then fled to the mountains. Lopez has become insane with grief.

A Cleveland Primary Victory New York, January 19. A dispatch to the "Inquirer" from Philadelphia says: "A sweeping victory was won by the Cleveland and Paulson forces at the Democratic Primaries here last night. The contest was particularly important by reason of the fact that upon the result depended the election of the delegates to the Democratic convention from this city and the control of the state convention, which will elect the eight delegates-at-large. Philadelphia sends 35 delegates to the state convention under the new apportionment, and thus will have the balance of power in that body."

A Blizzard at Work in Texas Dallas, Tex., January 19. A blizzard suddenly struck this place at 3 o'clock Monday morning, the mercury dropping from 44 to 10 above zero in a short time. The ground is frozen as hard as a stone and covered with sleet and snow. Business is at a standstill, no hauling of any kind being done. Dispatches from Northwest Texas say a blizzard of unprecedented severity is prevailing, extending over the vast plains, and it is apprehended cattle will be frozen by the thousands.

An Endowment Order Treasurer in Jail Boston, January 19. Augustus N. Doe, treasurer of the Bay State League, an endowment order having 22,000 members, was arrested today, charged with the embezzlement of $15,610 of the league's funds. The order is in the hands of a receiver.

A Hearing on the Bering Sea Arbitrator Washington, January 19. Edward J. Phelps, of Vermont, formerly minister to England, had an audience with the President at the White House today. It is generally understood he will be one of the representatives of the United States on the tribunal to be selected for the arbitration of the Bering Sea question.

Senator Quay Wins Libel Suit Beaver, Pa., January 19. The jury in the libel suit of Senator Quay against the Beaver Argus, after being out two minutes, returned a verdict of guilty as indicted. The penalty is a fine not to exceed $1,000 or imprisonment, or both. It is believed Senator Quay will intercede in behalf of the defendants.

Garza Located in Texas Laredo, Texas, January 19. From private sources, a reporter learns that Garza and five or six followers have been located at a point called La Prieta (Black Hill), near the line of Encinal and Duval counties, and if the authorities get wind of it, he will probably be captured there.

Cold Weather in Illinois Chicago, January 19. Advices from many points in Illinois show that a severe snowstorm is prevailing throughout the state. At most points, it is rapidly growing colder, the thermometer already ranging from zero to 10 below.

Burned to Death New York, January 19. In a fire at six o'clock this morning in the three-story building at 2777 Third Avenue, Mrs. J. Men Hoean, 53 years old, lost her life, and her daughter Neillie, aged 10, was almost suffocated.

A Vicious Knife and Pistol Milwaukee, January 19. John Thompson (colored) early this morning cut his mother-in-law's throat and shot and seriously wounded his wife.

Senator Gorman Re-elected Annapolis, Md., January 19. Hon. Arthur F. Gorman was re-elected today United States senator to succeed himself.

Cracked a Gambling House Safe Hot Springs, Ark., January 19. The safe in the Bonanza Club was blown open last night by cracksmen, who secured $8,000.

St. Joseph, Mo., January 19. The college building at Tarkio, eight miles northeast of here, has been burned. Loss $10,000.

Malone, N.Y., January 19. Fire broke out in the Houston block last night about 11:30 o'clock. Houston's block is a wooden structure with a brick front. Adjoining the Houston block on the west side is a frame row of three stores, occupied by R. D. Kloe, shoes; Davis Bros., drugs; and others.

18920204: J, valued at $100,000, of which Post was John Wanamaker. Wanamaker is the reputed owner, was attached by the sheriff yesterday. The "settlement" has been the summer rendezvous of the members of Sunday schools of Philadelphia.

Settled for 7 Percent on Bankruptcy Boston, Mass., February 3. The case of Brownsteins & Clark, the failed woolen merchants of Boston, which has been in the insolvency court for two years, has been settled by the acceptance by the creditors of 7 percent on about $3,000,000, which the firm's liabilities amount to.

A Sunken Vessel Identified Philadelphia, February 3. The supposed steamer which is lying sunk nine miles off Cape Henlopen was discovered today to be the barge McClellan, from Lambford's Point, Va., for New Haven, coal laden. The barge foundered on January 30. The crew was taken off before it sank.

They Will Give Way to Boyd Lincoln, Neb., February 3. Notwithstanding sensational reports to the contrary, the best information obtainable today is that Governor Thayer will make no resistance to Governor Boyd should the latter wish to immediately assume his duties.

A Bank Cashier Suicide San Antonio, February 3. Col. John Withers, cashier of the San Antonio National Bank, committed suicide here this morning by shooting himself through the head with a revolver. No cause is assigned or known for the deed.

Two Families Frozen to Death Hot Springs, Ark., February 3. Two families, Watkins and McGuffy, who started for Oklahoma from Cedar Glades, were frozen to death in the recent blizzard. The bodies were found on the prairie near the Arkansas line.

Hysteria in New York Bluster New York, February 3. Late tonight, Maggie Weisenmuller, a domestic employee at 2 East 126th Street, was shot and killed by Frederick Vecner, who escaped. The cause of the tragedy has not yet been ascertained.

Steel Workers on Strike Pittsburgh, February 3. The employees of the steel department of Moorehead, McLain & Co.'s mills struck today against an obnoxious rule, and the department closed down. The strike affects 1,000 men.

A Bank Watchman and an Icicle Baltimore, February 3. Shortly after 3 o'clock this morning, Watchman McCauley, at the Continental National Bank, committed suicide in the bank by shooting. Cause unknown.

Fears for Steamer's Safety New York, February 3 - There are fears for the safety of the steamer Kapler, which left Gibraltar January 8 with a cargo of fruit for this city. The Napier's crew numbered 27 men. Scarlet Fever In Children's Home, Newark, N.J.

18920225: "M. Lion Esquime, a French-Moslem savant, is said to have perfected recently a marvelous instrument for photographing speech. By speaking into a photophone transmitter which consists of a highly polished diaphragm reflecting a ray of light, the ray of light itself is set into rapid vibrations, and a photograph is made of the sound of the voice as it travels along a band of sensitized paper. Now comes the wonderful part of the story: if the image of the photographic tracing is projected by means of an electric arc or oxyhydrogen light upon a selenium receiver, the original speech is instantly emitted from the tube of the receiver, and may be heard as plainly as if uttered by a human being in an ordinary tone of voice. It is true, this is a most wonderful discovery, as it is evident that there is no limit to the development of this peculiar combination of methods. There is one curious thing about a Russian winter: in the latter part of October or the first of November, the weather will be as mild as it is here in September. Not a sign can be seen of an approaching change, when suddenly, without an apparent warning, a light haze will be seen in the northern sky, and in 12 hours the thermometer may fall 50 degrees. The change is so sudden and violent that travelers are frequently frozen to death before they can gain shelter. It has occurred that farmers, out looking after their flocks, have been caught in one of these blizzards, and, missing their way home, have lost their lives, their bodies remaining under the snow until the following spring. The suddenness of a Dakota blizzard is well known in the northwestern part of our country, but it is tardiness personified when compared with the rapidity with which a Russian winter storm comes. Dispense with one cigar a day and obtain this monumental literary production. It will pay you. Tobacco destroys vitality, while study brightens and expands the intellect. No such offer will be made again. The Encyclopaedia Britannica, Revised and Amended, is the only encyclopedia brought down to the present. It embraces all the good features of the English work of the same name and has none of its defects. The ninth edition, with its five supplementary volumes, is now over two years old. The Revised Edition is brought down to November, 1890. THE GAZETTE is justly proud in making this UNPARALLELED OFFER.

18920305: I read by Peer and Working-men. London, March 4 - London is astir with meetings preparatory to tomorrow's county council elections. Among the candidates deemed secure, the Duke of Norfolk stands first of thirty Moderates. Among the Progressives are Lords Rosebery, Carrington, and Moulsewell, and Messrs. Burns, Cooier, and Sidney Webb. Old Tories are all astir at the prospect of a social revolution led by peers and workmen. As these elections will have an important bearing on the Parliamentary elections, disclosing as they will the current of opinion in the Capital, all parties await the result with interest. The dissenting clergy have thrown their influence for the Progressives. 

FROM TORONTO: A Benefit Association In Trouble. Man-itary Reform: Trifling with the Temperance Question. (From our own correspondent) Toronto, March 4 - The Massachusetts Benefit Association of Boston, an insurance concern doing business here, was charged in the Police Court today with unlawfully neglecting to have the words "Assessment system" printed in every advertisement issued and used in Canada in connection with their business. Efforts are being made to secure the closing of all privy vaults and cesspools and the proper drainage of all privies within the city limits. To enable property owners to do this, it is proposed by Alderman Lamb that the City Council should seek authority to issue debentures to be called "sanitary improvement debentures," and that amounts be advanced for sanitary purposes and charged against the property as a local improvement. The estimates of the Police Department were submitted by Chief Grissett today. The amount asked for this year's police protection is $121,275.50, an increase of $11,010 over last year. Mr. Meredith, in the local House this afternoon, charged the Government with trifling with the temperance question and asked for an order of the House for a return of copies of the case submitted for the opinion of the Court of Appeals as to the validity of the local option provision of the Municipal Act, and of the opinions of the Judges of the said court therein and of the judgment pronounced by the court in the premises.

THE PERILS OF SNOW: Thirteen Dead and Eleven Missing of the Newfoundlanders Caught in the Recent Blizzard. Halifax, March 4 - The steamer Conscript, which arrived at noon today from St. John's, Nfld., brought the following additional particulars regarding the dreadful calamity at Trinity Bay by which so many sealers lost their lives: Trinity, March 1 - The Hosecleer returned this morning, bringing sixteen of the men reported from Heart's Content yesterday, and the bodies of John Penney and Solomon Penny, found in boats. The sixteen men, all of English Harbor, except Patrick Hanlon and three sons, got on a pan of ice seven feet high Saturday night and made a shelter with some of their boats and a fire of others and three seals which they had. The ice drifted into Heart's Delight Sunday morning and they walked ashore. One young fellow was frozen stiff when they made the fire, but he revived. These sixteen are well, but William Kavanagh and his four sons are at Shoal Harbor, on the south side of the bay, just beaten. They could not board the craft. Captain Foolow saw fires in the direction of Norman's Cove on Sunday night, but it was impossible to get there, where it is hoped more missing men are. Eleven are still missing. The following are the names of the dead as far as ascertained: John Penney, Tobias Penney, Martin Bullion, Solomon Penney, English Harbor; Edward Pottle, Charles Day, John Nurse, Salmon Cove; William Stockley and Jesse Butler, Robinhood; Robert Bannister and Charles Bannister, Ship Cove; William Barnes, English Harbor. The Evening Herald of Tuesday says: "At first it was feared that over 200 people were cast away, but we are thankful to say, as far as we can learn, there are only eleven now missing, and thirteen have died, making a total of twenty-four fathers and brothers who have succumbed to the blizzard of Saturday night." The men still missing are: Isaac Batson, William Batson, Arthur Bauson, Reuben Pottle, of English Harbor; Henry Nurse, George Nurse, Charles Nurse, and William Nurse, Salmon Cove; John Moore, George Moore, and Jacob Moore, Trinity South.

FAIR WEATHER: Promised for Today, With Higher Temperature and Westerly Winds. Toronto, March 4, 11 p.m. The storm over the Maritime provinces is abating and is moving northward. A gale is still blowing in the Gulf, accompanied by snow and rain. There is little change in pressure in the lake district, but a general decrease is taking place in the Northwest. Fair, comparatively mild weather is general in these districts. Temperature minimum and maximum: Calgary, 24, 52; Qu'Appelle, 18, 40; Winnipeg, 38, 34; Port Arthur, 24, 40; Toronto, 20, 39; Kingston, 12, 38; Montreal, 10, 20; Quebec, 10, 20; Halifax, 32, 42. Lakes: Cloudy to fair weather; local falls of sleet or rain in southern portions; stationary or a little higher temperature. St. Lawrence: Winds mostly westerly; fair weather; higher temperatures.

18920310: I (Mo) N, Neb., March 9 - Charles Warning, who was fined by Acting Judge Horacelette on Saturday morning, entered the courtroom today and attempted to murder him, firing two shots at him as he sat in his courtroom. The first shot took effect in the region of the heart, but was turned from its course by some articles in the vest pocket; the second bullet struck the judge over the left eye and ploughed through the flesh in an upward direction. Warning was locked up. It is not believed that the judge's injuries are fatal. 

Ontario and Western's New Step. New York, March 10 - The Tribune says: "An important step has been taken by the directors of the New York, Ontario, and Western Railway, looking toward the development of the property and the improvement of its finances. A meeting of stockholders has been called for April 20th. It is proposed to create a mortgage of $20,000,000, the bonds to be payable in gold, to run for 100 years and to carry 4 percent interest." 

A Blizzard in Minnesota. Minneapolis, March 9 - The city is now in the storm center of the worst blizzard that has been seen in the Northwest in four years.

Street, report the opening, closing, highest and lowest quotations of grain and provisions at Chicago to-day as follows:

**Corn**

May: 0.81, 0.81, 0.80, 0.80

**Lard**  
May: 11.00, 11.20, 11.05, 11.20

Irwin, Green & Co.'s Chicago special to the Gazette says: "Wheat opened somewhat excited and higher on very cold weather in the Northwest, amounting to a blizzard in Dakota, with every prospect of much lower temperature further south to-morrow. English cables were higher. The miscellaneous smaller shorts covered, after which the market was dull with a drooping tendency, caused by reports that exporters were selling in New York and strenuous efforts by larger shorts to keep the market down. Notwithstanding this, and lower continental cables, the market closed firm at nearly the top. If the cold wave works eastward without getting further south, the tendency will be toward lower prices, as considerable local buying was based on severe weather to-morrow. The absolute prohibition of the privileges of trading by the board will doubtless result in a wider daily range. Corn was exceedingly dull, and the general tone inclined to weakness, but the strength in wheat checked the decline. The country bought moderately on the cold weather, while the offerings came principally from local traders. There was slight improvement in the cash enquiry. Provisions ruled dull and heavy in the early part of the session, but firmer later. Very little was done on outside account, the trading being confined to packers and home speculators. At the stockyards, 32,000 hogs were expected for to-morrow, and prices ruled lower.

On account of the fire in the Great North Western Telegraph office this morning, the "ticker" service was not very good to-day, and we are without our usual closing quotations of the grain markets. Peerbohm's cable to-day says: Cargoes off coast, wheat and corn, all cargoes on passage and for shipment, wheat slightly better; corn, there is a demand for cargoes near at hand, while there is not much enquiry for more distant periods of delivery. Liverpool spot wheat, quiet; corn do firm. Liverpool mixed maize, 4s 8d; Canadian peas, 6s 2d. Weather in England milder. Mark Lane English and foreign wheat "quiet; do American maize steady; do Languedoc maize, quiet; do English and American flour, slow. No. 2 Club Calcutta wheat, ex-ship, 35s 0d; present and following month, 30s 0d.

London, March 7. The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: English wheats were steady. Foreign wheats made a fractional advance, Californian being 6d dearer and American red winter 3d dearer. Barley was weak, the provincial markets quoting American 6d lower. Oats were firm; there was a rise of 1d in prices with a reduced sale at the advance; corn went up 3d; new American on passage was quoted at 20s 6d. The market for oats was steady; American was quoted at 18s 6d. At to-day's markets there was a better enquiry for English wheats at full prices, while foreign wheats were neglected. English flour was 1d cheaper and American flour 1d cheaper. Corn and oats were 3d dearer. Beans and peas were steady.

**Movements of Grain and Flour**  
At Chicago, the receipts were 62,217 flour, 157,000 wheat, 203,000 corn, 28,000 oats, 18,000 rye, 31,000 barley, and the shipments 25,701 flour, 31,000 wheat, 124,000 corn, 208,000 oats, 22,000 rye, 32,000 barley. At New York, the receipts were 15,000 brls, 12,417 sacks flour, 70,500 wheat, 101,075 corn, 58,425 oats, 14,745 rye, 8,250 barley, and the shipments 1,314 brls, 22,523 sacks flour, 48,381 wheat, 104,431 corn, 5,202 oats, 10,000 barley. At Milwaukee, the receipts were 5,250 flour, 3,000 corn, 12,500 oats, 3,000 rye, 37,000 barley, and the shipments 18,800 flour, 22,000 oats, 5,000 rye, 1,800 barley. At St. Louis, the receipts were 27,000 wheat, 10,000 corn, 10,000 oats, and the news of this Northwest.

**Gold Found Near Portage**  
A blizzard at Winnipeg—the grain market. Winnipeg, March 9. An explorer named Benson has brought into Fort Portage samples of gold discovered near there which have set the town wild with excitement. Experts say the samples will run $25,000 to the ton. The Manitoba Legislature opens tomorrow afternoon. This is the last session of this Parliament and some exciting times are expected when Mr. Greenway springs his Redistribution bill. Winnipeg was struck by a blizzard last night, but as the temperature did not fall to any extent, no one suffered very much. There are snowdrifts today as high as houses, and the streetcars had to be taken off the routes. There is considerable difficulty running trains. At the close of the present session of the Manitoba legislature, the Conservatives intend holding a big convention here to organize for the approaching campaign. A bitter contest is expected, the separate school question being the main issue. The magnificent work done by the Pacific Railway Telegraph company in collecting Quebec election returns is highly praised by the provincial papers. Half an hour after the close of the polls, the first returns began to arrive here. About 200 cars of wheat of excellent quality were inspected at this point during the past week. At the annual meeting of the Manitoba Pacific Association yesterday, the following officers were elected: Patron, Sir Donald A. Smith; vice-presidents, Lieut. Governor Schultz, Wm. Whyte, J. T. Kturmam.

**The Cratan Company**  
A JILOW IN RETURN. Sir Charles Tupper's significant words at the Commerce dinner on the British Bill. London, March 10. At the Chamber of Commerce dinner last night, Sir Charles Tupper responded to the toast "Canada, her Commercial Relations." He said Canadian manufacturers and exporters were marching under the hardships of the McKinley tariff, and it would not be long before the people would show their loyalty to the integrity of the British Empire by striking the United States a blow in return for her present policy. Canada prevented Boston and New York from booming (commercial capitals), and with the aid of the home government, she could still further encroach upon the prestige of those cities and make one of her seaports the greatest outlet in the world for grain. Canada had the soil and the willingness to accomplish those results and the time was ripe when she should receive an opportunity to show the capabilities of her territory and people.

**A Frightful Blizzard**  
The worst storm in years sweeps over the Northwestern States; great damage done. Chicago, March 10. A frightful winter blizzard from Lake Michigan to Montana, the worst in years and unexampled, raged last night. Fifty degrees fall in temperature, a whirling cyclone of snow and sleet, and reports from all sides of destruction to property and life are the features of the extraordinary visitation. Individual cases are given of people freezing to death. All trains are delayed, says a dispatch from Dubuque; the wind is blowing at a forty-five mile rate, with the mercury at zero and rapidly descending. At Waterloo, Iowa, many cars along the Illinois Central railroad are reported blown from the track. The roof of the Ketchum wagon works in Marshalltown was lifted away by the gale. From nearly every place heard from come details of damage aggregating many thousands of dollars from the wreckage of fencing, mill towers, factory smokestacks, plate glass windows, trees, chimneys, signs, and out-buildings. From oppressive warmth Tuesday night, the change in Chicago last evening was remarkable, ice and gale making havoc with street traffic and greatly embarrassing electric communication. A building in course of erection in Chicago was blown down and two workmen were fatally injured.

**Blazing in the Storm**  
Br. Paci, Minn., March 10. Several school children who started for school yesterday morning and two teamsters who drove into the country are missing, and it is feared they are victims of the blizzard. Br. Minn., March 10. At West Duluth yesterday, the smokestack of Merrills & King's saw-mill blew down, killing F. Cullen and injuring two others. It is feared there will be much suffering if not loss of life before the storm is over. 

**Temperature Drops to Zero**  
St. Paul, March 10. After raging with terrific fury for thirty-four hours, the blizzard passed on to the northeast, leaving in its wake intense cold, the mercury early this morning reaching 10 below. As fuller details of the storm are received, it grows in magnitude and intensity, and fears are expressed that there may be greater loss of life. On account of the bad shape the wires are in and the drift-covered country roads, the full details of the loss of life will be slow in coming in, but that there have been serious results from this storm is undoubtedly true. Damage to property from the severity of the gale is reported very great at Fargo, Crookston, and other places. So far as the railroads were concerned, the gale and blizzard got in their deadly work last night when it blew and drifted the snow badly. Snow ploughs are out on every division, while several trains have been annulled and others are coming in slowly. A snow plough carrying two engines and running as the first section of the regular train had a head-on collision at Lake Park this morning with the first section of the passenger train. George Carrier, engineer of the passenger train, was seriously injured.

This corrected text maintains the original meaning and formatting while fixing OCR errors. Here is the corrected text:

On favorable legislative action in New Jersey toward the Reading combination, exports of wheat (and of flour and wheat) from the coasts of the United States for the six days ended March 10, equal 3,754,000 bushels, against 208,000 bushels the week before. The Agricultural Bureau report indicates that the United States will carry over 72,000,000 bushels of wheat visible and available July 1, 1892, even should we export 50,000 bushels in four months preceding that date against a total surplus July 1, 1891, amounting to about 32,000,000 bushels. An improvement is noted in general trade in the provinces of Ontario and Quebec. In both, there is a moderately active demand for staple goods, sugar being higher. Demand for wheat is not heavy. An early opening of navigation is expected at Montreal, where there is already considerable demand for ocean freights. Bank clearings at four Canadian cities equal $18,520,856, an increase of 6 percent during the week. There were 40 failures in the Dominion reported to Bradstreet this week, against 33 last week and 479 January 1 to date, against 403 in a like share of 1891.

METAL MARKET

London, March 6. The market for pig iron warrants has been irregular, with a very fair business in English sorts, but only moderate movement in Scotch and Hematites. Scotch prices have stood at about 40s 3d; those for Cleveland averaged somewhat lower at 35s 3d-35s 7d, and Hematites receded to 45s 4½d. Some speculative interest has been aroused by anticipation of a rise in price of coal and an increase of cost of production, but that has died out the past few days and the market at present is flat. Consumptive demand is moderate and export movement spiritless, but Board of Trade returns show exports last month of 40,000 tons, against 38,000 tons in February 1891. Stocks of Scotch iron in warrant stores have decreased to 498,000 tons, and those of Cleveland iron to 157,000 tons. The pig tin market has been easier during the last half of the week, with only moderate business on speculative account and hardly average purchases for consumption. The bulk of supply, however, is still very well under control. Copper has been active at a higher range of prices, with large purchases by consumers as well as brisk speculative trading. Further reports of a combination of American producers to regulate production and secure better prices have been instrumental in helping prices upward, but better purchases for consumption and improvement in European statistical positions helped to strengthen the market. Tin plate has been in fair demand, but large buyers hold aloof, owing to lack of confidence in the future of the market. Business has been chiefly in lightweight Bessemer squares at 11s 0d, and Siemens do at 12s 3d f.o.b. Swansea. Exports last month were 33,000 tons, including 23,000 tons to the United States, against 82,000 tons and 88,000 tons in February 1891. Ship plates were very quiet, and the market remained easy. Several mills in the Cumberland district are idle owing to scarcity of orders and fuel. Old iron is rather weaker and more freely offered. Scotch pig iron demand continues slow, and prices have undergone little change. No. 1 Collins, f.o.b. Glasgow, 53s; No. 1 Siemens, f.o.b. Glasgow, 50s 6d; No. 1 Ganshorie, f.o.b. Glasgow, nos; No. 1 Langloan, f.o.b. Glasgow, 51s 6d; No. 1 Carnbroe, f.o.b. Glasgow, 43s 6d; No. 1 Shotts, f.o.b. at Leith, 52s; No. 1 Glongarnoek, f.o.b. Ardrossan, 61s; No. 1 Dalmellington, f.o.b. Ardrossan, 48s; No. 1 Eglinton, f.o.b. Ardrossan, 47s. Steamer freights, Glasgow to New York, 2s; Liverpool to New York, 7s 6d. Cleveland pig, the market is unsettled, with fair business the last few days at about 65s 0d for No. 1 f.o.b. Middlesborough. Bessemer pig business continues rather slow and the market is barely steady at 43s for West Coast brands, Nos. 1, 2, and 3, f.o.b. shipping port. Spiegoleisen, a very quiet market, with prices unchanged. English 20 percent quoted at 80s, f.o.b. shipping port. Steel rails, orders come forward slowly and the market is barely steady. Heavy sections quoted at 5s, f.o.b. shipping port. Steel bloom, there is little doing and prices are nominal: makers ask 12s 11d for 7x7, f.o.b. shipping point. Steel billets, dealings are still of moderate volume and makers' prices without change. Bessemer, 2½x2½ inches, quoted at 45s, f.o.b. shipping point. Steel slabs, very slow market, and no change in sellers' prices. Bessemer quoted at 64 5s, f.o.b. at shipping point. Old iron mills, demand runs light and prices are easy, without quotable change. Tees quoted at 2 17s 6d, and double heads at 3, f.o.b. Scrap iron, there has been a fair business, and prices steady. Heavy wrought iron quoted at 2 8d-2 12s 6d, f.o.b. Crop ends dull market for these and prices unchanged. Bessemer quoted at 2 12s 6d-2 15s, f.o.b. Tin plate, demand is irregular and prices still lean in sellers' favor. We quote f.o.b., Liverpool: 10 charcoal, Alloway grade, 14s-14s 6d; 16 Bessemer steel, toke finish, 12s 6d-12s 9d; 10 Siemens steel coke finish, 12s 0d-13s; 12 coke, B.

18920314: Prices are about 1 per cwt above last year. Kangoons are firmly held at a considerable advance. New crop is being bought so freely amid Indian wants. Prices are high, but shippers say they must go higher, for as they have lost heavily upon the 50,000 tons already sold, they decline to make further sales. Smalls or granulated rice on the spot in Europe and new crop to arrive are again some 6d per cwt higher. The quantity of small or granulated to be made this year is expected to be low, as a much larger proportion of the Burmese rice crop has been sold as rough to adjacent countries, so that the product of the rough rice mills in the Burmese ports will be much less than usual. We hear of new crop smalls for English markets to the extent of 6,000 to 6,000 tons having been resold by buyers to sellers, and the shipments presumably canceled at a loss of about 1d per cwt. This explains fully the current high prices of granulated rice for old and new crop deliveries.

DAILY RECEIPTS

The receipts posted on 'Change today were as follows: G. T. U. Cheese furnishes nothing worthy of mention. Butter was quiet, with very little doing today, e.g., creamery 20-22; firm milk 18-20; Morrisburg and Rockyville 18-19; Western dairy 18-17. The New York Commercial Bulletin says: "The market has continued quiet all the week, and while receipts have been larger, the proportion of fancy table grades does not show much increase. Still, the continued absence of demand of importance and advices of a tendency to an increase in the make have caused a weak and unsettled feeling, with a disposition on the part of holders to put prices down to a point that would attract increased attention. Pennsylvania creamery has not been in large supply and bulk working out to grocery trade, but prices lower in sympathy with the general depression. Elgin creamery very uncertain. The stock here cost high prices, and holders have tried to get out with as little loss as possible, and in a small way have exceeded quotations, but on the open market 29c is the extreme. Other finest Western has declined to 28c-28½c, and the latter is very extreme, and few receivers would hesitate to accept 28c to clean up. Firsts are plenty, dull and weak, with 20c-20½c top prices, while seconds are obtainable at 22c-23c. June Western is very dull and lower. New state dairy tubs have ruled slow and tending to accumulate, and 25c-62½c have become extreme prices for the finest, while bulk shows irregular quality and offering from 24c down. Old State dairy very dull and weaker. Imitation creamery quiet, with 22c-23c top prices for best lots. Fresh factory has been plenty and lower. Exporters have taken a few lots at about 17c, but the scarcity of freight room interferes with exporters' operations. Cheese has had another week that probably at the best could only be called fairly active, and shows no further gain in value. Shippers do not appear to have found any backing that would permit them to pay much attention to the really fancy goods, and while the deal for export took out a couple of good-sized parcels and a number of smaller caliber, they were about all made up of something below finest and thence along down into the mediums and the bulk of the hard skims, though all the latter were not forwarded for want of freight room. The home trade movement was somewhat fluctuating, but rarely animated, and buyers in a majority of cases appeared pretty well impressed with the notion of keeping their investments as close as possible to limits of early wants. In a general way, the position has been very well supported by holders who have maintained the former line of valuation, and in no case, so far as can be learned, made any direct effort to realize beyond the scope of the naturally developed inquiry, but all bids at old rates were accepted, and some lots of stock have been tendered for negotiation not before available. There is, in point of fact, just a toning down of bullish sentiment to be noticeable without amounting to any reaction, yet sufficient to make the bearish inclined element pick up its ears and commence to suggest adverse features. The failure of the English demand to go on to fancy cheese, the progress of the season and the temptation of ruling prices as a basis for an early and full make of new crop, and even in the face of post-winter blizzards and cold snaps, the chance for a warm spell to impair quality covers about the current talk at the moment, but the effect upon the market is not noticeable. It is simply an effect of the present condition of trade.

The egg market continues easy in tone. Friday's storm was thought would have a strengthening effect, but it was of too short a duration. The stocks west of Toronto are very large, and so long as they can be moved without difficulty, the same easy feeling will prevail. We quote fresh 15c-16c and limed 13c. Considering the state of other markets, prices are very high here. Fresh are selling at 13c in Toronto and limed at 10c-11c.

COFFEE MARKET

The coffee market during the week showed no feature of interest, being intensely dull. Brazilian markets continue to show a fair disposition to accept any bid and sold on the basis of 13c-13½c for Ts. The world's visible supply of March 1 shows an increase of 107,000 bags over February. Warehouse deliveries in New York continue exceedingly large, and there is no indication as yet of an oversupply in the inland markets. Appearances now tend to show a notable increase in the consumption of coffee in the United States in excess of any yet since 1894, when prices were much lower.

18920315: J. Pheljis, ex-minister to England, had an interview with the President on the Retiring Sea affair. The matter before the Senate: The Senate in executive session to-day spent an hour in the discussion of the Retiring Sea question. The matter came before the Senate in the shape of a message from the President in reply to a resolution requesting further information as to the effect of pelagic sealing. The President sent extracts from official reports of the Retiring Sea Commissioners showing that, contrary to Lord Salisbury's statement, the British commission had conceded that the seals had diminished in numbers by the hand of man, which, of course, meant largely through the action of the poachers in killing the seals at sea. The message was laid before the Senate and read. Short speeches were made by Senators Sherman, Butler, and Morgan, of the Committee on Foreign Relations, and by Messrs. Piatt, White, and others. At their conclusion, the papers were referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations. 

Killing Out for Police Service. Washington; March 14. The steamer Thetis has arrived at San Diego and will be ordered to San Francisco to be fitted out for service in the Retiring Sea. 

Chicago Board of Trade Discipline. CHICAGO, March 14. In the case of the temporary injunction against the directors of the Board of Trade restraining them from hearing charges against Baldwin & Furnam, preferred by Elick Lowita, to the effect that they had defrauded their customers by unprofessional methods of dealing, Judge Horton to-day decided that the Board of Trade is an involuntary association; that its members consent to be governed by its rules and regulations; that it has final and complete jurisdiction affecting the discipline of the members and that, therefore, the injunction must be dissolved. 

Freight Trains Wrecked. YONKERS, March 14. All trains on the New York Central and Hudson River railroad are delayed here by a wreck which occurred at 4:45 this afternoon. The trouble was caused by one southbound freight train running into the rear of another. Seven cars and the engine of the second train were demolished and the wreckage was strewn over the track. The wreckage caught fire and the contents of one of the cars, consisting of general merchandise, were destroyed. The colliding trains were southbound freight trains from Albany to New York. 

The Sugar Trust's New York. NEW YORK, March 14. All the principal interests in the Richmond Terminal Company will meet tomorrow in this city and the affairs of the company will be adjusted. The Stock Exchange to-day placed on the unlisted departments $25,000,000 new Sugar stock, which was authorized at the last meeting of the stockholders of the Sugar trust. This is taken as a confirmation of the story that the Trust has absorbed all the competing refineries and will have a complete monopoly of the sugar trade. The officials of the Trust decline to make any statements. 

Volume of East-Bound Freight. CHICAGO, March 14. There was a big decrease in the volume of east-bound freight last week as compared with that of the week before. The total number of tons by all lines was 61,475, while that of the previous week was 100,592. The shipments, however, amounted to about 11,000 tons more than they did during the corresponding week last year. Through shipments of flour, grain, and provisions by the lines in the Central Traffic Association amounted to 47,054 tons, against 68,122 for the preceding week. 

Severe Blizzard in Kansas. Kansas City, Mo., March 14. Despatches from points all over Kansas report that a severe blizzard is raging. The weather throughout the state was warm Saturday; yesterday a change in the atmosphere took place, and at night a heavy snow driven by a strong wind set in. The snow is of the hard variety, and wherever it drifts it forms banks as hard as sand. Trains on the Santa Fe main line west of Newton are delayed on account of the storms. 

A Broken Flywheel's Work. Cincinnati, March 14. Shortly before 1 o'clock this morning, the gigantic flywheel at the Cincinnati electric light works broke. It was 24 feet high, weighed 24 tons, and was making 73 revolutions per minute. It smashed the engine, the office, crushed several dynamos, and knocked out one side of the building. Loss: $20,000. There were narrow escapes, but no one was hurt. 

The Cuban Treaty All Right. Washington, March 14. The disputed questions arising out of the reciprocity treaty with Cuba have been decided by the Spanish government at Madrid in favor of the United States, and orders accordingly have been issued at Havana. The treaty is very popular in Cuba and this action of the Spanish Government gives great satisfaction. 

Another Electrocution Coming. FRESNO, March 14. Warden Brown, of the State prison, is preparing for the execution by electricity of James E. Winbaugh, convicted of the murder of Edward Moran on December 21, 1896. The execution is expected to be carried out on Monday next, the first day of the week set by Recorder Smythe, of New York, for Winbaugh to die. 

Fatal Elevator Accident. St. Louis, March 14. While two boys were lowering an elevator loaded with iron at Rohan Bros.' boiler factory today, the rope broke and the elevator fell to the floor beneath. Three workmen who were standing below were caught and crushed to death. The boys were flung out of the elevator and seriously hurt. 

A Natural Gas Strike. Kansas City, Mo., March 14. The Midland Hotel Company, in sinking an artesian well on its property here, struck natural gas at a depth of 800 feet. The gas was carried in a flue up to the second-story windows of the hotel, where it was ignited. When burning at night, the center of the city is illuminated for an iron ground. 

A Benefit Order. BOSTON, March 14.

18920405: Feed remains the same, with bran and shorts steady. We quote bran $11, shorts $17, and meal $23. Wheat is dull on spot, with nothing in the way of spot business to note. Barley, peas, and oats and the coarser grains furnish nothing specially worthy of mention. We quote values generally as follows: No. 2 hard Manitoba, 95c-96c; No. 3 do, 87c-90c; No. 2 Northern, 90c-95c; peas, 72c-74c per 60 pounds; oats, 31c per 31 pounds for Quebec; Ontario, 34c per 34 pounds; corn, 60c-62c, duty paid; feed barley, 42c-43c; good malting do nominal. 

At Chicago, wheat was firmer, closing at 79c May, 80c July. Corn closed at 39c May, 37c June, 37.5c July, and oats at 28c May, 28c June, 27c July. Messrs. Schwartz, Dupee, and McCormick, of Chicago, telegraph Oswald Bros., 13 and 15 Hospital Street, as follows: "Wheat today was firmer, May opened at 78.5c, sold between 78c and 80c, and closed at 79c. The approaching holiday here had some effect, with New York and St. Louis bullishly inclined, and with Chicago closed up Tuesday. It was apprehended that the market might be run. The scareboard was made bullish by the very small world's wheat shipments. The Northwest reported a very large decrease in its country stock, and North Dakota also promised a blizzard. There was talk of a large cash wheat business. Caldes were very weak again, and the Hatch bill, as agreed upon unanimously by the committee, was considered very dangerous legislation for all grain markets. For some reason or other, however, the bear news was rejected. The decrease in the visible supply, 2,000,000 bushels, was about as expected. The outside news is no more bullish on wheat than it was last week. The crop prospects continue good and the export clearances small. These are important facts and are the causes which affect the market." 

Corn was just barely steady. May sold between 38c and 39c and closed at 39c with light receipts and poor grading. This was just about offset by the very dull trade. The little advance which was scored was in sympathy with wheat. Oats kept firm in sympathy with wheat. The provision market was weak under free selling by local packers, the chief buyers being shorts. The receipts of hogs estimated for tomorrow are only 16,000. This is accounted for by the bad roads and tomorrow's legal holiday.

Messrs. Irwin, Green & Co.'s Chicago special to the Gazette says: "The full text of the Hatch bill was published Saturday night and the trade has had time to digest it. While the general opinion is that its own provisions should be sufficient to preclude a moment's consideration by any ordinary intelligent body of men, yet it hangs as a menace to business in all commodities affected by its terms and tends to demoralization. It was the chief depressing factor in our markets today. Wheat recovered partially only because of unusually strong conditions. About 300,000 bushels of No. 2 spring wheat was worked here at the May price. The Straits reported practically open now, but vessels will not hasten to leave for the lower lakes until there is less ice in Lake Erie. The world's wheat shipments were a million and a quarter bushels less than last week. Early cables were easier, but foreign markets improved with us towards the close. Corn was quiet and the range of prices very small. The selling of quite a line of long stuff weakened the market early, the trade feeling the effects of Hatch bill talk, as in all other markets. The weather operates as a bullish factor. Provisions were dull and dragging. The chief feature was the turning over of a line of May lard to July by a packing house. The fact that tomorrow is a local holiday had a restrictive effect on business in all pits."

FAIR TO CLOUDY TODAY, With Strong Winds, Local Showers and Higher Temperature. Toronto, April 27, 11 p.m. Since last night the storm center has moved northeastward from Nebraska to the northward of Lake Superior. The area of high pressure has moved southeastward from the lake region to the Atlantic, and another high area has set in over the Northwest territories. A northwestern blizzard has prevailed in Alberta since yesterday and now extends as far east as Manitoba. The weather has been cloudy with light local rain in Ontario and fine east. Minimum and maximum temperatures: Toronto, 36, 52; Montreal, 30, 64; Quebec, 30, 54; Halifax, 34, 50. Lakes: Strong winds and gales, northeast to northwest; partly fair and warm, with local showers or thunderstorms today, turning cooler again tonight and tomorrow.

18920611: BELTIM COMPANY, 894 St. James St. IT IS HARRISON AL RED. Mr. Blaine Cut a Very Poor Figure in the Voting at Minneapolis. ONLY ONE BALLOT NEEDED to Renominate the President—McKinley’s Belt Sacrifice. A New York Editor the Tail of the Ticket. Mr. Blaine on the Result. MINNEAPOLIS, June 16—The fourth day of the convention opened with a miniature Dakota blizzard. It was not cold and it was not accompanied by snow or hail, but it was lively enough to tear from their places the decorations which adorned the buildings along the principal streets. The rain fell in torrents for a time, but the storm was of short duration and the sky soon cleared. At 10 o'clock, an hour before the convention was to meet, not a band had appeared on the streets and there was but a small crowd turning toward Convention Hall. It was evident that the convention would be late in assembling. Chairman McKinley appeared shortly before 11 o'clock and looked rather wearied as a result of last night's vigil. It was also before a quorum had taken their seats, and at that hour, by way of consolation to the Blaine supporters, the band opened the musical program with "The Lost Chord." At 11:37 the convention was called to order. Prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. Wayland Hoyt, of the First Baptist Church of Minneapolis. The chair made the qualifying announcement to the convention that Senator Quay had authorized him to say that no further opposition would be made to the adoption of the majority report. The question was then put and the majority report was unanimously adopted amid cheers. The Michigan delegation were permitted to retire for consultation and in the interim Warner Miller of New York, sent up to the desk and had read a women's suffrage memorial. Mr. Miller asked that the officers of the Women's Republican Association named in the communication be presented to the convention and this was done. Mrs.

18920705: M Jetticoat's ch. Huillton, by Himyar Grenadine 97; F. Gtbhard's ch. a Blizzard, by Eole Belphoebe 83.

18920708: I trained for Ste Anne's, arriving at 9:41. I proceeded at once to the tasteful and commodious home of the Gold Cure. Here I introduced myself to the genial Dr. Foster, who, on hearing that I came from Montreal, gave me a hearty welcome. I then proceeded to catechize the medical man in reference to certain much-discussed questions regarding the famous Gold Cure. "Does the Gold Cure kill anybody?" "No, never," replied Dr. Foster, "instances have occurred and been made much of by malicious newspapers and jealous, ignorant or prejudiced physicians, where patients have died shortly after being discharged, cured, from the Gold Cure institute. Now, what do these cases show, when properly investigated? Simply that the patient has been the victim of organic liver, kidney or lung disease, the result of long years of debauchery and exposure. Take a typical case: Here is a man with far advanced phthisis or tuberculosis, induced by lying drunk in the gutter in the pelting rain or driving snow, or on an open doorstep all night beneath the frosty skies of a January blizzard. He is brought to the Gold Cure, as a last resort, to cure his drinking habits. He remains the allotted three or four weeks, and goes home fully and completely cured forever of his taste for alcohol. In a month or two he is dead. 'The Gold Cure did it.' The traducers and the unthinking public take up the cry without investigation or scientific proof. The Gold Cure will unfailingly cure drunkenness in every shape or form; this its opponents don't attempt successfully to deny, so they are compelled to fall back on libelous inventions, false reasoning and willful perversion of facts. What we undertake absolutely to cure is drunkenness, but to replace a pair of varnished lungs or renew a 'hob-nail' liver is not within the scope of the Gold Cure, or in fact of any other cure known to mortal man. You must also remember that many cases seek the Gold Cure when far advanced in the throes of delirium tremens. If such patients, in isolated instances, soon after coming to our institute, pistol or throw themselves out of an open window, before the cure has had a fair chance to get in its work on them, can this be reasonably laid at its door? No; as well blame the ordinary antipyretic remedies for the self-destruction of a patient delirious through fever. We must seek for carelessness or ignorance on the part of nurse or guardian, to that, unhesitatingly, I repeat that the Gold Cure cannot authentically be charged with directly or indirectly causing the premature death of a single one of its thousands and thousands of patients, but, on the contrary, has rescued hundreds who were tottering on the very verge of a drunkard's grave. "But doctor, is the cure lasting?" "It is. In fact, many patients who have been cured for months and years, have assured me that before they took the cure their desire for alcohol kept growing more and more intense every day, fight it off as they would, trying to stave off the evil day and make the sober interval between drunks as long as possible, till finally will power was conquered and the much dreaded debauch broke out without restraint. Whereas, after experiencing the Cure, the disgust for, or indifference to, alcohol becomes more deeply rooted as time goes by. The very memory of liquor has faded away. Such men are free agents. They, like burnt children, dread the... tire, and with reason, desire and will all on their side, no longer fear their adversary, King Alcohol. If, however, a person is determined on self-destruction and educates himself to drink again, he can, of course, do so, but will find it much harder than will an individual who has never before tasted liquor. What more in reason can be asked?" 

"How many days does it take you to cure drunkenness?" 

"Three or four weeks. We can cure absolutely the worst cases of drunkenness on earth in three to four weeks." 

Here I asked: "Is it also true that you treat the opium, morphine, and cocaine habits?" 

"Yes." 

"And are they also cured in three or four weeks?" 

"No, they take four, six, and, in some very bad cases, eight weeks for an absolute cure. We have cases here now who spent a year in secluded isolation at Guelph with no benefit whatever. In fact, such patients, on discharge, as a rule, break out worse than ever to make up for lost time. These cases, with us, are doing well after one week's treatment." 

"How are patients doing who have been discharged from your Institute?" 

"Well, they are all occupying good positions, attending to their duties, and feeling better than they remember ever being in their lives before. They seem to have taken a new lease of life. We can refer enquirers to them." 

"Is it necessary that a patient should be subjected to publicity during treatment?" 

"Not in the slightest. We are treating patients here privately now, and not even their most intimate friends are aware of it. You see, people can come here for a summer's outing and take the Gold Cure at the same time. The patient may be treated in his own apartment if he so chooses. Ladies are always treated privately. But I may say that once you convince a man that alcoholism is a disease, he ceases to be falsely ashamed of it, especially when he witnesses the practical results of the cure in other patients." 

"It seems rather absurd for a man not to be ashamed of drunkenness, yet afraid to have anyone aware of his taking a cure for the same." 

The doctor then politely showed me around the building, introducing me to several of the patients, one and all of whom had but the same story to tell of the beneficial effects of the treatment. It was an easy matter to pick out the ones who had been at the institute a fortnight from the arrivals of only a few days. The former presented all the brightness of eye, steadiness of hand, and clearness of complexion found in healthy men. All, with the exception of the alert and busy doctor, seemed to be enjoying one long joyous holiday. Fishing and boating on the river and long walks and drives through the attractive surrounding country are much indulged in by the patients. They are under no restraint whatever, beyond reporting to the physicians four times a day at convenient hours for treatment. 

On shaking hands with the doctor just before leaving for the city, I fired a parting shot: "Is it true that you don't refuse your patients their ordinary supply of whiskey?" 

"We give them all of the very best liquor they can drink, and as often as they want it. They don't want it very long. In from two to three days after commencing treatment, they have no more use for it, and that ends the business." 

"Wonderful and almost presumptuous as seemed to my mind the claims of the doctor, I left Ste. Anne's, convinced in my own mind that they are able to bear the test of facts and close inspection. If you doubt them, as I did myself at first, go and see in propria persona."

QUOITING Challenge Match Caledonian vs. Montreal 

The friendly match between the Caledonian and Montreal Quoiting clubs, which was to have commenced at two o'clock this afternoon, will not commence till four o'clock, owing to many of the players being officially engaged at funerals this afternoon.

For a general family cathartic, we confidently recommend Hood's Pills. They should be in every home medicine chest.
