For 13 hours trains are from 12 to 24 hours late; freight trains are snowed up along the lines. The Rock Island, Denver limited, is lost between here and Fairbury. The snow extends into Oklahoma, and reports of terrible suffering among the settlers are coming in. The loss of stock will be great. 

Denison, Texas, December 8. The cyclone of Tuesday evening caused no fatalities in this section, but the destruction of property was great. A cattleman named Wiesmar, while riding over a prairie, was killed by a bolt of lightning. 

Brenham, Texas, December 8. Tuesday's cyclone near this city demolished everything in its path. Several persons were seriously injured. Many families are homeless and utterly destitute. 

Pahokee, Ark., December 8. A heavy windstorm struck this town Tuesday and caused damage to the amount of $50,000. Twenty-six buildings were wrecked. Several persons were seriously injured.

SLOWLY GROWING COLDER, And There May Be a Slight Fall of Snow or So: Toronto, December 8, 11 p.m. The storm that was central over Lower Michigan yesterday is central tonight over the Upper Ottawa. It is now dispersing. Unsettled weather and local falls of sleet or rain have fallen over Ontario and Quebec. In the Maritime provinces, it is raining. In the Northwest, fine weather with temperatures near zero and higher pressure prevails. 

Minimum and maximum temperatures: Calgary, 12, 20; Edmonton, 10, 20; Qu'Appelle, 2, 8; Winnipeg, 10, 10; Port Arthur, 18, 24; Toronto, 37, 42; Kingston, 30, 48; Montreal, 28, 40; Quebec, 20, 28; Halifax, 28, 42. 

Upper St. Lawrence: Westerly winds become local falls of sleet or rain; becoming slowly colder. 

There is strong opposition to President Harrison's suggestions that the international traffic between Canada and the United States should be legally hampered. They have had an eighteen-hour blizzard down in Kansas, and all the trains are stuck in the snow. Mr. Blake's paradise for Canada's farmers was located in this state. If any of the deluded people who went there trusting in his word hear of the open weather Canada is enjoying, how mad they will be! 

The Marquis of Huntly thinks the agricultural distress in England is due to bad seasons. The low price and abundance of farm produce in the world's markets would rather indicate that it is due to good seasons. The Texan silver mine people have formulated a demand that the United States shall coin all the silver brought to its mint. They represent a monetary conference that has influence. There are votes behind their platform. 

The Chicago Woman's Club has petitioned Congress to permit the World's Fair to be open on Sundays. This is a blow in the house of a friend. Woman is wont to be looked on as a defender of the Sabbath's rest.

1892-12-26: HAVEN'T HEARD OF IT. Washington officials don't know about the Canal scheme. Washington, December 24. Officials of the State Department have no information regarding the application of the International Navigation Company to the Canadian Parliament for a charter authorizing the company to connect Lake Erie with Montreal and New York by a system of canals, the Hudson River, and the St. Lawrence and Richelieu rivers and Lake Champlain. 

The telegram from Ottawa making the announcement that an application had been filed is not definite enough to afford a clear idea of the scope of the proposed scheme. Government officials said that by this scheme it was intended to secure the navigation of the Hudson by Canadian vessels; the promoters would doubtless be disappointed. That stream would no more be free to vessels from the North reaching it through canals than it is at present to vessels from the West via the Erie canals. Foreign vessels will be stopped at the end of the canal route, as now.

A BLIZZARD IN KILLING STOCK AND BLOCKING UP HALL MAY OUT. Kansas City, Mo., December 25. Kansas, Oklahoma, and the West generally are experiencing a genuine blizzard today, which threatens not only to block railroads but also to do great damage to stock. Last night, a drizzling rain began which continued almost to daylight, when it gave way to driving snow, and the wind having in the meantime shifted to the northeast, the temperature grew many degrees colder. The snow kept up all day, and before night it had developed into a regular blizzard. Several inches of snow fell and drifted badly. Scattering reports from Kansas and the southwest generally show that the railroads are in trouble from the drifted snow in the cuts. 

He is a kleptomaniac. St. Louis, Mo., December 24. Eugene Dutcher, daughter of millionaire Isaac W.

1892-12-27: OUT OF A JOB. Hint is how some of the extra clerks at Ottawa will begin the year. (From our own correspondent.) Ottawa, December 20. The thirty-nine extra clerks in the Department of Railways and Canals, who have received notice that their services will not be required after the end of the year, got a little Christmas present at Saturday's meeting of the Council in the shape of a gratuity equal to two months' salary, but it is understood that the hopes of reinstatement entertained by some of them will not be fulfilled, as the work at the department has so much decreased that in future it will be done entirely by the permanent staff. 

In the Public Works Department also, a considerable reduction of the number of extra clerks is said to be contemplated, and about a dozen have either received notice or will do so shortly. There are over one hundred extra clerks in this department who have not passed the Civil Service examination. A huge number of these are architects or engineers, who do not require to pass the examination, and many others were employed prior to 1882 and are specially exempted by the Civil Service Act, but of the others, it is most likely that there will be a considerable weeding out.

COLD WEATHER. It is met with both at sea and on the land. New York, December 26. Incoming steamships report fierce storms and bitter cold weather at sea. Every vessel that came into port today was a mass of ice from waterline to masthead. Several steamships had deck work smashed, and members of the crews were frostbitten. The tramp steamer Lauristan, from Bremen, December 3, came in with deck and side covered with ice two feet thick in places and with huge icicles hanging from her yards. Her captain says the weather was so severe that all three of the ship's compasses froze in the alcohol box, and he was obliged to make his course by the stars. 

Davenport, IA, December 26. In exposed places, the mercury dropped to 12 below this morning. This afternoon, persons were crossing the Mississippi on foot, and tonight the ice bridge will hold. 

Bellair, Ohio, December 20. The Ohio River at this place is frozen over for the first time since 1885. 

Amsterdam, N.Y., December 20. The weather in the Mohawk Valley today is the coldest of the season. At 7 a.m., it was 6 degrees below zero and 14 below in Gloversville. The mercury is at zero tonight along the valley, and there is little snow. 

Kansas City, December 20. A typical blizzard began forming in this locality last night, and at 3 o'clock this morning had fully materialized, the mercury at that time having fallen to six degrees below zero. The blizzard was preceded by considerable snow and accompanied by the usual biting north wind. The storm is far-reaching, extending over the entire southwest, and is particularly severe in Kansas. In this city, the thermometer marked 4 degrees below zero at 10 o'clock this morning.

FROM THE ANCIENT CAPITAL. Quebec. People are finding it cold. Personal Intelligence, from our own correspondent. Quebec, December 20. The weather has been excessively cold for the past four days, and today it is worse than ever, and a gale of wind is blowing. Any number of people have been frostbitten, but no very serious cases are reported. Mr. Louis H. Tache, formerly private secretary to the Hon. Mr. Chapleau, has been appointed extra.

A B CASH. The voyage of the derelict American ship "While" is recorded in the hydrographic office as one of the remarkable cases in the history of navigation. Her cruise came to a close on January 23, 1889, when she stranded on one of the islands of the Hebrides. The "While" was one of the many vessels wrecked or abandoned during the great blizzard of March 1888, when so many persons lost their lives at sea or ashore. During the blizzard, it was estimated that 138 vessels were blown ashore, sunk, or damaged along the coast of the United States north of Hatteras. Off the coast west of the fortieth meridian, some twenty vessels were sunk or abandoned, among them the "While." 

She was a three-masted schooner, lumber laden. She sailed from Delaware Bay on March 13, 1888. She started off southward, and under the influence of the inshore current and the northwest gale, with her sails and ensign set, reaching the Gulf Stream, she turned to the eastward and commenced her long voyage towards Europe directly in the track of thousands of vessels engaged in transatlantic commerce, drifting about at the mercy of wind and current. She traveled north-northeast at the rate of about 15 miles a day until she reached latitude 44 north, longitude 33 west, when she began a remarkable zigzag performance, which lasted from the beginning of May to the end of October. 

She landed in latitude 51 north, longitude 44 west, whence she moved east and northward 1,200 miles in eighty-four days, or at the rate of about fifteen miles a day. During her summer zigzag, she was directly in the highway of the greatest ocean commerce, and, tossed about by the winds and drifted this way and that by the Gulf Stream and the Labrador current, she was a constant menace to navigation. During those six months, she was reported by thirty-six vessels, three of which sighted her in one day. 

In her range of ten months and ten days, she traveled more than 6,000 miles and was reported forty-five times. How many more vessels passed dangerously near to her at night and in thick weather it is impossible to estimate. The name of the "While" was called to the attention of mariners in a special supplement to the Pilot Chart for February 1890, prepared by Mr. Hayden with a view to impressing upon the masters of vessels and others the necessity of reporting to the Hydrographic Office all facts connected with derelicts that might come to their knowledge, as the Pilot Chart is the only publication which disseminates this valuable information. An idea of its importance to mariners may be gained by Lieutenant Hayden's statement that the number of derelicts reported in the North Atlantic alone ranges from 25 to 45 every month since then. 

Another remarkable derelict was the ship "Oriflamme," which was abandoned on fire in June 1881. On the 24th of the following October, the steamship "Iron Gate," on a voyage from Adelaide, Australia, to Portland, Oregon, passed an iron ship apparently burned. On the 12th of February following, the hull of an iron ship, laden with coal and iron, drifted ashore on the Island of Karoia, one of the Paumotu or low Archipelago. She was visited by some natives, who brought away a small bell, on which was engraved "Oriflamme, 1865." She was completely burned out, and in a short time sank in deep water. She had drifted 2,840 miles in about eight months. 

The abandoned schooner "Twenty-One Friends" drifted a greater distance in about the same time. She was reported on March 24, 1885, 100 miles off the Capes of Chesapeake Bay. The Gulf Stream carried her east-northeast for about four and a half months, covering 2,130 miles. Thence she drifted in an easterly and southeasterly direction toward the northern coast of Spain and was last reported on December 4 of the same year about 130 miles from Cape Finisterre. Total distance traveled: 3,525 miles; time: 8 months and 10 days. She was reported in all twenty-two times, which shows how dangerous such derelicts can be. Here is the corrected text:

A derelict is in the North Atlantic. One of the mysteries of the seas was the case of the derelict Marie Celeste, a barque found in the Mediterranean, under full sail, with every rope in place. Her captain and crew had disappeared, and nothing is known of them to this day. She was taken into port and restored to her owners.

1892-12-28: C, December 27. A blizzard struck Charleston this morning, and for the first time within the past fifteen years, rooftops were covered in a thin coating of snow and sleet. The mercury averaged about three or four degrees below freezing point during the day, and pedestrians, not being accustomed to ice, had a hard time getting along the sidewalks. The orange trees in the city are injured somewhat and will probably bear only one crop this year. Fort Monroe, Va., December 27. The worst blizzard in twenty years struck this vicinity about midnight, and the snow has been falling ever since. The electric car line to Hampton is blocked, and navigation is suspended.

1892-12-29: Where is the Steamer Umbria and her six hundred souls? This is causing much anxiety. Nothing but conjecture. The most probable theory is that she has encountered rough seas. New York, December 28. Conjecture as to what has happened to the long overdue Cunard liner Umbria is all that can be indulged in. That she has met with an accident is agreed in shipping circles, but just the nature, extent, and seriousness of that mishap will not be known until she is spoken by some ship or until she arrives. At midnight, the Umbria was five days overdue, not a word having been heard from her since she was sighted off Tascott Light, outward bound 11 days ago. Late yesterday afternoon, Mr. Brown was seen by a reporter, and after declaring that he was not at all alarmed over the non-arrival of the Umbria, he said that all Atlantic vessels that had been caught in the prevailing ocean blizzard had been overdue. The Umbria is under the command of Capt. Horatio McKay, vice-commodore of the Cunard fleet, and one of the most careful commanders about. The Cunard people had every confidence in his ability and discretion and were satisfied that the Umbria could not be in better hands. The Umbria was built and engined in the famous Fairfield yard at Govan, on the Clyde, in 1884. She was designed both for speed and comfort. At the time she was launched, she was the largest steamship afloat except the Great Eastern, and she was the most powerful without any exception. She is a sister ship of the Etruria and is the swiftest single-screw steamship in the world. She is 501.6 feet in length, 57.2 feet broad, and 38.2 feet deep, with 3,245 net tonnage and 7,718 gross tonnage. She is wider, deeper, and shorter than the ordinary ocean greyhound, and thus has greater steadiness. Her boilers are all "double-ended," that is, they are provided with a set of furnaces at each end. The flame passes to a chamber in the center, returns through the tubes, and passes thence to the funnels. The latter are of large diameter but are of ordinary length. The engines are extremely powerful. The central high-pressure cylinder is 71 inches in diameter, and the two low-pressure cylinders are each 105 inches. They have a sufficient stroke and turn a screw of manganese bronze of great accuracy of pitch. The Umbria is provided throughout with transverse bulkheads, or watertight compartments, and the engine room is surrounded with bulkheads. If she has met with any serious accident, she would remain afloat as long as any of those compartments remained intact. On her present trip, the Umbria has 130 first cabin, 123 second, and 120 steerage passengers. The officers and crew number 225. The Umbria holds the eastward record of 1 day, 1 hour, and 15 minutes made in September of this month. Her shortest westward passage was made last August when she crossed in 9 days, 22 hours, and 7 minutes. Schooners Wrecked, Halifax, N.S., December 23. The schooner Flora Dell, of Northeast Harbor, Shelburne, from Cape Negro, bound to Halifax, ran ashore at Moose Harbour last night and will probably be a total loss. She has a cargo of herring. The schooner Willie Craig, Capt. Palmer, from Cape Breton, bound for Halifax, is reported wrecked at Little Harbor, near Ship Harbor. She was built in Pugwash in 1862 and is owned by Edward Macpherson of this city.

1892-12-31: McEntyre & Son, Importers and Tailors. Latest patterns in fine English Woollens for Suiting and Overcoatings. 53 Beaver Hall. Tornado Tom: He was tough, but his heart was in the right place. Blizzard Pen: That so? Tornado Tom: Yes, I shot for the place where it ought to be, and by gum, it was right there!

1893-01-11: London, January 10. A severe storm is raging throughout Western Ontario, and all railway lines are blocked, and trains from the West have lost hours in finding their way through. The streetcar company put a gang of men on early, and though they managed to get the tracks uncovered, the cars are running regardless of the timetable. The storm is not merely local, as trains from all directions are either blockaded or far behind time. No trains on the Grand Trunk Railway had arrived up to 11 o'clock this afternoon from the west, although one was waiting at Komoka until the track was cleared. Two locomotives were placed on every outgoing train. The snowplows were sent out early along the different lines and did good work. Fifty men from the car shops were placed at work shoveling in the yards, which were almost impassable, as many as four locomotives pulling one train. The Canadian Pacific Railway express, due from the East at 4 a.m., arrived at noon, and others are timed in proportion. Altogether, railroad men pronounce it the worst they have had for years. The thermometer registered 2 degrees below zero at noon, and the intense cold adds to the general discomfort. Skaroft, Ont., January 10. The storm of yesterday has culminated in a complete blizzard. Tonight's trains from Goderich were two to three hours late, and freight trains were canceled. The weather is intensely cold, and if the storm continues until morning, all traffic, both on the country highways and the railway, will be blockaded. The cold in the Neanon, Owen Sound, Ont., January 10. Last night was the coldest of the season here, the thermometer marking 10 degrees below zero. Cornwall, Ont., January 10. A blizzard has been blowing here for the past three days. The roads are blocked in all directions. The railway is running, but trains are delayed by heavy drifts in the cuttings. This is the worst storm that has been experienced here in many years. Paris, Ont., January 10. It was 21 degrees below zero here last night, with a strong northerly wind. This is the coldest experienced here this season. The snow is three feet deep, and the winter so far is the most severe for many years. Mattawa, Ont., January 10. Stormy weather; thermometer, 10 below. Buckingham, Que., January 10. Cloudy, with light sprinkling of snow; temperature, 7 above. Deschenes, Ont., January 10. The thermometer registered 22 degrees below zero here last night, the coldest that has been experienced here for some time. The trains are all reported very late. Streator, Ont., January 10. The thermometer registered 15 degrees below zero here this morning. All the morning trains were about two hours late on account of a heavy snowfall and drifts. Noville, below at Mornin, Sarnia, Ont., January 10. The weather here for the past twenty-four hours has been the coldest experienced in years. During last night, the thermometer registered 17 degrees below zero. Last night about seven o'clock, the ferry Conger got blocked in the ice and was detained there until seven this morning. Many Sarnia people were aboard but got off this morning, walking ashore on the ice. All the mail and other trains are many hours late. Lindsay, Ont., January 10. The thermometer this morning registered about 25 degrees below zero, with a strong northwest wind blowing. Caledon Black, Ont., January 10. Turning colder; ton and a half below zero now. Benshew, Ont., January 10. Fifteen below zero at noon today, strong westerly winds and drifting badly. Maniwaki, Ont., January 10. A strong westerly wind, with thermometer 8 below at 2 p.m. Roads are becoming badly drifted; six inches of snow since last night and this morning. Montmorency, Que., January 10. Strong east wind, with some snow; thermometer 2 below. Barrie, Ont., January 10. The weather today is the coldest in years, the thermometer registering 25 degrees below zero. A strong north wind has been blowing since last night, causing railway traffic to be interrupted. Toronto, January 10. At 1 o'clock, a thermometer at the corner of King and Yonge streets registered 9 degrees below zero. At 8 o'clock this morning, it was 12 below.

1893-01-19: The Reign of Jack Frost. Great suffering caused in Europe by intense cold. The wolves driven out of the forests into the villages. The mercury freezes in Northern Michigan. Memphis, January 18. The cold throughout Europe continues to be intense. In this city, the cold is very severe, being 23 degrees Fahrenheit. There is great suffering and a large fatality among the poor, owing partly to the cold and partly to acute destitution among the laboring classes. The bodies of three persons who had been frozen to death were found in the streets today, and numerous instances are reported of people being frostbitten. Navigation is being suspended on the Elbe, and Hamburg ship owners have ordered their vessels to proceed to other ports, steamers from South America being sent to Bremen Haven. Horrible stories come from the remoter regions of Europe, and especially the Balkans, of death and suffering caused by the severity of the winter. In Serbia, the wolves have abandoned the forests and prowl about the towns and villages in search of prey. A young girl was devoured by wolves in the suburbs of Belgrade, and the animals, made more ferocious than ever by hunger, have actually appeared in the streets of the city. In Montenegro, packs of wolves have attempted to enter the sheepfolds, refusing to retreat when fired upon by the peasantry. Despatches from Russia state that there is great suffering in the provinces where the famine prevailed last year, the people having been so much weakened by their sufferings as to make insufficient provision of food and fuel for the winter. In Russia, also, the wild animals, made desperate by hunger and cold, have invaded the villages and devoured both human beings and domestic animals. Rome, January 18. In Venice, the ingredients are frozen, and the canals are filling with ice and snow. Provisions are at a premium. The thermometer shows 16 degrees below zero centigrade. In Vienna, the thermometer stands at 20 degrees below zero centigrade; in Padua, 11 degrees; Stockholm, January 18. Intense cold prevails throughout Sweden. In the north, the mercury freezes. All harbors are ice-bound. Steamers due from London and Hull on Saturday have not arrived yet. Memphis, Tenn., January 18. A blizzard struck Memphis last evening. At 11 o'clock, the snow was eleven inches deep on the level and in drifts two and three feet deep. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed while preserving the original meaning and formatting as much as possible:

Cars are blockaded and traffic suspended. St. Louis, January 18. Teams and wagons are now crossing the Mississippi River on the ice bridge. This is the first time in several years that teams have crossed the river on ice.

1893-02-01: J. Auston Chamberlain, the Unionist, drove up to the House at an early hour in a cab. The young Unionist brought with him in the cab a store of silk ham which he rapidly deposited on the third bench below the gangway on the Government side, thus securing these places for the Liberal-Unionists. The crowd outside the House was small throughout the morning hour, but increased towards midday. Prominent members of Parliament were, as usual, hissed or applauded, according to the sentiments of the spectators toward them. 

The Speech from the Throne: The following was the Queen's speech opening the session: 

"My Loyal and Gracious Lords, My friendly and harmonious relations with all the powers continue. Their declarations from every quarter are favorable to the maintenance of European peace. In connection with the approaching evacuation of Egypt by the British East African Company, I have deemed it expedient to authorize a commissioner of inquiry and ability to examine on the spot, with suitable provisions for his safety, all the best means of dealing with the country, and to report to the Government. In view of recent occurrences in Egypt, I have determined upon making a slight augmentation in the number of British troops stationed in that country. This measure does not indicate a change of policy or a modification of the assurances my Government has given from time to time respecting the British occupation of Egypt. The executive has declared in terms satisfactory to me. I shall henceforth follow the established practice of previous consultation with any government in political affairs, and I desire to act in cordial cooperation with it in relation to both Egypt and Canada. Papers in continuation of those heretofore presented will at once be laid before you, gentlemen. 

If the estimates of the charges necessary for the public service during the coming financial year have been framed, they will be laid before you at an early date. 

My Lords and Gentlemen: I have observed with concern the wide prevalence of agricultural distress in many parts of the country. It is to be hoped that among the causes of the present depression some are of a temporary nature, but without doubt you will take this grave matter into your consideration and make it a subject of careful inquiry. 

The proclamation which placed Ireland under exceptional provisions of law has been revoked, and I have satisfaction in informing you that the condition of that country with respect to crime continues to improve. A bill will be submitted to you, on the earliest available occasion, to annul the provisions for the government of Ireland. This bill has been prepared with the desire to afford contentment to the Irish people, to confer important relief upon Parliament, and to establish additional securities for the strength and union of the Empire. Bills will be promptly laid before you for the amendment of the system of registration in Great Britain, for shortening the duration of Parliament, and for establishing equality in the franchise by the limitation of each elector to a single vote. There will also be proposed to you various bills regarding the condition of labor, among which there will be measures in relation to the liability of employers, the hours of labor of railway servants, and a bill to amend the law of conspiracy. Your attention will likewise be invited to measures for the further improvement of local government, including bills for the creation of parish councils, for an enlargement of the powers of the London County Council for the prevention of the growth of new vested interests in ecclesiastical establishments in Scotland and Wales, and to establish direct local control of the liquor traffic, together with other measures of public utility. I humbly commend your labors on these and other subjects to the guidance of the Almighty. 

Mr. Balfour's Attaché: The early evening was passed in the House of Commons in giving notices of motion. Notice that Mr. Gladstone would introduce his Home Rule bill on next Monday elicited prolonged Liberal cheers. The mover and seconder spoke to empty benches. The House filled like magic, however, when Mr. Arthur J. Balfour, first lord of the Treasury in the last Salisbury Cabinet, and now leader of the Unionist Opposition, arose somewhat languidly and amid a storm of Opposition cheers began a general criticism of the Government. He congratulated the Cabinet upon the abandonment of the policy to abandon Uganda. In their Egyptian policy, Mr. Balfour said the ministers could rely upon the support of the Opposition as long as they upheld British rights. He trusted the Government would at their earliest convenience let Parliament know the cause which led to the recent troubles in Cairo. Among the causes, undoubtedly, were the rash utterances made by the Prime Minister and the Chief Secretary for Ireland when they were in the Opposition. Both were to blame for rising hopes which would certainly be productive of future difficulties. He demanded that the Home Secretary should say whether or not the release of Egan and Callan, the Irish dynamiters, was a part of a policy of amnesty intended to involve the release of all the Irish dynamiters, and he charged Mr. Morley, Irish Secretary, with having used the Crown prerogative for political purposes. 

Mr. Gladstone's Reply: Mr. Gladstone was cheered loudly when he rose to answer Mr. Balfour. He had noticed, he said, that with the continued growth of legislative arrears, the eagerness of the country for vigorous legislation increased. He had decided to lose no time, therefore, in satisfying this eagerness. He would secure the appointment of a Royal Commission to inquire into the Westland question. He reproached Mr. Balfour for assailing with inflammatory criticism a bill not yet introduced, and for doing his utmost to prejudice the minds of his followers against a plan of home rule of which he was still ignorant. He would not reply to Mr. Balfour's invectives against Mr. Morley's administration of Ireland except to say that the wise policy of clemency had been simultaneous with a great decrease of agrarian crime. The mission to Uganda was necessary in order that an impartial and thorough inquiry be made into affairs there. The result of this inquiry would enable the Government to arrive at a rational decision. He did not believe that in his long Parliamentary career he had ever uttered words so rash and dangerous as were those uttered by Mr. Balfour concerning the difficulties in Egypt. These words seemed to suggest that the Government would lose no time in getting out of Egypt. Mr. Balfour rose and repudiated the charge that he had suggested the probability of a hasty evacuation. Upon resuming, Mr. Gladstone said that the Government had not to consider the question of occupation, but merely the maintenance of order. The relations of the two governments had now been placed on a satisfactory footing, and further trouble was not apprehended. 

In conclusion, Mr. Gladstone repeated his appeal to the House not to be moved by premature denunciations of the Home Rule bill. He could understand the impatience of members if they discovered any disposition to delay the bill, but this did not exist. It surely would be better for all to wait and give the provisions of the bill their full careful deliberation, perhaps calm, impartial, even benevolent judgment. 

After Mr. Gladstone's speech, the House adjourned. 

Lord Salisbury's Speech: In the House of Lords, several new peers, including Lord Playfair, took the oath prescribed for new peers. The Prince of Wales and his son, the Duke of York, had seats on the cross bench. They remained through part of the debate on the address in reply to the Queen's speech. Lord Brassey moved the adoption of the address. His motion was seconded by Lord Thring. Both mover and seconder spoke in general terms in support of the Government. Lord Salisbury, who today appeared in Opposition, after passing a compliment on Lord Thring, said he declined in the meantime to question the foreign policy of the Government. So far as known, in the absence of official papers, the policy of the new ministry seemed to be founded on sound principles and to be executed with judgment and skill. Events in Egypt rendered the difficulties surrounding the British occupation more numerous. The Government must postpone the withdrawal of British troops, but this in no wise modified the assurances that had been given to foreign powers concerning Egypt. Touching upon the question of home rule for Ireland, Lord Salisbury said that the one object of the Government during the past six months had been to get the support of a class of men whom hitherto no politicians in England had tried to conciliate. The keynote of the Irish policy of the Government was to get the support of the criminal classes. The provisions necessary to maintain the law had been repealed. Though agrarian crime was not prevalent generally, yet in districts where it did prevail, the hands of the law were paralyzed. (Conservative cheers.) The prerogative of the Crown had been used to shield murderers and release dynamiters. All the acts of the Government caused the impression that they were much more in sympathy with criminals than desirous of vindicating the law. (Cries of "Hear, hear.") The reference in the Queen's speech to home rule was the most peculiar sentence he had ever seen in a public document. It seemed to indicate that the Government's opinion of the whole Irish question with which Parliament had to deal was that it was for one portion of the Irish to place their heel upon the neck of the Protestant population of Ireland. 

With regard to the other measures indicated in the Queen's speech, Lord Salisbury declared that nobody believed that they would ever be undertaken. They were simply a repetition of the programme adopted by the Liberal conference at Newcastle. Lord Salisbury alluded to the agricultural depressions. He said that agriculture suffered most from want of confidence. Political partisans now preached doctrines that were filling the minds of the owners of capital with apprehension. There was no country in the world, Lord Salisbury added, where property was now so insecure as in Great Britain in consequence of erroneous legislative action. (Cries of "Hear, hear.") 

The Earl of Kimberley, Lord President of the Council and Secretary of State for India, replied to Lord Salisbury. He mildly remonstrated with Lord Salisbury for accusing the Government of having sympathy with Irish criminals. 

Mr. Gladstone Irritated: In his speech this evening, Mr. Gladstone showed plainly that he had been irritated by Mr. Balfour's taunts. The tones of his voice indicated deep indignation, and his gestures were rapid and violent, especially when he repudiated the imputation that royal clemency had been exploited for political purposes in the cases of the Irish dynamiters and the Gweedore prisoners. When he came to the discussion of Uganda and Egypt, his energy was partially exhausted, his voice was husky, and he was obliged to relapse into a conversational tone. He spoke for forty-eight minutes with good effect. The curious distribution of seats resulted in some confusion, especially during the last three or four speeches, which were interrupted repeatedly with cheers, laughter, and expressions of dissent from unexpected quarters. Nearly 400 notices of bills and motions were given during the sitting. This is the largest number recorded at any one sitting of Parliament. 

Lord Randolph Churchill, in conversation with friends this evening, disclaimed any intention of playing a conspicuous part in the present Parliament. A meeting of Parnellites decided this evening that John Redmond should move an amendment to the address in favor of a general amnesty for Irish political prisoners. Mr. Goschen, ex-Chancellor of the Exchequer, was elected to the Carlton Club tonight. The Unionists have resolved to abstain from pairing during the session. 

A WESTERN BLIZZARD Which Has Some Features Peculiar. St. Paul, January 31. A heavy blizzard is now raging. Here is the corrected text:

Throughout the Northwest, its violence is still unaltered. Wires are prostrated and trains delayed. The cold wave has acted strangely, as at eight o'clock this morning it was 38 below at Helena, and at Missoula, 100 miles north of there, it was 10 above at the same time. At Helena, there was a high wind from the west and another at Missoula from the east. In Duluth, it was 0 below, Winnipeg 10, and Jamestown 0, while at Fergus Falls, Grand Forks, and Fargo it was fully 20 degrees warmer, with high winds from a different point in each of these places. The mercury is now falling in most places. 

A Herman Prince, Berlin, January 31: Duke Victor of Battenberg, Prince of Corvey, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst, and president of the Prussian Upper House, died at Breslau last evening. It is not what its proprietors say but what Hood's Sarsaparilla does that tells the story of its merit. 

Hood's Sarsaparilla.

FRANCE'S NATIONAL CREDIT was being weakened by assaults on savings banks. A SCENE IN THE CHAMBER when the Government brought down a bill to punish those who attack the bank. Paris, January 31.

1893-02-03: W. H. Agar, president of the Royal Electric Light Company, and Mr. Hudger, city electrician, with a staff of eight linemen, cut out 500 incandescent lights, but by forming loops on the arc lights, the latter were maintained and sufficient light was afforded to enable the firemen to perform their duty. The storm increased to a regular blizzard, which added to the difficulties under which the firemen were laboring. The hydrants are frozen, and the streams are only put in by the steamers. The clouds of steam and smoke rendered it impossible for the firemen to work. The firemen were knee-deep in slush and water. 

The flagstaff which adorned the pinnacle of the Holland building was the subject of innumerable wagers as to how long it would stand, whether it would fall inward or outward, etc. It made a hard fight of it, and finally wound up with a flourish by falling gracefully right into the heart of the fiery debris underneath. There was a constant stream of unfortunates from the houses adjacent to the burning buildings. They were loaded up with all kinds of household goods. The most novel incident in this connection was two persons of the colored persuasion who staggered along with a heavy Saratoga trunk crowned with a canary bird, and with a small pickaninny perched on top. A pitiful feature of the fire was the fact that the buildings were all surrounded by dwellings of the poorer classes of the community. On St. David's line and the yards abutting from it, whole families were seated out in the cold, and by this time a drifting snowstorm had set in serenely shortly after one o'clock to make matters more unpleasant if it were feasible for the unfortunates who had been driven out from their comfortable beds. 

"This is too bad," said a gentleman evidently of the insurance persuasion. "Too bad is it," was the reply from a hod carrier alongside. "Not by a blank sight! It will be good for the bricklayers." "What's the matter with the water pressure?" was the question on every side. "Why, it does not reach to the second story of Hardman's building." In fact, this seemed to be the principal difficulty with the hard-working firemen. At about two o'clock, the fire in the rear of the Ogilvie building looked threatening. The fire was only prevented from spreading to the stores of Porter, Teskey & Co. by the fire wall. From the Shand & Mason engine on Inspector Street, two streams were thrown into the burning building, but despite the desperate efforts, the fire looked as if it would spread. 

At three o'clock, a telephone message announced that the fire had spread to Porter, Teskey & Co.'s store along the roof. It looked as if the fire would burn clear through to Inspector Street. The Notre Dame hospital ambulance was early on the scene, and soon after its arrival, the attendants were called to care for a Frenchman who was suffering from inflammation of the bowels. The man had been sleeping in the house adjoining the Hood, Mann & Co.'s building, and when the fire caught at the latter place, some of the water played on the flames fell through the roof of the Frenchman's dwelling and drenched him in his bed. Between the scare and the chill resulting from the soaking, the poor man was almost a corpse when taken out of the house. He was removed to the hospital. 

Fires in Other Towns: Ainsworth, Ont., February 2: At 5 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the rear of Bertrand's confectionery, destroying Galvin's block from Menzies' drug store, which is gutted, down to the Arcade building on John Street. The loss on the block is $18,000; insured for $1,000 in the North British and Mercantile and Northern and Imperial. The stock of Mr. Menzies was insured in the Queen's for $1,000. His loss is $800.

1893-02-04: I, February 3: The new Washington express via the Reading and the New England railroad, eastbound, ran into the rear of the Norwich boat express in front of the station at East Douglass, Mass., on the New England road at 6 o'clock this morning. The shock was a terrible one and nearly all the passengers were more or less injured by being violently thrown from their seats. Engine No. 2, drawing the New York express, telescoped the rear car of the train, the locomotive entering the car about eight feet and smashing seats and floors into kindling wood. The smokestack was smashed and steam entered the car. In this car, there were 10 or 15 persons, but none were badly injured. When the impact came, the force drove the rear car into the combination car next forward, crushing in the forward end of the former and the rear of the latter for a distance of 10 feet, causing a mass of wreckage. In the combination car were a number of Italians. The shock threw them in all directions, and four of them were injured. Two doctors set the limbs of the injured, and they were removed to the hospital in Boston. The passengers in the rear car of the boat train escaped through the rear windows. 

Bomb, N.Y., February 1: Between five and six o'clock, a freight train left this city for the north on the Rome, Watertown, and Ogdensburg railway, followed by a snow plow. At McConnellsville, the train became stalled in the snow. A flagman was sent back to warn the snow plow. Before he had proceeded far, his lantern went out. He placed a torpedo on the track and undertook to relight his lantern, but before he could do so, the snow plow, running at a high rate of speed, dashed by and crushed into the freight train. The force of the collision was so great that it threw several cars on top of the snow plow. George Aiken and Thomas Kearney, who were inside, were instantly killed, and Conductor Wright of Richmond was so badly hurt that he may die. 

Denver, Colo., February 3: A wreck occurred last night on the Denver & Rio Grande railroad near Toltec, Southern Colorado, caused by a snow slide striking the train. Three cars were thrown from the track and eight persons injured. 

FROM THE ANCIENT CAPITAL: Visited by a Howling Blizzard: Court of Appeals Judgments, From our own correspondent: Quebec, February: The city was visited today by a howling blizzard. The streets were rapidly blocked with snow, and it was all but impossible in exposed places to proceed in the teeth of the wind, such was its force. To make matters worse, the temperature fell to 12 degrees below zero, and a number of people were more or less frozen. One man had his nose badly frozen in a St. John streetcar. One of the pages of the House had a narrow escape from being frozen to death. He was sent on a message outside the House, and on turning a corner, he was caught up by a gust of wind and thrown into a snowdrift. He found it impossible to extricate himself, and there he lay until some persons passing noticed him and got him out. He was carried inside the building, where it was found that his hands and face were slightly frozen. 

A recount of the votes cast at the late election in L'Islet will take place on the 14th instant before Judge Pelletier at St. Jean Port Joli. A letter from Malbaie, county of Charlevoix, brings news of a fatal accident that occurred to Leon Tremblay, who fell from a load of hay, dislocating his neck. The deceased was 40 years of age and the father of a family. Louis Mathieu, brother of the Rev. Dr. Mathieu, superior of the Quebec Seminary, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of apoplexy. 

This morning in the Court of Appeals, presided over by Hon. Judges Lacoste, Wurtele, Baby, Bosse, Blanchet, and Hall, judgment was rendered in the case of Dominick Fortier vs. the Quebec Central Railway, confirming the judgment of the Superior Court and awarding $5,000 to Fortier for injuries he received a year ago in the case of the Bell Asbestos Company vs. Johnston. Judgment was confirmed. The argument in the Boss will case was adjourned to hear some appeals from Arthabaska; it may be continued tomorrow.

1893-02-07: O. Libby, representing a syndicate of capitalists in the state of Maine, arrived here today, his object being to spy out land for the proposed colony of Maine farmers. He says that two hundred well-to-do agriculturists are prepared to leave that state for Manitoba in the spring. Chris Ctsik's furniture store and H. Fruger's hardware store, at the town of McGregor, were totally destroyed by fire last night. Mr. Robert Parker, a well-known wheelwright, last night swallowed quicksilver in mistake for medicine and is so fearfully burned internally that there is small hope of his recovery. The fish hatchery now being completed at Selkirk will be as large as all the thirteen other Canadian hatcheries combined. It will have a capacity for one hundred and fifty million spawn. J. Patrick Warde, resident of Swift Current, was frozen to death on Saturday while attempting to walk to a house eight miles across the prairie during the blizzard. He was only a mile from his destination when he sank exhausted. He leaves an invalid wife either in Toronto or Montreal. Winnipeg is overrun with crooks and sneak thieves. Eighteen or twenty of them committed to jail last fall have just been released.

HE CALLED IT A LIE, and it took the priests and police to protect him. Dublin, February 6: Rival meetings of Parnellites and anti-Parnellites were held a short distance apart in South Meath. While Wm. O'Brien, M.P. 

THE RAVAGES IN THE SOUTH: It looks as if the rash and atrociously barbarous revenge of the Texans on the negro wretch, Henry Smith, were not to pass without its nemesis. It is not the first time that negroes have combined with vindictive determination to avenge, if not redress, the wrongs of their race at the hands of the whites. Not only have the West Indies, Haiti, Jamaica, Barbados, etc., been laid waste from time to time by a war of retaliation, or the whites have only escaped extermination by anticipating the doings of the blacks, but every region of the United States has also had its day of terror from this same cause. Twice even New York, in its sturdy infancy, when wealthy patrons and merchants were served by the sons of Ham, shuddered at the imminent prospect of a slave rising with murder, outrage, and indiscriminate massacre in its train. New England too had its uprisings, and from Virginia to Florida, the negro has at some time or another dealt out justice (as he deemed it) to the owners of his body. Since the war and emancipation, the fear of slave insurrection no longer robs Southerners of their sleep, but here and there, in the ruder portions of the Southern States, the bitter prejudice against the blacks reveals itself in ways that make resentment unavoidable and provoke all the ferocity of the still lurking savage. It generally happens that the blacks are in character and conduct very much like the white communities in which they live. What they are likely to be in the part of Texas where Smith met his awful doom, we may imagine. The state of affairs in Madrid shows that though Spain has a so-called Liberal Government, there is not enough... Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

Liberality in the population of the capital to permit a few Protestants to worship in peace as their conscience dictates. It is now twelve years since Señor Bagasla, with the consent of the late King, proclaimed freedom of religious opinion and worship for Spain. But when it came to putting the King's will and that of his minister into legal shape, it was found that the only concessions which could be wrested from hoary and obstinate bigotry were excessively slender. A few advanced democrats have to air their views about liberty, equality, and fraternity. There are even Socialists of the revolutionary allegiance in the ranks of Spanish agitators. But the rights of a little handful of simple Protestants have, it seems, no champion. It is a deplorable situation, almost incredible that it should exist within the pale of Christendom and civilization were it not only too well established. The Globe, discussing the situation at Toronto, says: "There is much vacant land in the suburb of Toronto that will not be saleable for years. A factory located upon it would cause an embryo village to spring up, and make a demand for small building lots. It might be well for the Industrial Association to canvass among owners of suburban property for those who would be willing to give free factory sites. Such gifts would not be entirely unselfish, as they would secure the sale of adjacent property that would otherwise be a burden for years." The protective tariff which Conservatives support, but which the Globe rails at, is the carrying out in national affairs of the policy the Globe commends in local affairs to the Industrial Association. The Globe invites the proprietors of Toronto to give something to private individuals that they and the public may gain more, and the whole be benefited. The National policy does the same thing. Would the Globe indicate the particular point where such aid to industries ceases to be a virtue and becomes an offense? President Harrison has surprised both friends and opponents by appointing Judge Howell S. Jackson, of Tennessee, a Democrat, to the seat on the Supreme Court bench, vacant by Judge Lamar's death. The Boston Herald remembers no case in fifty years to parallel this move. In Canada, we can show better than that. Not a few of the present Superior Court judges throughout the country have been appointed by a government of a different side in politics. Neither the government nor the public have had cause to regret such action, and neither, it is safe to say, will Mr. Harrison, even though he has broken a fifty years' precedent. The grant to the Trappists by the Quebec Legislature of 60,000 acres of land in the Lake St. John district is being quoted in some Western papers as evidence of the rule of the Monk in Quebec politics. Usually, public grants to religious corporations are not commendable. In this case, however, the Monks in question are going into the forest to show how it can be reclaimed. If they re-imbue the habitant with the old pioneering spirit, and help to make glad the waste places of the north country, their work will pay for their land, even if another 60 is added to the total of the acres. Between the cranky and cheeky Saxon who insisted on calling his innocent baby Robespierre Danton and the arbitrary registrar who, having declined to accept such a name, fined the obstinate father for neglect to register, because he must have his choice or nothing, who shall decide? Mulcted, the admirer of Robespierre appealed to a higher court, only to have his case dismissed, on the ground that in a country both Christian and monarchical no one has a right to name his child after avowedly atheistic and republican scoundrels—a judgment at which Carlyle would have smiled. Mr. John Dillon's advice that the agitation for amnesty for Irish convicts should cease is timely in two senses. First, calling for the release of the prisoners detracts public attention from the support of the rule, whose prospects are not bright. Secondly, it is not a very wise agitation in itself. It requires a specially constituted stomach to hold the claim that blowing up houses and mobbing men to death are political offenses. Within the past two months, fifteen animals, taken from twelve steamers sailing from the ports of Baltimore, Boston, and New York, have been condemned by the English authorities for being infected with pleuro-pneumonia. It must have been a strain on Mr. Rusk's vision not to see this recently made heap of his own pet stock when he was searching for the molehill of Canada's alleged cases buried three months ago. A recent issue of the Congressional Globe contains thirteen columns of titles of petitions for the opening of the World's Fair on Sundays. Getting up petitions to Parliament and Congress has heretofore been rather the forte of the good people. It looks as if in this instance the evil one had beaten them at their own game. The New Zealand Government has protested against the threatened annexation of Hawaii by the United States. New Zealand is a true pup of the John Bull breed. It recognizes only one power as having any legitimate business in the way of annexing other people's territory. A telegram from St. Paul says the Dakotas are experiencing the worst blizzard of the season. As this has been a peculiarly bad season, the inhabitants of the blizzard land would seem to be entitled to special sympathy.

Hamilton, Ont., February 20: One of the most severe blizzards experienced here in years raged yesterday and last night. The thermometer fell to eight below zero, and in the mountains, it ranged much lower. Railroad travel in this vicinity has not been interrupted, and trains are running as usual today. At a meeting of the quarterly board of Centenary Church held on Saturday, it was decided to extend a call to the Rev. K. Lanceley, who has been called to Baltimore. A special cable to the Evening Telegram from London says the Hon. Charles Tupper, Canadian Minister of Marine and Fisheries, left for Paris today to attend the first meeting of the Retiring Sea Commission as one of the representatives of Canada. A regular Manitoba blizzard prevailed throughout the province of Ontario on Saturday night and Sunday and today. All railroad lines and highways are badly blocked with snow. Trains that have got through are from two to twelve hours late, and many have had to be canceled. Country travel is almost suspended, and streetcar lines have had a hard time. Business in many places is almost entirely suspended. The weather was bitterly cold.

Knights of the Round Table Rejoice Again: The recent spell of soft weather was not a soft snap for the curlers; in fact, it was a very disappointing one, for it looked as if several matches would have to be left unfinished till next season. But the blizzard of yesterday brought joy to the heart of the curler, and last night the ice at all rinks was in splendid condition, and some scratch matches were in progress. St. Lawrence Curling Club: Owing to the mild turn in the weather during the past ten days, the rink competitions have been somewhat retarded, and until today, when Old Sol decided to favor us with cooler weather, it was feared that the completion of the following competitions would have to stand over until the season of 1893-94. The directorate, however, are now in hopes that members interested in these matches will better themselves and take advantage of the cold snap and complete all competitions during the present week. In the second drawing for the John J. McGill Cup, Hugh Ross's rink has still to play against Frank Founder's rink, and J. D. Anderson against W.

A destructive hurricane swept on the 10th of March over the New Hebrides islands and New Caledonia, clearing villages and causing great loss of life. Large numbers of the natives are said to have perished, and extensive districts were devastated. New Caledonia forms with neighboring islands the most important penal colony of France, and particulars are anxiously awaited as to the destruction of life and property at Noumea and other points. The New Hebrides have but few white inhabitants, but among those are missionaries from America and Europe. The hurricane raged incessantly for three days and the rainfall was enormous. Half of New Caledonia is flooded. In Tohio alone ten persons were drowned. The total property loss was at least $120,000. 

St. John's, March 20: A fearful blizzard visited this section yesterday. It was the worst experienced in twelve years. The streets were snowed under to the extent of three feet. In the country, the snow is ten feet deep in places. All railway lines are blocked. At Salmon, five men were drowned by the swamping of a herring skiff. It is feared that other disasters have occurred. 

THE ANN ARBOR STRIKE: Interviews with Grand Masters. 

Sargeant, of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, in an interview yesterday, said: "The action on the part of Judge Picks, of Toledo, looking to the arrest for contempt of court of all engineers who have led their engines on the Lake Shore road rather than handle Ann Arbor freight is news to me. I left Toledo Friday morning as soon as I saw there was no possible chance for a settlement, and came home Saturday. I got a telegram from Chief Arthur saying he and I had been jointly sued in Judge Taft's court for $250,000 damages by the Ann Arbor road for ordering the strike on their road. But there is no provision in the Brotherhood's rules that requires firemen on other roads to refuse to handle freight from a road on which there is a strike; so the present action of Judge Picks can hardly apply to us. The engineers have such a rule, however, and this rule will now be put to the test as to whether or not it is legal. I realize that both the actions in Judge Taft's and Judge Picks' courts are very important ones, and on their verdict depends much of interest to the future of railroad organizations. Yesterday I received a telegram that three Brotherhood firemen had been discharged from the Lake Shore for refusing to handle Ann Arbor freight. I shall expect the engineers to see that these men get back their places, as they got into trouble through the engineers living up to their boycott rule, which drew the firemen into it. Chief Arthur is merely enforcing the laws of his order as he finds them, which he is obliged to do. Whether we can be sued for damages for ordering a strike on a railroad as the head of the firemen's organization is one of the questions involved, and as soon as I am summoned I shall appear to answer. The question is one of the gravest that ever confronted our organization."

Cleveland, Ohio, March 20: Chief Engineer Arthur, of the Brotherhood of Engineers, was here yesterday but refused to discuss the Ann Arbor strike further than to say: "We are law-abiding citizens and are going to obey the order of the court." Mr. Arthur would give no hint as to the future course of the Brotherhood.

SOME OF THE PLUMS: The President Nominates a Number of Ministers to Foreign Countries. Washington, March 20: The President today sent the following nominations to the Senate: James E. Eustis, of Louisiana, to be envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of the United States to France; Theodore Runyon, of New Jersey, to be envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of the United States to Germany; John K. Risley, of New York, to be envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of the United States to Denmark; Walter U. Jabney, of Virginia, to be solicitor of the Department of State. The Senate has confirmed the following nominations: Josiah Quincy, Massachusetts, assistant secretary of state; Isaac P. Gray, Indiana, minister to Mexico; James E. Eustis, Louisiana, minister to France; Patrick A. Collins, Massachusetts, consul-general at London; Robert A. Maxwell, New York, fourth assistant postmaster general; Wade Hampton, South Carolina, commissioner of railroads; William McAdoo, New Jersey, assistant secretary of the navy; also a number of postmasters and army and navy nominations.

DIED IN THE SNOW: Nearly Three Hundred Prisoners Perish on the Journey to Siberia. London, March 20: Advices from St. Petersburg give the details of a sad loss of life among a band of convicts bound for the prisons of Siberia. The band numbered in all three hundred and seventy-four persons, including a large number of persons sentenced to exile for political crimes. In accordance with custom, the convicts were marching to their various destinations. They had spent the night in Tomsk, Western Siberia, and continued their journey early in the morning. A snowstorm was prevailing. Here is the corrected text:

And when six hours' march from Tomsk the storm had become so severe that all the roads were obliterated. Chained together, the convicts struggled on until gradually the weaker ones fell in the deep snow, dragging the stronger ones down with them. Despite the efforts of the Cossack guards, the exhausted people could make no attempt to save themselves, and they were abandoned to freeze to death while the others were driven forward, those in charge of them hoping to get them into shelter. The storm continued to increase in violence and the traveling became worse and worse. Now and then, prisoners would drop by the wayside, where they would soon be covered by the rapidly falling and drifting snow. When the guards managed to get what few remained of their charges to a place of safety, they found that of the 374 persons they had started with, only 61 survived. Sixty-two of those who had perished were political prisoners. Among those lost were Madame Lazarov, six other women, and four children.

18930323: 

M. Carroll finds full sway for his character ability, as well as ample scope in which to display his excellent dancing attributes. Edwin H. Carroll, who plays the Irish policeman, has gained for himself an enviable reputation as a delineator of Hibernian roles. Richard F. Carroll, as Old Sponge, a tramp, excites the comedy vein of the audience. Among the many realistic scenic effects in "The Dago," may be mentioned the fire scene, the blizzard, the Dago's attic, and the Brooklyn Bridge. The Carrolls are well supported by a capable company, including John K. Newman, Minnie Bowe, Britton Stephens, Blanche Howard, Nellie Lawrence, and little Annie Robin.

The Native African Choir

The first appearances of the celebrated Native African Choir, which took place in the Academy of Music, Hall Tax, Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday of this week, have proved an unqualified success artistically as well as financially. At 4 o'clock on Monday evening, seats reserved had been sold for all the performances, and every evening the "standing room" sign has been hoisted. All up the line news has reached the city that the visitors from South Africa will be greeted with like receptions. The members of the choir complain terribly of the cold experienced in this country, and consequently, the greatest care has to be taken to prevent any of the company from suffering from the effects of our Canadian climate. The native piano, which has caused so much interest among the seekers of musical curiosities in Europe, is now on its way to Montreal, where, upon arrival, it is to be exhibited prior to the performances here on April 10th, 11th, and 12th.

18930325: 

MUSIC AND THE DRAMA

Academy of Music

"The Two Sisters," which comes to the Academy of Music for Easter week, is a domestic comedy of the "Old Homestead" type, being, in fact, the production of the same authors. The moral of the story is shot at the audience with the force of a catapult. It is one of the best plays of its class. "Jane," bright and breezy "Jane," with the endorsement of two seasons' genuine success, comes to the Queen's Theatre Easter week, commencing with Monday matinee. Nichols and Lestoco stand in the very front rank of American playwrights, but they have turned out nothing so fairly amusing as "Jane." Its engagement here will no doubt meet with the same success as in other cities. The comedy will be presented with Manager Fishman's brilliant company. The New York Herald's prize play, in one act, entitled "Chums," will precede "Jane" in a matinee raiser. 

The Carrolls, in "The Lhigo," will be the next attraction at the Theatre Royal. The play is a scenic-comedy-drama in four acts, from the pen of Richard F. Carroll, who for several seasons was a comedian of the New York Casino. Its story is founded upon the abduction of a child heiress by a wily and cruel Italian, and follows her life in the slums of New York, where her captor compelled her to beg and sing in the streets to provide him with money. After a lapse of two years, she is restored to her home by a heroic but humorous Irish policeman. The scenic features call for special mention as careful attention has been paid to this part of the production. The Brooklyn Bridge, the blizzard, a thrilling fire scene, and others are among the number. Tuneful medleys and catchy songs judiciously intersperse the action and dialogue of the play. The supporting company is one of merit. 

A Full Musical Entertainment

The members of Miss Barnjum's special classes will give a calisthenic entertainment in aid of the "Barnjum Memorial Gymnasium" on 17th April, in the Windsor Hall. Judging from the number of tickets already sold, there will be a bumper house. The box plan is open at Sheppard's music store, 174 St. Catherine Street. 

A Recital Concert

Madame Mourner, the celebrated contralto of the Grand Opera at Paris, who during the last week at Kohmur parts sang with much success different solos created by her at Paris and New Orleans, will give a partially sacred concert in this city before leaving for France. The programme will be one of the choicest ever heard in this city, and all lovers of classical music are invited to witness the concert of one of the greatest contraltos of the present age. 

Mme. Mounier will sing the "Ave Maria" by Gounod, as well as the "Church Grave of the Prophet." 

The following paragraph is trying to secure for our music lovers the opportunity of hearing in Montreal all the artists who come to New York who are the very "crème de la crème" from an artistic point of view. And for an Easter musical event, she has arranged with the New York managers for the appearance in Montreal of Russie Cottlow and Henri Marleau. These young artists have already achieved a high position, Marleau having gained his position in the first rank of violinists in all the great European centers of music, and his American successes have been second only to Paderewski. He is already compared to Sarasate and is only nineteen. Miss Cottlow's successes are, as yet, solely American; but they have been such as to gain for her a rank equal to many of the great artists of piano fame, and it is quite safe to predict that she will gain other laurels when she goes to Europe. Miss Cottlow is not yet fifteen. These two young artists will give a performance quite unique in its interest and which claims recognition from our public for the success already achieved.

18930508: 

SUNNY MANITOBA

It is always of importance to have honest estimates of what we prize, especially when the authors of them have some right to consider themselves experts in the matters as to which they pronounce judgment. Since the opening up of the Northwest, we have had a considerable variety of opinion touching the value of the prairie country as a home for immigrants. The latest of these expressions of opinion comes to us in the form of a volume for which the writer claims attention as the outcome of personal observation, unbiased by the interests of governments, companies, or individuals. He avoids indiscriminate eulogy on the one hand and unjust depreciation on the other, and his recommendation of "Sunny Manitoba" as a land of promise for a large class of his English compatriots has a note of sincerity which sometimes rises to the pitch of enthusiastic faith. 

Mr. Alfred O. Legge, the writer in question, has given hostages, so to speak, to the good fortune of the land that he praises, for his sons, to whom he dedicates his book, have for years been denizens of that land. For those who have read the statistical blue books of the Government and the many pamphlets of Prof. Tanner, Fream, Gilbert, and other experts, as well as the testimony of Prof. Macoun, Saunders, Bryce, and others who are intimately acquainted with the resources of the province, Mr. Legge's book will possess little novelty. One-half of it is mainly made up of gleanings from previous publications, and the remainder, while giving the writer's personal experience and opinions of the country, its products, and its people, goes over ground which has been largely covered by works already in print. The value of the book consists, however, in the fact that even when he avails himself of the data and conclusions of preceding writers, Mr. Legge adds information and reflections of his own which confirm what he deems justifiable and reject or refute what he considers unwarranted in the statements. His object is to correct certain mistaken impressions which spiteful or carelessly false accounts of the Northern prairie have made in the minds of many Englishmen. Some of those false accounts originated with emigration agents from the other side of the border, others from croakers among the settlers who, chiefly through lack of industry, judgment, patience, and other essential qualities, had failed to achieve a reasonable success, and others again from the willful misrepresentations of politicians eager to aim a telling blow at their opponents but unscrupulous in their choice of weapons. 

The best answer to the calumnies of all these interested detractors is to tell the true story of a typical settler, the owner of Riverside Farm, a homestead in which the author spent many a happy day. Of this farm, possession was taken in the fall of 1882, and we are initiated into the secrets of its development during the ten years that ensued. To the English farmer or citizen desirous of making himself an independent home in the new world, this record of progress must be of extreme practical interest. Mr. Legge describes the prairie, its natural means of irrigation, its flora, its fauna, its climate, the fertility of the soil, the risks of early frost and how they may be best guarded against, the mixed farming that is most likely to succeed, the society of the prairie land, the provisions for education, for religious ministration, for social intercourse and relaxation, and for intellectual culture. 

Among the unfounded notions that have come, in the minds of some old country people, to be associated with Manitoba and the Northwest, one is a belief that the blizzard has its Aeolian cave north of the boundary line. This Mr. Legge pronounces a popular delusion, which leaves those of his fellow-countrymen who read his book no excuse for continuing to cherish. Compared with Dakota and the other states to the south, Manitoba has the advantages both in climate and fertility, and those Canadians who hearkened to the interested wants of federal or state agents had sad reason to deplore their rashness. Apart from acknowledged diversities of climate, greatly in Canada's favor, statistics quoted by Mr. Legge show that the yield of wheat which in Dakota averages 9, in Minnesota 12, and in Wisconsin 12½ bushels to the acre, has in Manitoba an average of 24 bushels. From these figures, English farmers can draw their own conclusions. Other cereals, as well as most vegetables and many of the fruits of temperate latitudes, yield in like proportion. Of wild berries, there is an amazing growth, and the prairie is bright with wildflowers. Trees, once scarce in parts, are by judicious planting and experiments made with butternut, black walnut, soft maple, cottonwood, hard maple, white elm, white and green ash, and other trees, though the results varied in different localities, have on the whole been encouraging. Mr. Legge considers the birch, queen of ornamental trees, by no means difficult of propagation in the province, and wonders at its absence from the selection made by the Central Farm authorities. The high value of trees to the farmer is beyond question, and perseverance in experimental forestry is of the utmost importance to the future of Manitoba and the region beyond. 

Mr. Legge disagrees with those who condemn beet culture for sugar-making in the Prairie province and insists that it would be profitable to both growers and manufacturers. He devotes a good deal of attention to the industries, both actual and possible, of Sunny Manitoba. He points out its many and manifold attractions for the sportsman and lover of outdoor life and expresses his conviction that it is the healthiest country in the world. Social life, with acknowledged drawbacks, such as the proneness to intemperance among some of the young men and the ignorance... Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

In honor of others, has very real pleasure? Englishman-like, Mr. Lege prefers his compatriots to those who have had the honor to be born in Canada. He evidently was just long enough in the Northwest to lose his way in the labyrinth of our Dominion and provincial politics, and some of his judgments are curious. He is evidently a Liberal when he is at home, and, of course, he is a free trader, like the average Englishman everywhere. But he admires Canadian loyalty and its great spokesman and champion, the late Sir John Macdonald. Mr. Legge classes his book (which is published by Mr.

Probably the largest tombstone in the world is that of the late Henry Scarlett, of Upson County, Ga. Years before Mr. Scarlett's death, he selected a monster boulder, a miniature mountain of granite, 100 feet by 250 in dimensions, and when he died this huge tombstone was placed over his grave. Jackson says some people never know what they didn't want until they have to pay for it. Elmira Gazette. Do you want to learn something that every good housekeeper should know about baking powders? A large proportion of the powders sold in Canada are made from alum, or alum, ammonia, and phosphate. The best baking powders are made from pure cream of tartar and bicarbonate of soda. The best among these is the one known as Pure Gold Baking Powder, which is made by the Pure Gold Manufacturing Company, Toronto.

The subjects are various. Some of them relate to incidents of heroism, adventure, or peril that happened under the old regime; others pertain to the Loyalist cycle; the war of 1812 furnishes themes for others; the rebellions of 1837 under Papineau and Mackenzie are not forgotten; neither are the Fenian raids and the Half-breed risings. From Newfoundland to Vancouver, no region in British North America has failed to supply scenes to young narrators. In time, the range is a quarter of a millennium.
