1895-02-09: FEBRUARY 9, 1895

ECHOES OF THE PRESS 

The boy's bright dreams are all before; The man's romance lies far behind. Had we the present and no more, Fate were unkind. But, brother, tolling in the night, Still count yourself not all unblest if in the East there gleams a light, Or in the West. 

Blackwood's Magazine 

Animating Motive in Froude's Writing: The first thing that must strike the mind of anyone who looks at Froude's writings as a whole is their amazing sameness of object, or, at all events, point of view. It is always the same nail he is hammering on the head. It reminds one of Pope's ruling passion. It crops up everywhere and at all times, firing his zeal wherever he is. What is that object? Why, to counteract what he calls "the Counter-Reformation," to denounce monkery; to unfrock priests by stripping them of all sacramental pretensions; to topple over everything standing between man and the force which called him into being; to preach good works and plain homespun morality. This was Froude's work from 1849 to 1894. If only he was about this business, he did not mind blundering about his facts; a misquotation or two never disturbed his night's rest. 

Augustine Birrell, in Scribner's 

The Indian Swell: A long-skirted tunic or frock of white muslin, close-fitting white trousers, and a tea-colored turban with a broad band of gold lace, and a tall, flashing plume of dark heron feathers and gold filigree were the salient points. Other accessories were the sword belt, crossing his breast and encircling his waist, of dark green velvet, richly worked with unalloyed gold, and thickly studded with emeralds, rubies, and brilliants; a transparent yellow shield of rhinoceros hide with knobs of black and gold enamel; a sash of stiff gold lace with a crimson thread running through the gold; bracelets of the dainty workmanship known as Jeypore enamel, thickly jeweled, which he wore on his wrists and arms; and there were strings of dull, uncut stones about his neck. The skirts of his tunic were plaited with many folds and stood stiffly out like the skirts of a premier danseuse in the ballet, and when he mounted his horse, a servant on either side held them so that they might not be crushed. Four valets had charge of this costume, and it took them some little time to array their master. The trappings of the horse were scarcely less elaborate; his neck was covered on one side with silver plates, and his mane, which hung on the other side, was braided and lengthened by black fringes relieved by silver ornaments. White yaks' tails hung from beneath the embroidered saddle cover on both sides, and his head, encased in a headstall of white enameled leather and silver, topped with tall aigrettes, was tied down by an embroidered scarf in order to give his neck the requisite curve. 

Harper's Magazine 

Fortified Paris: To-day, Paris, regarded as a fortified center, is an intrenched camp, upon the margin of which are numerous new permanent forts. The circle formed by the line of these new forts, which are far outside the forts of 1870, is about 85 miles in circumference, and it contains about 680 square miles, not more than one-seventh of that area being built over. It is a region nearly as large as Monmouthshire, with a population of 3,000,000. The smallest possible circuit to be formed around it by an investing army is 100 miles, so that at least 500,000 men actually upon the spot would be required to undertake any serious operations for the reduction by siege of the French capital. In practice, no fewer than 1,000,000 would be necessary. And fortified Paris, although so much more extensive than it was in 1870, can, nevertheless, be defensively held at present by 350,000 men, while, if 700,000, or even more, were called for, they could, without detriment to the field armies, be provided out of the 3,710,000 trained soldiers whom France now has at her disposal. 

The National Review 

A Good Builder: Mention was made in the early summertime of an oracle that one morning flitted into a half-grown apple tree, not 30 feet away from the window of a writer in the Hartford Journal, craned its little head this way and that, danced about on the limbs, and flitted away. Next day it returned with its mate, and the two began their work of building a home. A tiny branch pointing southeast and another pointing southwest were selected. Neither would hold the weight of the bird without bending. Before the day had passed, bits of thread were dangling from either limb, and thereafter the bird home took form rapidly. Thread after thread, raveling after raveling, hair after hair, followed each other into place, with as much precision and nicety as masons would use in adjusting pressed brick. After days of perseverance, the home was finished. It hung perhaps four inches below the limbs, the tiniest of threads reaching down to it from either limb. The slightest stir of air would sway it just enough to coo the young birds to sleep if they needed that sort of soothing. All through the long summer, the frail thing hung there. The family was reared after the manner of these handsomest of all nature's children; then the birds flew away, leaving the little structure to the mercy of the summer gales and showers. It withstood them all, and when a few weeks later the ice storm came, that for the moment paralyzed the whole country, filling the birdhouse to overflow with snow and ice, the tiny limbs bending almost to breaking under the weight, this bit of architecture still clung to the limbs, resuming its gentle swinging as soon as the ice gave way. Three days ago it was again overflowed with ice, the glistening drops freezing about it till, when the sun struck it, it looked a veritable ball of fire. When the wind shook off this last visitation of ice, the structure was still swinging gently, only here and there a stray bit of string and a disheveled look that indicated the struggle it had passed through. The little house is not only an interesting study, but is a source of continual wonder and marvel; all the more when one reads of the great weight of the ice that gathered upon it and its supports, as indicated by the measurements taken at Trinity College. 

A Quirky Halting Much Noise: A discussion is raging in Erie over a question propounded by a school teacher to her class: "If a tree located in a forest should fall and no one should see it, would it make a noise?" The question has created much discussion among the pupils to whom it was presented, and it has spread into other and wider circles. The debate turns upon the theory that sound exists only in the ear, and that there can be no sound where there is no ear to receive and respond to the atmospheric waves. 

Oil City Blizzard 

Treasures of the Polar Seas: In 1800, Count Komanzoff sent M. Ledentrom to explore the New Siberian islands, fitting him out at his own expense. Ledentrom reached La Roll's first island and was amazed at the prodigious stores of fossil ivory it contained; for although the ivory hunters had for forty years regularly carried away each year large quantities of ivory from the island, the supply of ivory in it appeared to be not in the least diminished. In about half a mile, Ledentrom saw ten tusks of elephants sticking up in the sand and gravel, and a large sandbank on the west coast of the island was always covered with elephants' tusks after a gale, leading him to hope that there was an endless amount of ivory under the seal. Ledentrom and Bannikoff went on to Kotelnoi and New Siberia, and they found the hills in the former island absolutely covered with the bones, tusks, and teeth of elephants, rhinoceroses, and buffaloes, which must have lived there in countless numbers, without the slightest vegetation. They also found that in New Siberia, the most eastern of the islands, the quantity of mammoth ivory was still more abundant, and in 1806, Bannikoff brought away 10,000 pounds of fossil ivory from New Siberia alone. 

Chambers' Journal 

The Decayed Music Teacher: The ordinary parent or guardian of a girl with a "turn for music" will very probably make his choice of a teacher from those to whom he listens with the greatest pleasure, forgetting that executive skill and the gift of imparting knowledge are more often found separate than together. The partially successful artist, then, is wont to fall back upon such teaching as he can get if he wants to make a livelihood out of his profession; and so enormous is the number of those who wish to take music lessons, if not to "go in for" music thoroughly, that the moderately efficient teachers have hitherto had small reason to despair of getting profitable pupils. These worthy people, however, will before long be singing a very different tune; in fact, something very like a repetition of the dirge performed by the respectable "gentlewomen" of the last generation, who, after taking to teaching music for a living on the strength of a dozen lessons taken when they were young and comfortably off, found their circle of pupils diminishing as the taste for music widened and deepened. For such as these, the increase in the number and the rise in efficiency of the regular schools of music has been their doom, for not merely in London, where the "decayed lady teacher" never flourished, but in every country town, the standard of taste has left them far behind, and nearly all such centers of their employment are now "worked" either by actual representatives of the great educational institutions of London, or their places are filled by younger artists, educated at such places as the Royal Academy of Music or the Royal College of Music, the principle of whose joint organization, in the matter of local examinations and the like, has been doing a most important work all over England during the short time of its existence. That inefficient teachers of art should have the bread taken out of their mouths is not a legitimate subject for regret, though hard cases could no doubt be cited, just as they can against such a work as that done by the organization of charity. 

The National Review 

Color or Dogs: As to color, Xenophon shares our modern prejudice; he dislikes whole colored hounds, all black, all tan, all white, and prefers the colors mixed. With the shape aforesaid, good color, good nose, and plenty of tongue, you can make a good pack and hope to kill a hare. Breed your puppies in the spring, is his advice, and do not overfeed them; train them by taking them out in a leash to follow the old hounds on a line of scent; and if you have a spirited puppy, do not let him go away in view of a hare, or he will over-exert himself and do himself an injury. Would the reader like a list of Greek hound names? Xenophon will furnish him with a catalogue of forty-seven, most of which flow naturally into an English equivalent: Active, Bustler, Ravager, Reveler, Cheerful, and the like. "Give your hounds short names," he says, "that it may be easy to call them." Accordingly, the names which he leaves us are... Here is the corrected text:

without exception dissyllabic; for the Greek ear was not alive to the merits of the dactyl in sound nomenclature, and we look in vain for such a name as Aggelos. But we find, at all events, Hebe in his list; a name which, after 2,000 years, still does duty in our English kennels. 

Macmillan's Magazine 

Pronunciation of Pepys' Name 

Some time ago there was a sort of Notes and Queries controversy on the subject of the pronunciation of the name Pepys. If I recollect aright, the point was undecided when the combatants dried their pens. In a footnote in the fifth volume of the new edition of the "Diary of Samuel Pepys," just issued by George Bell & Sons, there is an extract from some verses by one James Carcasse, a contemporary of Samuel's, who hated him like poison, which at least puts out of court one theory of the pronunciation. Exclaims virulent Mr. Carcasse: "Him I must praise who opened with my lips, Rent me from Navy to the Ark by Pepys." The late George Dawson's pronunciation was "Peps." If Mr. Carcasse rhymed with accuracy, "Bips" was the commonly accepted form. 

London Figaro 

The Tuscan Peasant 

In Tuscany, you will often find peasants whose families have been on the same farms for two or three hundred years. They talk of themselves as gents (the Roman gens) of the padrone (landlord), and take an affectionate interest in him and his family. But the Tuscan peasant is a thorough conservative; he has not yet grasped the changes brought about by railroads, steamboats, and international communication. He banks on a large extent of land on which to grow wheat enough to provide bread for the whole year, and is inclined to regard other crops as accessories. With the actual low price of corn, this does not suit the owner, particularly as in Tuscany it is customary to grow wheat two years running on the same land, with little or no manure. As soon as the corn is carried (early in July), the stubble is ploughed up and maize or millet is grown for early autumn cutting as green fodder. The yield of wheat is, of course, wretched, from six to thirteen fold, and enlightened proprietors who possess the requisite capital are dividing their larger farms and building the necessary farmhouses. 

Macmillan's Magazine 

The well-known strengthening properties of iron, combined with other tonics and a most perfect nervine, are found in Carter's Iron Pills, which strengthen the nerves and body, and improve the blood and complexion. Every house where there are young children should be supplied with Ayer's Cherry Pectoral. In croup, it gives immediate relief. 

THE WORLD OF STAGE 

The week has revealed nothing new of importance to New York theatre-goers, but at the opera there have been great doings. Monday saw the finest first performance on this continent of Verdi's "Falstaff," one of the most remarkable musical productions of the century. Possibly no opera ever written occasioned such world-wide interest and comment as did "Falstaff" on its first production in Milan just about two years ago. From "Oberto" in 1839 to "Falstaff" in 1893 marks a career practically without parallel in the annals of music; a career of many successes and few failures, and one distinguished by a greater artistic and progressive development than that which has marked the career of any other composer, not even excepting Wagner. That Verdi, after having revolutionized his own art, personally speaking, astonished the whole world by the production of "Otello," should, at the age of eighty-four, have produced an important operatic work is remarkable enough; that he should have produced a work of such commanding musical merit and interest as "Falstaff" is little short of miraculous. For many years Verdi has been desirous of writing a comic opera, or at least one from a humorous standpoint, but had searched in vain for a libretto. But when in 1890 Boito suggested "Falstaff" to him as the subject for which he was in search, the composer became enthusiastic at once, set to work, and in two years and a half had completed the opera. The material for the story the librettist took from Shakespeare's "Merry Wives of Windsor" and "King Henry IV," but for operatic purposes the story was condensed and reduced to three acts and five scenes. The characters, too, were sifted down to ten, as follows: Sir John Falstaff, Bardolph, Pistol, Ford and his Wife and their daughter Nanette (under which title Anne Page of Shakespeare's immortal comedy masquerades), Mistress Page, Dr. Caius, Mrs. Quickly, and Fenton. The opera has no overture. The curtain rises after the fourth bar and the voice begins at the eighth. 

Monday night's performance at the Metropolitan was a most excellent one for a "premiere." The central figure was, of course, Victor Maurel, and a most lifelike, sympathetic impersonation of the fat knight he gave. The reading and composition of the role, making all due allowance for the heightened hues of the operatic ideal, were wonderful. No actor on the theatrical stage today can vie with Maurel in the part. Unctuous in action, if not in voice, fidelity as to dress and action, Maurel's Falstaff is worthy to rank as a humorous pendant to his subtle Jago. He was in good voice and acted with great spirit, humor, and unfailing intelligence. He had to twice sing the charming measures in the second act, "Quando ero paggio del Duca di Norfolk." In a word, his creation of Falstaff is a masterpiece. Emma Karnes, the Mistress Ford, was the only woman who had any idea of costuming and of her environment. She looked early-English, and very lovely, and she sang with brilliancy. Campanari, the artist that he always is, was Ford, and sang nobly. Scalchi was not very convincing as Dame Quickly, Miss Itano was a sweet Teuton, and Zalie de Lussan a colorless Anne. Jane de Vigue was Mistress Page. There was no Master Page and no Blunder in the libretto, but our old friends, Bardolph, Pistol, and Dr. Caius were in evidence. The opera scored a triumph, and it bids fair to be a second "Carmen" success. Certainly, it is the most significant apparition in the world of opera since "Otello." 

As for the orchestration, says a New York critic, it is simply a never-ending charm, with delicacy of handling, such color-sense, such tact and characterization! The first act is broadly humorous; the second has a tragic note, and the third is suffused with a poetic glow, and in all is the salt of life—humor, kindly humor, is a reproach to the younger generation of driveling pessimistic composers of today. Mancinelli conducted, and came in for his share of flowers and bravos. Besides, it was his birthday, and his stand was ornamented with flowers, and he got a fanfare when he took up his baton. It was a great night for Verdi, for Maurel, and Mancinelli. 

"Samson et Dalila," which was given its initial performance at the Metropolitan on Friday evening, is one of the earliest of Camille Saint-Saëns' larger compositions. He was still organist of the Madeleine when it was written, in 1877, and received its first performance in the drawing-room of Madame Pauline Viardot, in Paris, where many a famous work has been heard. Some three years later Weimar saw it in 1877; it was produced at Rouen in 1890, and a couple of years later it was added to the repertoire at the Paris Opera. The libretto is the work of M. Lemaire, a cousin of the composer, and differs in many essential particulars from the Biblical story. Dalila is a priestess of Dagon, and when she witnesses the slaying of Abimelech, and the revolt of the Israelites, headed by Samson, she resolves to encompass the leader's ruin. In the second act, Samson is before the house of the temptress, in the valley of Horek, and falls a victim to her wiles, the Philistines stealing upon the helpless giant as the curtain falls. In the last act, Samson is led into the temple and tears down the pillars, burying himself under the ruins with his jeering enemies. The two principal characters are played by Mme. Mantelli and Signor Tainagno. Signor Campanari appears as the High Priest, M. Plancon as Abimelech, and the other roles are played by Signori Kinaldini, Vanni, and de Vacchetti. 

"Tristan and Isolde" will open the season of German opera in the Metropolitan on the 25th inst., with Frau Rose as Isolde, Frl. Marie as Brangäne, Herr Franz Schwarz as Kurwenal, Herr Paul Lange as the Seaman, Herr Rudolph Oberhauser as Melot, Herr Emil Fischer as King Marke, and Herr Max Aivary as Tristan. "Siegfried," with Herr Aivary in the title role, will be given the same week by Frau Schuber, Miss Marcella Lindh, and Herr Lange, Schwarz, Behrens, and Oberhauser. "Lohengrin" will introduce Frl. Godski as Elsa, and Herr Nicholaus Bothmühl as Lohengrin; the Ortrud being Frl. Brema, Herr Franz Schwarz appearing as Telramund and Herr Oberhauser as the Herald. The performance will be under the direction of Mr. Walter Damrosch. 

Tony Pastor says: "When Lillian Russell came to me she was a slender, awkward girl of sixteen, but her face was a picture. It was a girlish beauty that has developed with womanhood into the glorious beauty that has made her famous. That night was an awful trial for her. She didn't know what to do with her hands. Frank Gerard, once a cannon-ball tosser, was the stage manager of my theatre then. He told me that he gave Lillian her first instructions: 'Just clasp your hands behind your back and leave them there while singing.' Her first song was a simple little thing; to see her second and her third, but she sang them all with such exquisite sweetness that even her audience of sporting men and men about town, not always bad critics either, was generously enthusiastic." 

"Robber Roy," a new burlesque, was produced at the Imperial Music Hall, New York, on Monday. The piece is in three acts. The first scene is laid among the Highlands of Scotland where Rob Roy McGregor and his clan are gathered. A message comes offering them all places on the New York police force. Of course, they accept, and in the next scene, which shows the exterior of the Manhattan Athletic Club, they appear in their new uniforms as members of the "finest." In the last act, the interior of the club is shown while a vaudeville performance is in progress. A raid by the new police force brings the whole to a close. There are numerous local hits, and the new burlesque promises to have a long and successful run. 

A new melodrama "Humanity," by W. H. E. Ibe Monil Wan. 

Evidently an International Affair. 

New York, February 8. The blizzard has effectively blockaded navigation in the harbor. Ferryboats are running under great difficulties. The boat plying between this city and Liberty Island is not running on account of the heavy ice in the harbor. Off Liberty Island, the British ship Frankenstein, ready to sail for Shanghai, is caught in the ice and dragging her anchor toward Brooklyn. A tug has gone to her assistance. The British steamer Greenlands, lying at the Commercial Wharf, Brooklyn, which was to have sailed at 5 o'clock this morning for Gibara, Cuba, is frozen fast in the ice, and will scarcely be able to get out today. Erie Basin is completely tied up. Travel on the suburban railroads is greatly impeded by the storm. The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western road is reported completely blocked. The Jersey Central got four through trains into the city at 10 o'clock, but only one went out before that hour. The freight traffic on this road was frozen up early last night, and the side tracks are lined with coal and freight cars. The fishing schooner Emma was driven ashore near Swinburne Island last night and became a wreck. The captain and four seamen reached shore in a small boat, after terrible suffering. Four men took to the other boat and are missing. According to E. B. Dunn, weather prophet, today's storm is worse than the famous blizzard of March 12-15, 1888, in several ways—in wind, temperature, and the area affected. Only in snowfall was the storm of 1888 greater than in today's. Mercury will probably go 10 below zero tomorrow morning. At 2:00 o'clock this afternoon, there were seventeen crafts stalled in the harbor. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

Ice in the vicinity of the Battery. The N.Y., February 8. Snow about a foot deep on the level fell last night. The wind was violent and the snow drifted. At ten o'clock this forenoon, no train had reached here from New York on either the Hudson River or West Shore roads. Lockport, N.Y., February 8. The worst blizzard within the memory of the present generation is raging here. No trains have reached here from any direction this morning, and business is nearly suspended. Newport, H.J. 8 Cache & Co., of New York, Telegraph Meters Meredith & O'Brien as follows: "The feature of today's market is the issue of the bond call, the facts being revealed in a message to Congress from the President. Prior to this announcement, the market had been very heavy as the Administration bill had suffered a very heavy defeat yesterday in the House. At first, traders were somewhat bewildered as a number of rumors were in circulation, but the facts in the case are that the President sells $62,317,600 of thirty-year 4 percent bonds, for which the Treasury is to get three and a half million ounces of gold, which will bring the reserve in the Treasury up to a little above the $100,000,000 mark. The syndicate formed will get half of this gold from Europe, while the other half will be supplied from this side. The rate at which the bonds were sold to the syndicate, 5½ percent, was a surprise, it being a higher price than had been anticipated, and the general list broke quite badly, closing with but a small rally. Some of the foregoing details may not be correct in every particular, but the facts are that Mr. Cleveland has shown his determination to take care of the Treasury's finances. The news, however, that the Government is compelled to sell bonds on a 3 percent basis is nothing to boast about. In former years, it has been the proud boast of this country that its credit was ahead of all other countries, judging from the price of its bonds. This has now all been changed, and when the people realize the situation, they will very readily see the cause of this, which is that our legislators have been content to play cheap politics rather than take care of the country's needs, and that the country at large has been made to suffer; the syndicate price, namely 3½ percent, will open the eyes of the taxpayers to this fact, and it will, in our opinion, lead to a better realization of the situation and avert another and severer object lesson. We think the market will be lower as the money market will harden from this on, and the bank statement will show about $5,000,000 decrease, and when the money for the bond issue has been paid into the Treasury, the reserve will show another large shrinkage. The money market has been so easy for years that a tightening of rates will no doubt influence prices. Regarding earnings, some may be temporarily interfered with by the blizzard in the West, and we expect the St. Paul earnings for the second week to show a big decrease; still, people must not forget that this is not the time to be bearish as conditions in the mercantile world are not on the mend. 

MacDongall Bros., stock brokers, 69 St. Francois Xavier street, report the closing prices on the New York Stock Exchange today as follows: Stocks, American Cotton Oil, American Sugar Refining Co. pref, American Tobacco 110, pref, Atchison, C.I. & A., Keynote National. The first number of this new monthly shows that Captain Chartrand has at last deserved success. The Lieutenant-Governor, Mr. Laurier, Mr. Mantel, Mr. Marchand, Mr. Beausoleil, Mr. David, and Mr. Perrault wish the new venture success and adorn its pages with their photographs. Mr. Joseph Royal contributes a pleasantly written domestic sketch, "Les Amours d'un Notaire," and Mr. Louis Frechette a charming little poem, "À Ma Petite Louise." Dr. Hinstone discusses the influence of the Canadian climate in an interesting paper, and Mr. Dansereau writes learnedly on the mechanism of the eye. Mr. Benjamin Bulte has a historical study, "Fort Frontenac, 1673-84." Mr. Jos Marmette begins a serial story, Mr. John Hague deals with finances, Mr. Ch. des Carres with foreign affairs, while the ladies' corner is under the care of "Françoise." It will be seen that Captain Chartrand has secured the services of some of the ablest of our French-Canadian writers, and their work is presented in very pleasing style, paper and print being all that could be desired. 

The Grand Trunk Coal Tenders. The coal men still continue in town. What with the blizzardy state of the weather and the uncertain train communication, and the still greater uncertainty as to who of the mighty host of gems and owners have been successful in securing the big contracts, the great majority determined last night to remain in Montreal another night. Another ten hours will decide the question, but already rumors as to the successful ones are flying thick and fast. The disappointed ones are taking revenge for their loss of time and trouble by spreading broadcast statements of terms, quantities, etc., altogether impossible. Some of them, while condoling with each other in the expectation of defeat, are so palpably on the tenterhooks of uncertainty as to be positively amusing. 

Mr. H. Bartolo, Mr. Allan Macduff, Mrs. Wallace, and Misses B. Dyer, L. Potter, Anna Miles, and F. da Fontoura. St. John the Evangelist's Dean Norman's many friends in the local area will be glad to learn that they will shortly have an opportunity of again hearing him lecture. He has kindly consented to speak on Shakespeare's play "Julius Caesar," in the Church of St. John the Evangelist's Parish hall, Ontario street, on Tuesday evening next at eight o'clock. The Dean is a devoted Shakespearean scholar, and that he will treat the subject in an interesting manner goes without saying. 

The Opening Postponed. The president and directors of the United Counties Railway Company had issued invitations to a large number of friends to attend the formal opening of the road today, leaving the Bonaventure depot at nine o'clock and returning to the city by seven. In consequence of the severe storm, however, the inauguration has been postponed until a future date. 

Ancient Order of Foresters. There was a good attendance at Court Unity last night. After business, a program was gone through very creditably. Pro Wheble, of Court Reliance, contributed to the evening's enjoyment by singing several songs. Bros. Silverwood, Scruton, Davidson, Green, and McDowell, of Court Unity, also took part. It is intended to visit Court Reliance on Tuesday next. 

Found in Time. An old man was found asleep in a pile of snow at the corner of Craig and Gosford Streets last evening. He was half frozen and was taken to the Central Police Station where he was cared for. His hands were bare, and it was all he could do to hold the snow shovel he had been using. He had a cloth cap on and a short jacket but no overcoat. 

Death of Mrs. Owen Drury. The death occurred last evening at 41 St. Alexander street, of Mrs. Owen Drury. The deceased lady was a sister of Messrs. Bernard, Denis, and Owen Tansey, and mother of Mrs. James Drury, of the Gazette newsroom. She had been ill for some time. Mrs. Drury possessed a large circle of friends, to whom her death will be a great grief. 

The Snow and the Railroad. The snowstorm and blizzard played havoc with the service on the Grand Trunk and Canadian Pacific yesterday; all the trains due in the city in the morning got in all the way from two hours to eight hours late, and some of the outgoing trains left on time. On the Grand Trunk, many of the local trains were cancelled. 

Mr. Floquin, Sr., Dead. Another of the men of 1837 has passed away in the person of Charles Pelquin, who died yesterday at Sault-au-Récollet at the age of 73 years. Deceased, who did business formerly at St. Jude's, was the father of fifteen children, one of them being Mr. 

THE CRIMINAL COURTS. 

Lanieri Paid to Appear in an Enquete. Paid $21 for a Kiss. "They were not present; that was the only trouble," remarked Judge Dugas yesterday afternoon in the Police court, when he gave a roasting to the lawyers who had cases in enquete for not being there when the cases were called, and as the judge said, it was a shame, in such a storm, to bring out witnesses and put them to such inconvenience. In the morning, there were two prisoners before the court, which took up all its attention. These were Stanislas Veroneau and Philippe Léveque. These gentlemen of leisure had been arrested by High Constable Bissonnette for stealing sheep, but when the case came up, it came out that there were four cases, and the result was a long investigation. It came out that they had been living on the farmers in the vicinity of their residence, and that when they wanted meat, they simply went to a barn and stole the first sheep they could find and then proceeded to cut its throat and skin the carcass. The court said that this was a most flagrant case and sentenced the first named to twenty-three months in jail and the other to twelve months. Twenty-five dollars is a high price to pay for a kiss, but this is what Casimir Dault had to pay yesterday in the Recorder's court for one. The party who was the means of his doing this was Madeline Favard, who swore that while she was employed as a domestic in the Winnipeg house, on Windsor street, the accused kissed her by force. 

THE WAY OF THE BLIZZARD. Yesterday's blizzard was the worst of the season for many years, and fortunes were lost. Those who could not venture out remained indoors during the evening and enjoyed the comfort of smoking Hirsch's Perique Mixture. Headquarters for the same, Hirsch's Havana Cigar depot, opposite the 2nd and 3rd division of the same road. 

Exeter, Ont., February 8. A regular northwest blizzard has been raging here all day with unabated fury, with the temperature about 3 below zero. The roads will be badly blocked up by morning. The trains on the L.R. train, which left here this morning, had to return, being unable to get through the drifts on the Queenston mountain. The trail stage from Niagara Falls managed to get through, though several hours late. The temperature is still below zero. 

Barbie, Ont., February 8. The thermometer is 10 below zero, and it is snowing and blowing a terrific gale. The roads are blocked up fast, railway traffic greatly impeded, and many cases of frozen faces have been reported. 

Montreal, Ont., February 8. Special. An ice bridge has formed at Baker's Point, just east of Farran's Point. Floating ice has filled the river as far west as Aultsville and is still filling in. The water has risen here nearly two feet in twenty-four hours and is still rising. Unless something is done at once to remove the bridge, serious damage may result in this town and vicinity. 

Lindsay, Ont., February 8. There was a light fall of snow during last night, which, with a high northwest wind, has turned into a real blizzard. All trains are very late, with every prospect of their being entirely snowed and drifted up. Business is at a standstill, very few people venturing out. The thermometer is below zero and the storm is increasing. 

Hawkesbury, Ont., February 8. Severe snowstorm; fall continues; about nine inches of snow has fallen; roads blocked. 

Hunt's Falls, Ont., February 8. This is the worst storm of the season. About eight inches of snow has fallen, and it is still snowing heavily and drifting very badly. The roads are impassable, and all trains are many hours late. 

Cornwall, Ont., February 8. A heavy gale has been blowing here from the north and east since last night. The thermometer registered 20 below zero. Trains are from one to two hours late. 

Peterborough, Ont., February 8. A blinding snowstorm set in here early this morning, accompanied by very high north and northwest winds. Travel through the country is almost entirely suspended, and all trains are from two to five hours late. 

Napanee, Ont., February 8. A severe storm set in about 10 o'clock last night and still continues. The mixed trains are cancelled, and all express trains are late. 

Port Hope, Ont., February 8. The storm of last night was one of the most severe of the season. Trains on the C.K. are from one to two hours late. The Brockville and Westport Train, however, arrived only a few minutes late.

**Mes hue Lom on, Ont, February 8**  
The worst storm in for many years is now raging here. Business is completely at a standstill. The Humane Society officers are looking sharply after the streetcar horses, and they have stopped all but the cars on Lunulas and Richmond streets, and have sent a large number of horses to the stables. Reports from various places in this section show that the storm is very severe.

**C-KAioinn, Ont, February 8**  
At noon today we are experiencing the wildest snowstorm and blizzard from the west ever seen here, and the cold is intense. Business is practically suspended.

**Wnmiv, February 8**  
With the thermometer 11 below and a terrible north wind, accompanied by large particles more cutting than snow, the storm now raging makes this the worst day of the winter.

**Bicihkviij p, February 8**  
A fine snowfall during most of the night continues today. The temperature was 8 below zero, and at noon was still 2 below. Three stagecoaches had not arrived up to 2 p.m., and all freights and the mixed on the Grand Trunk Railway were cancelled. The mails from the West were over an hour late.

**Kknfrkw, Ont, February 8**  
Strong north-westerly winds; snowing and drifting.

**PmmuoKE, Ont, February 8**  
The weather is very cold and stormy, and the roads are badly drifted; it is still snowing.

**Jskpiimas, Ont, February 8**  
The worst storm of the season began about 12 o'clock last night. It is still snowing. All roads are blocked. Not one sleigh from the country has been seen in the village; it is very cold with high winds.

**Plktaoknt, Ont, February 8**  
A snowfall of about 8 inches. Still snowing at 1 p.m. and drifting, which makes the roads almost impassable.

**Aikxanuria, Ont, February 8**  
Weather mild; very little wind. Snowstorm began at an early hour this morning and still continues. About eight inches have fallen. The roads are badly blocked and are almost impassable.

**Pkmh, Ont, February 8**  
We are having a very heavy storm. The roads are all blocked. Trains from the East are one hour late. No news from the West on how trains are. Snow has fallen to the depth of six inches and drifting badly.

**IN OLEHKR PROVINCE**  
The storm was fully as severe as it was in Ontario.

**QiiiLC, February 8 (Special)**  
The storm today was one of the worst of the season, the wind having attained a velocity of 60 miles an hour, and huge snow drifts are piled up on the streets. Tonight, after the east wind went down somewhat, it veered about and commenced storming from the west. There were specially high tides tonight, and the effect of the strong east winds has blown up the water of the river to such an extent that the lower parts of the city were all inundated. In St. Roch's, the water was two or three feet deep on Prince Edward Street, and cellars as far back from St. Charles as Deslosses Street were flooded. In Lower Town, D'Aubigny Street and the stores about Finley Market were flooded, and considerable damage was done in the flour store. It is expected that in many cases the loss will be heavy. All the trains today were late.

**M. Tin cotte & Co**  
The water stood four feet in the basement of Messrs. Thibaudeau Frere & Co, but this firm was not to be caught napping and had removed everything of value to safe places, leaving only a few empty packing cases for the flood. A funeral was blockaded on the little river road in the afternoon. The hearse got jammed in a snowbank. The horses were unharnessed and placed in a stable close by, and the hearse passed the night in the snowbank. An old man, named Bussiere, a milkman from Little River, was found almost frozen to death under his horse near Lorett. The old man is 70 years of age. His horse was blinded by the blizzard and unable to proceed on its way. The animal broke away from the sleigh, but had only proceeded a short distance when it became stuck hard and fast in a snowbank. Bussiere reached the horse and sheltered himself under it. When found, the unfortunate old man was in an almost dying condition. He will probably die. At Hedleyville and at Levis, the water was several feet deep. An ice bridge formed here in the river opposite the city today but went down with the ice this evening, and it may jam again when it ascends with the turn of the tide.

**Montreal, Ont, February 10**  
The situation of the ice bridge remains unchanged. At this writing, floating ice and snow has blocked the river as far west as Weaver's Point, three miles above Ants-ville, and is still filling in. The water here has risen about a foot in the last twenty-four hours. Considerable indignation is expressed at the Government for not taking steps earlier in having the bridge cut out when it was first seen; it being too late now. A flood seems inevitable. Parties in this vicinity are removing rowboats, etc., which shows a flood is expected. As this bridge is swung every season, it is high time the Government take some action to prevent its swinging, or when swung to cut it out immediately, and thus save a lot of trouble and damage to property which always follows.

**Across the Lines**  
**Philadelphia, February 10**  
The snow blockade on the Pennsylvania and Reading railways was practically raised today. Trains on the main lines of both roads are running, but a little behind time. On the Reading, the first through train from New York since Thursday afternoon reached here at 9 o'clock this evening by a roundabout way. The branches of both roads are still badly snowed under, and a number of trains are stalled in various parts, and their passengers are being cared for in farmhouses along the lines. The most serious situation is on the Delaware railroad in Delaware. Four passenger trains are walled in by big drifts at different points along the road, and they may not be reached by relief trains before tomorrow morning. These trains have been snowed in since Friday, and the passengers must have suffered greatly from cold and exposure. On all the branch lines of the Delaware road, not a wheel is turning, and all small towns are cut off from obtaining their usual supplies.

**New York, February 10**  
The aftereffects of the big storm on the railroads running into Jersey City were slowly dissipating themselves today, but there was still some trouble. The Pennsylvania road tonight announced the resumption of its train service to all points except on a few of its unimportant branches. The Lackawanna is clear to Buffalo. At the Grand Central station, the New York Central reported that there had been a fresh storm on the Buffalo and Mohawk divisions. The road was quickly assuming its normal conditions, but there was more or less delay in all directions.

**On the Other Side**  
**Dublin, February 10**  
An unprecedented snowstorm has blocked traffic throughout the south of Ireland today. The American mail, which left Dublin this morning, has been unable to get beyond Charleville. The Cork trains for Dublin are fast in the snow near Banteer, fifteen miles from here. The snow falls so rapidly as to prevent clearing the tracks.

**London, February 10**  
The extreme cold throughout the United Kingdom still prevails. Isolated cases of skaters drowning were reported today, and many churches caught fire this morning from overheated flues, but none were destroyed.

**T. McGrath, editor of the Herald**

**Common Sense**  
(Should be used in attempting to cure that very disagreeable disease, catarrh. As catarrh originates in impurities in the blood, local applications can do no permanent good. The common-sense method of treatment is to purify the blood, and for this purpose, there is no preparation superior to Hood's Sarsaparilla. Boon's Pills cure constipation by restoring peristaltic action to the alimentary canal.)

**10 O'Higgins**  
(Continued from First Page)  
The Teutonic, from Queenstown, January 31, with 212 cabin and 199 steerage passengers, came up to quarantine this morning. The Teutonic arrived at the bar at 7:04 p.m. last night and was detained outside 25 hours, owing to a heavy snowstorm and blizzard. Time of passage: 7 days, 11 hours, and 1 minute. Day's runs: 477, 481, 478, 488, 330, 228, 240, and 136 to Sandy Hook. Distance: 2,804 knots. The Teutonic was within three miles of Sandy Hook at 5:38 p.m. Thursday, but owing to a hurricane from the east.

**18950212:**  
**H, 12 Banning on Scheduled Time**  
The electric cars for Outremont were seen standing at their usual waiting post at the foot of Bleury Street on Sunday in spite of the terrific storms of last week. Prof. Carus-Wilson, with another gentleman of McGill, went on the plough and sweeper with Messrs. Corriveau and Mar-pie on Saturday afternoon, experiencing the hard battle the Park and Island Railway Company was having in fighting the blizzard and ploughing through the snowbanks of from 9 to 10 feet on the Outremont division. On account of the hard-packed snow in Mile End, the Back River line did not get on schedule time before Sunday night; but, although the drifts lay from eight to twelve feet deep in many places, and the wind drifted the snow across the rails almost as fast as the ploughs and sweepers could clear it out, the cars have been well on time ever since. The company received many congratulatory messages for the manner in which it had mastered the heavy storm.

**A Scare Firing Through the Air**  
There was quite a lively time on Saturday night at a certain fashionable boarding house on University Street. One of the boarders became suddenly excited and, seizing a couple of razors, attacked a fellow boarder named Mr. Vesy U. Wigmore. The latter was in bed and took a flying leap to get out of the way, and with great dexterity struck the razors out of the other's hand. The attacking party then retreated to his room, but almost immediately returned with a revolver, swearing that he would have Mr. Wigmore's heart's blood. The latter, thinking discretion the necessary virtue just then, skipped into the street in only his shirt and a short jacket, preferring the cruel blasts of Boreas to being bored by a pistol ball. Finally, the revolver was taken away from the sanguinary boarder, and his friends are watching to see that he does not break out again in a fresh place.

At a special general meeting of the shareholders of the Bell Telephone Company, held yesterday, a by-law was passed authorizing the directors to issue bonds to the extent of $600,000 at 5 percent.

**18950218:**  
K. Woodward asked his opinion on the subject of cutting dogs' ears and tails, a practice which the Prince of Wales has recently condemned very strongly. Dr. Mills said that his opinion on the subject was very decided. A mutilation of nature's handiwork rarely effected any improvement. It was a cruel practice to cut dogs' ears, and generally it was not done properly, and the dog's appearance was spoiled. If their tails were cut when they were very young, it did not hurt them much when done properly.

**The Jacques Cartier Ice Track**  
Not discouraged by the great blizzard which prevented the race meeting of two weeks ago from being carried out, the proprietors of the Jacques Cartier Ice Track announce an attractive program for Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of this week, when $1,000 will be offered in purses. It is expected that quite a number of the horses which competed at the Hamilton meeting last week will come down for these races, and with others expected from Ottawa and the Townships, three days of excellent sport are assured. Entries will close tonight at the Turf house, corner Boy and St. Lawrence streets, where pools will be sold on the events each evening during the meeting. Hamilton, Ontario, February 16. The fourth and last day of the Hamilton Jockey Club's trotting races opened with beautiful weather and a magnificent track. The ice was flooded again last night and was smooth as glass. The attendance was only fair. The 2:25 unfinished race of yesterday was won by Grimsby Girl, Nettie Y second, and Hamlet third; time, 2:14. 

**SKOLH Winter in England**  
London, February 21. The continued cold weather in Great Britain is having a most serious effect in all parts of the country. Aside from the suffering involved, the low temperature has caused a practical standstill of all horse training and hunting during the last six weeks. A number of important race meetings, including the big military steeplechase at Sandown Park, fixed for yesterday, and the Manchester February meeting, have been entirely abandoned. One distressing feature of the situation is that fully two-thirds of the houses in London are entirely without their usual water supply, in consequence of the freezing of the water. An extraordinary scene was witnessed on Wednesday last in front of the Mansion House, the official residence of the Lord Mayor, in connection with the intensely cold weather. A large number of people gathered there in consequence of the circulation of a false report that the Lord Mayor had issued a proclamation warning the citizens of London of the near approach of an enormous blizzard, which would impede all traffic and cause cessation of business. It was also reported that the proclamation urged the people to provide themselves with a full stock of provisions for three days in order to be prepared for any emergency, and also warned all citizens to be within the doors of their residences before midnight on Thursday in order to escape being overtaken by the elements. Skaters, however, in England have never had such an excellent opportunity for indulging in sport on the ice, and the lakes and ponds, all of which are frozen over, are crowded day and night. The interests of society are centered in the daily skating parties which have been held on the lake in Buckingham Palace gardens, at which the Prince of Wales and his daughters, the Princesses Victoria and Maud, the Duke and Duchess of York, Princess Henry of Battenberg, who is a beautiful skater; Lord Marcus Beresford, Sir Francis Edmund George Astley-Corbett, son of the Prince of Wales' friend the late Sir John Dugdale Astley, a noted patron of sports, and numbers of other prominent persons, were in daily attendance. Hockey matches on the ice, beginning at 3 o'clock in the afternoon and lasting until 5 o'clock, when tea and other hot drinks were served, have been the features of these parties. The most notable match was played on Thursday afternoon between teams captained by the Prince of Wales and Mr. Francis Midmay.

**CALIFORNIA ORANGES**  
There is much interest in green fruit circles concerning the condition of California oranges in view of the damage to oranges by the blizzard which swept across the Florida peninsula Christmas week; also the damage to the crop in Valencia, Spain, and the subsequent reduction of the crop of oranges in Aderno and Sicily by hailstorms. The orange dealers in this city are anxious to obtain some definite information regarding the orange crop and weather in California. A prominent California shipper was conversed with on the subject yesterday at the Fifth Avenue hotel. He said in reply to questions: "During the early part of last month the weather in Los Angeles and surrounding sections was moderately cool. Frosts in the latter part of last month were frequent, and very naturally have caused some fear among the growers of oranges and lemons. Up to date, however, no damage has been sustained, except to some of the most delicate vegetables in exposed places. At this time interest is pretty much centered in the better prospects for marketing the oranges. The recent despatches announcing the destruction of the Spanish crop of Valencia by frost have created a feeling among the exchanges in California that with the Florida disaster it will give them a grand opportunity for making a wider distribution of their fruit. It is also claimed, through these misfortunes of their competitors, that they intend to hold to high prices. From what I learned of the situation when in Los Angeles, it may be inferred that some of the growers are laboring under misapprehension respecting the competition of foreign crops with their own relative to prices. It has been announced authoritatively that the Southern Fruit Exchange of Los Angeles have fixed their prices and intend to stay right with them. They are not sufficiently high to give the growers a good profit, which they are deserving of. The step taken to maintain high prices has occasioned numerous complaints from the East, the dealers intimating that they will handle foreign oranges. Nearly or in fact all the packing houses are busy, and the fruit is moving well to a good market. Riverside, Highlands, Colton, Pomona, and Redlands are marketing their oranges with excellent results. California will be a leading spirit in filling the gap caused by the recent freeze in Florida, with the assistance of the Mediterranean fruits.

**DROWNING ACCIDENT**  
I happened to be left here to attend a dance at Charles Shipman’s in one of D. Lloyd's livery rigs and a very valuable horse, and drove into open water. As soon as the men found they were in the water they jumped, but the ice wouldn’t hold them. Their cries attracted the farmers along the river, who got them out terribly exhausted. The horse and cutter are at the bottom of the river in 70 feet of water. 

**SOUTHERN SNOWSTORM EXTENDS**  
From the Mississippi to the Atlantic. St. Louis, March 20. A snowstorm in this vicinity has been raging during the past 24 hours. Reports from Southern Missouri and Illinois show that the storm has been severe in these sections. Railway traffic is greatly impeded. The storm is still raging and is the most severe in years. The snow is six inches deep and is drifting. At Percy, Ills., a steady northwest gale with blinding snow and minute particles of ice is blowing at the rate of 42 miles an hour. The snow has drifted three and four feet deep in places. 

**Demi-ov, Tex., March 20**  
A terrific sandstorm, filling the air with sand, swept over this section last night. Houses were unroofed, trees blown down, and a great deal of damage done. It was the most violent windstorm ever experienced in this section. It is not known that any lives were lost. 

**Roanoke, Va., March 20**  
Roanoke was given another touch of winter today. A blizzard raged during the forenoon, and snow continued to fall all the afternoon and evening. Trains were delayed. 

**Charles, Va., March 20**  
About five inches of snow fell on the peninsula today.

**THE SUMMER CYCLISTS**  
Good Shooter at the Traps Racing in the States. Miscellaneous Sporting. The intermediate lacrosse braves are evidently mixing the colors for their season's war paint, judging by the numerous meetings now being held and the genial smile which frequently lights up the face of one of the intermediate princes of lobbyists who is on the warpath as an organizer of certain combinations. The seniors are for the moment lost in the meshes of obscurity, and no other subject is now being discussed by lacrosse people except what clubs will constitute the intermediate championship league during the coming summer. In the West, the feeling seems to be to give the Quebecers the cold shoulder, but in this city, especially amongst the Shamrocks, the idea seems to be to have the Quebecers in the combination. Then, again, there is the Nationals club to count upon. They are going to be considerably more than a cipher in the grand total which will be made up at the end of the season. There seems to be no reference made whatever to them. The Crescents and the disgruntled members of the ex-champion team are seemingly going to unite their forces, but the question again arises, will they have any place in the favorite league? It seems impossible to have more than two teams entered from this city in any championship league which will include teams from Ottawa and Quebec and, perhaps, Brockville, because the length of the season would not permit it unless the middlemen are anxious for a repetition of that sickly spectacle of playing a match in a blizzard, such as occurred at Ottawa last season. Those are the following clubs, which would make an excellent and interesting league series: Young Shamrocks, Quebec, Stars of Ottawa, Ottawa, Nationals, Brockville, and Montrealers. It is even doubtful if the latter will enter against the other clubs named, because the Juniors, which played intermediate last year, in all probability may rather desire to look for the junior district championship against the Junior Shamrocks and the Junior Nationals as well as a number of other junior clubs who are now seeking a place in another series. The coming battle for league building will create quite a little stir, as the Crescents will make a lively bid for a place. At present, it looks as though they might be out of the race with the first-class teams in the intermediate series. Another feature of the rumors in connection with the movements of the intermediates is that they are growing less enthusiastic in their views regarding the usefulness of the Nationals.

**AT THE HORSE SHOW**  
Perhaps the most attractive feature at the horse show yesterday was the exhibition under the auspices of the Montreal Hunt. These classes provided something different from the usual run of agricultural shows and resulted in proving that there is really better horse flesh and more showy than is usually thought of in this part of the country. We cannot run a week's show as they do in New York, and unfortunately have not the constituency to cater to who care for horses, as is the case in Toronto. But when these disabilities are taken into consideration, there is only credit to be given to the Montreal Hunt, whose members are naturally anxious that everything equine should be up to the top notch. In the harness classes, there was as neat an all-round turn-out as could be wished for, and the decision of the judges gave general satisfaction, with perhaps the exception of class 5, single horses in harness, over 15.2. General opinion seemed to favor the style of Mr. Meighen's horse, but the judges thought otherwise, and that settled it. There was not a large attendance, but those who were there knew the difference between a horse and any other animal. Among the most interested spectators was Mr. Koutledge, of Virden, Manitoba, who is a thorough believer in the Canadian Northwest as a breeding country, and who has been following up precept by example. He has been breeding a good thoroughbred, Dean Swift, to the best half-bred mares he could find, and the result is a splendid lot on the ranch, of which he has brought eleven east, all thoroughly broken. A particularly nice one is a thoroughbred filly by Dean Swift, dam Queen of the West by imp Norfolk out of Grace Darling. The dam has done a mile in 1:42. There is also a fine looking two-year-old thoroughbred by Dean Swift that horsemen will take an interest in.

**Alexander Island Race**  
Alexander Island, April 25. The heat was intense and the majority of the crowd picked winners and elbowed through the betting ring in shirt sleeves. The attendance was fully up to the average. The track was dry and the jockeys have been reinstated. President Jones was asked today what he would do in case St. Asaph raced in opposition to his track. He said he had given the matter no thought and would not until he was certain opposition was certain. First race 6½ furlongs: Commuter, 110 Morris, 1 to 2, 1; Blizzard, 110 Ham, 15 to 1, 2.

**TUESDAY, MAY 14, 1895**  
PRICE TWO CENTS  
**DEADLY JACK FROST**  
Does Much Damage in a Great Many Places  
**FOOT OF SNOW IN MICHIGAN**  
And Indiana is Also Suffering From a Big Blizzard  
**FRUIT CROP IS RUINED**  
In the Chautauqua Region of New York  
**BESIEGED BY FROST**  
On the Niagara Peninsula to Small Fruit Crops. Many Montrealians donned their winter overcoats yesterday by way of compensating for the hurried discarding of underclothing, owing to the hot spell of last week. But many still felt that the...

--- 

This text has been corrected for clarity and readability while maintaining the original meaning and formatting. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed:

---

An unusually quick drop in the temperature was anything but pleasant. The records at the Observatory showed that such a prolonged spell of hot weather as last week has seldom been experienced, even in mid-summer. During six days, the highest temperature at three PM was 87, the lowest 81, and the mean 84, with corresponding high readings during the afternoon and night. Between Saturday night and noon yesterday, there was a drop of 24 degrees. That was the reason city people felt chilled. Yet they were not alone in their experience. The cold snap has extended west as far as Ohio and Michigan, east to Quebec, and south over the northern half of New York, affecting early fruit more or less severely within these bounds. Complete reports are not yet to hand, but it is feared the damage will be great. According to dispatches from the Niagara Peninsula received in this city yesterday, the destruction of early fruit in that district has been terrible, while there is scarcely an intervening fruit section that has not felt the effects of the cool snap. The following message from St. Catharines, Ont., received yesterday by Messrs. Hart & Tuckwell, the well-known fruit dealers of McGill Street, gives an indication of the damage done in that section of the country. It stated: "The thermometer, which ranged between 85 and 90 degrees most of last week, took a sudden drop on Sunday morning, and during Sunday night and Monday morning, sad havoc was wrought in the Niagara district. Hundreds of acres of grapes, just bursting into leaf, were burned black. Peaches and garden stuff are also probably ruined. Altogether, the blow to the fruit-growing industry here is a severe one. At five o'clock this morning, the thermometer registered from 21 to 26 degrees, according to location." 

Further messages received by this firm from Windsor, Meaford, Niagara, Ont., Chatham, Thorold, Port Dalhousie, Hamilton, Paris, Beamsville, Amherstburg, Toronto, and other places show that great damage was done by frost Sunday night. Plums, early apples, pears, grapes, strawberries, and other small fruits, where advanced enough, especially suffered. The thermometer had registered as low as 25 at some points. Grain had escaped, but mention of strawberries was made in nearly all of the reports. Around Port Dalhousie, a dispatch stated, ice had been an inch thick. Hopes were entertained that the grapes would recover. 

"A very serious disaster to the fruit growers of the peninsula," said Mr. Hart, commenting on the dispatches, "that is, the Niagara district, because they depend upon their fruit crop altogether, but the outlook may not be as bad as the reports make it appear. Again, it may turn out very much worse than anticipated; it is almost impossible that the ground could have been all gone over yet or that the fruit growers could have compared notes so soon. Peas, tomatoes, beans, and small fruit come under the head of what is called 'garden stuff.' Although we have had no reports, I understand there has been no frost locally. A good many of the strawberry beds all over the country must be protected by hills, and I hope the fruit has not been so much injured as anticipated. At all events, it is too early yet to form an opinion as to what the extent of the damage will be. We cannot tell where we will draw our supplies from until we hear further reports."

Across the Lines: Detroit, Mich., May 13. Reports from 9 to 11 inches of snow; Davison, 10 inches; Oscoda, 3 inches and still snowing; Lewiston, 8 inches and still snowing; Menominee, 4 inches with all gardens and many fruit and shade trees ruined, and Manistee, 2 inches. The frost did no damage to fruit trees at Grand Haven, and it is believed that generally throughout the state, fruit has escaped serious injury. 

Grand Rapids, Mich., May 13. Western and Northern Michigan was visited by a heavy storm today, and grave fears are felt for fruit, as the storm is heaviest throughout the fruit belt. In this city, the fall of snow commenced about 3 PM and is not as great as is reported from the northern part of the state, where railroad traffic is badly hindered. At Mancelona, snow to the depth of 18 inches is reported. The snow is accompanied by a fierce north wind. 

Pittsburgh, May 11. Dispatches from points in Western Pennsylvania, Eastern Ohio, and West Virginia show that the cold wave last night was general in these localities, and that vegetables of all kinds suffered greatly from the heavy frosts. In many places, the thermometer fell from 5 to 10 degrees below the freezing point. At some points, ice over an inch thick was formed. 

North East, Pa., May 13. The grape crop in this vicinity is damaged to the estimated extent of $100,000. Milwaukee, May 13. Reports received here from all sections of Wisconsin indicate a general frost accompanied in many parts by high wind and snow, reaching in some cases the severity of a blizzard. The freezing weather and snow began last night and continued throughout the day. Early fruit and vegetables, as well as much grain, have been destroyed by the sudden fall in temperature. 

Rock Falls, May 13. Reports from numerous sections of this state show that heavy damage was done last night by frost to fruit and garden truck. Corn that was up is reported to have been nipped to the ground. 

Champaign, Ill., May 13. Up to the present time, the cold weather has done no serious damage to Illinois crops, but there is every indication that there will be a heavy frost before morning in Central Illinois. It will doubtless do much damage to fruit, but wheat and corn are considered out of danger. 

Chicago, May 13. The ball game here today between New York and Chicago was postponed on account of the snowfall. 

La Porte, Ind., May 13. Northern Indiana was visited by a snowstorm today which raged for several hours. The cold has increased greatly, and it is feared all growing vegetation has been seriously injured. A blizzard is blowing tonight. 

South Bend, Ind., May 13. A blinding snowstorm has been raging here since 4 o'clock this afternoon with the temperature four degrees above freezing. 

St. Louis, Mo., May 13. A severe cold wave prevails throughout Missouri, and in many places, heavy frosts occurred last night. In the southwestern portion of the state, considerable damage to fruit and vegetable crops is reported. A heavy westerly wind saved growing wheat. 

Buffalo, May 13. Frost last night ruined the Chautauqua grape crop, and reports from other grape regions are to the effect that the crop is either partially or totally destroyed. The Western New York fruit belt reports that nearly all fruit has been damaged and in some cases totally destroyed. The loss is incalculable as many farmers had almost wholly given up general farming and turned their efforts toward fruit culture. Early tomatoes, cucumbers, and small vegetables are also ruined and will have to be replanted. 

Dunkirk, N.Y., May 13. The loss in Chautauqua's grapevines is estimated at a million and a half. Loss to others directly and indirectly interested in fruit raising will exceed $500,000. 

Saranac Lake, May 13. The thermometer is at the freezing point here tonight, a drop of 58 degrees in two days. There was a slight fall of snow today. The surrounding mountains are covered with snow. 

THE HYAMS' CASE. Expressman Fox Gives Some Interesting Evidence. Toronto, May 13. In the Hyams' murder trial this morning, Mr. Osier, at the opening of the court, announced that Mrs.

18950525: R McGarry; last year's winner Blizzard, 1:20; Coquette, 8 to 5; Running Bird, 4 to 1; Village Lass, 30 to 1; Ruth S., 20 to 1; Runaway, 11 to 1; Lord Motley, 30 to 1; Foam, 4 to 1; Martello, 4 to 1; Auntie Miller, 20 to 1. At the fall of the flag, it looked as if Starter McLaughlin had made a gift of the race to Running Bird, as that animal got fully three lengths the best of the send-off. Running and Coquette, with Foam a good fourth, were the next to be distinguished. The rest of the field were bunched. Running Bird reported his performance of yesterday and ran like a startled deer up the stretch when Coquette, who had been running well, overhauled him and lapped with the son of Kunnymede for some yards before she drew away and won by a half length. Foam was third, about a length away. Martello, after running fifth nearly the whole distance, beat Runaway out for fourth place at the wire.

18951114: At grounds, the board of Directors having granted the club the exclusive use of them for that afternoon, which the committee very much appreciated, as it greatly facilitated the work at the races. Permission having been obtained from the executive of the Amateur Athletic Association of Canada, three championship events were held, viz., 110 yards hurdles, 220 yards, and 833 yards. The track was in very soft condition, and the weather terrific, a perfect blizzard setting in on Friday morning, which lasted until Saturday morning. The committee worked hard to make these meets a success, having secured a very large list of entries, some sixty-three, besides having them extremely well advertised, as many will remember who were on St. James Street. The events were well contested, and our club had the good fortune to win six firsts and four seconds out of seven open events. In the evening of the same day, the fifty-fifth annual dinner was held in the Windsor Hotel, when 138 members sat down. This was one of the finest dinners held by the club, both as regards the menu, table decorations, and the number present. The members of the Association, through the President, Mr.

18951120: R notice of its intention to pay the amount due was withdrawn at the request of the Government. The theory has suffered much, however, by contact with events that have transpired since it had its birth, and yesterday's discussion will probably be the end of it. A commission is to be appointed to arrange the details of the Pacific cable scheme, and the cable also brings confirmation of the report that the Imperial Government will give assistance to the fast Atlantic service. Both these projects have seemed to hang fire a little, but when one considers the vast number of affairs, domestic and foreign, the British Government has to consider, it is not surprising that there should be delay. Perhaps the Dominion Government has not lost anything by the postponement. Both projects are for the permanent benefit of the Dominion, but they involve a considerable expenditure of Canadian money, and there need be no very particular hurry about assuming the burden. While Mr. Laurier is recommending "free trade as it is in England," to Canadian farmers, the English farmers are calling out for protection as it is in Canada, and duties on wheat and other cereals. If this should be pointed out to Mr. Laurier, he would, doubtless, reply that the circumstances of Great Britain and Canada are entirely different. If so, why urge on Canada a fiscal policy which England alone, of all the nations in the world, has ventured to adopt? A New York Central engineer has been killed and several postal clerks injured in a wreck caused by a number of young men whose heads had been turned by reading the exploits of train-robbing adventurers. The culprits are in custody and will probably get a taste of the robbers' punishment. It is a pity some of it could not be also administered to the publishers of the misleading books, as accessories before the crime. They deserve it. Mr. John Morley is to re-enter public life as the member for Montrose. His defeat at Newcastle was one of the incidents of battle which even the Conservatives regretted, though they gloried in the party triumph, and his return to the House of Commons will be warmly welcomed by men of all parties. Even his opponents admire his intellectual capabilities.

This corrected text maintains the original meaning and formatting while fixing OCR errors. Here is the corrected text with OCR errors fixed while preserving the original meaning and formatting as much as possible:

---

Intellectual power and his adherence to principle, and Parliament has been the poorer by his absence. That great shouter for economy, Mr. George W. Stephens, does not seem to have been present in the Legislature yesterday to vote for a reduction of the sessional indemnity, and to effect a saving of $20,000 a year to the Provincial Treasury. He will probably make up for the neglect, however, by louder shouting sometime, when he has nothing to lose. Mr. Stephens' shouts are always more inspiring than his votes. Mr. Goldwin Smith has favored the Saturday Review with an article on Canadian copyright and other matters, including patents and divorce. There is no objection to this, so long as it is understood that the writer only represents Mr. Goldwin Smith; but if English readers suppose that what the Professor says represents any considerable body of feeling in Canada, they are very much mistaken. Both Mr. Taillon, the leader of the Government, and Mr. Marchand, the leader of the Opposition, voted with the minority in the Legislature when the resolution in favor of a reduction of the sessional indemnity was killed. In their cases, conspicuous ability seems to go with seeming modesty. An outbreak of the old hostility to the English Sparrow is noted in some Canadian newspapers. This pugnacious feathered immigrant seems to be absolutely without friends on this continent. He also seems to be built on a plan to get along without them. Premier Canovas del Castillo says no negotiations with the Cuban rebels will be entered into. This sounds assuring from a Spanish point of view; but a sound thrashing of one of the rebel bands would be more convincing to outsiders. The early arrival of a blizzard is predicted by the weather observers, and we are only one day from the great Thanksgiving football festival!

At 111 Drummond Street, on Tuesday, November 19th, the wife of Dr. Muller, of a son, prematurely, DIED.
