**JACK FROST'S GRASP Causes Intense Suffering**  
In Chicago and St. Louis. 

**APPEAL FOR ASSISTANCE**  
Made by the Mayor of Chicago - Wants $100,000 - Suffering in St. Louis - At Canadian Points. 

Chicago, January 25. The people of Chicago were aroused today to take prompt and generous action for the relief of the two score thousand destitute inhabitants, whose suffering for want of fuel, food, and clothing had reached an extreme stage, as a result of the terrible cold wave which came upon the city Saturday, increasing in intensity until today, when the temperature reached the lowest point officially recorded in a quarter of a century. Between five and seven o'clock, the thermometer at the Weather Bureau in the Auditorium tower, where it was warmer than in the street, recorded 20 degrees below zero. Only once in the history of the Bureau - December 24th, 1872, - has the temperature fallen lower. From 6 a.m. to 2 p.m. there was a gradual rise, the range being 18 to 22 degrees, but the relief was hardly felt when accompanied by a cutting wind from the northwest. The highest temperature today was 10 below zero, and tonight the mercury is moving slowly down again with no hopes of material relief held out for tomorrow. Mayor Swift issued a proclamation this afternoon appealing in urgent language to all citizens who have the means to spare to contribute at once money and supplies to prevent the starvation and freezing of unfortunate thousands. He urged the subscription of $100,000 as being too much to afford the help needed. The funds of the charity organizations have become depleted owing to the extreme demands made upon them even during the mild weather that had prevailed here until a few days ago. The Chicago Relief and Aid Society was compelled to make a special appeal for money last week to carry on its work, because of the unusually large number of heads and supporters of families who are unemployed. Before the Mayor's proclamation was issued, contributions to the special fund came pouring into his office in currency and cheques, while offers of provisions, clothing, coal, and wood were received on a liberal scale. The Board of Trade and other organizations started to raise a relief fund, and the churches and Salvation Army began making systematic and extensive arrangements to help in the charitable work along their special lines. Soup houses and shelters will be established and maintained as long as necessary. The city will buy with the special fund food and fuel, and distribute them on demand through the agency of the police department. This relief is to be afforded without the usual investigation until the regular charitable organizations are able to take up the work. All police stations have been thrown open to the homeless, and tonight everyone was crowded with refugees from the freezing air. The Mayor's proclamation is the first of the kind to be issued in 25 years. The worst and most numerous cases of suffering were reported from South Chicago and Kensington, where thousands of men have been laid off at the steel mills and other establishments. The work of affording not temporary relief was pushed by the police agents using patrol wagons and ambulances in such a systematic manner that no case of destitution reported remained unattended to tonight.

**Suffering in St. Louis**  
St. Louis, January 25. The cold wave which gathered in British Columbia on Friday swept down upon this section yesterday and still continues here, though slightly abated tonight. At seven o'clock this morning the temperature was exactly zero. At noon, 3 above was indicated, and at 6 p.m. four degrees above was the reading. This extreme low temperature followed sharply upon a long season of mild weather and found the condition of the people unprepared. The demand upon the Associated Charities for food and fuel was never greater. When the ticket window of the Provident Association opened at 6 a.m., 300 men and women were in line waiting for assistance. The police department is doing everything possible to relieve the distress. Twenty-five frost-bitten victims were treated at the City Dispensary today and three amputations were necessary. Hundreds of homeless people are sheltered tonight at the police stations. The river has not yet closed here though it is full of floating ice, which endangers shipping. Trains from points west and south were late tonight. All were delayed by snow blockades. Special dispatches show that no section west or south of this city has escaped the sudden fury of the blizzard. For the first time ever known, ice formed for a short time over Lower White River in Arkansas today. Snow is reported in West Tennessee and Southern Illinois. The great fruit section of Southwest Missouri and Northern Arkansas has suffered severely and nothing can save the crops. A fall of snow that would have saved the wheat fields of Missouri, Iowa, and Nebraska did not come with the cold wave, and predictions of disaster to the cereals were frequent on 'Change.

Washington, January 25. The mercury here stood at 12 at midnight tonight. Ernest Southern, a white man, was frozen to death on the street in the southwestern part of the city.

**At Canadian Points**  
Quebec, January 25. The thermometer marked 28 below zero here this morning. There is a sharp wind up, and the cold is more penetrating than that of the cold spell of last week. 

Ottawa, January 25. The past twenty-four hours have been the coldest in 1897 or this winter. At midnight last night at Rideau Hall, the thermometer registered 20 degrees below zero. At 6 a.m. this morning it stood at 21 degrees below. On Parliament Hill at midnight it was 24 degrees below, and at 6 a.m. in the same place it stood at 26 degrees below. At 9 o'clock this morning it had only risen five degrees.

Winnipeg, January 25. Cold weather extends over the entire Canadian Northwest, but as it is really the first extreme cold snap of the season, there is not much cause for complaint. The stock on the ranches is in good condition and well prepared for a cold spell. A dispatch from Pilot Mound, Southern Manitoba, today, says: Wm. Tisdale, living in the dry settlement, 14 miles north of this place, is reported missing since the storm of Thursday. He had been at Manopolis and started to walk home. After walking about two miles he took shelter at Mr. Dell Stevens, where it... Here is the corrected text:

---

He was found; he had been more or less frozen. Mr. Stevens insisted on Mr. Tisdale remaining all night, but while Mr. Stevens was out attending to his stock, Mr. Tisdale started out for his home, fully four miles distant. He has never been seen since. Search parties are still looking for his body. 

**Law Is All Right**  
Washington, January 22. That part of the shipping law of the United States that allows the arrest of sailors who refuse to observe the terms of their contracts to serve on board vessels was today declared by the Supreme Court to be constitutional and within the jurisdiction of State Courts to enforce. If saving twenty percent on the purchase of high-class MEN'S FURNISHINGS interests you, step into one of Tooke's stores and see the value we are offering. Regular prices are plainly marked on the goods. Just deduct 20 percent, and that is what the price is now.

**18970203: BRITISH LIVE STOCK**  
Better Prices Noted - Manchester Expectations. From our own correspondent. Liverpool, January 23. With more or less of a blizzard, as the papers are reporting, the two or three degrees of frost sell the wild Rochdale wind prevalent. During the past twenty-four hours, our meat salesmen have been shaking hands with themselves, and looking forward to prices that have only been known to them of late in dreams. What a sanguine, hopeful lot they are, to be sure! Markets are better all over the country; this is evident, but I do not think the occurrences which have induced this state of affairs are very permanent. To begin with, the dealers of stock have had an open winter and plenty of fodder up to now, and consequently held on to their stock. Direct Canadian supplies finished off at the beginning of December. States shipments since have been more or less restricted. Argentines, ditto; result limited; effecting both native and foreign cattle and sheep. An advance in values, well, as in steers, cattle, say to $1 and on sheep firm 60c to 75c, but only the very best of either. Two weeks hence we shall receive later receipts from all United States ports; the first touch of winter will force many feeders to market their stock early, and then oversupplies and lack of demand will come into play. Thus hath it been in the past, and from the dead past let my Canadian friends gain some living experience, especially from Millar, Port Laird, and Boston.

**MANCHESTER AND A DIRECT CATTLE TRADE**  
The Lord Mayor of Liverpool presiding at the annual dinner of the Butchers' Association this week made some very pointed references to the designs of Manchester on the cattle and meat trade from Canada and the States. Although it had entirely gone across the water to Birkenhead, he said, the Corporation of Liverpool were not at all jealous; but they were decidedly opposed to its getting up the water via Manchester. He had been interested to know that although the civic authorities of Cottonopolis had spent over £100,000 to foster a direct cattle trade, yet only three cargoes had found their way to the unknown regions of Mode Wheel. The tolls upon these cargoes would about meet the expenses of the lading for one week. Whatever other trades had done, very little of the cattle trade had been taken from the port of Liverpool to the port of Manchester. The efforts of Manchester to encourage the trans-Atlantic cattle trade were not likely to do much more successfully in the future than they had met with in the past, for the tendency of the trade was to produce larger steamers, and larger steamers could not possibly go up to Manchester, but only to places like Liverpool. It was in those larger steamers that the cattle trade of the world would be done. That being so, they might fairly say that Liverpool was likely to be as well supported in the future as in the past. He was proud of the civic patriotism of the men in the meat and cattle trade who felt it their duty to try and keep their trade in the old channel for the good of the old city of Liverpool.

**LONDON PRICES**  
Monday's supply was 1,330 beasts. From the United States came 1,230, and from South America 100. The colder weather, combined with the small number of offers, stimulated trade, and an advance of from 2d to 3d per 8 lb has to be recorded. A quick clearance was made. The best States beasts on offer made 4s per 8 lb. Argentines quoted at 3s 6d to 3s 8d. Sheep totaled 970, or 110 less than the previous Monday, and consisted entirely of shipments from the Argentine. Trade was dull, best prices making 3s 8d per 8 lb. On Thursday there were 736 cattle forward: 616 States and 120 Argentines. Consequently, business was a bit brisker than usual, and an early clearance was effected, but no advance can be reported on Monday's rates. A few picked American beasts probably made all of 4s 1d (12.1c), but 4s (12c) was the general top current rate. Secondary and middling sorts, 2s 8d to 3s 10d (11c to 12.5c). South American cattle participated in the advance and sold well (quality considered) at 3s 6d to 3s 8d (10c to 11c). In the sheep pens, there were 678 Argentines and 446 States. Trade ruled firm, but not as firm for cattle. However, a good clearance was made at prices to equal 12 per lb. Home States lambs made up to 15s, so the buyers averred, but they were worth it this time of year.

**LIVERPOOL AND BIRKENHEAD**  
At Stanley on Monday there was a much larger supply of cattle, and prime quality met a good demand at last rates. Other sorts, however, slow and lower. Sheep were also in larger numbers, but the demand was slow and prices lower all round. Beef, 6d to 8d per lb; Scotch mutton, 8½d to 6d; Irish, 7½d to 8d. The numbers marketed were 1,834 cattle, and 4,089 sheep. At the foreign fairs, trade ruled fairly firm, the colder weather helping sellers right along. The actual advance in values, however, has not been very great as the supplies were rather in excess of demand. Country buyers have not been operating very freely as the offerings at the chief distributing markets have been liberal enough to prompt many dealers to stay away from Birkenhead. At present writing, the best beef is not making more than a small fraction over 10s per lb (say 6 1/16d), really good to choice bodies selling at 3s 4d per stone (10c per lb). Coarser descriptions are selling better (they always do when we get a touch of frost) at prices ranging from 3s 1d (7½c) to 4d (9c). London buyers, the principal operators, went in mostly for the choice, but the secondary grades were good enough and cheap enough to be taken by provincial salesmen at a small advance. The sheep trade keeps pretty firm, some Al American making very close on 12s (6d), while a few picked lambs are reported to have made as much as 13s (6½d). For next week we have about 4,600 cattle in sight and nearly 6,000 sheep. Sellers are looking forward to better prices being made, as the cold weather, which seems to have come with every prospect of staying, is bound to create a good demand. But what run of weather can we rely on in this country?

**CLASHOW YORKSHIRE**  
At the Monday sale of States cattle there were in the sheds 408 animals, ex Sarmatian, from New York; 386, ex Cppim, from Boston; 405, ex Scandinavian, from Boston, and 345, ex Tritonia, from Baltimore—a total available supply of 1,691. There were no Canadians presented a year ago. There was a large and representative attendance of purchasers, both local and from a distance. The cattle consisted principally of bullocks, but there were also a few oxen and heifers included in the various lots, while there was about the usual percentage of bulls sold in the bytes. As regards quality, the cattle were fully up to the average standard presented here, the bulk of them being shown in excellent condition, while they were of a well-tubed class, and most suitable for the requirements of the trade. The remainder were animals of a heavier tone with a few beasts which scarcely showed so well while being passed through the ring. Trade during the sale was similar to that experienced last week, the high currency level being well maintained. Small, neat bullocks of the best sort were in most request and met a keen competition, the bidding at times being of an animated description. Heavy prime beasts met a good selling trade at slightly lower rates, while plainer and secondary animals moved off steadily, no difficulty being experienced in cashing them. Bulls were also in good demand, the market for them being somewhat similar to that for bullocks, anything of a choice character being wanted and eagerly competed for, and in consequence former values were easily sustained. The approximate deadweight quotations may be given as follows: Bullocks, best quality medium weights up to 68s per cwt; heavy prime 64s to 66s; and current, 52 to 54s per cwt. Bulls realized from 44s to 49s per cwt, according to the quality and finish. At the conclusion of the sale, there were about 400 of the Scandinavian cattle held over till next week, the supply being rather short.

**18970206:** M. Remusat, who received a larger vote at the time of the polling than M. Constant, has died since the election, and the seat was accordingly given to M. Clist. 

**LONDON, February 5.** A special to the Standard from Paris says: "Two sergeants and four privates connected with the Alpine Chasseurs in charge of the mail between Sees and Mont Valensen, lost in the recent blizzard, are supposed to have perished in the line of duty during the storm." 

Paris, February 5. The Echo de Paris says that fighting has occurred on the frontier of Siam between the French and the Siamese. 

London, February 5. A Standard special from Paris announces that the judgment in the case of the Princess de Wrede, a noted amateur singer, upholds the validity in France of the Munich decree, annulling the marriage of Prince de Wrede with Mme. Maldaner, and that she has, therefore, lost her case. A special dispatch from Paris, dated December 3rd, said that a sensation was caused there by an action for divorce commenced by Princess de Wrede against her husband, Prince Adolphe de Wrede. It was also reported that Prince Adolphe recently went through the form of marriage with an American heiress at Geneva, Switzerland. 

London, February 5. The Chinese Government recently requested the British Government to loan to it a British naval officer to assist in the reorganization of the Chinese Navy, which was practically wiped out of existence by the Japanese during the recent war. Great Britain has acceded to the request, and has selected for the position Commander Charles H. Dundas, who is at present attached to the battleship Repulse.

Orillia, Ont., February 6. The Conservatives of Orillia are tonight celebrating their victory of yesterday. Mr. Bennett came in from Midland this evening and was met at the station by a large number of the rank and file in carriages, and was driven to the Orillia House. After supper, a procession was formed.

It is supposed his death was caused from effects of his spree. An inquest will be held. Neither pasteurized nor carbonated, and free from unwholesome ingredients, Labatt's London Ale is the best. SPORTS AND PASTIMES (Continued from Fifth Page)

THE LONG The Big Fight, New York, March 6 A Carson special says: The storm that started yesterday did not do a thing to the pugs in training. As a storm, it might have been classed as a toe-curling affair without following it up with a heavy fall of snow, but the chilly breath of the Sierra peaks makes it more unwelcome. This knocked out Corbett's new venture in the fashion of road work and made the sandy highway about Carson like the trails through polar regions. All this, too, a week after the natives had declared that winter was a thing of the past, to be laid away and forgotten as a matter of record only at the severest season ever known in this region. Not for a minute did the snow let up, and by daylight the ground was six inches under the surface with more coming. It is believed that this snow will disappear quickly, as there is nothing in it of the same character as the blizzard of two days ago. The temperature is much higher, and weather experts predict a hard three days' thaw to follow, which will remove all trace of the storm. The sun began business early this morning, and for once the weather experts were looked upon as people whose word might be accepted. Fitzsimmons has been giving three-minute rounds at the bag to each of several punches. For instance, he would give the bag a whirl of successive left swings, rest a minute, then jab it for three more, and so on. News of this method of procedure has come to Jim Corbett's ears, and he started to discount it. Corbett delivered left hooks on the bag for ten minutes without an interval. They were left hooks for fair, too, and frequently were triple blows, allowing the bag no time to recover its swing between any two of the time. Corbett practices some favorite blows, notably a hard straight right following a light left lead, and kept at the bag for twenty minutes longer. In the gymnasium, he flipped to his flannels and sweater and invited Jeffries to go at him. Jeffries was willing, but at every vicious lead was met with a straightening jab that shook and jarred the men's sensibilities into chaos. He was susceptible to a knockout at any time during the first three minutes. Edgar came next, and defeating counters was wary. In a mix-up, Corbett sent him reeling with a left hook and apologized. Charley White's call of time was welcome, although Corbett had been more than merciful. Masey next tried to twist his opponent's head off in clinching tactics and was made to back and give ground across the handball court, the second time landing with his head against the pineboards. Billy Wools then had a three-minute bout. This program was repeated four times, Corbett taking absolutely no rest and giving each man nine minutes between rounds. Corbett likes the change in method recommended by his trainers and seems none the worse for his two days of rest. He has lost no speed, and all danger of his good state has been obviated. If necessary, he will be given another let-up before the fight. Fitz nearly cracked Roeber's skull in practice. He is in line, too, with the medical examination fad. He has been prodded and thumped by a physician. No traces of acute dipsomania were revealed, and while the doctor did not call him "the most perfectly developed athlete he had ever seen," the diagnosis was of such a nature as to assure the public the men are fit to slug each other without serious injury. Doctor Gulnan, who made the examination, when he concluded, said: "I am not in the habit of examining fighters, and I am not the man to say whether they are in what is called fighting condition. They are, however, in as good shape as it is possible for two human animals to be." There is probably no betting here, as most of the betting men are holding off until the week of the fight before putting up cash. Julian says that he will call Bon off early next week and make him do some loafing for the last week. He will allow him to do nothing but such work as club-swinging and moderate walks. Corbett, too, will let up on the most vigorous exercising next week. He will do just enough to keep his wind and muscles in trim and expects to fill out some before he responds to the clang of the timer's bell.

LOOKING OUT FOR REWARDS, San Francisco, March 6

18970325: I. Doty, 1611 Blake Street, Denver, Col., who will take charge of Colorado, Wyoming, and temporarily of Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Texas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and Indian Territory. Herbert W. Foltz, Indianapolis, who will take charge of Ohio, Indiana, Kentucky, Tennessee, West Virginia, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, and Florida. The Chairman will take charge of the balance of the territory until President Potter completes his appointments. When the board is complete, districts will be reassigned to each by the Chairman. The following letter explains itself and is published for the information of racing men generally: 

Mr. Frederick J. Titus, New York, 

"Dear Sir, Your very courteous letter, dated February 15, is received. Your suspension is removed in accordance with the recommendation of the National Assembly, which is considered an instruction. The date set by the motion is March 15. You are in the amateur class from that date. The most that has been claimed in extenuation of your offense is that in your generosity you proposed to permit a friend to win a race at St. Louis because it was his home. That generosity was misdirected. You have no doubt since reflected upon this matter, as you intimate, and have come to the conclusion that such generosity would naturally be reciprocated, and that would involve serious consequences to the grand spirit we are all interested in. The sequence would be that in some of the largest cities in the country, spectators would be inveigled on false pretenses into paying admission to see some races which were not competed for and were not won on the merits of the contestants. In that case, the occupation of the racing men would soon be gone. It would not be wise for any racing man to believe that he would receive such clemency again from the National Assembly in a similar case. 

Sincerely wishing you all the artistic success during the coming season which your well-known abilities merit, I am very respectfully, 

Albert Mott, 

Chairman Racing Board, 

Baltimore, March 15, 1897 

The Scramble for Office (Leslie's Weekly) 

Whenever there is a change of administration in Washington, an army of hungry office-seekers assembles there, and the scramble for office is amusing or pitiful, accordingly as we look upon it. Some professional commentators on public happenings say that this office-seeking is a part of the American system, and being American, it is all right and proper. As a matter of fact, there is nothing peculiarly American about it; indeed, the custom is as old as government itself, and it has flourished most extensively and most perniciously in those monarchies where courts were most corrupt. We are not of those who believe that the political millennium is to be attained through the extension of the civil service regulations so that every governmental office must be bestowed after an examination fashioned on academic lines, but we are persuaded that such a method is at once better and more dignified than that which now prevails, and through which loud insistence counts for more than genuine worth. The President of the United States is selected for other work than parcelling out the spoils of victory. To him, the country looks for its statesmanship in internal affairs and foreign relations as well; in him are reposed our national credit and our national honor. How can he attend to these things when all his days are taken up with these persistent office-seekers? It is a pity that a rule like this could not be applied: the first shall be last, and to him who comes not at all shall be the prize. 

Profits on School Books (Mail and Umpire) 

The debate on the educational estimates has brought out some peculiar facts. It seems that textbook making is a very profitable occupation. The Minister has it in his power to authorize just such books as he pleases and can therefore distribute the profits at will. The reader monopoly is an excellent franchise. Dr. Byerson has secured the figures, which show that Part I of the first book costs 3 cents and sells for 10 cents; Part II costs 4 cents and sells for 15 cents. The second reader costs 91 cents to produce and sells at 25 cents; the third costs 12 cents and sells at 40, and the fourth costs 14 cents and sells at 50. 

Family Burned to Death 

Nashville, Tenn., March 24 The house of Jacob Ade, a German farmer, was partly burned at Paradise Ridge last night, and in the ashes were found the charred remains of his wife, his daughter Lizzie, aged 14, and the ten-year-old daughter of Henry Moiref, a neighbor, who was spending the night with the Ades. Henry Ade, a ten-year-old boy, is missing. The deed is supposed to have been the work of tramps, who have lately been numerous in the locality. 

Chicago Storm Struck 

Chicago, March 24 A severe storm struck Chicago yesterday, accompanied by snow and high wind. At midnight, the storm had assumed the proportions of a blizzard. Railroad and streetcar service was seriously interfered with. The storm was general throughout the northern part of Illinois and portions of Wisconsin, Iowa, and Minnesota.

SUPERIOR COURT—JURISPRUDENCE 

Montreal, March 24 By Mr. Justus DeLobimi, Canada Paper Company vs. Boyd et al. The court sustained the seizures in revindication issued by the company, plaintiff, and rescinded the losses passed between the parties on the 25th of July, 191, and the defendants were ordered to deliver up to the plaintiff the effects seized, and in default to pay plaintiff the sum of $79.91.

18970413: HEBS 2230 St. Gaul's Gilo: 4232 St. Louis. REFRESHING COMEDY presented by a Strong Company at the Queen's Theatre. KEARNEY IN THE CANUCK. At the Theatre Francais. Melodrama at the Royal - My Friend From India. Returning: There was a good audience at the Queen's Theatre last night, and it may justly be said that no one went away disappointed; everybody enjoyed "Dodge at the French Ball." It is one of those pieces that is vim and go all the way through; it is a musical comedy of a type that is calculated to chase away ennui; it is a production that puts each one in high good humor, its brightness and sprightliness of their very nature producing an infection that the audience is only too willing to catch, and of which there is a feeling that it would gladly have more. Indeed, last night the audience did have more than the original lines contained, for they would not rest contented until some of the songs, choruses, etc., had been repeated! The plot turns upon the complicated and at times embarrassing situations that arise out of the fact that Mr. Dodge has practiced a little deception upon his wife by attending a masked French ball without her knowledge and topped with a lady other than her whom he promised to love and cherish. As may readily be conceived, this affords groundwork for almost innumerable laughable incidents, and it has been well taken advantage of. The comedy consists of three acts, the first and last of which may be said to have the most direct connection with Mr. Dodge and his ball escapade, the second act, by a mere thread of connection so far as the plot goes, being devoted to vaudeville. This relieves to some extent the great amount of fun-making that predominates in the other two acts, while the vaudeville itself is of a very high class, the several turns, no matter whether choruses, dances, songs or duets, being given with a finish that is exceptional. The comedy is given by the Henahaw-Tew Brock Company, and it is a decidedly strong combination. The bulk of the fun-making, of course, falls upon the shoulders of the gentleman who interprets the role of Mr. Dodge, president of the Montquitoville Bank, and in this instance it is Mr. John E. Leoshaw, whose acting is marked by a naturalness, both of manner and facial expression, that is perfectly charming. He plays his part without appearing in any way to force the slightest point, and in that lies much of the charm of his acting. He is well supported by Mr. Frank David, who sustains the character of Barnaby Potter, Mr. Dodge's confidential clerk. Of him it may be said that he possesses great ease of manner and never misses a point. Mr. William Blaisdell, with whom Montrealers have been acquainted in the past, is with the company, and his reception was all that he could ever desire. To him is allotted the role of Alphonse d'Arville, waiter in a French restaurant, and he interprets it with that ability which has ever characterized his work. As Zenobia Dodge, wife of the gentleman who is responsible for all the trouble, May Ten Bloeck gives an admirable presentation of the part, and Miss Carlotta depicts Harriet Pelham, Mrs. Dodge's unmarried sister, with ability, whilst as Mackenzie, Mrs. Dodge's maid, Clara Lavine endows the part with all the vivacity and artfulness for which it calls. McKee Rankin's play "The Canuck" was played at the Theatre Francais yesterday by the stock company to good houses. The author, in his palmy days, made great fame (being a Canadian himself) in the delineation of L'Habitant, and in the character of Jean Baptiste Cadeaux scored an unqualified success. The play being of local interest it was naturally expected that Mr. Alex Kearney, who personates the leading role this week, would receive a rousing reception, being a Montrealer himself, and he did. Mr. Kearney appears to have made a thorough study of the part, and somewhat astonished his friends by the excellence with which he portrayed the French Canadian dialect. He cited and played the part to perfection, and in the scene where his erring daughter returns to her home and begs his forgiveness, he was applauded to the echo. Mr. Kearney appears to have a proper conception of the part and at once sinks his personality in the delineation of the French habitant. Mr. Kearney, Mr. John E. Henshaw has ably assisted by Miss Beryl Hope, who took the part of Archange (his daughter) most acceptably, and won the deserved plaudits of the audience. Mr. Walter B. Aytodall, as Cyrus Stebbins, played the part to perfection, and showed that he was a diligent student. Mr. Alexander Gaden as the villain of the piece, and in the scene where he attempts to burglarize the premises of Jean Baptiste was very effective. The play is well mounted, the scenery is appropriate, and "The Canuck" is an assured success for the balance of the week. The vaudeville, as usual, is up to date, and is headed by Mr. Walter J. Talbot, described as a descriptive tenor, who sings some ballads well. Adeline Marden has a good voice, if a little harsh, and warbles some operatic airs in a fairly finished manner. Hornmann does some tricks of legerdemain which are clever, if not new, and Dean and Jose, in their satire on society's four hundred, are a clever pair, although their little skit is not the most refined in the world. They are both clever, however, and well worth seeing. The management is to be congratulated on the general excellence of the performance, and the determination to produce nothing but first-class attractions should be noted and appreciated by their patrons. The Theatre Royal is this week producing a melodrama based much on the lines of some of its old-time sensational attractions, of which there has been of late a lack. It is "The Great North-West," and when it is stated that the principal incidents occur in a spot that is undergoing a boom, and where a horse thief is regarded as worse than a murderer, the idea of exciting scenes will at once suggest itself. And there is no dearth of thrills. There is the arrival of the first railway train at Boom City; there is a rescue from a prairie fire; there is a trial for horse stealing, with every prospect of a lynching; there is a blizzard, during which a fight between two enemies ensues, and there is a somewhat thrilling swing on one of the sails of a windmill by a woman who wishes to save the life of the man she loves. Of villainy and plots for revenge there is any amount; and love, misplaced and otherwise, is dealt out in homeopathic doses, whilst veins of various types of comedy come along at refreshingly opportune moments. The production was well received yesterday by large houses, the scenery, which is above the average staged at the Royal, adding considerably to the enjoyableness of the piece. The characters, as a whole, are fairly well taken. The role of Captain Sheaf, the hero, is ably filled by Mr.

18970419: TUPUNGATO CONQUERED. On one of the Great Volcanic Peaks of the Andes Ascended for the First Time. London, April 18. The Chronicle will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Vaca, Argentine Republic, recording another achievement by the Fitzgerald mountain-climbing expedition in the Andes. The members of the expedition started on March 25 up the Tupungato Valley to ascend the Tupungato Mountain, which had never been ascended. The mountain is directly south of Mount Aconcagua, believed to be the highest mountain in the Andes, and which was ascended by the Fitzgerald expedition about two months ago. When the party had reached a high altitude on the slope of Tupungato...

--- 

Let me know if you need any further assistance! Here is the corrected text:

Tupungato. They were driven back three times by strong winds and intense cold. The fourth venture was made on April 11, on the sight of which day the party slept at an altitude of 17,000 feet above sea level. The morning of April 12 dawned without a cloud in the sky, and the party proceeded toward the summit. When a height of 20,000 feet had been reached, all the porters gave out and were obliged to retrace their steps. The explorer Vines and the Swiss guide Surbriggen continued, however, and arrived in the afternoon of the 12th on the summit of Tupungato Mountain, a virgin peak. The instruments which the climbers carried with them showed the mountain to be 21,000 feet above sea level. It is a volcanic mountain, and from it was obtained a magnificent view of Mount Aconcagua, standing to the northward absolutely alone. Twenty miles to the westward, an active volcano was seen. The mercury at the top of Mount Tupungato registered 10 below.

LOST HALF THEIR STOCK  
Blizzards and Floods Hard on Cattlemen  
Cattlemen in Iowa Sioux City, Ia., April 16. Between blizzards and high water, cattle on the ranges throughout the Northwest have been having a tough time of it since the first of last winter's storms. In several South Dakota counties, the loss to stockmen will be 40 or 50 percent. In many instances, it will foot up to 25 to 30 percent, and scarcely anywhere will it fall below 20. The losses came notwithstanding the fact that unusual precautions were taken last fall to supply stock liberally with hay and to fence them in on comparatively small tracts to prevent drifting before heavy storms. Had not such precautions been taken, the general opinion is that most of the big herds throughout the section would have been completely wiped out. The winter opened unprecedentedly early, the storms were remarkably severe and frequent, and when the high water struck, the herds found them weakened by cold and hunger and unable to fight for their lives. The big Sioux, Floyd, Vermillion, Jim, Elkborn, and Little Sioux Rivers were black with floating cattle, hogs, and poultry when the ice went out. Such losses will aggregate millions and will not be made up for years.

April 27: The extremes of weather so far this week throughout northern New York have been a very hot summer day and thunderstorms Sunday, and a heavy snowstorm and blizzard all Monday night and up to ten o'clock today. Six or eight inches of snow now covers the ground. Milkmen were making their deliveries this morning on runners.

THE RESORT

L.F. were to play the Berks on board, but when they arrived at the barracks, the Berks were not there; they had gone on board the transport as soon as the Leinsters arrived at the barracks. There was no departing music. "The Girl I Left Behind Me" was there in the flesh, but not in the old familiar tune. Heartbroken maidens were not much in evidence, though a lady of color caused quite a commotion after the gate shut forever on the departing regiment. The Berks were given a great send-off. Officers and men have been well liked in Halifax. As a rule, the men behaved well. Besides the Leinsters, the Avoca brought 67 Royal Engineers, 127 Royal Artillery, one Army Ordinance Corps, 35 women, and 104 children. The Avoca is now on her way to Bermuda with the Royal Berkshires. After leaving Halifax, she will call at Bermuda, then go to Barbados, St. Lucia, Jamaica, St. Helena, Natal, Mauritius, Bombay, Karachi, and from there home to Southampton via the Suez Canal, Malta, and Gibraltar, being due home early in January. The Avoca is an able-looking ship of 1,053 tons net and 1,734 gross. She has engines of 250 horsepower and is owned by Hajee Cusum Jootub of Bombay. For the past two years, she has been under charter to the Spanish Government and has been engaged carrying troops from Barcelona to Cuba. A noticeable circumstance in connection with the Royal Canadians is that a larger number of the regiment are Roman Catholics and will worship at St. Patrick's in Halifax.

We have been asked, says the Broad Arrow, whether the latest thing in medals, in the early days of the settlement of the Dakotas, the newspapers frequently contained stories of the hardships and sufferings and sometimes the death of the new settlers who were lost in the blizzards. The man or woman who is frozen to death in a winter's storm undergoes great sufferings, but they are mild compared with those daily borne by thousands of victims of that dread disease, consumption. For centuries this relentless disease was considered incurable. It is now known to be distinctly curable. Dr. Pierce's Golden Medical Discovery cures 98 percent of all cases of consumption, bronchitis, asthma, laryngitis, and diseases of the air passages. It has stood the test for thirty years. It acts directly on the blood, nourishing it with the life-giving qualities of food. It tears down old, half-dead tissues and builds up new ones in all parts of the body. Through the blood, it acts directly on the lungs, driving out all impurities and disease germs. It soothes the cough, but facilitates expectoration. It deepens the breathing, supplying the system with life-giving oxygen. It stimulates the appetite, facilitates the flow of digestive juices, invigorates the liver, and tones and builds up the nerves. It is the great blood-maker and flesh-builder. It does not make flabby flesh like cod liver oil, but firm, muscular, healthy tissues.

"I had been troubled with bronchitis for several years," writes Mrs. Orlin O'Hara, Box 114, Fergus Falls, Ottertail Co., Minn. "In the first place, I had a sore throat. I doctored with different doctors and took various medicines, but got no relief. I raised from my throat a sticky substance like the white of an egg. I could not sleep, and had made up my mind that I would not live through the winter. I took Dr. Pierce's Golden Medical Discovery and 'Favorite Prescription' alternately, and in a few days began to see that I was better. I took eight bottles. I have not felt as well in years." The quick constipation cure: Doctor Pierce's Pleasant Pellets. Never gripe. Accept no substitutes or imitations.

The Queen Victoria medal, to be granted to cadets at the Royal Military Academy and Royal Military College, who distinguish themselves during their course of study at these institutions, are to be worn in uniform. We are not quite sure, the journal answers, but imagine that the answer should be in the affirmative, and certainly these cadets will have done more to earn their decoration than many who now wear the ribbon of the jubilee medal and those of foreign orders, gained by attending court functions abroad. A prominent English paper, in speaking of the granting of this Queen Victoria medal, remarks that it would be much more appropriate and practical were a sword, and not a medal, granted to the youths who are deserving of special recognition at college. No less than seventeen British regiments are now taking part in the operations under General Sir William Lockhart, the largest number employed together in active service in India since the days of the Sepoy mutiny. By the way, the Punjab command is shortly to become vacant, and there is considerable speculation as to Sir William Lockhart's successor. As regards the Aldershot command, when the time of the Duke of Connaught is up, two officers' names are prominently mentioned in connection with it: Lord Methuen and Sir Redvers Buller. It is thought that Lord Methuen will eventually find himself at the Government House, Aldershot. 

The general annual return of the British army for 1896 shows that up to the 1st of January last, the effective strength of the regular army of all ranks was 220,869, of whom 100,641 were at home, 4,711 in Egypt, 38,522 in the colonies, and 76,903 in India. The average number of men in the army during last year was 220,742, of whom 10,584 were cavalry, 37,307 artillery, 3,808 horse, 14,075 field, 1,454 mountain, and 17,586 garrison; 7,829 engineers, 5,851 foot guards, 136,965 infantry of the line, 5,331 colonial corps, 3,581 army service corps, 1,306 army ordnance corps, 2,609 medical staff corps, and 673 army pay corps. The total number of recruits obtained was 28,532, of whom 27,670 were raised at home, 22,104 being recruited in England, 2,825 in Scotland, and 2,865 in Ireland. The total number of trials by court martial was 9,167, and the number of minor punishments, including fines for drunkenness (14,441), was 206,857; 105,666 men possessed good conduct badges and 870 men had good conduct medals. The annual inspection of the 65th Battalion, Mount Royal Rifles, postponed from last spring, will take place on the Champ de Mars at half-past three o'clock this afternoon. Lieutenant Colonel Maunsell, Inspector of Infantry, will come up from Fredericton for the affair and will make the inspection with Lieutenant Colonel Gordon, U.C.O. The inspection of the right and left half battalions was satisfactorily made on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, respectively, and last evening the commanding officer, Lieutenant Colonel Labels, made his inspection. It is understood that Lieutenant Colonel Gordon is pleased with what he has seen of the regiment, particularly with the officers, who are smart and energetic. It will be seen this afternoon whether the regiment is, or is not, strong numerically, for it has been said that the parades in some cases have not been what they should. With the population that the 65th, the only French battalion in Montreal, has to call upon, it should be not only the strongest regiment in Montreal but one of the strongest in Canada. Captain Peltier, of the 65th Battalion, was in the Police Court this week prosecuting two members of the regiment for non-attendance at drill. One of them pleaded guilty and was reprimanded, and sentence was suspended. The other man pleaded not guilty. His lawyer protested that first he should have been advised to attend drill and afterwards a month's time should have been allowed before proceedings were taken against him. The judge has the case under deliberation.

In charge of the instrumental measurement and astronomical work for the determination of the first meridian, besides the ascertainment of the point at which the Yukon crossed that meridian, the object of the expedition was to obtain all possible information touching a large tract of country, as yet little known, forming the extreme northwesterly portion of the Northwest Territory. The Yukon district lies between the northern boundary of British Columbia, lat 60, and the Arctic Ocean, and between the 141st meridian on the west and the 136th meridian and the Rocky Mountain ridges on the east. It has thus an approximate area of 192,000 square miles, which is about ten times the area of Nova Scotia or three times that of New England. As to its general character, Dr. Dawson thought it might be compared with the Russian province of Vologda. The province in question, situated between latitudes 68 and longitude 60, has an area, according to the Stateman's Year-Book, of 155,498 square miles and a population of 1,239,705. Dr. Dawson fixed upon Vologda, and not Archangel, because it is inland with respect to the White Sea, as the Yukon district is inland with respect to Bering Sea and the Yukon Delta. So far as isotherms are concerned, however, Archangel would be, perhaps, a better parallel, though in its relation to the Ural Mountains, Vologda has conditions that match the Canadian region. Hepworth Dixon began his Russian tour at the north and passed through both Archangel and Vologda. His first stage was by tarantass from Solovetsk to Archangel. Solovetsk is a town that has grown up around a famous convent (that of Saints Savatle and Zozima) on an islet of the same name in Onega Bay. To this shrine, emperors as well as peasants have gone on pilgrimage. There is a like delta of isles and islets at the mouth of the Dowlna. Having entered the river by the most convenient of its twelve arms, the newcomer catches a glimpse of a forest of domes and spires, the domes of all colors, the spires all golden. This is Archangel. Here's the corrected text:

succeeded in landing, he finds a camp of shanties around groups of belfries and cupolas. "Imagine a vast green marsh along the bank of a broad brown river, with mounds of clay cropping here and there out of the peat and bog; put buildings with frescoes, crown them with cupolas and crosses; fill the space between church and convent with piles and planks, so as to make ground for gardens, streets, and yards; cut two wide lanes from the church called 'Smith's Wife' to the monastery of St. Michael, three or four miles in length; paint the walls of church and convent white, the domes green and blue; surround the log houses with open gardens; stick a geranium, a fuchsia, an oleander in every window; leave the grass growing everywhere in street and clearing and there you have Archangel." Such is Hepworth Dixon's picture of the northern Russian seaport at latitude 13, nearly the same as that of Dawson City. Not far from Archangel is Hukkogory, birthplace of Lomonosov, poet and philosopher, greatly honored by his countrymen. It is a city set on a hill, pretty and bright, with golden crops in sight and grassy roads, pink and white houses on the wide streets, boats on the river, and stretches of yellow sunlight, churches, cloisters, and all around forests of pine and birch. This northern part of Russia just swarms with villages on both sides of the Arctic Circle. For navigation, however, Archangel, Onega, and other sub-Arctic Russian ports are not so favorably situated as those of Norway, Tromsø, and Hammerfest. The latter, in latitude 70 degrees, 40 minutes, 11 seconds, is, so far, the most northerly town in the world. It has a population of over 2,000 souls, and, though he can occasionally light his cigar at midnight with a sunglass, the Hammerfester is by no means cut off from the outer world. Electric light, introduced some years ago, is in general use and one can telegraph in all directions. Though the inhabitants are said to be of a pensive turn, they are not at all without enjoyments. They are industrious and, besides the characteristic industries, in which the export of cod liver oil has a prominent place, there are shops of all kinds and the fashions are not unknown. St. Petersburg is in the latitude (60 degrees) of the southern boundary of the Yukon district. North of that line are some important Russian provinces west of the Urals, the Grand Duchy of Finland, nearly the whole of Norway, and a considerable portion of Sweden. On the American continent, the isotherms correspond with parallels of latitude much less than they do in the Old World. Mr. Dull, who was the first to write about Alaska at the transfer to the United States, and in whose statements Dr. Dawson generally places confidence, says that the winters on the Yukon may be compared to those of Canada and Minnesota. The air is crisp and cold, with occasional blizzards. The mid-winter temperature may average 30 degrees below zero (Fahrenheit). The summer comes on with amazing rapidity and during the mosquito season life is unendurable without a net or leather gloves. About May 20, the river bursts its bonds and the lowlands are flooded. The cry of the brant, sailing northward, is heard, and all the minor forms of life are afoot, on the wing, or creeping in the low grass. Vegetation springs at a bound into leaf and flower. Both Dr. Dawson and Mr. Ogilvie devote some attention to the agricultural capacities of the Yukon district. The former quotes Mr. James Anderson, of the Hudson Bay Company, in proof of the fact, questioned by Petroff, that potatoes and barley were grown at Fort Yukon. From all that he has learned by personal observation and otherwise, Dr. Dawson did not hesitate to affirm that such hardy crops as barley, rye, turnips, and flax could be successfully raised as far north as the former site of Fort Selkirk near the 63rd parallel. It is also interesting to know that excellent summer grazing for horses and cattle can be found along the river valleys, while natural hay meadows are frequent. In Appendix I, Dr. Dawson gives important information as to the distribution of trees and in Appendix III a verified list of the plants that he collected in the Yukon district and adjacent parts of British Columbia. Mr. Ogilvie, though not enthusiastic as to the agricultural capabilities of the Pelly-Yukon basin, mentions some tracts here and there that admit of cultivation. For instance, there is Ogilvie Valley (so called in his honor by the chief of the expedition). Northward from the end of Lake Labarge, mixed timber, poplar, and spruce occurs of a size that betokens fair soil, while the herbaceous is more than usually rich for that region. Several such exceptional tracts are mentioned. On the whole, however, Mr. Ogilvie forms a very moderate estimate of the total area of agricultural land in the Yukon district. He thinks that 360 square miles would be a generous allowance. That would make 230,400 acres or about 1,000 farms for the Yukon-Pelly basin, and he estimates the available land on the affluents of the river at about the same figure. It is to the discovery and development of its mineral wealth that, in his judgment, the region will owe whatever prosperity is in store for it. The Yukon country has long been the scene of missionary labor and Mr. Ogilvie acknowledges its good effects on some of the Indians with whom he came in contact. The Greek Church had established missions in Alaska before the transfer to the United States. The Roman Catholic Church has a large staff of workers engaged. There was an Anglican missionary at Fort Yukon as early as 1861, and Presbyterian, Methodist, and Moravian missionaries carry on the work of evangelization on both sides of the frontier. Now that provision has been made for the maintenance of law and order in the district, the residents will enjoy that security of person and property which pertains to a civilized community and the future development of that great lone land will be awaited with interest. There are no quarrels so bitter as family quarrels, and this holds good of newspapers as well as individuals. The dispute between the two leading Liberal papers of British Columbia, the Victoria Times and the Vancouver World, waxes hotter and hotter as the days go by. The Times describes the World's editorial as "a splenetic Jeremiad," and the World retorts by calling the Times' Editor (Senator Templeman) an unsuccessful fabricator, who went round, hat in hand, pauper-like, imploring the assistance and influence of everyone with whom he came in contact. The World has two columns and a half on the subject, winding up with the following peroration: "If the Times is not aware of these facts, the sooner a night school is established for the education of writers of such misleading sentences as the above, the sooner will the period be reached when it will cease to become the laughing stock of the community, and display its culpable ignorance of the country in which it is published." The remarkable development of dairying in Canada is again illustrated in the review of the export trade of this city during the season of 1897, printed this morning. For the first time, the transatlantic shipments of cheese have exceeded the two million boxes mark, while as regards butter there has been since 1896 an increase from 157,821 packages to 220,200 packages. The value of the whole to the producers approximates sixteen and a half million dollars. THEATRE FRANCHISES, WEEK OF NOVEMBER 22nd "GOOD MORNING BLIND," AND HAMMERVILLE AND DAILY, the Happy Hour. Prices: 10, 20 and 30. Office Open from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. AT LENNOXVILLE, ON FRIDAY EVENING, NOVEMBER 1897. WHEAT IS BOOMING. The December option sells at one dollar at Chicago. FOREIGN ADVICES ALL STRONG. Blizzard raging west. Visible will show small increase. Kansas crop report gives area winter wheat sixteen percent increase. Friday Evening. This was a bull day in the Chicago wheat pit and considerable excitement prevailed, especially in the December option which sold 4c higher at $1.00, and the market closed strong at an advance of 1 1/4c to 3 1/8c, at 99c, November; 99 1/2c December; 94 3/8c May; 87c July. Corn shows little change in spite of the above, prices closing 1/8c higher at 26 1/8c November; 26 1/8c December; 29 5/8c May. Oats closed 20 1/2c November; 20 1/2c December; 22 1/4c May. New York, November 26. After several weeks of unsatisfactory markets, "dollar wheat," in the speculative acceptance of the term, was realized on 'Change today. The December option early attained that figure and soon passed it, reaching $1.00 3/8 in the afternoon, which was also the final price. A bad squeeze of the shorts was chiefly responsible for local strength, although higher cables had much to do with the early advancing tendency of local markets. S. Bache & Co., of Chicago, wire their manager, C. D. Monk, as follows: Liverpool cable advanced 3/8d yesterday and 1/4d early this a.m., but lost the 1/4d advance later. Paris markets were higher, November being quoted equivalent to 1 13/16 per bushel. San Francisco, which heretofore has advanced strongly, is up again today two cents per bushel. Demand for flour at Minneapolis is good. Exporters took 25 loads at the seaboard today and closed up 250,909 on Wednesday. The Modern Miller construed bearish but stated demand for flour is good, owing to heavy flour sales. Blizzard raging in the west and headed this way promising to reach winter wheat fields tonight. Considering the plant and condition, unless accompanied by snow, it will not be a serious circumstance. Receipts Northwest are still strong and weather seems to be the only impediment in sight. Kansas crop report makes wheat yield 50,000,000 bushels, and the winter wheat just sown, 16 percent increase, condition high, outlook for visible Monday is for a slight increase against a decrease of a million last year and Bradstreet's exports for the week will show well notwithstanding the intervening holding. The shorts in December were scared and the price of that option went easily to a dollar. We think there was some selling of a depressing kind on the part of a clique but not to any great extent and we think this flurry only foreshadows what in a larger way is likely to take place in that option at any time. We repeat again, "Get out of December option and stay out of it." Cable advices to the Board of Trade this morning were as follows: Cargoes off coast, wheat, nothing doing; maize, nothing doing. Cargoes on passage, wheat nominally unchanged; maize, firm. Parcels of No. 1 hard Manitoba wheat, steam on passage, 37s 6d; American clipped oats, 14s d. December Liverpool Spot wheat, firm; spot maize, firm; No. 2 spring spot wheat, 7s 1 1/2d to 7s 9d; mixed American spot maize, 3s 3 1/4d. Minneapolis first bakers' flour 25s 3d. Futures Wheat steady, 7s 6 5/8d December; 7s 7d March; 7s 6d May; maize, steady, 3s 2 3/4d November; 3s 2 7/8d December; 2 1/2d March. Paris Wheat, 30.75 November; 29.50 December; flour, 62.90 November; 62.30 December. French country markets, firm. There was a good demand from foreign buyers in this market today for Duluth hard and Manitoba wheat and some large sales were made.

1897-12-25: A, for Sunbury County, was drowned in the canal connecting French Lake with the Oromocto River. He was a large lumber operator and mill owner. John Dewar, of St. George, Charlotte County, died at his residence yesterday. Mr. Dewar was one of the best-known men in Charlotte, and a very successful businessman. Now again enjoying satisfactory health, and will spend Christmas quietly with his family. Lisbon, December 24. Further advices from St. Paul de Loanda, Portuguese Lower Guinea announce that the Portuguese officer who, with a number of men, has been massacred by the natives of the Humbe Plateau, is Count Almoster, a grandson of the Duke of Baldanha. The Portuguese killed and missing number 21 persons. The murderers were Herero and Ovambo tribesmen. Suakim, December 24. The native levies of the Kassala garrison surprised a Dervish post at El Fasher on the Atbara, on Wednesday, and drove out the Dervishes with great loss, capturing the post, a number of camels, a quantity of stores, and many cattle. Two Dervish emirs were killed. The Dervish post at Asabri has also been invested. Madrid, December 23. The Queen Regent has signed the appointment of General Gonsales Munoz as Captain-General of Porto Rico. Candia, Island of Crete, December 23. There has been a recrudescence of conflicts between the Mussulmans and Christians. The former yesterday attacked a caravan near Artimro, and killed 12 Christians. The Hague, December 23. The second chamber has adopted a bill abolishing the export duty on Java sugar. Victoria, Labuan, December 23. The Sikh police force, which has been attacking the stronghold of the insurgent Mtsalleh, has been forced to retire. Adjutant Jones and six Sikhs were killed. Victoria is the capital of the Island of Labuan, six miles from the northwest coast of Borneo. The area of the island is 45 square miles. Toulon, December 23. In view of the disquieting news from Crete, two French cruisers are ready to sail for the island at a moment's notice. The French cruiser Pascal sailed for China today. Lisbon, December 23. An official despatch from St. Paul de Loanda, Portuguese Lower Guinea, says that the natives of the Humbe Plateau in the Portuguese colony of Angola have massacred a Portuguese officer, a sergeant, and 12 men. Reinforcements have been sent from St. Paul de Loanda. Angola is south of the Congo Free State.

AT MIDNIGHT MASS

Thousands Crowded the Churches Last Night. THE MUSIC WAS BEAUTIFUL and in keeping with the festive occasion. Real Christmas weather replaced the afternoon's blizzard. The mass at midnight, one of the features of the Catholic Church at this time of the year, when people seem to be under the benign influence of all that is good and pretty and attractive, was perhaps never better attended at the different churches in the city than was the case last night. Blizzards might have marked the day when the question of buying presents was a real difficulty; but when it came to the night, then there was a change in keeping with the season. The atmosphere seemed tempered to the geniality of the time. The rawness and severity of the afternoon seemed to have hid itself away before the bells tolled of the midnight services. The sky cleared itself and the twinkling stars appeared as if they were little holes picked in a mantle of night to let celestial spirits peep out at the doings of their terrestrial kindred, while all were joining in a great hosanna to the Man God. The heavier chimes that came from the church towers, and their music mingled into a harmonious whole as grand, as impressive, as inspiring as any theme that ever lifted Haydn or Mozart or Beethoven above mere earthly things. The whole of nature, which is usually quiet at midnight, seemed to have been awakened. The glad tidings of great joy resounded again and came almost as sweetly as did the angelic voices to the shepherds in the lonely hills of Bethlehem. And then the stars were all out, too; they seemed to vie with each other in shining their brightest, as if they followed their prototype that guided the Magi. But the heavens last night were full of guiding stars. There was not the thunder of hail; but there was that tremulous atmospheric motion that spoke musically of things agreeable that fitted into the season as if all living beings should be happy. The spires that shine like burnished gold in the drowsy summer days had on their coats of dazzling white and stood out like silhouettes against the winter sky. The flakes that flustered down fell as gently as manna feeding the first steps of the looked-for winter. And even they fell softly in consonance with the time when "Gloria in Excelsis Deo" first fell on the midnight air and spoke to the hearts of men through shepherds. It was a perfect Christmas night, when every feeling that was human seemed to be tinctured with some of the religion that lies latent in everybody's breast. The season that makes everybody feel better to his fellows, that prompts the making up of quarrels, that makes one shake hands not perfunctorily, but as if one meant it; the season when above all times everything looks brighter than even the occasion may permit, could have had a better exemplification than last night, and from all quarters of the city came to the churches men influenced by the spirit of the occasion whose heads bowed reverently, and whose hearts were rejoiced as the echo of "Peace on earth" filled the ears. At Christmas time, perhaps, there are few things more religiously important than the midnight mass, and there are few cities in the world where such popular importance is attached to it as in Montreal. All the Catholic churches last night were filled to overflowing. The musical arrangements were of the most elaborate character; there had been preparation for many weeks and in all cases were the services equal to the importance attached to the occasion. At the Church of Notre Dame, a grand choir of over two hundred voices under the leadership of Mr. McMahon, rendered Rheinberger's Mass in D major, with the "Credo" from Gounod's Messe Solennelle. Gounod's third mass was sung at the Church of the Gesu, Niedermeier's mass was sung at St. James Church, and Fauré's at St. Anne's. At Mount St. Louis Institute, Rev. Brother Bonitus' mass was rendered.

18971227: "JACKSON'S PLANS

Intends to Start for the North Pole in the Near Future. London, December 25. As soon as Jackson, the explorer, completes the work connected with his Franz Josef Land expedition, he will start for the North Pole. He informed a representative of the Associated Press that his original plans were identical with those of Lieut. Peary, except that he intended to take the east coast of the island instead of the west, mapping out undiscovered land en route. But, since he heard Lieut. Peary's lecture, Jackson has changed his plans. Considering that Peary had prior claims, Jackson now proposes to proceed via Davis' Straits and Baffin's Bay, up the west coast to Ellesmere Land and Greenland, and thence across to the furthermost point reached by Aldrich in 1876 whence he will push north, making in the direction of any land visible from the coast. The date of his departure is unsettled. Jackson will have only one companion outside of his crew. Talking over his plans, he said: "I hope to push my ship considerably beyond Coburg Island, at the entrance of Jones' Sound. At the furthest navigable point I shall establish a base and thence push north with sledges, dogs, and ponies, and with one companion I expect to be absent about two years."

In the purchase of railway ties at an excessive price from party friends in Quebec for transportation 700 miles to Cape Breton, evidence of the adoption of a "business policy" on the Intercolonial? Or is it "business is business?"

IN OLD MONTREAL

How the City Looked to a Westerner's Eyes. SUNDAY SEEMED QUIET. The Street Car Peculiarities. Relations with the Twin Cities - The Oldest Newspaper - (St. Paul Globe) Montreal, December 12. For the first time since the Globe started, January 15, 1878, I am passing a Sabbath in a city where there is no seven-day-a-week paper, and Sunday is the day omitted. There is a weekly Sunday paper here of very modest proportions, and the clergy certainly have no reason to complain of the Sunday newspapers of Montreal detracting from devotional exercises. On the principle of "the better the day, the better the deed," while all the other people in the city have gone to church, I concluded to pay my devotions to the Globe. I have had so many invitations to go to church that I imagine there is nothing else going on in this town on Sunday. The saloons are all closed, and, unlike an American city, which considers its freedom abridged when it can't get a drink, nobody worries, but all accept it as a matter of course. I cannot learn that the health of the city suffers or that there has been any increased mortality owing to "dry Sundays." Perhaps the climate differs from the States, and damp atmosphere prevents the internal bureau from becoming dry. When I struck the Canadian line I ran into a blizzard, which continued all the way and two days after I arrived, so that I felt I had brought "all the comforts of home" right along with me. Everything was on runners, and the only wheeled vehicles to be seen were the streetcars. I felt like improving on Mr. Kipling's tribute to "The Lady of the Snows" and making it read: "There was a small boy in Montreal who was buried in snow head and all. When asked, 'Are you friz?' He says 'Yes, I is, but we don't call that cold in Montreal.'" 

Perhaps just to prove this, the weather clerk ordered up rain: the carriage wheels have disappeared and today people, feeling the necessity of going to church, emblematic of the old proverb, stand on slippery places. By not going, I have no difficulty in keeping on my feet. The mind of the American public when thinking of Montreal (at least that portion of the mind which is writing this letter) is clearly associated with ice palaces and smallpox. With ice palaces, because Montreal was the first to borrow the idea from St. Petersburg on this continent, and set an example which St. Paul was quick to follow. With smallpox, owing to the almost religious war which was waged against vaccination. But both have now passed away, and the visitor can no longer enjoy either. The ice palace novelty wore out, as it did in St. Paul, and both places have apparently concluded that they will have just as much climate to the square inch without going to the trouble and expense of a palace to prove what is a self-evident fact.

THE STREET CARS

Some of the electric streetcars go up and down hills with grades approximating Selby Avenue, with ease, and Merriam Park might take heart of hope from this fact, after St. Paul elects a new city council, which will not increase the Selby Avenue grade by legislative attachments. The streetcars stop on both sides of the crossings, so that you can catch them coming and going and amidship as well, if you step daintily on your pins. The fenders hang so high that, instead of throwing a person off the track, he can roll right under the wheels. This is a great convenience for those who fall down or sleep on the tracks. They collect the fares in a contribution box with a slot; it is a box about ten inches high by six wide, and the slot will just admit a thin Canadian 5-cent piece or a ticket. The box has a handle like a beer mug, and is hung on a hook by the door at the rear end of the car, and the conductor passes it around to each passenger, in a manner which would remind one of a foreign missionary collection in a church, if the slot were wide enough to admit a button. If you have not got the change, the conductor will make it for you, handing it all back to you, and you drop in your own fare. It differs from the foreign missionary collection in that everyone contributes. Still, it reminds me of my usual Sabbath experiences. Montreal ought to be a bonanza for artists who practice streetcar holdups. The box hangs on a hook by the open door at the rear of the car, and all you need to do is to grab it off the hook, bat the conductor over the head, and run. It looks so easy that it is tempting. Most of the streets have French names, and, if you are looking for some place that you can't find on a dark night, and a French conductor calls the streets, you don't know whether you are riding in the English or French language. There is one advantage: you can get off and walk and find your street perhaps. I know this from experience, but have not tackled the contribution box yet, and cannot speak of that with as much positiveness as to ultimate results.
